BEG_SENT Call me Ishmael.
BEG_SENT Some years ago- never mind how long precisely-
having little or no money in my purse, and nothing particular to
interest me on shore, I thought I would sail about a little and see
the watery part of the world.
BEG_SENT It is a way I have of driving off the
spleen and regulating the circulation.
BEG_SENT Whenever I find myself growing
grim about the mouth; whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my
soul; whenever I find myself involuntarily pausing before coffin
warehouses, and bringing up the rear of every funeral I meet; and
especially whenever my hypos get such an upper hand of me, that it
requires a strong moral principle to prevent me from deliberately
stepping into the street, and methodically knocking people's hats
off- then, I account it high time to get to sea as soon as I
can.
BEG_SENT This is my substitute for pistol and ball.
BEG_SENT With a philosophical
flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I quietly take to the
ship.
BEG_SENT There is nothing surprising in this.
BEG_SENT If they but knew it,
almost all men in their degree, some time or other, cherish very
nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me.
BEG_SENT There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by
wharves as Indian isles by coral reefs- commerce surrounds it with
her surf.
BEG_SENT Right and left, the streets take you waterward.
BEG_SENT Its extreme
downtown is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by waves,
and cooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out of sight
of land.
BEG_SENT Look at the crowds of water-gazers there.
BEG_SENT Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon.
BEG_SENT Go from
Corlears Hook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitehall,
northward.
BEG_SENT What do you see?- Posted like silent sentinels all around
the town, stand thousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean
reveries.
BEG_SENT Some leaning against the spiles; some seated upon the
pier-heads; some looking over the bulwarks of ships from China; some
high aloft in the rigging, as if striving to get a still better
seaward peep.
BEG_SENT But these are all landsmen; of week days pent up in
lath and plaster- tied to counters, nailed to benches, clinched to
desks.
BEG_SENT How then is this?
BEG_SENT Are the green fields gone?
BEG_SENT What do they
here?
BEG_SENT But look!
BEG_SENT here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and
seemingly bound for a dive.
BEG_SENT Strange!
BEG_SENT Nothing will content them but
the extremest limit of the land; loitering under the shady lee of
yonder warehouses will not suffice.
BEG_SENT No.
BEG_SENT They must get just as nigh
the water as they possibly can without falling And there they stand-
miles of them- leagues.
BEG_SENT Inlanders all, they come from lanes and
alleys, streets avenues- north, east, south, and west.
BEG_SENT Yet here they
all unite.
BEG_SENT Tell me, does the magnetic virtue of the needles of the
compasses of all those ships attract them thither?
BEG_SENT Once more.
BEG_SENT Say you are in the country; in some high land of
lakes.
BEG_SENT Take almost any path you please, and ten to one it carries you
down in a dale, and leaves you there by a pool in the stream.
BEG_SENT There
is magic in it.
BEG_SENT Let the most absent-minded of men be plunged in his
deepest reveries- stand that man on his legs, set his feet a-going,
and he will infallibly lead you to water, if water there be in all
that region.
BEG_SENT Should you ever be athirst in the great American desert,
try this experiment, if your caravan happen to be supplied with a
metaphysical professor.
BEG_SENT Yes, as every one knows, meditation and water
are wedded for ever.
BEG_SENT But here is an artist.
BEG_SENT He desires to paint you the dreamiest,
shadiest, quietest, most enchanting bit of romantic landscape in all
the valley of the Saco.
BEG_SENT What is the chief element he employs?
BEG_SENT There
stand his trees, each with a hollow trunk, as if a hermit and a
crucifix were within; and here sleeps his meadow, and there sleep his
cattle; and up from yonder cottage goes a sleepy smoke.
BEG_SENT Deep into
distant woodlands winds a mazy way, reaching to overlapping spurs of
mountains bathed in their hill-side blue.
BEG_SENT But though the picture lies
thus tranced, and though this pine-tree shakes down its sighs like
leaves upon this shepherd's head, yet all were vain, unless the
shepherd's eye were fixed upon the magic stream before him.
BEG_SENT Go visit
the Prairies in June, when for scores on scores of miles you wade
knee-deep among Tiger-lilies- what is the one charm wanting?- Water-
there is not a drop of water there!
BEG_SENT Were Niagara but a cataract of
sand, would you travel your thousand miles to see it?
BEG_SENT Why did the
poor poet of Tennessee, upon suddenly receiving two handfuls of
silver, deliberate whether to buy him a coat, which he sadly needed,
or invest his money in a pedestrian trip to Rockaway Beach?
BEG_SENT Why is
almost every robust healthy boy with a robust healthy soul in him, at
some time or other crazy to go to sea?
BEG_SENT Why upon your first voyage as
a passenger, did you yourself feel such a mystical vibration, when
first told that you and your ship were now out of sight of land?
BEG_SENT Why
did the old Persians hold the sea holy?
BEG_SENT Why did the Greeks give it a
separate deity, and own brother of Jove?
BEG_SENT Surely all this is not
without meaning.
BEG_SENT And still deeper the meaning of that story of
Narcissus, who because he could not grasp the tormenting, mild image
he saw in the fountain, plunged into it and was drowned.
BEG_SENT But that
same image, we ourselves see in all rivers and oceans.
BEG_SENT It is the
image of the ungraspable phantom of life; and this is the key to it
all.
BEG_SENT Now, when I say that I am in the habit of going to sea whenever I
begin to grow hazy about the eyes, and begin to be over conscious of
my lungs, I do not mean to have it inferred that I ever go to sea as
a passenger.
BEG_SENT For to go as a passenger you must needs have a purse,
and a purse is but a rag unless you have something in it.
BEG_SENT Besides,
passengers get sea-sick- grow quarrelsome- don't sleep of nights- do
not enjoy themselves much, as a general thing;- no, I never go as a
passenger; nor, though I am something of a salt, do I ever go to sea
as a Commodore, or a Captain, or a Cook.
BEG_SENT I abandon the glory and
distinction of such offices to those who like them.
BEG_SENT For my part, I
abominate all honorable respectable toils, trials, and tribulations
of every kind whatsoever.
BEG_SENT It is quite as much as I can do to take
care of myself, without taking care of ships, barques, brigs,
schooners, and what not.
BEG_SENT And as for going as cook,- though I confess
there is considerable glory in that, a cook being a sort of officer
on ship-board- yet, somehow, I never fancied broiling fowls;- though
once broiled, judiciously buttered, and judgmatically salted and
peppered, there is no one who will speak more respectfully, not to
say reverentially, of a broiled fowl than I will.
BEG_SENT It is out of the
idolatrous dotings of the old Egyptians upon broiled ibis and roasted
river horse, that you see the mummies of those creatures in their
huge bakehouses the pyramids.
BEG_SENT No, when I go to sea, I go as a simple sailor, right before the mast,
plumb down into the fore-castle, aloft there to the royal
mast-head.
BEG_SENT True, they rather order me about some, and make me jump
from spar to spar, like a grasshopper in a May meadow.
BEG_SENT And at first,
this sort of thing is unpleasant enough.
BEG_SENT It touches one's sense of
honor, particularly if you come of an old established family in the
land, the Van Rensselaers, or Randolphs, or Hardicanutes.
BEG_SENT And more
than all, if just previous to putting your hand into the tar-pot, you
have been lording it as a country schoolmaster, making the tallest
boys stand in awe of you.
BEG_SENT The transition is a keen one, I assure you,
from a schoolmaster to a sailor, and requires a strong decoction of
Seneca and the Stoics to enable you to grin and bear it.
BEG_SENT But even
this wears off in time.
BEG_SENT What of it, if some old hunks of a sea-captain orders me to get a
broom and sweep down the decks?
BEG_SENT What does that indignity amount to,
weighed, I mean, in the scales of the New Testament?
BEG_SENT Do you think the
archangel Gabriel thinks anything the less of me, because I promptly
and respectfully obey that old hunks in that particular instance?
BEG_SENT Who
ain't a slave?
BEG_SENT Tell me that.
BEG_SENT Well, then, however the old sea-captains
may order me about- however they may thump and punch me about, I have
the satisfaction of knowing that it is all right; that everybody else
is one way or other served in much the same way- either in a physical
or metaphysical point of view, that is; and so the universal thump is
passed round, and all hands should rub each other's shoulder-blades,
and be content.
BEG_SENT Again, I always go to sea as a sailor, because they make a point of
paying me for my trouble, whereas they never pay passengers a single
penny that I ever heard of.
BEG_SENT On the contrary, passengers themselves
must pay.
BEG_SENT And there is all the difference in the world between paying
and being paid.
BEG_SENT The act of paying is perhaps the most uncomfortable
infliction that the two orchard thieves entailed upon us.
BEG_SENT But being
paid,- what will compare with it?
BEG_SENT The urbane activity with which a
man receives money is really marvellous, considering that we so
earnestly believe money to be the root of all earthly ills, and that
on no account can a monied man enter heaven.
BEG_SENT Ah!
BEG_SENT how cheerfully we
consign ourselves to perdition!
BEG_SENT Finally, I always go to sea as a sailor, because of the wholesome
exercise and pure air of the fore-castle deck.
BEG_SENT For as in this world,
head winds are far more prevalent than winds from astern (that is, if
you never violate the Pythagorean maxim), so for the most part the
Commodore on the quarter-deck gets his atmosphere at second hand from
the sailors on the forecastle.
BEG_SENT He thinks he breathes it first; but
not so.
BEG_SENT In much the same way do the commonalty lead their leaders in
many other things, at the same time that the leaders little suspect
it.
BEG_SENT But wherefore it was that after having repeatedly smelt the sea
as a merchant sailor, I should now take it into my head to go on a
whaling voyage; this the invisible police officer of the Fates, who
has the constant surveillance of me, and secretly dogs me, and
influences me in some unaccountable way- he can better answer than
any one else.
BEG_SENT And, doubtless, my going on this whaling voyage, formed
part of the grand programme of Providence that was drawn up a long
time ago.
BEG_SENT It came in as a sort of brief interlude and solo between
more extensive performances.
BEG_SENT I take it that this part of the bill
must have run something like this:

                      "Grand Contested Election
              for the Presidency of the United States."
BEG_SENT "Whaling voyage by one Ishmael."
BEG_SENT "Bloody battle in Affghanistan."
BEG_SENT Though I cannot tell why it was exactly that those stage managers, the Fates, put me
down for this shabby part of a whaling voyage, when others were set down for magnificent
parts in high tragedies, and short and easy parts in genteel comedies, and jolly parts in
farces- though I cannot tell why this was exactly; yet, now that I recall all the
circumstances, I think I can see a little into the springs and motives which being
cunningly presented to me under various disguises, induced me to set about performing the
part I did, besides cajoling me into the delusion that it was a choice resulting from my
own unbiased freewill and discriminating judgment.
BEG_SENT Chief among these motives was the overwhelming idea of the great
whale himself.
BEG_SENT Such a portentous and mysterious monster roused all my
curiosity.
BEG_SENT Then the wild and distant seas where he rolled his island
bulk; the undeliverable, nameless perils of the whale; these, with
all the attending marvels of a thousand Patagonian sights and sounds,
helped to sway me to my wish.
BEG_SENT With other men, perhaps, such things
would not have been inducements; but as for me, I am tormented with
an everlasting itch for things remote.
BEG_SENT I love to sail forbidden seas,
and land on barbarous coasts.
BEG_SENT Not ignoring what is good, I am quick
to perceive a horror, and could still be social with it- would they
let me- since it is but well to be on friendly terms with all the
inmates of the place one lodges in.
BEG_SENT By reason of these things, then, the whaling voyage was welcome; the
great flood-gates of the wonder-world swung open, and in the wild
conceits that swayed me to my purpose, two and two there floated into
my inmost soul, endless processions of the whale, and, mid most of
them all, one grand hooded phantom, like a snow hill in the air.
BEG_SENT The Carpet-Bag


I stuffed a shirt or two into my old carpet-bag, tucked it under my
arm, and started for Cape Horn and the Pacific.
BEG_SENT Quitting the good
city of old Manhatto, I duly arrived in New Bedford.
BEG_SENT It was a
Saturday night in December.
BEG_SENT Much was I disappointed upon learning
that the little packet for Nantucket had already sailed, and that no
way of reaching that place would offer, till the following Monday.
BEG_SENT As most young candidates for the pains and penalties of whaling stop
at this same New Bedford, thence to embark on their voyage, it may as
well be related that I, for one, had no idea of so doing.
BEG_SENT For my mind
was made up to sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, because there
was a fine, boisterous something about everything connected with that
famous old island, which amazingly pleased me.
BEG_SENT Besides though New
Bedford has of late been gradually monopolizing the business of
whaling, and though in this matter poor old Nantucket is now much
behind her, yet Nantucket was her great original- the Tyre of this
Carthage;- the place where the first dead American whale was
stranded.
BEG_SENT Where else but from Nantucket did those aboriginal
whalemen, the Red-Men, first sally out in canoes to give chase to the
Leviathan?
BEG_SENT And where but from Nantucket, too, did that first
adventurous little sloop put forth, partly laden with imported
cobblestones- so goes the story- to throw at the whales, in order to
discover when they were nigh enough to risk a harpoon from the
bowsprit?
BEG_SENT Now having a night, a day, and still another night following before
me in New Bedford, ere could embark for my destined port, it became a
matter of concernment where I was to eat and sleep meanwhile.
BEG_SENT It was
a very dubious-looking, nay, a very dark and dismal night, bitingly
cold and cheerless.
BEG_SENT I knew no one in the place.
BEG_SENT With anxious grapnels
I had sounded my pocket, and only brought up a few pieces of silver,-
So, wherever you go, Ishmael, said I to myself, as I stood in the
middle of a dreary street shouldering my bag, and comparing the
towards the north with the darkness towards the south- wherever in
your wisdom you may conclude to lodge for the night, my dear Ishmael,
be sure to inquire the price, and don't be too particular.
BEG_SENT With halting steps I paced the streets, and passed the sign of "The
Crossed Harpoons"- but it looked too expensive and jolly
there.
BEG_SENT Further on, from the bright red windows of the "Sword-Fish
Inn," there came such fervent rays, that it seemed to have melted the
packed snow and ice from before the house, for everywhere else the
congealed frost lay ten inches thick in a hard, asphaltic pavement,-
rather weary for me, when I struck my foot against the flinty
projections, because from hard, remorseless service the soles of my
boots were in a most miserable plight.
BEG_SENT Too expensive and jolly, again
thought I, pausing one moment to watch the broad glare in the street,
and hear the sounds of the tinkling glasses within.
BEG_SENT But go on,
Ishmael, said I at last; don't you hear?
BEG_SENT get away from before the
door; your patched boots are stopping the way.
BEG_SENT So on I went.
BEG_SENT I now by
instinct followed the streets that took me waterward, for there,
doubtless, were the cheapest, if not the cheeriest inns.
BEG_SENT Such dreary streets!
BEG_SENT blocks of blackness, not houses, on either hand,
and here and there a candle, like a candle moving about in a tomb.
BEG_SENT At
this hour of the night, of the last day of the week, that quarter of
the town proved all but deserted.
BEG_SENT But presently I came to a smoky
light proceeding from a low, wide building, the door of which stood
invitingly open.
BEG_SENT It had a careless look, as if it were meant for the
uses of the public; so, entering, the first thing I did was to
stumble over an ash-box in the porch.
BEG_SENT Ha!
BEG_SENT thought I, ha, as the
flying particles almost choked me, are these ashes from that
destroyed city, Gomorrah?
BEG_SENT But "The Crossed Harpoons," and the "The
Sword-Fish?
BEG_SENT "- this, then must needs be the sign of "The Trap."
BEG_SENT However, I picked myself up and hearing a loud voice within, pushed
on and opened a second, interior door.
BEG_SENT It seemed the great Black Parliament sitting in Tophet.
BEG_SENT A hundred
black faces turned round in their rows to peer; and beyond, a black
Angel of Doom was beating a book in a pulpit.
BEG_SENT It was a negro church;
and the preacher's text was about the blackness of darkness, and the
weeping and wailing and teeth-gnashing there.
BEG_SENT Ha, Ishmael, muttered
I, backing out, Wretched entertainment at the sign of 'The Trap!'
BEG_SENT Moving on, I at last came to a dim sort of light not far from the
docks, and heard a forlorn creaking in the air; and looking up, saw a
swinging sign over the door with a white painting upon it, faintly
representing tall straight jet of misty spray, and these words
underneath- "The Spouter Inn:- Peter Coffin."
BEG_SENT Coffin?- Spouter?- Rather ominous in that particular connexion,
thought I.
BEG_SENT But it is a common name in Nantucket, they say, and I
suppose this Peter here is an emigrant from there.
BEG_SENT As the light
looked so dim, and the place, for the time, looked quiet enough, and
the dilapidated little wooden house itself looked as if it might have
been carted here from the ruins of some burnt district, and as the
swinging sign had a poverty-stricken sort of creak to it, I thought
that here was the very spot for cheap lodgings, and the best of pea
coffee.
BEG_SENT It was a queer sort of place- a gable-ended old house, one side
palsied as it were, and leaning over sadly.
BEG_SENT It stood on a sharp bleak
corner, where that tempestuous wind Euroclydon kept up a worse
howling than ever it did about poor Paul's tossed craft.
BEG_SENT Euroclydon,
nevertheless, is a mighty pleasant zephyr to any one in-doors, with
his feet on the hob quietly toasting for bed.
BEG_SENT "In of that tempestuous
wind called Euroclydon," says an old writer- of whose works I possess
the only copy extant- "it maketh a marvellous difference, whether
thou lookest out at it from a glass window where the frost is all on
the outside, or whether thou observest it from that sashless window,
where the frost is on both sides, and of which the wight Death is the
only glazier."
BEG_SENT True enough, thought I, as this passage occurred to my
mind- old black-letter, thou reasonest well.
BEG_SENT Yes, these eyes are
windows, and this body of mine is the house.
BEG_SENT What a pity they didn't
stop up the chinks and the crannies though, and thrust in a little
lint here and there.
BEG_SENT But it's too late to make any improvements
now.
BEG_SENT The universe is finished; the copestone is on, and the chips
were carted off a million years ago.
BEG_SENT Poor Lazarus there, chattering
his teeth against the curbstone for his pillow, and shaking off his
tatters with his shiverings, he might plug up both ears with rags,
and put a corn-cob into his mouth, and yet that would not keep out
the tempestuous Euroclydon.
BEG_SENT Euroclydon!
BEG_SENT says old Dives, in his red
silken wrapper- (he had a redder one afterwards) pooh, pooh!
BEG_SENT What a
fine frosty night; how Orion glitters; what northern lights!
BEG_SENT Let them
talk of their oriental summer climes of everlasting conservatories;
give me the privilege of making my own summer with my own coals.
BEG_SENT But what thinks Lazarus?
BEG_SENT Can he warm his blue hands by holding them
up to the grand northern lights?
BEG_SENT Would not Lazarus rather be in
Sumatra than here?
BEG_SENT Would he not far rather lay him down lengthwise
along the line of the equator; yea, ye gods!
BEG_SENT go down to the fiery pit
itself, in order to keep out this frost?
BEG_SENT Now, that Lazarus should lie stranded there on the curbstone before
the door of Dives, this is more wonderful than that an iceberg should
be moored to one of the Moluccas.
BEG_SENT Yet Dives himself, he too lives
like a Czar in an ice palace made of frozen sighs, and being a
president of a temperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears of
orphans.
BEG_SENT But no more of this blubbering now, we are going a-whaling, and there
is plenty of that yet to come.
BEG_SENT Let us scrape the ice from our frosted
feet, and see what sort of a place this "Spouter" may be.
BEG_SENT The Spouter-Inn


Entering that gable-ended Spouter-Inn, you found yourself in a wide,
low, straggling entry with old-fashioned wainscots, reminding one of
the bulwarks of some condemned old craft.
BEG_SENT On one side hung a very
large oil painting so thoroughly besmoked, and every way defaced,
that in the unequal crosslights by which you viewed it, it was only
by diligent study and a series of systematic visits to it, and
careful inquiry of the neighbors, that you could any way arrive at an
understanding of its purpose.
BEG_SENT Such unaccountable masses of shades and
shadows, that at first you almost thought some ambitious young
artist, in the time of the New England hags, had endeavored to
delineate chaos bewitched.
BEG_SENT But by dint of much and earnest
contemplation, and oft repeated ponderings, and especially by
throwing open the little window towards the back of the entry, you at
last come to the conclusion that such an idea, however wild, might
not be altogether unwarranted.
BEG_SENT But what most puzzled and confounded you was a long, limber,
portentous, black mass of something hovering in the centre of the
picture over three blue, dim, perpendicular lines floating in a
nameless yeast.
BEG_SENT A boggy, soggy, squitchy picture truly, enough to
drive a nervous man distracted.
BEG_SENT Yet was there a sort of indefinite,
half-attained, unimaginable sublimity about it that fairly froze you
to it, till you involuntarily took an oath with yourself to find out
what that marvellous painting meant.
BEG_SENT Ever and anon a bright, but,
alas, deceptive idea would dart you through.- It's the Black Sea in a
midnight gale.- It's the unnatural combat of the four primal
elements.- It's a blasted heath.- It's a Hyperborean winter scene.-
It's the breaking-up of the icebound stream of Time.
BEG_SENT But last all
these fancies yielded to that one portentous something in the
picture's midst.
BEG_SENT That once found out, and all the rest were
plain.
BEG_SENT But stop; does it not bear a faint resemblance to a gigantic
fish?
BEG_SENT even the great leviathan himself?
BEG_SENT In fact, the artist's design seemed this: a final theory of my own,
partly based upon the aggregated opinions of many aged persons with
whom I conversed upon the subject.
BEG_SENT The picture represents a
Cape-Horner in a great hurricane; the half-foundered ship weltering
there with its three dismantled masts alone visible; and an
exasperated whale, purposing to spring clean over the craft, is in
the enormous act of impaling himself upon the three mast-heads.
BEG_SENT The opposite wall of this entry was hung all over with a heathenish
array of monstrous clubs and spears.
BEG_SENT Some were thickly set with
glittering teeth resembling ivory saws; others were tufted with knots
of human hair; and one was sickle-shaped, with a vast handle sweeping
round like the segment made in the new-mown grass by a long-armed
mower.
BEG_SENT You shuddered as you gazed, and wondered what monstrous
cannibal and savage could ever have gone a death-harvesting with such
a hacking, horrifying implement.
BEG_SENT Mixed with these were rusty old
whaling lances and harpoons all broken and deformed.
BEG_SENT Some were
storied weapons.
BEG_SENT With this once long lance, now wildly elbowed,
fifty years ago did Nathan Swain kill fifteen whales between a
sunrise and a sunset.
BEG_SENT And that harpoon- so like a corkscrew now- was
flung in Javan seas, and run away with by a whale, years afterwards
slain off the Cape of Blanco.
BEG_SENT The original iron entered nigh the
tail, and, like a restless needle sojourning in the body of a man,
travelled full forty feet, and at last was found imbedded in the
hump.
BEG_SENT Crossing this dusky entry, and on through yon low-arched way- cut
through what in old times must have been a great central chimney with
fireplaces all round- you enter the public room.
BEG_SENT A still duskier
place is this, with such low ponderous beams above, and such old
wrinkled planks beneath, that you would almost fancy you trod some
old craft's cockpits, especially of such a howling night, when this
corner-anchored old ark rocked so furiously.
BEG_SENT On one side stood a
long, low, shelf-like table covered with cracked glass cases, filled
with dusty rarities gathered from this wide world's remotest nooks.
BEG_SENT Projecting from the further angle of the room stands a dark-looking
den- the bar- a rude attempt at a right whale's head.
BEG_SENT Be that how it
may, there stands the vast arched bone of the whale's jaw, so wide, a
coach might almost drive beneath it.
BEG_SENT Within are shabby shelves,
ranged round with old decanters, bottles, flasks; and in those jaws
of swift destruction, like another cursed Jonah (by which name indeed
they called him), bustles a little withered old man, who, for their
money, dearly sells the sailors deliriums and death.
BEG_SENT Abominable are the tumblers into which he pours his poison.
BEG_SENT Though
true cylinders without- within, the villanous green goggling glasses
deceitfully tapered downwards to a cheating bottom.
BEG_SENT Parallel
meridians rudely pecked into the glass, surround these footpads'
goblets.
BEG_SENT Fill to this mark, and your charge is but a penny; to this a
penny more; and so on to the full glass- the Cape Horn measure, which
you may gulp down for a shilling.
BEG_SENT Upon entering the place I found a number of young seamen gathered
about a table, examining by a dim light divers specimens of
skrimshander.
BEG_SENT I sought the landlord, and telling him I desired to be
accommodated with a room, received for answer that his house was
full- not a bed unoccupied.
BEG_SENT "But avast," he added, tapping his
forehead, "you haint no objections to sharing a harpooneer's blanket,
have ye?
BEG_SENT I s'pose you are goin' a-whalin', so you'd better get used
to that sort of thing."
BEG_SENT I told him that I never liked to sleep two in a bed; that if I should
ever do so, it would depend upon who the harpooneer might be, and
that if he (the landlord) really had no other place for me, and the
harpooneer was not decidedly objectionable, why rather than wander
further about a strange town on so bitter a night, I would put up
with the half of any decent man's blanket.
BEG_SENT "I thought so.
BEG_SENT All right; take a seat.
BEG_SENT Supper?- you want supper?
BEG_SENT Supper'll be ready directly."
BEG_SENT I sat down on an old wooden settle, carved all over like a bench on
the Battery.
BEG_SENT At one end a ruminating tar was still further adorning
it with his jack-knife, stooping over and diligently working away at
the space between his legs.
BEG_SENT He was trying his hand at a ship under
full sail, but he didn't make much headway, I thought.
BEG_SENT At last some four or five of us were summoned to our meal in an
adjoining room.
BEG_SENT It was cold as Iceland- no fire at all- the landlord
said he couldn't afford it.
BEG_SENT Nothing but two dismal tallow candles,
each in a winding sheet.
BEG_SENT We were fain to button up our monkey
jackets, and hold to our lips cups of scalding tea with our half
frozen fingers.
BEG_SENT But the fare was of the most substantial kind- not
only meat and potatoes, but dumplings; good heavens!
BEG_SENT dumplings for
supper!
BEG_SENT One young fellow in a green box coat, addressed himself to
these dumplings in a most direful manner.
BEG_SENT "My boy," said the landlord, "you'll have the nightmare to a dead
sartainty."
BEG_SENT "Landlord," I whispered, "that aint the harpooneer is it?"
BEG_SENT "Oh, no," said he, looking a sort of diabolically funny, "the
harpooneer is a dark complexioned chap.
BEG_SENT He never eats dumplings, he
don't- he eats nothing but steaks, and he likes 'em rare."
BEG_SENT "The devil he does," says I.
BEG_SENT "Where is that harpooneer?
BEG_SENT Is he here?"
BEG_SENT "He'll be here afore long," was the answer.
BEG_SENT I could not help it, but I began to feel suspicious of this "dark
complexioned" harpooneer.
BEG_SENT At any rate, I made up my mind that if it
so turned out that we should sleep together, he must undress and get
into bed before I did.
BEG_SENT Supper over, the company went back to the bar-room, when, knowing not
what else to do with myself, I resolved to spend the rest of the
evening as a looker on.
BEG_SENT Presently a rioting noise was heard without.
BEG_SENT Starting up, the
landlord cried, "That's the Grampus's crew.
BEG_SENT I seed her reported in
the offing this morning; a three years' voyage, and a full
ship.
BEG_SENT Hurrah, boys; now we'll have the latest news from the Feegees."
BEG_SENT A tramping of sea boots was heard in the entry; the door was flung
open, and in rolled a wild set of mariners enough.
BEG_SENT Enveloped in their
shaggy watch coats, and with their heads muffled in woollen
comforters, all bedarned and ragged, and their beards stiff with
icicles, they seemed an eruption of bears from Labrador.
BEG_SENT They had
just landed from their boat, and this was the first house they
entered.
BEG_SENT No wonder, then, that they made a straight wake for the
whale's mouth- the bar- when the wrinkled little old Jonah, there
officiating, soon poured them out brimmers all round.
BEG_SENT One complained
of a bad cold in his head, upon which Jonah mixed him a pitch-like
potion of gin and molasses, which he swore was a sovereign cure for
all colds and catarrhs whatsoever, never mind of how long standing,
or whether caught off the coast of Labrador, or on the weather side
of an ice-island.
BEG_SENT The liquor soon mounted into their heads, as it generally does even
with the arrantest topers newly landed from sea, and they began
capering about most obstreperously.
BEG_SENT I observed, however, that one of them held somewhat aloof, and though
he seemed desirous not to spoil the hilarity of his shipmates by his
own sober face, yet upon the whole he refrained from making as much
noise as the rest.
BEG_SENT This man interested me at once; and since the
sea-gods had ordained that he should soon become my shipmate (though
but a sleeping partner one, so far as this narrative is concerned), I
will here venture upon a little description of him.
BEG_SENT He stood full six
feet in height, with noble shoulders, and a chest like a
coffer-dam.
BEG_SENT I have seldom seen such brawn in a man.
BEG_SENT His face was
deeply brown and burnt, making his white teeth dazzling by the
contrast; while in the deep shadows of his eyes floated some
reminiscences that did not seem to give him much joy.
BEG_SENT His voice at
once announced that he was a Southerner, and from his fine stature, I
thought he must be one of those tall mountaineers from the
Alleghanian Ridge in Virginia.
BEG_SENT When the revelry of his companions had
mounted to its height, this man slipped away unobserved, and I saw no
more of him till he became my comrade on the sea.
BEG_SENT In a few minutes,
however, he was missed by his shipmates, and being, it seems, for
some reason a huge favorite with them, they raised a cry of
"Bulkington!
BEG_SENT Bulkington!
BEG_SENT where's Bulkington?"
BEG_SENT and darted out of the
house in pursuit of him.
BEG_SENT It was now about nine o'clock, and the room seeming almost
supernaturally quiet after these orgies, I began to congratulate
myself upon a little plan that had occurred to me just previous to
the entrance of the seamen.
BEG_SENT No man prefers to sleep two in a bed.
BEG_SENT In fact, you would a good deal
rather not sleep with your own brother.
BEG_SENT I don't know how it is, but
people like to be private when they are sleeping.
BEG_SENT And when it comes
to sleeping with an unknown stranger, in a strange inn, in a strange
town, and that stranger a harpooneer, then your objections
indefinitely multiply.
BEG_SENT Nor was there any earthly reason why I as a
sailor should sleep two in a bed, more than anybody else; for sailors
no more sleep two in a bed at sea, than bachelor Kings do ashore.
BEG_SENT To
be sure they all sleep together in one apartment, but you have your
own hammock, and cover yourself with your own blanket, and sleep in
your own skin.
BEG_SENT The more I pondered over this harpooneer, the more I abominated the
thought of sleeping with him.
BEG_SENT It was fair to presume that being a
harpooneer, his linen or woolen, as the case might be, would not be
of the tidiest, certainly none of the finest.
BEG_SENT I began to twitch all
over.
BEG_SENT Besides, it was getting late, and my decent harpooneer ought to
be home and going bedwards.
BEG_SENT Suppose now, he should tumble in upon me
at midnight- how could I tell from what vile hole he had been coming?
BEG_SENT "Landlord!
BEG_SENT I've changed my mind about that harpooneer.- I shan't
sleep with him.
BEG_SENT I'll try the bench here."
BEG_SENT "Just as you please; I'm sorry I cant spare ye a tablecloth for a
mattress, and it's a plaguy rough board here"- feeling of the knots
and notches.
BEG_SENT "But wait a bit, Skrimshander; I've got a carpenter's
plane there in the bar- wait, I say, and I'll make ye snug enough."
BEG_SENT So saying he procured the plane; and with his old silk handkerchief
first dusting the bench, vigorously set to planing away at my bed,
the while grinning like an ape.
BEG_SENT The shavings flew right and left;
till at last the plane-iron came bump against an indestructible
knot.
BEG_SENT The landlord was near spraining his wrist, and I told him for
heaven's sake to quit- the bed was soft enough to suit me, and I did
not know how all the planing in the world could make eider down of a
pine plank.
BEG_SENT So gathering up the shavings with another grin, and
throwing them into the great stove in the middle of the room, he went
about his business, and left me in a brown study.
BEG_SENT I now took the measure of the bench, and found that it was a foot too
short; but that could be mended with a chair.
BEG_SENT But it was a foot too
narrow, and the other bench in the room was about four inches higher
than the planed one- so there was no yoking them.
BEG_SENT I then placed the
first bench lengthwise along the only clear space against the wall,
leaving a little interval between, for my back to settle down in.
BEG_SENT But
I soon found that there came such a draught of cold air over me from
under the sill of the window, that this plan would never do at all,
especially as another current from the rickety door met the one from
the window, and both together formed a series of small whirlwinds in
the immediate vicinity of the spot where I had thought to spend the
night.
BEG_SENT The devil fetch that harpooneer, thought I, but stop, couldn't I
steal a march on him- bolt his door inside, and jump into his bed,
not to be wakened by the most violent knockings?
BEG_SENT It seemed no bad
idea but upon second thoughts I dismissed it.
BEG_SENT For who could tell but
what the next morning, so soon as I popped out of the room, the
harpooneer might be standing in the entry, all ready to knock me
down!
BEG_SENT Still looking round me again, and seeing no possible chance of
spending a sufferable night unless in some other person's bed, I
began to think that after all I might be cherishing unwarrantable
prejudices against this unknown harpooneer.
BEG_SENT Thinks I, I'll wait
awhile; he must be dropping in before long.
BEG_SENT I'll have a good look at
him then, and perhaps we may become jolly good bedfellows after all-
there's no telling.
BEG_SENT But though the other boarders kept coming in by ones, twos, and
threes, and going to bed, yet no sign of my harpooneer.
BEG_SENT "Landlord!
BEG_SENT said I, "what sort of a chap is he- does he always keep
such late hours?"
BEG_SENT It was now hard upon twelve o'clock.
BEG_SENT The landlord chuckled again with his lean chuckle, and seemed to be
mightily tickled at something beyond my comprehension.
BEG_SENT "No," he
answered, "generally he's an early bird- airley to bed and airley to
rise- yea, he's the bird what catches the worm.
BEG_SENT But to-night he went
out a peddling, you see, and I don't see what on airth keeps him so
late, unless, may be, he can't sell his head."
BEG_SENT "Can't sell his head?- What sort of a bamboozingly story is this you
are telling me?"
BEG_SENT getting into a towering rage.
BEG_SENT "Do you pretend to
say, landlord, that this harpooneer is actually engaged this blessed
Saturday night, or rather Sunday morning, in peddling his head around
this town?"
BEG_SENT "That's precisely it," said the landlord, "and I told him he couldn't
sell it here, the market's overstocked."
BEG_SENT "With what?"
BEG_SENT shouted I.
BEG_SENT "With heads to be sure; ain't there too many heads in the world?"
BEG_SENT "I tell you what it is, landlord," said I quite calmly, "you'd better
stop spinning that yarn to me- I'm not green."
BEG_SENT "May be not," taking out a stick and whittling a toothpick, "but I
rayther guess you'll be done brown if that ere harpooneer hears you a
slanderin' his head."
BEG_SENT "I'll break it for him," said I, now flying into a passion again at
this unaccountable farrago of the landlord's.
BEG_SENT "It's broke a'ready," said he.
BEG_SENT "Broke," said I- "broke, do you mean?"
BEG_SENT "Sartain, and that's the very reason he can't sell it, I guess."
BEG_SENT "Landlord," said I, going up to him as cool as Mt.
BEG_SENT Hecla in a
snowstorm- "landlord, stop whittling.
BEG_SENT You and I must understand one
another, and that too without delay.
BEG_SENT I come to your house and want a
bed; you tell me you can only give me half a one; that the other half
belongs to a certain harpooneer.
BEG_SENT And about this harpooneer, whom I
have not yet seen, you persist in telling me the most mystifying and
exasperating stories tending to beget in me an uncomfortable feeling
towards the man whom you design for my bedfellow- a sort of
connexion, landlord, which is an intimate and confidential one in the
highest degree.
BEG_SENT I now demand of you to speak out and tell me who and
what this harpooneer is, and whether I shall be in all respects safe
to spend the night with him.
BEG_SENT And in the first place, you will be so
good as to unsay that story about selling his head, which if true I
take to be good evidence that this harpooneer is stark mad, and I've
no idea of sleeping with a madman; and you, sir, you I mean,
landlord, you, sir, by trying to induce me to do so knowingly would
thereby render yourself liable to a criminal prosecution."
BEG_SENT "Wall," said the landlord, fetching a long breath, "that's a purty
long sarmon for a chap that rips a little now and then.
BEG_SENT But be easy,
be easy, this here harpooneer I have been tellin' you of has just
arrived from the south seas, where he bought up a lot of 'balmed New
Zealand heads (great curios, you know), and he's sold all on 'em but
one, and that one he's trying to sell to-night, cause to-morrow's
Sunday, and it would not do to be sellin' human heads about the
streets when folks is goin' to churches.
BEG_SENT He wanted to last Sunday,
but I stopped him just as he was goin' out of the door with four
heads strung on a string, for all the airth like a string of inions."
BEG_SENT This account cleared up the otherwise unaccountable mystery, and
showed that the landlord, after all, had had no idea of fooling me-
but at the same time what could I think of a harpooneer who stayed
out of a Saturday night clean into the holy Sabbath, engaged in such
a cannibal business as selling the heads of dead idolators?
BEG_SENT "Depend upon it, landlord, that harpooneer is a dangerous man."
BEG_SENT "He pays reg'lar," was the rejoinder.
BEG_SENT "But come, it's a nice bed: Sal
and me slept in that ere bed the night we were spliced.
BEG_SENT There's
plenty of room for two to kick about in that bed; it's an almighty
big bed that.
BEG_SENT Why, afore we give it up, Sal used to put our Sam and
little Johnny in the foot of it.
BEG_SENT But I got a dreaming and sprawling
about one night, and somehow, Sam got pitched on the floor, and came
near breaking his arm.
BEG_SENT Arter that, Sal said it wouldn't do.
BEG_SENT Come
along here, I'll give ye a glim in a jiffy;" and so saying he lighted
a candle and held it towards me, offering to lead the way.
BEG_SENT But I
stood irresolute; when looking at a clock in the corner, he exclaimed
"I vum it's Sunday- you won't see that harpooneer to-night; he's come
to anchor somewhere- come along then; do come; won't ye come?"
BEG_SENT I considered the matter a moment, and then up stairs we went, and I
was ushered into a small room, cold as a clam, and furnished, sure
enough, with a prodigious bed, almost big enough indeed for any four
harpooneers to sleep abreast.
BEG_SENT "There," said the landlord, placing the candle on a crazy old sea
chest that did double duty as a wash-stand and centre table; "there,
make yourself comfortable now; and good night to ye."
BEG_SENT I turned round
from eyeing the bed, but he had disappeared.
BEG_SENT Folding back the counterpane, I stooped over the bed.
BEG_SENT Though none of
the most elegant, it yet stood the scrutiny tolerably well.
BEG_SENT I then
glanced round the room; and besides the bedstead and centre table,
could see no other furniture belonging to the place, but a rude
shelf, the four walls, and a papered fireboard representing a man
striking a whale.
BEG_SENT Of things not properly belonging to the room, there
was a hammock lashed up, and thrown upon the floor in one corner;
also a large seaman's bag, containing the harpooneer's wardrobe, no
doubt in lieu of a land trunk.
BEG_SENT Likewise, there was a parcel of
outlandish bone fish hooks on the shelf over the fire-place, and a
tall harpoon standing at the head of the bed.
BEG_SENT But what is this on the chest?
BEG_SENT I took it up, and held it close to the
light, and felt it, and smelt it, and tried every way possible to
arrive at some satisfactory conclusion concerning it.
BEG_SENT I can compare
it to nothing but a large door mat, ornamented at the edges with
little tinkling tags something like the stained porcupine quills
round an Indian moccasin.
BEG_SENT There was a hole or slit in the middle of
this mat, as you see the same in South American ponchos.
BEG_SENT But could it
be possible that any sober harpooneer would get into a door mat, and
parade the streets of any Christian town in that sort of guise?
BEG_SENT I put
it on, to try it, and it weighed me down like a hamper, being
uncommonly shaggy and thick, and I thought a little damp, as though
this mysterious harpooneer had been wearing it of a rainy day.
BEG_SENT I went
up in it to a bit of glass stuck against the wall, and I never saw
such a sight in my life.
BEG_SENT I tore myself out of it in such a hurry that
I gave myself a kink in the neck.
BEG_SENT I sat down on the side of the bed, and commenced thinking about this
head-peddling harpooneer, and his door mat.
BEG_SENT After thinking some time
on the bed-side, I got up and took off my monkey jacket, and then
stood in the middle of the room thinking.
BEG_SENT I then took off my coat,
and thought a little more in my shirt sleeves.
BEG_SENT But beginning to feel
very cold now, half undressed as I was, and remembering what the
landlord said about the harpooneer's not coming home at all that
night, it being so very late, I made no more ado, but jumped out of
my pantaloons and boots, and then blowing out the light tumbled into
bed, and commended myself to the care of heaven.
BEG_SENT Whether that mattress was stuffed with corncobs or broken crockery,
there is no telling, but I rolled about a good deal, and could not
sleep for a long time.
BEG_SENT At last I slid off into a light doze, and had
pretty nearly made a good offing towards the land of Nod, when I
heard a heavy footfall in the passage, and saw a glimmer of light
come into the room from under the door.
BEG_SENT Lord save me, thinks I, that must be the harpooneer, the infernal
head-peddler.
BEG_SENT But I lay perfectly still, and resolved not to say a
word till spoken to.
BEG_SENT Holding a light in one hand, and that identical
New Zealand head in the other, the stranger entered the room, and
without looking towards the bed, placed his candle a good way off
from me on the floor in one corner, and then began working away at
the knotted cords of the large bag I before spoke of as being in the
room.
BEG_SENT I was all eagerness to see his face, but he kept it averted for
some time while employed in unlacing the bag's mouth.
BEG_SENT This
accomplished, however, he turned round- when, good heavens; what a
sight!
BEG_SENT Such a face!
BEG_SENT It was of a dark, purplish, yellow color, here
and there stuck over with large blackish looking squares.
BEG_SENT Yes, it's
just as I thought, he's a terrible bedfellow; he's been in a fight,
got dreadfully cut, and here he is, just from the surgeon.
BEG_SENT But at
that moment he chanced to turn his face so towards the light, that I
plainly saw they could not be sticking-plasters at all, those black
squares on his cheeks.
BEG_SENT They were stains of some sort or other.
BEG_SENT At
first I knew not what to make of this; but soon an inkling of the
truth occurred to me.
BEG_SENT I remembered a story of a white man- a whaleman
too- who, falling among the cannibals, had been tattooed by them.
BEG_SENT I
concluded that this harpooneer, in the course of his distant voyages,
must have met with a similar adventure.
BEG_SENT And what is it, thought I,
after all!
BEG_SENT It's only his outside; a man can be honest in any sort of
skin.
BEG_SENT But then, what to make of his unearthly complexion, that part
of it, I mean, lying round about, and completely independent of the
squares of tattooing.
BEG_SENT To be sure, it might be nothing but a good coat
of tropical tanning; but I never heard of a hot sun's tanning a white
man into a purplish yellow one.
BEG_SENT However, I had never been in the
South Seas; and perhaps the sun there produced these extraordinary
effects upon the skin.
BEG_SENT Now, while all these ideas were passing
through me like lightning, this harpooneer never noticed me at
all.
BEG_SENT But, after some difficulty having opened his bag, he commenced
fumbling in it, and presently pulled out a sort of tomahawk, and a
seal-skin wallet with the hair on.
BEG_SENT Placing these on the old chest in
the middle of a room, he then took the New Zealand head- a ghastly
thing enough- and crammed it down into the bag.
BEG_SENT He now took off his
hat- a new beaver hat- when I came nigh singing out with fresh
surprise.
BEG_SENT There was no hair on his head- none to speak of at least-
nothing but a small scalp-knot twisted up on his forehead.
BEG_SENT His bald
purplish head now looked for all the world like a mildewed skull.
BEG_SENT Had
not the stranger stood between me and the door, I would have bolted
out of it quicker than ever I bolted a dinner.
BEG_SENT Even as it was, I thought something of slipping out of the window,
but it was the second floor back.
BEG_SENT I am no coward, but what to make of
this headpeddling purple rascal altogether passed my
comprehension.
BEG_SENT Ignorance is the parent of fear, and being completely
nonplussed and confounded about the stranger, I confess I was now as
much afraid of him as if it was the devil himself who had thus broken
into my room at the dead of night.
BEG_SENT In fact, I was so afraid of him
that I was not game enough just then to address him, and demand a
satisfactory answer concerning what seemed inexplicable in him.
BEG_SENT Meanwhile, he continued the business of undressing, and at last
showed his chest and arms.
BEG_SENT As I live, these covered parts of him were
checkered with the same squares as his face, his back, too, was all
over the same dark squares; he seemed to have been in a Thirty Years'
War, and just escaped from it with a sticking-plaster shirt.
BEG_SENT Still
more, his very legs were marked, as a parcel of dark green frogs were
running up the trunks of young palms.
BEG_SENT It was now quite plain that he
must be some abominable savage or other shipped aboard of a whaleman
in the South Seas, and so landed in this Christian country.
BEG_SENT I quaked
to think of it.
BEG_SENT A peddler of heads too- perhaps the heads of his own
brothers.
BEG_SENT He might take a fancy to mine- heavens!
BEG_SENT look at that
tomahawk!
BEG_SENT But there was no time for shuddering, for now the savage went about
something that completely fascinated my attention, and convinced me
that he must indeed be a heathen.
BEG_SENT Going to his heavy grego, or
wrapall, or dreadnaught, which he had previously hung on a chair, he
fumbled in the pockets, and produced at length a curious little
deformed image with a hunch on its back, and exactly the color of a
three days' old Congo baby.
BEG_SENT Remembering the embalmed head, at first
I almost thought that this black manikin was a real baby preserved
some similar manner.
BEG_SENT But seeing that it was not at all limber, and
that it glistened a good deal like polished ebony, I concluded that
it must be nothing but a wooden idol, which indeed it proved to
be.
BEG_SENT For now the savage goes up to the empty fire-place, and removing
the papered fire-board, sets up this little hunch-backed image, like
a tenpin, between the andirons.
BEG_SENT The chimney jambs and all the bricks
inside were very sooty, so that I thought this fire-place made a very
appropriate little shrine or chapel for his Congo idol.
BEG_SENT I now screwed my eyes hard towards the half hidden image, feeling but
ill at ease meantime- to see what was next to follow.
BEG_SENT First he takes
about a double handful of shavings out of his grego pocket, and
places them carefully before the idol; then laying a bit of ship
biscuit on top and applying the flame from the lamp, he kindled the
shavings into a sacrificial blaze.
BEG_SENT Presently, after many hasty
snatches into the fire, and still hastier withdrawals of his fingers
(whereby he seemed to be scorching them badly), he at last succeeded
in drawing out the biscuit; then blowing off the heat and ashes a
little, he made a polite offer of it to the little negro.
BEG_SENT But the
little devil did not seem to fancy such dry sort of fare at all; he
never moved his lips.
BEG_SENT All these strange antics were accompanied by
still stranger guttural noises from the devotee, who seemed to be
praying in a sing-song or else singing some pagan psalmody or other,
during which his face twitched about in the most unnatural manner.
BEG_SENT At
last extinguishing the fire, he took the idol up very
unceremoniously, and bagged it again in his grego pocket as
carelessly as if he were a sportsman bagging a dead woodcock.
BEG_SENT All these queer proceedings increased my uncomfortableness, and
seeing him now exhibiting strong symptoms of concluding his business
operations, and jumping into bed with me, I thought it was high time,
now or never, before the light was put out, to break the spell in
which I had so long been bound.
BEG_SENT But the interval I spent in deliberating what to say, was a fatal
one.
BEG_SENT Taking up his tomahawk from the table, he examined the head of
it for an instant, and then holding it to the light, with his mouth
at the handle, he puffed out great clouds of tobacco smoke.
BEG_SENT The next
moment the light was extinguished, and this wild cannibal, tomahawk
between his teeth, sprang into bed with me.
BEG_SENT I sang out, I could not
help it now; and giving a sudden grunt of astonishment he began
feeling me.
BEG_SENT Stammering out something, I knew not what, I rolled away from him
against the wall, and then conjured him, whoever or whatever he might
be, to keep quiet, and let me get up and light the lamp again.
BEG_SENT But
his guttural responses satisfied me at once that he but ill
comprehended my meaning.
BEG_SENT "Who-e debel you?
BEG_SENT "- he at last said- "you no speak-e, dam-me, I
kill-e." And so saying the lighted tomahawk began flourishing about
me in the dark.
BEG_SENT "Landlord, for God's sake, Peter Coffin!"
BEG_SENT shouted I.
BEG_SENT "Landlord!
BEG_SENT Watch!
BEG_SENT Coffin!
BEG_SENT Angels!
BEG_SENT save me!"
BEG_SENT "Speak-e!
BEG_SENT tell-ee me who-ee be, or dam-me, I kill-e!"
BEG_SENT again growled
the cannibal, while his horrid flourishings of the tomahawk scattered
the hot tobacco ashes about me till I thought my linen would get on
fire.
BEG_SENT But thank heaven, at that moment the landlord came into the
room light in hand, and leaping from the bed I ran up to him.
BEG_SENT "Don't be afraid now," said he, grinning again, "Queequeg here
wouldn't harm a hair of your head."
BEG_SENT "Stop your grinning," shouted I, "and why didn't you tell me that
that infernal harpooneer was a cannibal?"
BEG_SENT "I thought ye know'd it;- didn't I tell ye, he was a peddlin' heads
around town?- but turn flukes again and go to sleep.
BEG_SENT Queequeg, look
here- you sabbee me, I sabbee- you this man sleepe you- you sabbee?"
BEG_SENT "Me sabbee plenty"- grunted Queequeg, puffing away at his pipe and
sitting up in bed.
BEG_SENT "You gettee in," he added, motioning to me with his tomahawk, and
throwing the clothes to one side.
BEG_SENT He really did this in not only a
civil but a really kind and charitable way.
BEG_SENT I stood looking at him a
moment.
BEG_SENT For all his tattooings he was on the whole a clean, comely
looking cannibal.
BEG_SENT What's all this fuss I have been making about,
thought I to myself- the man's a human being just as I am: he has
just as much reason to fear me, as I have to be afraid of him.
BEG_SENT Better
sleep with a sober cannibal than a drunken Christian.
BEG_SENT "Landlord," said I, "tell him to stash his tomahawk there, or pipe,
or whatever you call it; tell him to stop smoking, in short, and I
will turn in with him.
BEG_SENT But I don't fancy having a man smoking in bed
with me.
BEG_SENT It's dangerous.
BEG_SENT Besides, I ain't insured."
BEG_SENT This being told to Queequeg, he at once complied, and again politely
motioned me to get into bed- rolling over to one side as much as to
say- I won't touch a leg of ye."
BEG_SENT "Good night, landlord," said I, "you may go."
BEG_SENT I turned in, and never slept better in my life.
BEG_SENT The Counterpane


Upon waking next morning about daylight, I found Queequeg's arm
thrown over me in the most loving and affectionate manner.
BEG_SENT You had
almost thought I had been his wife.
BEG_SENT The counterpane was of patchwork,
full of odd little parti-colored squares and triangles; and this arm
of his tattooed all over with an interminable Cretan labyrinth of a
figure, no two parts of which were of one precise shade- owing I
suppose to his keeping his arm at sea unmethodically in sun and
shade, his shirt sleeves irregularly rolled up at various times- this
same arm of his, I say, looked for all the world like a strip of that
same patchwork quilt.
BEG_SENT Indeed, partly lying on it as the arm did when
I first awoke, I could hardly tell it from the quilt, they so blended
their hues together; and it was only by the sense of weight and
pressure that I could tell that Queequeg was hugging me.
BEG_SENT My sensations were strange.
BEG_SENT Let me try to explain them.
BEG_SENT When I was a
child, I well remember a somewhat similar circumstance that befell
me; whether it was a reality or a dream, I never could entirely
settle.
BEG_SENT The circumstance was this.
BEG_SENT I had been cutting up some caper
or other- I think it was trying to crawl up the chimney, as I had
seen a little sweep do a few days previous; and my stepmother who,
somehow or other, was all the time whipping me, or sending me to bed
supperless,- my mother dragged me by the legs out of the chimney and
packed me off to bed, though it was only two o'clock in the afternoon
of the 21st June, the longest day in year in our hemisphere.
BEG_SENT I felt
dreadfully.
BEG_SENT But there was no help for it, so up stairs I went to my
little room in the third floor, undressed myself as slowly as
possible so as to kill time, and with a bitter sigh got between the
sheets.
BEG_SENT I lay there dismally calculating that sixteen entire hours must
elapse before I could hope for a resurrection.
BEG_SENT Sixteen hours in bed!
BEG_SENT the small of my back ached to think of it.
BEG_SENT And it was so light too;
the sun shining in at the window, and a great rattling of coaches in
the streets, and the sound of gay voices all over the house.
BEG_SENT I felt
worse and worse- at last I got up, dressed, and softly going down in
my stockinged feet, sought out my stepmother, and suddenly threw
myself at her feet, beseeching her as a particular favor to give me a
good slippering for my misbehaviour: anything indeed but condemning
me to lie abed such an unendurable length of time.
BEG_SENT But she was the
best and most conscientious of stepmothers, and back I had to go to
my room.
BEG_SENT For several hours I lay there broad awake, feeling a great
deal worse than I have ever done since, even from the greatest
subsequent misfortunes.
BEG_SENT At last I must have fallen into a troubled
nightmare of a doze; and slowly waking from it- half steeped in
dreams- I opened my eyes, and the before sunlit room was now wrapped
in outer darkness.
BEG_SENT Instantly I felt a shock running through all my
frame; nothing was to be seen, and nothing was to be heard; but a
supernatural hand seemed placed in mine.
BEG_SENT My arm hung over the
counterpane, and the nameless, unimaginable, silent form or phantom,
to which the hand belonged, seemed closely seated by my bed-side.
BEG_SENT For
what seemed ages piled on ages, I lay there, frozen with the most
awful fears, not daring to drag away my hand; yet ever thinking that
if I could but stir it one single inch, the horrid spell would be
broken.
BEG_SENT I knew not how this consciousness at last glided away from
me; but waking in the morning, I shudderingly remembered it all, and
for days and weeks and months afterwards I lost myself in confounding
attempts to explain the mystery.
BEG_SENT Nay, to this very hour, I often
puzzle myself with it.
BEG_SENT Now, take away the awful fear, and my sensations at feeling the
supernatural hand in mine were very similar, in the strangeness, to
those which I experienced on waking up and seeing Queequeg's pagan
arm thrown round me.
BEG_SENT But at length all the past night's events
soberly recurred, one by one, in fixed reality, and then I lay only
alive to the comical predicament.
BEG_SENT For though I tried to move his arm-
unlock his bridegroom clasp- yet, sleeping as he was, he still hugged
me tightly, as though naught but death should part us twain.
BEG_SENT I now
strove to rouse him- "Queequeg!
BEG_SENT "- but his only answer was a snore.
BEG_SENT I
then rolled over, my neck feeling as if it were in a horse-collar;
and suddenly felt a slight scratch.
BEG_SENT Throwing aside the counterpane,
there lay the tomahawk sleeping by the savage's side, as if it were a
hatchet-faced baby.
BEG_SENT A pretty pickle, truly, thought I; abed here in a
strange house in the broad day, with a cannibal and a tomahawk!
BEG_SENT "Queequeg!- in the name of goodness, Queequeg, wake!"
BEG_SENT At length, by
dint of much wriggling, and loud and incessant expostulations upon
the unbecomingness of his hugging a fellow male in that matrimonial
sort of style, I succeeded in extracting a grunt; and presently, he
drew back his arm, shook himself all over like a Newfoundland dog
just from the water, and sat up in bed, stiff as a pike-staff,
looking at me, and rubbing his eyes as if he did not altogether
remember how I came to be there, though a dim consciousness of
knowing something about me seemed slowly dawning over him.
BEG_SENT Meanwhile,
I lay quietly eyeing him, having no serious misgivings now, and bent
upon narrowly observing so curious a creature.
BEG_SENT When, at last, his
mind seemed made up touching the character of his bedfellow, and he
became, as it were, reconciled to the fact; he jumped out upon the
floor, and by certain signs and sounds gave me to understand that, if
it pleased me, he would dress first and then leave me to dress
afterwards, leaving the whole apartment to myself.
BEG_SENT Thinks I,
Queequeg, under the circumstances, this is a very civilized overture;
but, the truth is, these savages have an innate sense of delicacy,
say what you will; it is marvellous how essentially polite they
are.
BEG_SENT I pay this particular compliment to Queequeg, because he treated
me with so much civility and consideration, while I was guilty of
great rudeness; staring at him from the bed, and watching all his
toilette motions; for the time my curiosity getting the better of my
breeding.
BEG_SENT Nevertheless, a man like Queequeg you don't see every day,
he and his ways were well worth unusual regarding.
BEG_SENT He commenced dressing at top by donning his beaver hat, a very tall
one, by the by, and then- still minus his trowsers- he hunted up his
boots.
BEG_SENT What under the heavens he did it for, I cannot tell, but his
next movement was to crush himself- boots in hand, and hat on- under
the bed; when, from sundry violent gaspings and strainings, I
inferred he was hard at work booting himself; though by no law of
propriety that I ever heard of, is any man required to be private
when putting on his boots.
BEG_SENT But Queequeg, do you see, was a creature
in the transition stage- neither caterpillar nor butterfly.
BEG_SENT He was
just enough civilized to show off his outlandishness in the strangest
possible manners.
BEG_SENT His education was not yet completed.
BEG_SENT He was an
undergraduate.
BEG_SENT If he had not been a small degree civilized, he very
probably would not have troubled himself with boots at all; but then,
if he had not been still a savage, he never would have dreamt of
getting under the bed to put them on.
BEG_SENT At last, he emerged with his
hat very much dented and crushed down over his eyes, and began
creaking and limping about the room, as if, not being much accustomed
to boots, his pair of damp, wrinkled cowhide ones- probably not made
to order either- rather pinched and tormented him at the first go off
of a bitter cold morning.
BEG_SENT Seeing, now, that there were no curtains to the window, and that the
street being very narrow, the house opposite commanded a plain view
into the room, and observing more and more the indecorous figure that
Queequeg made, staving about with little else but his hat and boots
on; I begged him as well as I could, to accelerate his toilet
somewhat, and particularly to get into his pantaloons as soon as
possible.
BEG_SENT He complied, and then proceeded to wash himself.
BEG_SENT At that
time in the morning any Christian would have washed his face; but
Queequeg, to my amazement, contented himself with restricting his
ablutions to his chest, arms, and hands.
BEG_SENT He then donned his
waistcoat, and taking up a piece of hard soap on the wash-stand
centre table, dipped it into water and commenced lathering his
face.
BEG_SENT I was watching to see where he kept his razor, when lo and
behold, he takes the harpoon from the bed corner, slips out the long
wooden stock, unsheathes the head, whets it a little on his boot, and
striding up to the bit of mirror against the wall, begins a vigorous
scraping, or rather harpooning of his cheeks.
BEG_SENT Thinks I, Queequeg,
this is using Rogers's best cutlery with a vengeance.
BEG_SENT Afterwards I
wondered the less at this operation when I came to know of what fine
steel the head of a harpoon is made, and how exceedingly sharp the
long straight edges are always kept.
BEG_SENT The rest of his toilet was soon achieved, and he proudly marched out
of the room, wrapped up in his great pilot monkey jacket, and
sporting his harpoon like a marshal's baton.
BEG_SENT Breakfast


I quickley followed suit, and descending into the bar-room accosted
the grinning landlord very pleasantly.
BEG_SENT I cherished no malice towards
him, though he had been skylarking with me not a little in the matter
of my bedfellow.
BEG_SENT However, a good laugh is a mighty good thing, and rather too scarce a
good thing; the more's the pity.
BEG_SENT So, if any one man, in his own
proper person, afford stuff for a good joke to anybody, let him not
be backward, but let him cheerfully allow himself to spend and to be
spent in that way.
BEG_SENT And the man that has anything bountifully
laughable about him, be sure there is more in that man than you
perhaps think for.
BEG_SENT The bar-room was now full of the boarders who had been dropping in
the night previous, and whom I had not as yet had a good look
at.
BEG_SENT They were nearly all whalemen; chief mates, and second mates, and
third mates, and sea carpenters, and sea coopers, and sea
blacksmiths, and harpooneers, and ship keepers; a brown and brawny
company, with bosky beards; an unshorn, shaggy set, all wearing
monkey jackets for morning gowns.
BEG_SENT You could pretty plainly tell how long each one had been ashore.
BEG_SENT This
young fellow's healthy cheek is like a sun-toasted pear in hue, and
would seem to smell almost as musky; he cannot have been three days
landed from his Indian voyage.
BEG_SENT That man next him looks a few shades
lighter; you might say a touch of satin wood is in him.
BEG_SENT In the
complexion of a third still lingers a tropic tawn, but slightly
bleached withal; he doubtless has tarried whole weeks ashore.
BEG_SENT But who
could show a cheek like Queequeg?
BEG_SENT which, barred with various tints,
seemed like the Andes' western slope, to show forth in one array,
contrasting climates, zone by zone.
BEG_SENT "Grub, ho!"
BEG_SENT now cried the landlord, flinging open a door, and in we
went to breakfast.
BEG_SENT They say that men who have seen the world, thereby become quite at
ease in manner, quite self-possessed in company.
BEG_SENT Not always, though:
Ledyard, the great New England traveller, and Mungo Park, the Scotch
one; of all men, they possessed the least assurance in the
parlor.
BEG_SENT But perhaps the mere crossing of Siberia in a sledge drawn by
dogs as Ledyard did, or the taking a long solitary walk on an empty
stomach, in the negro heart of Africa, which was the sum of poor
Mungo's performances- this kind of travel, I say, may not be the very
best mode of attaining a high social polish.
BEG_SENT Still, for the most
part, that sort of thing is to be had anywhere.
BEG_SENT These reflections just here are occasioned by the circumstance that
after we were all seated at the table, and I was preparing to hear
some good stories about whaling; to my no small surprise nearly every
man maintained a profound silence.
BEG_SENT And not only that, but they looked
embarrassed.
BEG_SENT Yes, here were a set of sea-dogs, many of whom without
the slightest bashfulness had boarded great whales on the high seas-
entire strangers to them- and duelled them dead without winking; and
yet, here they sat at a social breakfast table- all of the same
calling, all of kindred tastes- looking round as sheepishly at each
other as though they had never been out of sight of some sheepfold
among the Green Mountains.
BEG_SENT A curious sight; these bashful bears,
these timid warrior whalemen!
BEG_SENT But as for Queequeg- why, Queequeg sat there among them- at the head
of the table, too, it so chanced; as cool as an icicle.
BEG_SENT To be sure I
cannot say much for his breeding.
BEG_SENT His greatest admirer could not have
cordially justified his bringing his harpoon into breakfast with him,
and using it there without ceremony; reaching over the table with it,
to the imminent jeopardy of many heads, and grappling the beefsteaks
towards him.
BEG_SENT But that was certainly very coolly done by him, and
every one knows that in most people's estimation, to do anything
coolly is to do it genteelly.
BEG_SENT We will not speak of all Queequeg's peculiarities here; how he
eschewed coffee and hot rolls, and applied his undivided attention to
beefsteaks, done rare.
BEG_SENT Enough, that when breakfast was over he
withdrew like the rest into the public room, lighted his
tomahawk-pipe, and was sitting there quietly digesting and smoking
with his inseparable hat on, when I sallied out for a stroll.
BEG_SENT The Street


If I had been astonished at first catching a glimpse of so outlandish
an individual as Queequeg circulating among the polite society of a
civilized town, that astonishment soon departed upon taking my first
daylight stroll through the streets of New Bedford.
BEG_SENT In thoroughfares nigh the docks, any considerable seaport will
frequently offer to view the queerest looking nondescripts from
foreign parts.
BEG_SENT Even in Broadway and Chestnut streets, Mediterranean
mariners will sometimes jostle the affrighted ladies.
BEG_SENT Regent Street
is not unknown to Lascars and Malays; and at Bombay, in the Apollo
Green, live Yankees have often scared the natives.
BEG_SENT But New Bedford
beats all Water Street and Wapping.
BEG_SENT In these last-mentioned haunts
you see only sailors; in New Bedford, actual cannibals stand chatting
at street corners; savages outright; many of whom yet carry on their
bones unholy flesh.
BEG_SENT It makes a stranger stare.
BEG_SENT But, besides the Feegeeans, Tongatobooarrs, Erromanggoans,
Pannangians, and Brighggians, and, besides the wild specimens of the
whaling-craft which unheeded reel about the streets, you will see
other sights still more curious, certainly more comical.
BEG_SENT There
weekly arrive in this town scores of green Vermonters and New
Hampshire men, all athirst for gain and glory in the fishery.
BEG_SENT They
are mostly young, of stalwart frames; fellows who have felled
forests, and now seek to drop the axe and snatch the whale-lance.
BEG_SENT Many are as green as the Green Mountains whence they came.
BEG_SENT In some
things you would think them but a few hours old.
BEG_SENT Look there!
BEG_SENT that
chap strutting round the corner.
BEG_SENT He wears a beaver hat and
swallow-tailed coat, girdled with a sailor-belt and a
sheath-knife.
BEG_SENT Here comes another with a sou'-wester and a bombazine
cloak.
BEG_SENT No town-bred dandy will compare with a country-bred one- I mean a
downright bumpkin dandy- a fellow that, in the dog-days, will mow his
two acres in buckskin gloves for fear of tanning his hands.
BEG_SENT Now when
a country dandy like this takes it into his head to make a
distinguished reputation, and joins the great whale-fishery, you
should see the comical things he does upon reaching the seaport.
BEG_SENT In
bespeaking his sea-outfit, he orders bell-buttons to his waistcoats;
straps to his canvas trowsers.
BEG_SENT Ah, poor Hay-Seed!
BEG_SENT how bitterly will
burst those straps in the first howling gale, when thou art driven,
straps, buttons, and all, down the throat of the tempest.
BEG_SENT But think not that this famous town has only harpooneers, cannibals,
and bumpkins to show her visitors.
BEG_SENT Not at all.
BEG_SENT Still New Bedford is a
queer place.
BEG_SENT Had it not been for us whalemen, that tract of land
would this day perhaps have been in as howling condition as the coast
of Labrador.
BEG_SENT As it is, parts of her back country are enough to
frighten one, they look so bony.
BEG_SENT The town itself is perhaps the
dearest place to live in, in all New England.
BEG_SENT It is a land of oil,
true enough: but not like Canaan; a land, also, of corn and wine.
BEG_SENT The
streets do not run with milk; nor in the spring-time do they pave
them with fresh eggs.
BEG_SENT Yet, in spite of this, nowhere in all America
will you find more patrician-like houses; parks and gardens more
opulent, than in New Bedford.
BEG_SENT Whence came they?
BEG_SENT how planted upon this
once scraggy scoria of a country?
BEG_SENT Go and gaze upon the iron emblematical harpoons round yonder lofty
mansion, and your question will be answered.
BEG_SENT Yes; all these brave
houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and
Indian oceans.
BEG_SENT One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up hither
from the bottom of the sea.
BEG_SENT Can Herr Alexander perform a feat like
that?
BEG_SENT In New Bedford, fathers, they say, give whales for dowers to their
daughters, and portion off their nieces with a few porpoises
a-piece.
BEG_SENT You must go to New Bedford to see a brilliant wedding; for,
they say, they have reservoirs of oil in every house, and every night
recklessly burn their lengths in spermaceti candles.
BEG_SENT In summer time, the town is sweet to see; full of fine maples- long
avenues of green and gold.
BEG_SENT And in August, high in air, the beautiful
and bountiful horse-chestnuts, candelabra-wise, proffer the passer-by
their tapering upright cones of congregated blossoms.
BEG_SENT So omnipotent
is art; which in many a district of New Bedford has superinduced
bright terraces ot flowers upon the barren refuse rocks thrown aside
at creation's final day.
BEG_SENT And the women of New Bedford, they bloom like their own red
roses.
BEG_SENT But roses only bloom in summer; whereas the fine carnation of
their cheeks is perennial as sunlight in the seventh
heavens.
BEG_SENT Elsewhere match that bloom of theirs, ye cannot, save in
Salem, where they tell me the young girls breathe such musk, their
sailor sweethearts smell them miles off shore, as though they were
drawing nigh the odorous Moluccas instead of the Puritanic sands.
BEG_SENT The Chapel


In the same New Bedford there stands a Whaleman's Chapel, and few are
the moody fishermen, shortly bound for the Indian Ocean or Pacific,
who fail to make a Sunday visit to the spot.
BEG_SENT I am sure that I did
not.
BEG_SENT Returning from my first morning stroll, I again sallied out upon this
special errand.
BEG_SENT The sky had changed from clear, sunny cold, to
driving sleet and mist.
BEG_SENT Wrapping myself in my shaggy jacket of the
cloth called bearskin, I fought my way against the stubborn storm.
BEG_SENT Entering, I found a small scattered congregation of sailors, and
sailors' wives and widows.
BEG_SENT A muffled silence reigned, only broken at
times by the shrieks of the storm.
BEG_SENT Each silent worshipper seemed
purposely sitting apart from the other, as if each silent grief were
insular and incommunicable.
BEG_SENT The chaplain had not yet arrived; and
there these silent islands of men and women sat steadfastly eyeing
several marble tablets, with black borders, masoned into the wall on
either side the pulpit.
BEG_SENT Three of them ran something like the
following, but I do not pretend to quote:

                               SACRED
                            TO THE MEMORY
                           OF JOHN TALBOT,
           Who, at the age of eighteen, was lost overboard
             Near the Isle of Desolation, off Patagonia,
                         November 1st, 1836.
BEG_SENT THIS TABLET
                      Is erected to his Memory
                           BY HIS SISTER.
BEG_SENT SACRED
                            TO THE MEMORY
                   OF ROBERT LONG, WILLIS ELLERY,
              NATHAN COLEMAN, WALTER CANNY, SETH MACY,
                          AND SAMUEL GLEIG,
                   Forming one of the boats' crews
                          OF THE SHIP ELIZA
               Who were towed out of sight by a Whale,
                   On the Off-shore Ground in the
                              PACIFIC,
                        December 31st, 1839.
BEG_SENT THIS MARBLE
                  Is here placed by their surviving
                             SHIPMATES.
BEG_SENT SACRED
                            TO THE MEMORY
                             Of The late
                       CAPTAIN EZEKIEL HARDY,
             Who in the bows of his boat was killed by a
                 Sperm Whale on the coast of Japan,
                          August 3d, 1833.
BEG_SENT THIS TABLET
                      Is erected to his Memory
                             BY HIS WID

Shaking off the sleet from my ice-glazed hat and jacket, I seated
myself near the door, and turning sideways was surprised to see
Queequeg near me.
BEG_SENT Affected by the solemnity of the scene, there was a
wondering gaze of incredulous curiosity in his countenance.
BEG_SENT This
savage was the only person present who seemed to notice my entrance;
because he was the only one who could not read, and, therefore, was
not reading those frigid inscriptions on the wall.
BEG_SENT Whether any of the
relatives of the seamen whose names appeared there were now among the
congregation, I knew not; but so many are the unrecorded accidents in
the fishery, and so plainly did several women present wear the
countenance if not the trappings of some unceasing grief, that I feel
sure that here before me were assembled those, in whose unhealing
hearts the sight of those bleak tablets sympathetically caused the
old wounds to bleed afresh.
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT ye whose dead lie buried beneath the green grass; who standing
among flowers can say- here, here lies my beloved; ye know not the
desolation that broods in bosoms like these.
BEG_SENT What bitter blanks in
those black-bordered marbles which cover no ashes!
BEG_SENT What despair in
those immovable inscriptions!
BEG_SENT What deadly voids and unbidden
infidelities in the lines that seem to gnaw upon all Faith, and
refuse resurrections to the beings who have placelessly perished
without a grave.
BEG_SENT As well might those tablets stand in the cave of
Elephanta as here.
BEG_SENT In what census of living creatures, the dead of mankind are included;
why it is that a universal proverb says of them, that they tell no
tales, though containing more secrets than the Goodwin Sands!
BEG_SENT how it
is that to his name who yesterday departed for the other world, we
prefix so significant and infidel a word, and yet do not thus entitle
him, if he but embarks for the remotest Indies of this living earth;
why the Life Insurance Companies pay death-forfeitures upon
immortals; in what eternal, unstirring paralysis, and deadly,
hopeless trance, yet lies antique Adam who died sixty round centuries
ago; how it is that we still refuse to be comforted for those who we
nevertheless maintain are dwelling in unspeakable bliss; why all the
