living so strive to hush all the dead; wherefore but the rumor of a
knocking in a tomb will terrify a whole city.
BEG_SENT All these things are
not without their meanings.
BEG_SENT But Faith, like a jackal, feeds among the tombs, and even from these
dead doubts she gathers her most vital hope.
BEG_SENT It needs scarcely to be told, with what feelings, on the eve of a
Nantucket voyage, I regarded those marble tablets, and by the murky
light of that darkened, doleful day read the fate of the whalemen who
had gone before me.
BEG_SENT Yes, Ishmael, the same fate may be thine.
BEG_SENT But
somehow I grew merry again.
BEG_SENT Delightful inducements to embark, fine
chance for promotion, it seems- aye, a stove boat will make me an
immortal by brevet.
BEG_SENT Yes, there is death in this business of whaling-
a speechlessly quick chaotic bundling of a man into Eternity.
BEG_SENT But
what then?
BEG_SENT Methinks we have hugely mistaken this matter of Life and
Death.
BEG_SENT Methinks that what they call my shadow here on earth is my
true substance.
BEG_SENT Methinks that in looking at things spiritual, we are
too much like oysters observing the sun through the water, and
thinking that thick water the thinnest of air.
BEG_SENT Methinks my body is
but the lees of my better being.
BEG_SENT In fact take my body who will, take
it I say, it is not me.
BEG_SENT And therefore three cheers for Nantucket; and
come a stove boat and stove body when they will, for stave my soul,
Jove himself cannot.
BEG_SENT The Pulpit


I had not been seated very long ere a man of a certain venerable
robustness entered; immediately as the storm-pelted door flew back
upon admitting him, a quick regardful eyeing of him by all the
congregation, sufficiently attested that this fine old man was the
chaplain.
BEG_SENT Yes, it was the famous Father Mapple, so called by the
whalemen, among whom he was a very great favorite.
BEG_SENT He had been a
sailor and a harpooneer in his youth, but for many years past had
dedicated his life to the ministry.
BEG_SENT At the time I now write of,
Father Mapple was in the hardy winter of a healthy old age; that sort
of old age which seems merging into a second flowering youth, for
among all the fissures of his wrinkles, there shone certain mild
gleams of a newly developing bloom- the spring verdure peeping forth
even beneath February's snow.
BEG_SENT No one having previously heard his
history, could for the first time behold Father Mapple without the
utmost interest, because there were certain engrafted clerical
peculiarities about him, imputable to that adventurous maritime life
he had led.
BEG_SENT When he entered I observed that he carried no umbrella,
and certainly had not come in his carriage, for his tarpaulin hat ran
down with melting sleet, and his great pilot cloth jacket seemed
almost to drag him to the floor with the weight of the water it had
absorbed.
BEG_SENT However, hat and coat and overshoes were one by one
removed, and hung up in a little space in an adjacent corner; when,
arrayed in a decent suit, he quietly approached the pulpit.
BEG_SENT Like most old fashioned pulpits, it was a very lofty one, and since a
regular stairs to such a height would, by its long angle with the
floor, seriously contract the already small area of the chapel, the
architect, it seemed, had acted upon the hint of Father Mapple, and
finished the pulpit without a stairs, substituting a perpendicular
side ladder, like those used in mounting a ship from a boat at
sea.
BEG_SENT The wife of a whaling captain had provided the chapel with a
handsome pair of red worsted man-ropes for this ladder, which, being
itself nicely headed, and stained with a mahogany color, the whole
contrivance, considering what manner of chapel it was, seemed by no
means in bad taste.
BEG_SENT Halting for an instant at the foot of the
ladder, and with both hands grasping the ornamental knobs of the
man-ropes, Father Mapple cast a look upwards, and then with a truly
sailor-like but still reverential dexterity, hand over hand, mounted
the steps as if ascending the main-top of his vessel.
BEG_SENT The perpendicular parts of this side ladder, as is usually the case
with swinging ones, were of cloth-covered rope, only the rounds were
of wood, so that at every step there was a joint.
BEG_SENT At my first glimpse
of the pulpit, it had not escaped me that however convenient for a
ship, these joints in the present instance seemed unnecessary.
BEG_SENT For I
was not prepared to see Father Mapple after gaining the height,
slowly turn round, and stooping over the pulpit, deliberately drag up
the ladder step by step, till the whole was deposited within, leaving
him impregnable in his little Quebec.
BEG_SENT I pondered some time without fully comprehending the reason for
this.
BEG_SENT Father Mapple enjoyed such a wide reputation for sincerity and
sanctity, that I could not suspect him of courting notoriety by any
mere tricks of the stage.
BEG_SENT No, thought I, there must be some sober
reason for this thing; furthermore, it must symbolize something
unseen.
BEG_SENT Can it be, then, that by that act of physical isolation, he
signifies his spiritual withdrawal for the time, from all outward
worldly ties and connexions?
BEG_SENT Yes, for replenished with the meat and
wine of the word, to the faithful man of God, this pulpit, I see, is
a self-containing stronghold- a lofty Ehrenbreitstein, with a
perennial well of water within the walls.
BEG_SENT But the side ladder was not the only strange feature of the place,
borrowed from the chaplain's former sea-farings.
BEG_SENT Between the marble
cenotaphs on either hand of the pulpit, the wall which formed its
back was adorned with a large painting representing a gallant ship
beating against a terrible storm off a lee coast of black rocks and
snowy breakers.
BEG_SENT But high above the flying scud and dark-rolling
clouds, there floated a little isle of sunlight, from which beamed
forth an angel's face; and this bright face shed a distant spot of
radiance upon the ship's tossed deck, something like that silver
plate now inserted into Victory's plank where Nelson fell.
BEG_SENT "Ah, noble
ship," the angel seemed to say, "beat on, beat on, thou noble ship,
and bear a hardy helm; for lo!
BEG_SENT the sun is breaking through; the
clouds are rolling off- serenest azure is at hand."
BEG_SENT Nor was the pulpit itself without a trace of the same sea-taste that
had achieved the ladder and the picture.
BEG_SENT Its panelled front was in
the likeness of a ship's bluff bows, and the Holy Bible rested on a
projecting piece of scroll work, fashioned after a ship's
fiddle-headed beak.
BEG_SENT What could be more full of meaning?- for the pulpit is ever this
earth's foremost part; all the rest comes in its rear; the pulpit
leads the world.
BEG_SENT From thence it is the storm of God's quick wrath is
first descried, and the bow must bear the earliest brunt.
BEG_SENT From thence
it is the God of breezes fair or foul is first invoked for favorable
winds.
BEG_SENT Yes, the world's a ship on its passage out, and not a voyage
complete; and the pulpit is its prow.
BEG_SENT The Sermon


Father Mapple rose, and in a mild voice of unassuming authority
ordered the scattered people to condense.
BEG_SENT "Star board gangway, there!
BEG_SENT side away to larboard- larboard gangway to starboard!
BEG_SENT Midships!
BEG_SENT midships!"
BEG_SENT There was a low rumbling of heavy sea-boots among the benches, and a
still slighter shuffling of women's shoes, and all was quiet again,
and every eye on the preacher.
BEG_SENT He paused a little; then kneeling in the pulpit's bows, folded his
large brown hands across his chest, uplifted his closed eyes, and
offered a prayer so deeply devout that he seemed kneeling and praying
at the bottom of the sea.
BEG_SENT This ended, in prolonged solemn tones, like the continual tolling of
a bell in a ship that is foundering at sea in a fog- in such tones he
commenced reading the following hymn; but changing his manner towards
the concluding stanzas, burst forth with a pealing exultation and
joy-

                 The ribs and terrors in the whale,
                   Arched over me a dismal gloom,
                                  
              While all God's sun-lit waves rolled by,
                 And lift me deepening down to doom.
BEG_SENT I saw the opening maw of hell,
                With endless pains and sorrows there;
                                  
               Which none but they that feel can tell-
                   Oh, I was plunging to despair.
BEG_SENT In black distress, I called my God,
                When I could scarce believe him mine,
                                  
                 He bowed his ear to my complaints-
                  No more the whale did me confine.
BEG_SENT With speed he flew to my relief,
                   As on a radiant dolphin borne;
                                  
                Awful, yet bright, as lightning shone
                    The face of my Deliverer God.
BEG_SENT My song for ever shall record
                  That terrible, that joyful hour;
                                  
                     I give the glory to my God,
                    His all the mercy and the pow

Nearly all joined in singing this hymn, which swelled high above the
howling of the storm.
BEG_SENT A brief pause ensued; the preacher slowly
turned over the leaves of the Bible, and at last, folding his hand
down upon the proper page, said: "Beloved shipmates, clinch the last
verse of the first chapter of Jonah- 'And God had prepared a great
fish to swallow up Jonah.'"
BEG_SENT "Shipmates, this book, containing only four chapters- four yarns- is
one of the smallest strands in the mighty cable of the
Scriptures.
BEG_SENT Yet what depths of the soul Jonah's deep sealine sound!
BEG_SENT what a pregnant lesson to us is this prophet!
BEG_SENT What a noble thing is
that canticle in the fish's belly!
BEG_SENT How billow-like and boisterously
grand!
BEG_SENT We feel the floods surging over us, we sound with him to the
kelpy bottom of the waters; sea-weed and all the slime of the sea is
about us!
BEG_SENT But what is this lesson that the book of Jonah teaches?
BEG_SENT Shipmates, it is a two-stranded lesson; a lesson to us all as sinful
men, and a lesson to me as a pilot of the living God.
BEG_SENT As sinful men,
it is a lesson to us all, because it is a story of the sin,
hard-heartedness, suddenly awakened fears, the swift punishment,
repentance, prayers, and finally the deliverance and joy of Jonah.
BEG_SENT As
with all sinners among men, the sin of this son of Amittai was in his
wilful disobedience of the command of God- never mind now what that
command was, or how conveyed- which he found a hard command.
BEG_SENT But all
the things that God would have us do are hard for us to do- remember
that- and hence, he oftener commands us than endeavors to
persuade.
BEG_SENT And if we obey God, we must disobey ourselves; and it is in
this disobeying ourselves, wherein the hardness of obeying God
consists.
BEG_SENT "With this sin of disobedience in him, Jonah still further flouts at
God, by seeking to flee from Him.
BEG_SENT He thinks that a ship made by men,
will carry him into countries where God does not reign but only the
Captains of this earth.
BEG_SENT He skulks about the wharves of Joppa, and
seeks a ship that's bound for Tarshish.
BEG_SENT There lurks, perhaps, a
hitherto unheeded meaning here.
BEG_SENT By all accounts Tarshish could have
been no other city than the modern Cadiz.
BEG_SENT That's the opinion of
learned men.
BEG_SENT And where is Cadiz, shipmates?
BEG_SENT Cadiz is in Spain; as far
by water, from Joppa, as Jonah could possibly have sailed in those
ancient days, when the Atlantic was an almost unknown sea.
BEG_SENT Because
Joppa, the modern Jaffa, shipmates, is on the most easterly coast of
the Mediterranean, the Syrian; and Tarshish or Cadiz more than two
thousand miles to the westward from that, just outside the Straits of
Gibraltar.
BEG_SENT See ye not then, shipmates, that Jonah sought to flee
worldwide from God?
BEG_SENT Miserable man!
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT most contemptible and worthy
of all scorn; with slouched hat and guilty eye, skulking from his
God; prowling among the shipping like a vile burglar hastening to
cross the seas.
BEG_SENT So disordered, self-condemning in his look, that had
there been policemen in those days, Jonah, on the mere suspicion of
something wrong, had been arrested ere he touched a deck.
BEG_SENT How plainly
he's a fugitive!
BEG_SENT no baggage, not a hat-box, valise, or carpet-bag,-
no friends accompany him to the wharf with their adieux.
BEG_SENT At last,
after much dodging search, he finds the Tarshish ship receiving the
last items of her cargo; and as he steps on board to see its Captain
in the cabin, all the sailors for the moment desist from hoisting in
the goods, to mark the stranger's evil eye.
BEG_SENT Jonah sees this; but in
vain he tries to look all ease and confidence; in vain essays his
wretched smile.
BEG_SENT Strong intuitions of the man assure the mariners he
can be no innocent.
BEG_SENT In their gamesome but still serious way, one
whispers to the other- "Jack, he's robbed a widow;" or, "Joe, do you
mark him; he's a bigamist;" or, "Harry lad, I guess he's the
adulterer that broke jail in old Gomorrah, or belike, one of the
missing murderers from Sodom."
BEG_SENT Another runs to read the bill that's
stuck against the spile upon the wharf to which the ship is moored,
offering five hundred gold coins for the apprenhension of a
parricide, and containing a description of his person.
BEG_SENT He reads, and
looks from Jonah to the bill; while all his sympathetic shipmates now
crowd round Jonah, prepared to lay their hands upon him.
BEG_SENT Frightened
Jonah trembles.
BEG_SENT and summoning all his boldness to his face, only
looks so much the more a coward.
BEG_SENT He will not confess himself
suspected; but that itself is strong suspicion.
BEG_SENT So he makes the best
of it; and when the sailors find him not to be the man that is
advertised, they let him pass, and he descends into the cabin.
BEG_SENT "'Who's there?'
BEG_SENT cries the Captain at his busy desk, hurriedly making
out his papers for the Customs- 'Who's there?'
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT how that harmless
question mangles Jonah!
BEG_SENT For the instant he almost turns to flee
again.
BEG_SENT But he rallies.
BEG_SENT 'I seek a passage in this ship to Tarshish;
how soon sail ye, sir?'
BEG_SENT Thus far the busy Captain had not looked up
to Jonah, though the man now stands before him; but no sooner does he
hear that hollow voice, than he darts a scrutinizing glance.
BEG_SENT 'We sail
with the next coming tide,' at last he slowly answered, still
intently eyeing him.
BEG_SENT 'No sooner, sir?
BEG_SENT '- 'Soon enough for any honest
man that goes a passenger.'
BEG_SENT Ha!
BEG_SENT Jonah, that's another stab.
BEG_SENT But he
swiftly calls away the Captain from that scent.
BEG_SENT 'I'll sail with ye,'-
he says,- 'the passage money how much is that?- I'll pay now.'
BEG_SENT For it
is particularly written, shipmates, as if it were a thing not to be
overlooked in this history, 'that he paid the fare thereof' ere the
craft did sail.
BEG_SENT And taken with the context, this is full of meaning.
BEG_SENT "Now Jonah's Captain, shipmates, was one whose discernment detects
crime in any, but whose cupidity exposes it only in the penniless.
BEG_SENT In
this world, shipmates, sin that pays its way can travel freely and
without a passport; whereas Virtue, if a pauper, is stopped at all
frontiers.
BEG_SENT So Jonah's Captain prepares to test the length of Jonah's
purse, ere he judge him openly.
BEG_SENT He charges him thrice the usual sum;
and it's assented to.
BEG_SENT Then the Captain knows that Jonah is a
fugitive; but at the same time resolves to help a flight that paves
its rear with gold.
BEG_SENT Yet when Jonah fairly takes out his purse,
prudent suspicions still molest the Captain.
BEG_SENT He rings every coin to
find a counterfeit.
BEG_SENT Not a forger, any way, he mutters; and Jonah is
put down for his passage.
BEG_SENT 'Point out my state-room, Sir,' says Jonah
now, 'I'm travel-weary; I need sleep.'
BEG_SENT 'Thou lookest like it,' says
the Captain, 'there's thy room.'
BEG_SENT Jonah enters, and would lock the
door, but the lock contains no key.
BEG_SENT Hearing him foolishly fumbling
there, the Captain laughs lowly to himself, and mutters something
about the doors of convicts' cells being never allowed to be locked
within.
BEG_SENT All dressed and dusty as he is, Jonah throws himself into his
berth, and finds the little state-room ceiling almost resting on his
forehead.
BEG_SENT The air is close, and Jonah gasps.
BEG_SENT Then, in that contracted
hole, sunk, too, beneath the ship's water-line, Jonah feels the
heralding presentiment of that stifling hour, when the whale shall
hold him in the smallest of his bowels' wards.
BEG_SENT "Screwed at its axis against the side, a swinging lamp slightly
oscillates in Jonah's room; and the ship, heeling over towards the
wharf with the weight of the last bales received, the lamp, flame and
all, though in slight motion, still maintains a permanent obliquity
with reference to the room; though, in truth, infallibly straight
itself, it but made obvious the false, lying levels among which it
hung.
BEG_SENT The lamp alarms and frightens Jonah; as lying in his berth his
tormented eyes roll round the place, and this thus far successful
fugitive finds no refuge for his restless glance.
BEG_SENT But that
contradiction in the lamp more and more appals him.
BEG_SENT The floor, the
ceiling, and the side, are all awry.
BEG_SENT 'Oh!
BEG_SENT so my conscience hangs in
me!'
BEG_SENT he groans, 'straight upwards, so it burns; but the chambers of
my soul are all in crookedness!'
BEG_SENT "Like one who after a night of drunken revelry hies to his bed, still
reeling, but with conscience yet pricking him, as the plungings of
the Roman race-horse but so much the more strike his steel tags into
him; as one who in that miserable plight still turns and turns in
giddy anguish, praying God for annihilation until the fit be passed;
and at last amid the whirl of woe he feels, a deep stupor steals over
him, as over the man who bleeds to death, for conscience is the
wound, and there's naught to staunch it; so, after sore wrestling in
his berth, Jonah's prodigy of ponderous misery drags him drowning
down to sleep.
BEG_SENT "And now the time of tide has come; the ship casts off her cables;
and from the deserted wharf the uncheered ship for Tarshish, all
careening, glides to sea.
BEG_SENT That ship, my friends, was the first of
recorded smugglers!
BEG_SENT the contraband was Jonah.
BEG_SENT But the sea rebels; he
will not bare the wicked burden.
BEG_SENT A dreadful storm comes on, the ship
is like to break.
BEG_SENT But now when the boatswain calls all hands to
lighten her; when boxes, bales, and jars are clattering overboard;
when the wind is shrieking, and the men are yelling, and every plank
thunders with trampling feet right over Jonah's head; in all this
raging tumult, Jonah sleeps his hideous sleep.
BEG_SENT He sees no black sky
and raging sea, feels not the reeling timbers, and little hears he or
heeds he the far rush of the mighty whale, which even now with open
mouth is cleaving the seas after him.
BEG_SENT Aye, shipmates, Jonah was gone
down into the sides of the ship- a berth in the cabin as I have taken
it, and was fast asleep.
BEG_SENT But the frightened master comes to him, and
shrieks in his dead ear, 'What meanest thou, O, sleeper!
BEG_SENT arise!'
BEG_SENT Startled from his lethargy by that direful cry, Jonah staggers to his
feet, and stumbling to the deck, grasps a shroud, to look out upon
the sea.
BEG_SENT But at that moment he is sprung upon by a panther billow
leaping over the bulwarks.
BEG_SENT Wave after wave thus leaps into the ship,
and finding no speedy vent runs roaring fore and aft, till the
mariners come nigh to drowning while yet afloat.
BEG_SENT And ever, as the
white moon shows her affrighted face from the steep gullies in the
blackness overhead, aghast Jonah sees the rearing bowsprit pointing
high upward, but soon beat downward again towards the tormented deep.
BEG_SENT "Terrors upon terrors run shouting through his soul.
BEG_SENT In all his
cringing attitudes, the God-fugitive is now too plainly known.
BEG_SENT The
sailors mark him; more and more certain grow their suspicions of him,
and at last, fully to test the truth, by referring the whole matter
to high Heaven, they all-outward to casting lots, to see for whose
cause this great tempest was upon them.
BEG_SENT The lot is Jonah's; that
discovered, then how furiously they mob him with their
questions.
BEG_SENT 'What is thine occupation?
BEG_SENT Whence comest thou?
BEG_SENT Thy
country?
BEG_SENT What people?
BEG_SENT But mark now, my shipmates, the behavior of
poor Jonah.
BEG_SENT The eager mariners but ask him who he is, and where from;
whereas, they not only receive an answer to those questions, but
likewise another answer to a question not put by them, but the
unsolicited answer is forced from Jonah by the hard hand of God that
is upon him.
BEG_SENT "'I am a Hebrew,' he cries- and then- 'I fear the Lord the God of
Heaven who hath made the sea and the dry land!'
BEG_SENT Fear him, O Jonah?
BEG_SENT Aye, well mightest thou fear the Lord God then!
BEG_SENT Straightway, he now
goes on to make a full confession; whereupon the mariners became more
and more appalled, but still are pitiful.
BEG_SENT For when Jonah, not yet
supplicating God for mercy, since he but too well knew the darkness
of his deserts,- when wretched Jonah cries out to them to take him
and cast him forth into the sea, for he knew that for his sake this
great tempest was upon them; they mercifully turn from him, and seek
by other means to save the ship.
BEG_SENT But all in vain; the indignant gale
howls louder; then, with one hand raised invokingly to God, with the
other they not unreluctantly lay hold of Jonah.
BEG_SENT "And now behold Jonah taken up as an anchor and dropped into the sea;
when instantly an oily calmness floats out from the east, and the sea
is as Jonah carries down the gale with him, leaving smooth water
behind.
BEG_SENT He goes down in the whirling heart of such a masterless
commotion that he scarce heeds the moment when he drops seething into
the yawning jaws awaiting him; and the whale shoots-to all his ivory
teeth, like so many white bolts, upon his prison.
BEG_SENT Then Jonah prayed
unto the Lord out of the fish's belly.
BEG_SENT But observe his prayer, and
learn a weighty lesson.
BEG_SENT For sinful as he is, Jonah does not weep and
wail for direct deliverance.
BEG_SENT He feels that his dreadful punishment is
just.
BEG_SENT He leaves all his deliverance to God, contenting himself with
this, that spite of all his pains and pangs, he will still look
towards His holy temple.
BEG_SENT And here, shipmates, is true and faithful
repentance; not clamorous for pardon, but grateful for
punishment.
BEG_SENT And how pleasing to God was this conduct in Jonah, is
shown in the eventual deliverance of him from the sea and the
whale.
BEG_SENT Shipmates, I do not place Jonah before you to be copied for
his sin but I do place him before you as a model for repentance.
BEG_SENT Sin
not; but if you do, take heed to repent of it like Jonah."
BEG_SENT While he was speaking these words, the howling of the shrieking,
slanting storm without seemed to add new power to the preacher, who,
when describing Jonah's sea-storm, seemed tossed by a storm
himself.
BEG_SENT His deep chest heaved as with a ground-swell; his tossed
arms seemed the warring elements at work; and the thunders that
rolled away from off his swarthy brow, and the light leaping from his
eye, made all his simple hearers look on him with a quick fear that
was strange to them.
BEG_SENT There now came a lull in his look, as he silently turned over the
leaves of the Book once more; and, at last, standing motionless, with
closed eyes, for the moment, seemed communing with God and himself.
BEG_SENT But again he leaned over towards the people, and bowing his head
lowly, with an aspect of the deepest yet manliest humility, he spake
these words:

"Shipmates, God has laid but one hand upon you; both his hands press
upon me.
BEG_SENT I have read ye by what murky light may be mine the lesson
that Jonah teaches to all sinners; and therefore to ye, and still
more to me, for I am a greater sinner than ye.
BEG_SENT And now how gladly
would I come down from this mast-head and sit on the hatches there
where you sit, and listen as you listen, while some one of you reads
me that other and more awful lesson which Jonah teaches to me, as a
pilot of the living God.
BEG_SENT How being an anointed pilot-prophet, or
speaker of true things and bidden by the Lord to sound those
unwelcome truths in the ears of a wicked Nineveh, Jonah, appalled at
the hostility he should raise, fled from his mission, and sought to
escape his duty and his God by taking ship at Joppa.
BEG_SENT But God is
everywhere; Tarshish he never reached.
BEG_SENT As we have seen, God came upon
him in the whale, and swallowed him down to living gulfs of doom, and
with swift slantings tore him along 'into the midst of the seas,'
where the eddying depths sucked him ten thousand fathoms down, and
'the weeds were wrapped about his head,' and all the watery world of
woe bowled over him.
BEG_SENT Yet even then beyond the reach of any plummet-
'out of the belly of hell'- when the whale grounded upon the ocean's
utmost bones, even then, God heard the engulphed, repenting prophet
when he cried.
BEG_SENT Then God spake unto the fish; and from the shuddering
cold and blackness of the sea, the whale came breeching up towards
the warm and pleasant sun, and all the delights of air and earth; and
'vomited out Jonah upon the dry land;' when the word of the Lord came
a second time; and Jonah, bruised and beaten- his ears, like two
sea-shells, still multitudinously murmuring of the ocean- Jonah did
the Almighty's bidding.
BEG_SENT And what was that, shipmates?
BEG_SENT To preach the
Truth to the face of Falsehood!
BEG_SENT That was it!
BEG_SENT "This, shipmates, this is that other lesson; and woe to that pilot of
the living God who slights it.
BEG_SENT Woe to him whom this world charms from
Gospel duty!
BEG_SENT Woe to him who seeks to pour oil upon the waters when
God has brewed them into a gale!
BEG_SENT Woe to him who seeks to please
rather than to appal!
BEG_SENT Woe to him whose good name is more to him than
goodness!
BEG_SENT Woe to him who, in this world, courts not dishonor!
BEG_SENT Woe to
him who would not be true, even though to be false were salvation!
BEG_SENT Yea, woe to him who as the great Pilot Paul has it, while preaching
to others is himself a castaway!
BEG_SENT He drooped and fell away from himself for a moment; then lifting his
face to them again, showed a deep joy in his eyes, as he cried out
with a heavenly enthusiasm,- "But oh!
BEG_SENT shipmates!
BEG_SENT on the starboard
hand of every woe, there is a sure delight; and higher the top of
that delight, than the bottom of the woe is deep.
BEG_SENT Is not the
main-truck higher than the kelson is low?
BEG_SENT Delight is to him- a far,
far upward, and inward delight- who against the proud gods and
commodores of this earth, ever stands forth his own inexorable
self.
BEG_SENT Delight is to him whose strong arms yet support him, when the
ship of this base treacherous world has gone down beneath
him.
BEG_SENT Delight is to him, who gives no quarter in the truth, and kills,
burns, and destroys all sin though he pluck it out from under the
robes of Senators and Judges.
BEG_SENT Delight,- top-gallant delight is to
him, who acknowledges no law or lord, but the Lord his God, and is
only a patriot to heaven.
BEG_SENT Delight is to him, whom all the waves of
the billows of the seas of the boisterous mob can never shake from
this sure Keel of the Ages.
BEG_SENT And eternal delight and deliciousness
will be his, who coming to lay him down, can say with his final
breath- O Father!- chiefly known to me by Thy rod- mortal or
immortal, here I die.
BEG_SENT I have striven to be Thine, more than to be
this world's, or mine own.
BEG_SENT Yet this is nothing: I leave eternity to
Thee; for what is man that he should live out the lifetime of his
God?"
BEG_SENT He said no more, but slowly waving a benediction, covered his face
with his hands, and so remained kneeling, till all the people had
departed, and he was left alone in the place.
BEG_SENT A Bosom Friend


Returning to the Spouter-Inn from the Chapel, I found Queequeg there
quite alone; he having left the Chapel before the benediction some
time.
BEG_SENT He was sitting on a bench before the fire, with his feet on the
stove hearth, and in one hand was holding close up to his face that
little negro idol of his; peering hard into its face, and with a
jack-knife gently whittling away at its nose, meanwhile humming to
himself in his heathenish way.
BEG_SENT But being now interrupted, he put up the image; and pretty soon,
going to the table, took up a large book there, and placing it on his
lap began counting the pages with deliberate regularity; at every
fiftieth page- as I fancied- stopping for a moment, looking vacantly
around him, and giving utterance to a long-drawn gurgling whistle of
astonishment.
BEG_SENT He would then begin again at the next fifty; seeming to
commence at number one each time, as though he could not count more
than fifty, and it was only by such a large number of fifties being
found together, that his astonishment at the multitude of pages was
excited.
BEG_SENT With much interest I sat watching him.
BEG_SENT Savage though he was, and
hideously marred about the face- at least to my taste- his
countenance yet had a something in it which was by no means
disagreeable.
BEG_SENT You cannot hide the soul.
BEG_SENT Through all his unearthly
tattooings, I thought I saw the traces of a simple honest heart; and
in his large, deep eyes, fiery black and bold, there seemed tokens of
a spirit that would dare a thousand devils.
BEG_SENT And besides all this,
there was a certain lofty bearing about the Pagan, which even his
uncouthness could not altogether maim.
BEG_SENT He looked like a man who had
never cringed and never had had a creditor.
BEG_SENT Whether it was, too, that
his head being shaved, his forehead was drawn out in freer and
brighter relief, and looked more expansive than it otherwise would,
this I will not venture to decide; but certain it was his head was
phrenologically an excellent one.
BEG_SENT It may seem ridiculous, but it
reminded me of General Washington's head, as seen in the popular
busts of him.
BEG_SENT It had the same long regularly graded retreating slope
from above the brows, which were likewise very projecting, like two
long promontories thickly wooded on top.
BEG_SENT Queequeg was George
Washington cannibalistically developed.
BEG_SENT Whilst I was thus closely scanning him, half-pretending meanwhile to
be looking out at the storm from the casement, he never heeded my
presence, never troubled himself with so much as a single glance; but
appeared wholly occupied with counting the pages of the marvellous
book.
BEG_SENT Considering how sociably we had been sleeping together the
night previous, and especially considering the affectionate arm I had
found thrown over me upon waking in the morning, I thought this
indifference of his very strange.
BEG_SENT But savages are strange beings; at
times you do not know exactly how to take them.
BEG_SENT At first they are
overawing; their calm self-collectedness of simplicity seems as
Socratic wisdom.
BEG_SENT I had noticed also that Queequeg never consorted at
all, or but very little, with the other seamen in the inn.
BEG_SENT He made no
advances whatever; appeared to have no desire to enlarge the circle
of his acquaintances.
BEG_SENT All this struck me as mighty singular; yet,
upon second thoughts, there was something almost sublime in it.
BEG_SENT Here
was a man some twenty thousand miles from home, by the way of Cape
Horn, that is- which was the only way he could get there- thrown
among people as strange to him as though he were in the planet
Jupiter; and yet he seemed entirely at his ease; preserving the
utmost serenity; content with his own companionship; always equal to
himself.
BEG_SENT Surely this was a touch of fine philosophy; though no doubt
he had never heard there was such a thing as that.
BEG_SENT But, perhaps, to
be true philosophers, we mortals should not be conscious of so living
or so striving.
BEG_SENT So soon as I hear that such or such a man gives
himself out for a philosopher, I conclude that, like the dyspeptic
old woman, he must have "broken his digester."
BEG_SENT As I sat there in that now lonely room; the fire burning low, in that
mild stage when, after its first intensity has warmed the air, it
then only glows to be looked at; the evening shades and phantoms
gathering round the casements, and peering in upon us silent,
solitary twain; the storm booming without in solemn swells; I began
to be sensible of strange feelings.
BEG_SENT I felt a melting in me.
BEG_SENT No more
my splintered heart and maddened hand were turned against the wolfish
world.
BEG_SENT This soothing savage had redeemed it.
BEG_SENT There he sat, his very
indifference speaking a nature in which there lurked no civilized
hypocrisies and bland deceits.
BEG_SENT he was; a very sight of sights to see;
yet I began to feel myself mysteriously drawn towards him.
BEG_SENT And those
same things that would have repelled most others, they were the very
magnets that thus drew me.
BEG_SENT I'll try a pagan friend, thought I, since
Christian kindness has proved but hollow courtesy.
BEG_SENT I drew my bench
near him, and made some friendly signs and hints, doing my best to
talk with him meanwhile.
BEG_SENT At first he little noticed these advances;
but presently, upon my referring to his last night's hospitalities,
he made out to ask me whether we were again to be bedfellows.
BEG_SENT I told
him yes; whereat I thought he looked pleased, perhaps a little
complimented.
BEG_SENT We then turned over the book together, and I endeavored to explain to
him the purpose of the printing, and the meaning of the few pictures
that were in it.
BEG_SENT Thus I soon engaged his interest; and from that we
went to jabbering the best we could about the various outer sights to
be seen in this famous town.
BEG_SENT Soon I proposed a social smoke; and,
producing his pouch and tomahawk, he quietly offered me a puff.
BEG_SENT And
then we sat exchanging puffs from that wild pipe of his, and keeping
it regularly passing between us.
BEG_SENT If there yet lurked any ice of indifference towards me in the Pagan's
breast, this pleasant, genial smoke we had, soon thawed it out, and
left us cronies.
BEG_SENT He seemed to take to me quite as naturally and
unbiddenly as I to him; and when our smoke was over, he pressed his
forehead against mine, clasped me round the waist, and said that
henceforth we were married; meaning, in his country's phrase, that we
were bosom friends; he would gladly die for me, if need should be.
BEG_SENT In
a countryman, this sudden flame of friendship would have seemed far
too premature, a thing to be much distrusted; but in this simple
savage those old rules would not apply.
BEG_SENT After supper, and another social chat and smoke, we went to our room
together.
BEG_SENT He made me a present of his embalmed head; took out his
enormous tobacco wallet, and groping under the tobacco, drew out some
thirty dollars in silver; then spreading them on the table, and
mechanically dividing them into two equal portions, pushed one of
them towards me, and said it was mine.
BEG_SENT I was going to remonstrate;
but he silenced me by pouring them into my trowsers' pockets.
BEG_SENT I let
them stay.
BEG_SENT He then went about his evening prayers, took out his idol,
and removed the paper firebrand.
BEG_SENT By certain signs and symptoms, I
thought he seemed anxious for me to join him; but well knowing what
was to follow, I deliberated a moment whether, in case he invited me,
I would comply or otherwise.
BEG_SENT I was a good Christian; born and bred in the bosom of the infallible
Presbyterian Church.
BEG_SENT How then could I unite with this wild idolator
in worshipping his piece of wood?
BEG_SENT But what is worship?
BEG_SENT thought I.
BEG_SENT Do
you suppose now, Ishmael, that the magnanimous God of heaven and
earth- pagans and all included- can possibly be jealous of an
insignificant bit of black wood?
BEG_SENT Impossible!
BEG_SENT But what is worship?- to
do the will of God?
BEG_SENT that is worship.
BEG_SENT And what is the will of God?-
to do to my fellow man what I would have my fellow man to do to me-
that is the will of God.
BEG_SENT Now, Queequeg is my fellow man.
BEG_SENT And what do
I wish that this Queequeg would do to me?
BEG_SENT Why, unite with me in my
particular Presbyterian form of worship.
BEG_SENT Consequently, I must then
unite with him in his; ergo, I must turn idolator.
BEG_SENT So I kindled the
shavings; helped prop up the innocent little idol; offered him burnt
biscuit with Queequeg; salamed before him twice or thrice; kissed his
nose; and that done, we undressed and went to bed, at peace with our
own consciences and all the world.
BEG_SENT But we did not go to sleep without
some little chat.
BEG_SENT How it is I know not; but there is no place like a bed for
confidential disclosures between friends.
BEG_SENT Man and wife, they say,
there open the very bottom of their souls to each other; and some old
couples often lie and chat over old times till nearly morning.
BEG_SENT Thus,
then, in our hearts' honeymoon, lay I and Queequeg- a cosy, loving
pair.
BEG_SENT Nightgown


We had lain thus in bed, chatting and napping at short intervals, and
Queequeg now and then affectionately throwing his brown tattooed legs
over mine, and then drawing them back; so entirely sociable and free
and easy were we; when, at last, by reason of our confabulations,
what little nappishness remained in us altogether departed, and we
felt like getting up again, though day-break was yet some way down
the future.
BEG_SENT Yes, we became very wakeful; so much so that our recumbent position
began to grow wearisome, and by little and little we found ourselves
sitting up; the clothes well tucked around us, leaning against the
headboard with our four knees drawn up close together, and our two
noses bending over them, as if our knee-pans were warming-pans.
BEG_SENT We
felt very nice and snug, the more so since it was so chilly out of
doors; indeed out of bed-clothes too, seeing that there was no fire
in the room.
BEG_SENT The more so, I say, because truly to enjoy bodily
warmth, some small part of you must be cold, for there is no quality
in this world that is not what it is merely by contrast.
BEG_SENT Nothing
exists in itself.
BEG_SENT If you flatter yourself that you are all over
comfortable, and have been so a long time, then you cannot be said to
be comfortable any more.
BEG_SENT But if, like Queequeg and me in the bed, the
tip of your nose or the crown of your head be slightly chilled, why
then, indeed, in the general consciousness you feel most delightfully
and unmistakably warm.
BEG_SENT For this reason a sleeping apartment should
never be furnished with a fire, which is one of the luxurious
discomforts of the rich.
BEG_SENT For the height of this sort of deliciousness
is to have nothing but the blankets between you and your snugness and
the cold of the outer air.
BEG_SENT Then there you lie like the one warm spark
in the heart of an arctic crystal.
BEG_SENT We had been sitting in this crouching manner for some time, when all
at once I thought I would open my eyes; for when between sheets,
whether by day or by night, and whether asleep or awake, I have a way
of always keeping my eyes shut, in order the more to concentrate the
snugness of being in bed.
BEG_SENT Because no man can ever feel his own
identity aright except his eyes be closed; as if, darkness were
indeed the proper element of our essences, though light be more
congenial to our clayey part.
BEG_SENT Upon opening my eyes then, and coming
out of my own pleasant and self-created darkness into the imposed and
coarse outer gloom of the unilluminated twelve-o'clock-at-night, I
experienced a disagreeable revulsion.
BEG_SENT Nor did I at all object to the
hint from Queequeg that perhaps it were best to strike a light,
seeing that we were so wide awake; and besides he felt a strong
desire to have a few quiet puffs from his Tomahawk.
BEG_SENT Be it said, that
though I had felt such a strong repugnance to his smoking in the bed
the night before, yet see how elastic our stiff prejudices grow when
once love comes to bend them.
BEG_SENT For now I liked nothing better than to
have Queequeg smoking by me, even in bed, because he seemed to be
full of such serene household joy then.
BEG_SENT I no more felt unduly
concerned for the landlord's policy of insurance.
BEG_SENT I was only alive to
the condensed confidential comfortableness of sharing a pipe and a
blanket with a real friend.
BEG_SENT With our shaggy jackets drawn about our
shoulders, we now passed the Tomahawk from one to the other, till
slowly there grew over us a blue hanging tester of smoke, illuminated
by the flame of the new-lit lamp.
BEG_SENT Whether it was that this undulating tester rolled the savage away to
far distant scenes, I know not, but he now spoke of his native
island; and, eager to hear his history, I begged him to go on and
tell it.
BEG_SENT He gladly complied.
BEG_SENT Though at the time I but ill
comprehended not a few of his words, yet subsequent disclosures, when
I had become more familiar with his broken phraseology, now enable me
to present the whole story such as it may prove in the mere skeleton
I give.
BEG_SENT Biographical


Queequeg was a native of Rokovoko, an island far away to the West and
South.
BEG_SENT It is not down on any map; true places never are.
BEG_SENT When a new-hatched savage running wild about his native woodlands in
a grass clout, followed by the nibbling goats, as if he were a green
sapling; even then, in Queequeg's ambitious soul, lurked a strong
desire to see something more of Christendom than a specimen whaler or
two.
BEG_SENT His father was a High Chief, a King; his uncle a High Priest;
and on the maternal side he boasted aunts who were the wives of
unconquerable warriors.
BEG_SENT There was excellent blood in his veins- royal
stuff; though sadly vitiated, I fear, by the cannibal propensity he
nourished in his untutored youth.
BEG_SENT A Sag Harbor ship visited his father's bay, and Queequeg sought a
passage to Christian lands.
BEG_SENT But the ship, having her full complement
of seamen, spurned his suit; and not all the King his father's
influence could prevail.
BEG_SENT But Queequeg vowed a vow.
BEG_SENT Alone in his
canoe, he paddled off to a distant strait, which he knew the ship
must pass through when she quitted the island.
BEG_SENT On one side was a
coral reef; on the other a low tongue of land, covered with mangrove
thickets that grew out into the water.
BEG_SENT Hiding his canoe, still
afloat, among these thickets, with its prow seaward, he sat down in
the stern, paddle low in hand; and when the ship was gliding by, like
a flash he darted out; gained her side; with one backward dash of his
foot capsized and sank his canoe; climbed up the chains; and throwing
himself at full length upon the deck, grappled a ring-bolt there, and
swore not to let it go, though hacked in pieces.
BEG_SENT In vain the captain threatened to throw him overboard; suspended a
cutlass over his naked wrists; Queequeg was the son of a King, and
Queequeg budged not.
BEG_SENT Struck by his desperate dauntlessness, and his
wild desire to visit Christendom, the captain at last relented, and
told him he might make himself at home.
BEG_SENT But this fine young savage-
this sea Prince of Wales, never saw the Captain's cabin.
BEG_SENT They put him
down among the sailors, and made a whaleman of him.
BEG_SENT But like Czar
Peter content to toil in the shipyards of foreign cities, Queequeg
disdained no seeming ignominy, if thereby he might happily gain the
power of enlightening his untutored countrymen.
BEG_SENT For at bottom- so he
told me- he was actuated by a profound desire to learn among the
Christians, the arts whereby to make his people still happier than
they were; and more than that, still better than they were.
BEG_SENT But,
alas!
BEG_SENT the practices of whalemen soon convinced him that even
Christians could be both miserable and wicked; infinitely more so,
than all his father's heathens.
BEG_SENT Arrived at last in old Sag Harbor;
and seeing what the sailors did there; and then going on to
Nantucket, and seeing how they spent their wages in that place also,
poor Queequeg gave it up for lost.
BEG_SENT Thought he, it's a wicked world in
all meridians; I'll die a pagan.
BEG_SENT And thus an old idolator at heart, he yet lived among these
Christians, wore their clothes, and tried to talk their
gibberish.
BEG_SENT Hence the queer ways about him, though now some time from
home.
BEG_SENT By hints I asked him whether he did not propose going back, and
having a coronation; since he might now consider his father dead and
gone, he being very old and feeble at the last accounts.
BEG_SENT He answered
no, not yet; and added that he was fearful Christianity, or rather
Christians, had unfitted him for ascending the pure and undefiled
throne of thirty pagan Kings before him.
BEG_SENT But by and by, he said, he
would return,- as soon as he felt himself baptized again.
BEG_SENT For the
nonce, however, he proposed to sail about, and sow his wild oats in
all four oceans.
BEG_SENT They had made a harpooneer of him, and that barbed
iron was in lieu of a sceptre now.
BEG_SENT I asked him what might be his immediate purpose, touching his future
movements.
BEG_SENT He answered, to go to sea again, in his old vocation.
BEG_SENT Upon
this, I told him that whaling was my own design, and informed him of
my intention to sail out of Nantucket, as being the most promising
port for an adventurous whaleman to embark from.
BEG_SENT He at once resolved
to accompany me to that island, ship aboard the same vessel, get into
the same watch, the same boat, the same mess with me, in short to
share my every hap; with both my hands in his, boldly dip into the
Potluck of both worlds.
BEG_SENT To all this I joyously assented; for besides
the affection I now felt for Queequeg, he was an experienced
harpooneer, and as such, could not fail to be of great usefulness to
one, who, like me, was wholly ignorant of the mysteries of whaling,
though well acquainted with the sea, as known to merchant seamen.
BEG_SENT His story being ended with his pipe's last dying puff, Queequeg
embraced me, pressed his forehead against mine, and blowing out the
light, we rolled over from each other, this way and that, and very
soon were sleeping.
BEG_SENT Wheelbarrow


Next morning, Monday, after disposing of the embalmed head to a
barber, for a block, I settled my own and comrade's bill; using,
however, my comrade's money.
BEG_SENT The grinning landlord, as well as the
boarders, seemed amazingly tickled at the sudden friendship which had
sprung up between me and Queequeg- especially as Peter Coffin's cock
and bull stories about him had previously so much alarmed me
concerning the very person whom I now companied with.
BEG_SENT We borrowed a wheelbarrow, and embarking our things, including my own
poor carpet-bag, and Queequeg's canvas sack and hammock, away we went
down to "the Moss," the little Nantucket packet schooner moored at
the wharf.
BEG_SENT As we were going along the people stared; not at Queequeg
so much- for they were used to seeing cannibals like him in their
streets,- but at seeing him and me upon such confidential terms.
BEG_SENT But
we heeded them not, going along wheeling the barrow by turns, and
Queequeg now and then stopping to adjust the sheath on his harpoon
barbs.
BEG_SENT I asked him why he carried such a troublesome thing with him
ashore, and whether all whaling ships did not find their own
harpoons.
BEG_SENT To this, in substance, he replied, that though what I
hinted was true enough, yet he had a particular affection for his own
harpoon, because it was of assured stuff, well tried in many a mortal
combat, and deeply intimate with the hearts of whales.
BEG_SENT In short, like
many reapers and mowers, who go into the farmer's meadows armed with
their own scythes- though in no wise obliged to furnish them- even
so, Queequeg, for his own private reasons, preferred his own harpoon.
BEG_SENT Shifting the barrow from my hand to his, he told me a funny story
about the first wheelbarrow he had ever seen.
BEG_SENT It was in Sag
Harbor.
BEG_SENT The owners of his ship, it seems, had lent him one, in which
to carry his heavy chest to his boarding house.
BEG_SENT Not to seem ignorant
about the thing- though in truth he was entirely so, concerning the
precise way in which to manage the barrow- Queequeg puts his chest
upon it; lashes it fast; and then shoulders the barrow and marches up
the wharf.
BEG_SENT "Why," said I, "Queequeg, you might have known better than
that, one would think.
BEG_SENT Didn't the people laugh?"
BEG_SENT Upon this, he told me another story.
BEG_SENT The people of his island of
Rokovoko, it seems, at their wedding feasts express the fragrant
water of young cocoanuts into a large stained calabash like a
punchbowl; and this punchbowl always forms the great central ornament
on the braided mat where the feast is held.
BEG_SENT Now a certain grand
merchant ship once touched at Rokovoko, and its commander- from all
accounts, a very stately punctilious gentleman, at least for a sea
captain- this commander was invited to the wedding feast of
Queequeg's sister, a pretty young princess just turned of ten.
BEG_SENT Well;
when all the wedding guests were assembled at the bride's bamboo
cottage, this Captain marches in, and being assigned the post of
honor, placed himself over against the punchbowl, and between the
High Priest and his majesty the King, Queequeg's father.
BEG_SENT Grace being
said,- for those people have their grace as well as we- though
Queequeg told me that unlike us, who at such times look downwards to
our platters, they, on the contrary, copying the ducks, glance
upwards to the great Giver of all feasts- Grace, I say, being said,
the High Priest opens the banquet by the immemorial ceremony of the
island; that is, dipping his consecrated and consecrating fingers
into the bowl before the blessed beverage circulates.
BEG_SENT Seeing himself
placed next the Priest, and noting the ceremony, and thinking
himself- being Captain of a ship- as having plain precedence over a
mere island King, especially in the King's own house- the Captain
coolly proceeds to wash his hands in the punch bowl;- taking it I
suppose for a huge finger-glass.
BEG_SENT "Now," said Queequeg, "what you tink
now?- Didn't our people laugh?"
BEG_SENT At last, passage paid, and luggage safe, we stood on board the
schooner.
BEG_SENT Hoisting sail, it glided down the Acushnet river.
BEG_SENT On one
side, New Bedford rose in terraces of streets, their ice-covered
trees all glittering in the clear, cold air.
BEG_SENT Huge hills and mountains
of casks on casks were piled upon her wharves, and side by side the
world-wandering whale ships lay silent and safely moored at last;
while from others came a sound of carpenters and coopers, with
blended noises of fires and forges to melt the pitch, all betokening
that new cruises were on the start; that one most perilous and long
voyage ended, only begins a second; and a second ended, only begins a
third, and so on, for ever and for aye.
BEG_SENT Such is the endlessness,
yea, the intolerableness of all earthly effort.
BEG_SENT Gaining the more open water, the bracing breeze waxed fresh; the
little Moss tossed the quick foam from her bows, as a young colt his
snortings.
BEG_SENT How I snuffed that Tartar air!- how I spurned that
turnpike earth!- that common highway all over dented with the marks
of slavish heels and hoofs; and turned me to admire the magnanimity
of the sea which will permit no records.
BEG_SENT At the same foam-fountain, Queequeg seemed to drink and reel with
me.
BEG_SENT His dusky nostrils swelled apart; he showed his filed and pointed
teeth.
BEG_SENT On, on we flew, and our offing gained, the Moss did homage to
the blast; ducked and dived her bows as a slave before the
Sultan.
BEG_SENT Sideways leaning, we sideways darted; every ropeyarn tingling
like a wire; the two tall masts buckling like Indian canes in land
tornadoes.
BEG_SENT So full of this reeling scene were we, as we stood by the
plunging bowsprit, that for some time we did not notice the jeering
glances of the passengers, a lubber-like assembly, who marvelled that
two fellow beings should be so companionable; as though a white man
were anything more dignified than a whitewashed negro.
BEG_SENT But there were
some boobies and bumpkins there, who, by their intense greenness,
must have come from the heart and centre of all verdure.
BEG_SENT Queequeg
caught one of these young saplings mimicking him behind his back.
BEG_SENT I
thought the bumpkin's hour of doom was come.
BEG_SENT Dropping his harpoon,
the brawny savage caught him in his arms, and by an almost miraculous
dexterity and strength, sent him high up bodily into the air; then
slightly tapping his stern in mid-somerset, the fellow landed with
bursting lungs upon his feet, while Queequeg, turning his back upon
him, lighted his tomahawk pipe and passed it to me for a puff.
BEG_SENT "Capting!
BEG_SENT Capting!
BEG_SENT yelled the bumpkin, running toward that officer;
"Capting, Capting, here's the devil."
BEG_SENT "Hallo, you sir," cried the Captain, a gaunt rib of the sea, stalking
up to Queequeg, "what in thunder do you mean by that?
BEG_SENT Don't you know
you might have killed that chap?"
BEG_SENT "What him say?"
BEG_SENT said Queequeg, as he mildly turned to me.
BEG_SENT "He say," said I, "that you came near kill-e that man there,"
pointing to the still shivering greenhorn.
BEG_SENT "Kill-e," cried Queequeg, twisting his tattooed face into an
unearthly expression of disdain, "ah!
BEG_SENT him bevy small-e fish-e;
Queequeg no kill-e so small-e fish-e; Queequeg kill-e big whale!"
BEG_SENT "Look you," roared the Captain, "I'll kill-e you, you cannibal, if
you try any more of your tricks aboard here; so mind your eye."
BEG_SENT But it so happened just then, that it was high time for the Captain
to mind his own eye.
BEG_SENT The prodigious strain upon the main-sail had
parted the weather-sheet, and the tremendous boom was now flying from
side to side, completely sweeping the entire after part of the
deck.
BEG_SENT The poor fellow whom Queequeg had handled so roughly, was swept
overboard; all hands were in a panic; and to attempt snatching at the
boom to stay it, seemed madness.
BEG_SENT It flew from right to left, and back
again, almost in one ticking of a watch, and every instant seemed on
the point of snapping into splinters.
BEG_SENT Nothing was done, and nothing
seemed capable of being done; those on deck rushed toward the bows,
and stood eyeing the boom as if it were the lower jaw of an
exasperated whale.
BEG_SENT In the midst of this consternation, Queequeg
dropped deftly to his knees, and crawling under the path of the boom,
whipped hold of a rope, secured one end to the bulwarks, and then
flinging the other like a lasso, caught it round the boom as it swept
over his head, and at the next jerk, the spar was that way trapped,
and all was safe.
BEG_SENT The schooner was run into the wind, and while the
hands were clearing away the stern boat, Queequeg, stripped to the
waist, darted from the side with a long living arc of a leap.
BEG_SENT For
three minutes or more he was seen swimming like a dog, throwing his
long arms straight out before him, and by turns revealing his brawny
shoulders through the freezing foam.
BEG_SENT I looked at the grand and
glorious but saw no one to be saved.
BEG_SENT The greenhorn had gone
down.
BEG_SENT Shooting himself perpendicularly from the water, Queequeg, now
took an instant's glance around him, and seeming to see just how
matters were, dived down and disappeared.
BEG_SENT A few minutes more, and he
rose again, one arm still striking out, and with the other dragging a
lifeless form.
BEG_SENT The boat soon picked them up.
BEG_SENT The poor bumpkin was
restored.
BEG_SENT All hands voted Queequeg a noble trump; the captain begged
his pardon.
BEG_SENT From that hour I clove to Queequeg like a barnacle; yea,
till poor Queequeg took his last long dive.
BEG_SENT Was there ever such unconsciousness?
BEG_SENT He did not seem to think that he
at all deserved a medal from the Humane and Magnanimous Societies.
BEG_SENT He
only asked for water- fresh water- something to wipe the brine off;
that done, he put on dry clothes, lighted his pipe, and leaning
against the bulwarks, and mildly eyeing those around him, seemed to
be saying to himself- "It's a mutual, joint-stock world, in all
meridians.
BEG_SENT We cannibals must help these Christians."
BEG_SENT Nantucket


Nothing more happened on the passage worthy the mentioning; so, after
a fine run, we safely arrived in Nantucket.
BEG_SENT Nantucket!
BEG_SENT Take out your map and look at it.
BEG_SENT See what a real corner
of the world it occupies; how it stands there, away off shore, more
lonely than the Eddystone lighthouse.
BEG_SENT Look at it- a mere hillock,
and elbow of sand; all beach, without a background.
BEG_SENT There is more
sand there than you would use in twenty years as a substitute for
blotting paper.
BEG_SENT Some gamesome wights will tell you that they have to
plant weeds there, they don't grow naturally; that they import Canada
thistles; that they have to send beyond seas for a spile to stop a
leak in an oil cask; that pieces of wood in Nantucket are carried
about like bits of the true cross in Rome; that people there plant
toadstools before their houses, to get under the shade in summer
time; that one blade of grass makes an oasis, three blades in a day's
walk a prairie; that they wear quicksand shoes, something like
Laplander snow-shoes; that they are so shut up, belted about, every
way inclosed, surrounded, and made an utter island of by the ocean,
that to the very chairs and tables small clams will sometimes be
found adhering as to the backs of sea turtles.
BEG_SENT But these
extravaganzas only show that Nantucket is no Illinois.
BEG_SENT Look now at the wondrous traditional story of how this island was
settled by the red-men.
BEG_SENT Thus goes the legend.
BEG_SENT In olden times an eagle
swooped down upon the New England coast and carried off an infant
Indian in his talons.
BEG_SENT With loud lament the parents saw their child
borne out of sight over the wide waters.
BEG_SENT They resolved to follow in
the same direction.
BEG_SENT Setting out in their canoes, after a perilous
passage they discovered the island, and there they found an empty
ivory casket,- the poor little Indian's skeleton.
BEG_SENT What wonder, then, that these Nantucketers, born on a beach, should
take to the sea for a livelihood!
BEG_SENT They first caught crabs and quahogs
in the sand; grown bolder, they waded out with nets for mackerel;
more experienced, they pushed off in boats and captured cod; and at
last, launching a navy of great ships on the sea, explored this
watery world; put an incessant belt of circumnavigations round it;
peeped in at Behring's Straits; and in all seasons and all oceans
declared everlasting war with the mightiest animated mass that has
survived the flood; most monstrous and most mountainous!
BEG_SENT That
Himmalehan, salt-sea, Mastodon, clothed with such portentousness of
unconscious power, that his very panics are more to be dreaded than
his most fearless and malicious assaults!
BEG_SENT And thus have these naked Nantucketers, these sea hermits, issuing
from their ant-hill in the sea, overrun and conquered the watery
world like so many Alexanders; parcelling out among them the
Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans, as the three pirate powers did
Poland.
BEG_SENT Let America add Mexico to Texas, and pile Cuba upon Canada;
let the English overswarm all India, and hang out their blazing
banner from the sun; two thirds of this terraqueous globe are the
Nantucketer's.
BEG_SENT For the sea is his; he owns it, as Emperors own
empires; other seamen having but a right of way through it.
BEG_SENT Merchant
ships are but extension bridges; armed ones but floating forts; even
pirates and privateers, though following the sea as highwaymen the
road.
BEG_SENT they but plunder other ships, other fragments of the land like
themselves, without seeking to draw their living from the bottomless
deep itself.
BEG_SENT The Nantucketer, he alone resides and riots on the sea;
he alone, in Bible language, goes down to it in ships; to and fro
ploughing it as his own special plantation.
BEG_SENT There is his home; there
lies his business which a Noah's flood would not interrupt, though it
overwhelmed all the millions in China.
BEG_SENT He lives on the sea, as
prairie cocks in the prairie; he hides among the waves, he climbs
them as chamois hunters climb the Alps.
BEG_SENT For years he knows not the
land; so that when he comes to it at last, it smells like another
world, more strangely than the moon would to an Earthsman.
BEG_SENT With the
landless gull, that at sunset folds her wings and is rocked to sleep
between billows; so at nightfall, the Nantucketer, out of sight of
land, furls his sails, and lays him to his rest, while under his very
pillow rush herds of walruses and whales.
BEG_SENT Chowder


It was quite late in the evening when the little Moss came snugly to
anchor, and Queequeg and I went ashore; so we could attend to no
business that day, at least none but a supper and a bed.
BEG_SENT The landlord
of the Spouter-Inn had recommended us to his cousin Hosea Hussey of
the Try Pots, whom he asserted to be the proprietor of one of the
best kept hotels in all Nantucket, and moreover he had assured us
that Cousin Hosea, as he called him, was famous for his chowders.
BEG_SENT In
short, he plainly hinted that we could not possibly do better than
try pot-luck at the Try Pots.
BEG_SENT But the directions hc had given us
about keeping a yellow warehouse on our starboard hand till we opened
a white church to the larboard, and then keeping that on the larboard
hand till we made a corner three points to the starboard, and that
done, then ask the first man we met where the place was; these
crooked directions of his very much puzzled us at first, especially
as, at the outset, Queequeg insisted that the yellow warehouse- our
first point of departure- must be left on the larboard hand, whereas
I had understood Peter Coffin to say it was on the starboard.
BEG_SENT However, by dint of beating about a little in the dark, and now and
then knocking up a peaceful inhabitant to inquire the way, we at last
came to something which there was no mistaking.
BEG_SENT Two enormous wooden pots painted black, and suspended by asses' ears,
swung from the cross-trees of an old top-mast, planted in front of an
old doorway.
BEG_SENT The horns of the cross-trees were sawed off on the other
side, so that this old top-mast looked not a little like a
gallows.
BEG_SENT Perhaps I was over sensitive to such impressions at the
time, but I could not help staring at this gallows with a vague
misgiving.
BEG_SENT A sort of crick was in my neck as I gazed up to the two
remaining horns; yes, two of them, one for Queequeg, and one for
me.
BEG_SENT It's ominous, thinks I.
BEG_SENT A Coffin my Innkeeper upon landing in my
first whaling port; tombstones staring at me in the whalemen's
chapel, and here a gallows!
BEG_SENT and a pair of prodigious black pots too!
BEG_SENT Are these last throwing out oblique hints touching Tophet?
BEG_SENT I was called from these reflections by the sight of a freckled woman
with yellow hair and a yellow gown, standing in the porch of the inn,
under a dull red lamp swinging there, that looked much like an
injured eye, and carrying on a brisk scolding with a man in a purple
woollen shirt.
BEG_SENT "Get along with ye," said she to the man, "or I'll be combing ye!"
BEG_SENT "Come on, Queequeg," said I, "all right.
BEG_SENT There's Mrs.
BEG_SENT Hussey."
BEG_SENT And so it turned out; Mr. Hosea Hussey being from home, but leaving
Mrs. Hussey entirely competent to attend to all his affairs.
BEG_SENT Upon
making known our desires for a supper and a bed, Mrs. Hussey,
postponing further scolding for the present, ushered us into a little
room, and seating us at a table spread with the relics of a recently
concluded repast, turned round to us and said- "Clam or Cod?"
BEG_SENT "What's that about Cods, ma'am?"
BEG_SENT said I, with much politeness.
BEG_SENT "Clam or Cod?"
BEG_SENT she repeated.
BEG_SENT "A clam for supper?
BEG_SENT a cold clam; is that what you mean, Mrs.
BEG_SENT Hussey?"
BEG_SENT says I, "but that's a rather cold and clammy reception in the winter
time, ain't it, Mrs.
BEG_SENT Hussey?"
BEG_SENT But being in a great hurry to resume scolding the man in the purple
shirt who was waiting for it in the entry, and seeming to hear
nothing but the word "clam," Mrs. Hussey hurried towards an open door
leading to the kitchen, and bawling out "clam for two," disappeared.
BEG_SENT "Queequeg," said I, "do you think that we can make a supper for us
both on one clam?"
BEG_SENT However, a warm savory steam from the kitchen served to belie the
apparently cheerless prospect before us.
BEG_SENT But when that smoking
chowder came in, the mystery was delightfully explained.
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT sweet
friends, hearken to me.
BEG_SENT It was made of small juicy clams, scarcely
bigger than hazel nuts, mixed with pounded ship biscuits, and salted
pork cut up into little flakes!
BEG_SENT the whole enriched with butter, and
plentifully seasoned with pepper and salt.
BEG_SENT Our appetites being
sharpened by the frosty voyage, and in particular, Queequeg seeing
his favourite fishing food before him, and the chowder being
surpassingly excellent, we despatched it with great expedition: when
leaning back a moment and bethinking me of Mrs. Hussey's clam and cod
announcement, I thought I would try a little experiment.
BEG_SENT Stepping to
the kitchen door, I uttered the word "cod" with great emphasis, and
resumed my seat.
BEG_SENT In a few moments the savoury steam came forth again,
but with a different flavor, and in good time a fine cod-chowder was
placed before us.
BEG_SENT We resumed business; and while plying our spoons in the bowl, thinks
I to myself, I wonder now if this here has any effect on the head?
BEG_SENT What's that stultifying saying about chowder-headed people?
BEG_SENT "But
look, Queequeg, ain't that a live eel in your bowl?
BEG_SENT Where's your
harpoon?"
BEG_SENT Fishiest of all fishy places was the Try Pots, which well deserved
its name; for the pots there were always boiling chowders.
BEG_SENT Chowder
for breakfast, and chowder for dinner, and chowder for supper, till
you began to look for fish-bones coming through your clothes.
BEG_SENT The
area before the house was paved with clam-shells.
BEG_SENT Mrs. Hussey wore a
polished necklace of codfish vertebra; and Hosea Hussey had his
account books bound in superior old shark-skin.
BEG_SENT There was a fishy
flavor to the milk, too, which I could not at all account for, till
one morning happening to take a stroll along the beach among some
fishermen's boats, I saw Hosea's brindled cow feeding on fish
remnants, and marching along the sand with each foot in a cod's
decapitated head, looking very slipshod, I assure ye.
BEG_SENT Supper concluded, we received a lamp, and directions from Mrs. Hussey
concerning the nearest way to bed; but, as Queequeg was about to
precede me up the stairs, the lady reached forth her arm, and
demanded his harpoon; she allowed no harpoon in her chambers.
BEG_SENT "Why
not?
BEG_SENT said I; "every true whaleman sleeps with his harpoon- but why
not?"
BEG_SENT "Because it's dangerous," says she.
BEG_SENT "Ever since young Stiggs
coming from that unfort'nt v'y'ge of his, when he was gone four years
and a half, with only three barrels of ile, was found dead in my
first floor back, with his harpoon in his side; ever since then I
allow no boarders to take sich dangerous weepons in their rooms at
night.
BEG_SENT So, Mr. Queequeg" (for she had learned his name), "I will just
take this here iron, and keep it for you till morning.
BEG_SENT But the
chowder; clam or cod to-morrow for breakfast, men?"
BEG_SENT "Both," says I; "and let's have a couple of smoked herring by way of
variety."
BEG_SENT The Ship


In bed we concocted our plans for the morrow.
BEG_SENT But to my surprise and
no small concern, Queequeg now gave me to understand, that he had
been diligently consulting Yojo- the name of his black little god-
and Yojo had told him two or three times over, and strongly insisted
upon it everyway, that instead of our going together among the
whaling-fleet in harbor, and in concert selecting our craft; instead
of this, I say, Yojo earnestly enjoined that the selection of the
ship should rest wholly with me, inasmuch as Yojo purposed
befriending us; and, in order to do so, had already pitched upon a
vessel, which, if left to myself, I, Ishmael, should infallibly light
upon, for all the world as though it had turned out by chance; and in
that vessel I must immediately ship myself, for the present
irrespective of Queequeg.
BEG_SENT I have forgotten to mention that, in many things, Queequeg placed
great confidence in the excellence of Yojo's judgment and surprising
forecast of things; and cherished Yojo with considerable esteem, as a
rather good sort of god, who perhaps meant well enough upon the
whole, but in all cases did not succeed in his benevolent designs.
BEG_SENT Now, this plan of Queequeg's or rather Yojo's, touching the selection
of our craft; I did not like that plan at all.
BEG_SENT I had not a little
relied upon Queequeg's sagacity to point out the whaler best fitted
to carry us and our fortunes securely.
BEG_SENT But as all my remonstrances
produced no effect upon Queequeg, I was obliged to acquiesce; and
accordingly prepared to set about this business with a determined
rushing sort of energy and vigor, that should quickly settle that
trifling little affair.
BEG_SENT Next morning early, leaving Queequeg shut up
with in our little bedroom- for it seemed that it was some sort of
Lent or Ramadan, or day of fasting, humiliation, and prayer with
Queequeg and Yojo that day; how it was I never could find out, for,
though I applied myself to it several times, I never could master his
liturgies and XXXIX Articles- leaving Queequeg, then, fasting on his
tomahawk pipe, and Yojo warming himself at his sacrificial fire of
shavings, I sallied out among the shipping.
BEG_SENT After much prolonged
sauntering, and many random inquiries, I learnt that there were three
ships up for three-years' voyages- The Devil-dam, the Tit-bit, and
the Pequod.
BEG_SENT Devil-dam, I do not know the origin of; Tit-bit is
obvious; Pequod you will no doubt remember, was the name of a
celebrated tribe of Massachusetts Indians; now extinct as the ancient
Medes.
BEG_SENT I peered and pryed about the Devil-dam; from her, hopped over
to the Tit-bit; and finally, going on board the Pequod, looked around
her for a moment, and then decided that this was the very ship for
us.
BEG_SENT You may have seen many a quaint craft in your day, for aught I know;-
square-toed luggers; mountainous Japanese junks; butter-box galliots,
and what not; but take my word for it, you never saw such a rare old
craft as this same rare old Pequod.
BEG_SENT She was a ship of the old school,
rather small if anything; with an old-fashioned claw-footed look
about her.
BEG_SENT Long seasoned and weather-stained in the typhoons and
calms of all four oceans, her old hull's complexion was darkened like
a French grenadier's, who has alike fought in Egypt and Siberia.
BEG_SENT Her
venerable bows looked bearded.
BEG_SENT Her masts- cut somewhere on the coast
of Japan, where her original ones were lost overboard in a gale- her
masts stood stiffly up like the spines of the three old kings of
Cologne.
BEG_SENT Her ancient decks were worn and wrinkled, like the
pilgrim-worshipped flag-stone in Canterbury Cathedral where Becket
bled.
BEG_SENT But to all these her old antiquities, were added new and
marvellous features, pertaining to the wild business that for more
than half a century she had followed.
BEG_SENT Old Captain Peleg, many years
her chief-mate, before he commanded another vessel of his own, and
now a retired seaman, and one of the principal owners of the Pequod,-
this old Peleg, during the term of his chief-mateship, had built upon
her original grotesqueness, and inlaid it, all over, with a
quaintness both of material and device, unmatched by anything except
it be Thorkill-Hake's carved buckler or bedstead.
BEG_SENT She was apparelled
like any barbaric Ethiopian emperor, his neck heavy with pendants of
polished ivory.
BEG_SENT She was a thing of trophies.
BEG_SENT A cannibal of a craft,
tricking herself forth in the chased bones of her enemies.
BEG_SENT All round,
her unpanelled, open bulwarks were garnished like one continuous jaw,
with the long sharp teeth of the sperm whale, inserted there for
pins, to fasten her old hempen thews and tendons to.
BEG_SENT Those thews ran
not through base blocks of land wood, but deftly travelled over
sheaves of sea-ivory.
BEG_SENT Scorning a turnstile wheel at her reverend
helm, she sported there a tiller; and that tiller was in one mass,
curiously carved from the long narrow lower jaw of her hereditary
foe.
BEG_SENT The helmsman who steered that tiller in a tempest, felt like the
Tartar, when he holds back his fiery steed by clutching its jaw.
BEG_SENT A
noble craft, but somehow a most melancholy!
BEG_SENT All noble things are
touched with that.
BEG_SENT Now when I looked about the quarter-deck, for some one having
authority, in order to propose myself as a candidate for the voyage,
at first I saw nobody; but I could not well overlook a strange sort
of tent, or rather wigwam, pitched a little behind the main-mast.
BEG_SENT It
seemed only a temporary erection used in port.
BEG_SENT It was of a conical
shape, some ten feet high; consisting of the long, huge slabs of
limber black bone taken from the middle and highest part of the jaws
of the right-whale.
BEG_SENT Planted with their broad ends on the deck, a
circle of these slabs laced together, mutually sloped towards each
other, and at the apex united in a tufted point, where the loose
hairy fibres waved to and fro like the top-knot on some old
Pottowottamie Sachem's head.
BEG_SENT A triangular opening faced towards the
bows of the ship, so that the insider commanded a complete view
forward.
BEG_SENT And half concealed in this queer tenement, I at length found one who
by his aspect seemed to have authority; and who, it being noon, and
the ship's work suspended, was now enjoying respite from the burden
of command.
BEG_SENT He was seated on an old-fashioned oaken chair, wriggling
all over with curious carving; and the bottom of which was formed of
a stout interlacing of the same elastic stuff of which the wigwam was
constructed.
BEG_SENT There was nothing so very particular, perhaps, about the appearance
of the elderly man I saw; he was brown and brawny, like most old
seamen, and heavily rolled up in blue pilot-cloth, cut in the Quaker
style; only there was a fine and almost microscopic net-work of the
minutest wrinkles interlacing round eyes, which must have arisen from
his continual sailings in many hard gales, and always looking to
windward;- for this causes the muscles about the eyes to become
pursed together.
BEG_SENT Such eye-wrinkles are very effectual in a scowl.
BEG_SENT "Is this the Captain of the Pequod?"
BEG_SENT said I, advancing to the door of
the tent.
BEG_SENT "Supposing it be the captain of the Pequod, what dost thou want of
him?"
BEG_SENT he demanded.
BEG_SENT "I was thinking of shipping."
BEG_SENT "Thou wast, wast thou?
BEG_SENT I see thou art no Nantucketer- ever been in a
stove boat?"
BEG_SENT "No, Sir, I never have."
BEG_SENT "Dost know nothing at all about whaling, I dare say- eh?
BEG_SENT "Nothing, Sir; but I have no doubt I shall soon learn.
BEG_SENT I've been
several voyages in the merchant service, and I think that-"

"Merchant service be damned.
BEG_SENT Talk not that lingo to me.
BEG_SENT Dost see that
leg?- I'll take that leg away from thy stern, if ever thou talkest of
the merchant service to me again.
BEG_SENT Marchant service indeed!
BEG_SENT I suppose
now ye feel considerable proud of having served in those marchant
ships.
BEG_SENT But flukes!
BEG_SENT man, what makes thee want to go a whaling, eh?- it
looks a little suspicious, don't it, eh?- Hast not been a pirate,
hast thou?- Didst not rob thy last Captain, didst thou?- Dost not
think of murdering the officers when thou gettest to sea?"
BEG_SENT I protested my innocence of these things.
BEG_SENT I saw that under the mask
of these half humorous innuendoes, this old seaman, as an insulated
Quakerish Nantucketer, was full of his insular prejudices, and rather
distrustful of all aliens, unless they hailed from Cape Cod or the
Vineyard.
BEG_SENT "But what takes thee a-whaling?
BEG_SENT I want to know that before I think of
shipping ye."
BEG_SENT "Well, sir, I want to see what whaling is.
BEG_SENT I want to see the world."
BEG_SENT "Want to see what whaling is, eh?
BEG_SENT Have ye clapped eye on Captain
Ahab?"
BEG_SENT "Who is Captain Ahab, sir?"
BEG_SENT "Aye, aye, I thought so.
BEG_SENT Captain Ahab is the Captain of this ship."
BEG_SENT "I am mistaken then.
BEG_SENT I thought I was speaking to the Captain
himself."
BEG_SENT "Thou art speaking to Captain Peleg- that's who ye are speaking to,
young man.
BEG_SENT It belongs to me and Captain Bildad to see the Pequod
fitted out for the voyage, and supplied with all her needs, including
crew.
BEG_SENT We are part owners and agents.
BEG_SENT But as I was going to say, if
thou wantest to know what whaling is, as thou tellest ye do, I can
put ye in a way of finding it out before ye bind yourself to it, past
backing out.
BEG_SENT Clap eye on Captain Ahab, young man, and thou wilt find
that he has only one leg."
BEG_SENT "What do you mean, sir?
BEG_SENT Was the other one lost by a whale?"
BEG_SENT "Lost by a whale!
BEG_SENT Young man, come nearer to me: it was devoured,
chewed up, crunched by the monstrousest parmacetty that ever chipped
a boat!- ah, ah!"
BEG_SENT I was a little alarmed by his energy, perhaps also a little touched
at the hearty grief in his concluding exclamation, but said as calmly
as I could, "What you say is no doubt true enough, sir; but how could
I know there was any peculiar ferocity in that particular whale,
though indeed I might have inferred as much from the simple fact of
the accident."
BEG_SENT "Look ye now, young man, thy lungs are a sort of soft, d'ye see; thou
dost not talk shark a bit.
BEG_SENT Sure, ye've been to sea before now; sure
of that?"
BEG_SENT "Sir," said I, "I thought I told you that I had been four voyages in
the merchant-"
