"Hard down out of that!
BEG_SENT Mind what I said about the marchant service-
don't aggravate me- I won't have it.
BEG_SENT But let us understand each
other.
BEG_SENT I have given thee a hint about what whaling is!
BEG_SENT do ye yet feel
inclined for it?"
BEG_SENT "I do, sir."
BEG_SENT "Very good.
BEG_SENT Now, art thou the man to pitch a harpoon down a live
whale's throat, and then jump after it?
BEG_SENT Answer, quick!"
BEG_SENT "I am, sir, if it should be positively indispensable to do so; not to
be got rid of, that is; which I don't take to be the fact."
BEG_SENT "Good again.
BEG_SENT Now then, thou not only wantest to go a-whaling, to find
out by experience what whaling is, but ye also want to go in order to
see the world?
BEG_SENT Was not that what ye said?
BEG_SENT I thought so.
BEG_SENT Well then,
just step forward there, and take a peep over the weather bow, and
then back to me and tell me what ye see there."
BEG_SENT For a moment I stood a little puzzled by this curious request, not
knowing exactly how to take it, whether humorously or in earnest.
BEG_SENT But
concentrating all his crow's feet into one scowl, Captain Peleg
started me on the errand.
BEG_SENT Going forward and glancing over the weather bow, I perceived that the
ship swinging to her anchor with the flood-tide, was now obliquely
pointing towards the open ocean.
BEG_SENT The prospect was unlimited, but
exceedingly monotonous and forbidding; not the slightest variety that
I could see.
BEG_SENT "Well, what's the report?"
BEG_SENT said Peleg when I came back; "what did ye
see?"
BEG_SENT "Not much," I replied- "nothing but water; considerable horizon
though, and there's a squall coming up, I think."
BEG_SENT "Well, what does thou think then of seeing the world?
BEG_SENT Do ye wish to
go round Cape Horn to see any more of it, eh?
BEG_SENT Can't ye see the world
where you stand?"
BEG_SENT I was a little staggered, but go a-whaling I must, and I would; and
the Pequod was as good a ship as any- I thought the best- and all
this I now repeated to Peleg.
BEG_SENT Seeing me so determined, he expressed
his willingness to ship me.
BEG_SENT "And thou mayest as well sign the papers right off," he added- "come
along with ye."
BEG_SENT And so saying, he led the way below deck into the
cabin.
BEG_SENT Seated on the transom was what seemed to me a most uncommon and
surprising figure.
BEG_SENT It turned out to be Captain Bildad who along with
Captain Peleg was one of the largest owners of the vessel; the other
shares, as is sometimes the case in these ports, being held by a
crowd of old annuitants; widows, fatherless children, and chancery
wards; each owning about the value of a timber head, or a foot of
plank, or a nail or two in the ship.
BEG_SENT People in Nantucket invest their
money in whaling vessels, the same way that you do yours in approved
state stocks bringing in good interest.
BEG_SENT Now, Bildad, like Peleg, and indeed many other Nantucketers, was a
Quaker, the island having been originally settled by that sect; and
to this day its inhabitants in general retain in an uncommon measure
peculiarities of the Quaker, only variously and anomalously modified
by things altogether alien and heterogeneous.
BEG_SENT For some of these same
Quakers are the most sanguinary of all sailors and
whale-hunters.
BEG_SENT They are fighting Quakers; they are Quakers with a
vengeance.
BEG_SENT So that there are instances among them of men, who, named with
Scripture names- a singularly common fashion on the island- and in
childhood naturally imbibing the stately dramatic thee and thou of
the Quaker idiom; still, from the audacious, daring, and boundless
adventure of their subsequent lives, strangely blend with these
unoutgrown peculiarities, a thousand bold dashes of character, not
unworthy a Scandinavian sea-king, or a poetical Pagan Roman.
BEG_SENT And when
these things unite in a man of greatly superior natural force, with a
globular brain and a ponderous heart; who has also by the stillness
and seclusion of many long night-watches in the remotest waters, and
beneath constellations never seen here at the north, been led to
think untraditionally and independently; receiving all nature's sweet
or savage impressions fresh from her own virgin voluntary and
confiding breast, and thereby chiefly, but with some help from
accidental advantages, to learn a bold and nervous lofty language-
that man makes one in a whole nation's census- a mighty pageant
creature, formed for noble tragedies.
BEG_SENT Nor will it at all detract from
him, dramatically regarded, if either by birth or other
circumstances, he have what seems a half wilful overruling morbidness
at the bottom of his nature.
BEG_SENT For all men tragically great are made so
through a certain morbidness.
BEG_SENT Be sure of this, O young ambition, all
mortal greatness is but disease.
BEG_SENT But, as yet we have not to do with
such an one, but with quite another; and still a man, who, if indeed
peculiar, it only results again from another phase of the Quaker,
modified by individual circumstances.
BEG_SENT Like Captain Peleg, Captain Bildad was a well-to-do, retired
whaleman.
BEG_SENT But unlike Captain Peleg- who cared not a rush for what are
called serious things, and indeed deemed those self-same serious
things the veriest of all trifles- Captain Bildad had not only been
originally educated according to the strictest sect of Nantucket
Quakerism, but all his subsequent ocean life, and the sight of many
unclad, lovely island creatures, round the Horn- all that had not
moved this native born Quaker one single jot, had not so much as
altered one angle of his vest.
BEG_SENT Still, for all this immutableness, was
there some lack of common consistency about worthy Captain
Peleg.
BEG_SENT Though refusing, from conscientious scruples, to bear arms
against land invaders, yet himself had illimitably invaded the
Atlantic and Pacific; and though a sworn foe to human bloodshed, yet
had he in his straight-bodied coat, spilled tuns upon tuns of
leviathan gore.
BEG_SENT How now in the contemplative evening of his days, the
pious Bildad reconciled these things in the reminiscence, I do not
know; but it did not seem to concern him much, and very probably he
had long since come to the sage and sensible conclusion that a man's
religion is one thing, and this practical world quite another.
BEG_SENT This
world pays dividends.
BEG_SENT Rising from a little cabin boy in short clothes
of the drabbest drab, to a harpooneer in a broad shad-bellied
waistcoat; from that becoming boat-header, chief mate, and captain,
and finally a shipowner; Bildad, as I hinted before, had concluded
his adventurous career by wholly retiring from active life at the
goodly age of sixty, and dedicating his remaining days to the quiet
receiving of his well-earned income.
BEG_SENT Now, Bildad, I am sorry to say, had the reputation of being an
incorrigible old hunks, and in his sea-going days, a bitter, hard
task-master.
BEG_SENT They told me in Nantucket, though it certainly seems a
curious story, that when he sailed the old Categut whaleman, his
crew, upon arriving home, were mostly all carried ashore to the
hospital, sore exhausted and worn out.
BEG_SENT For a pious man, especially
for a Quaker, he was certainly rather hard-hearted, to say the
least.
BEG_SENT He never used to swear, though, at his men, they said; but
somehow he got an inordinate quantity of cruel, unmitigated hard work
out of them.
BEG_SENT When Bildad was a chief-mate, to have his drab-colored
eye intently looking at you, made you feel completely nervous, till
you could clutch something- a hammer or a marrling-spike, and go to
work like mad, at something or other, never mind what.
BEG_SENT Indolence and
idleness perished before him.
BEG_SENT His own person was the exact embodiment
of his utilitarian character.
BEG_SENT On his long, gaunt body, he carried no
spare flesh, no superfluous beard, his chin having a soft, economical
nap to it, like that worn nap of his broad-brimmed hat.
BEG_SENT Such, then, was the person that I saw seated on the transom when I
followed Captain Peleg down into the cabin.
BEG_SENT The space between the
decks was small; and there, bolt upright, sat old Bildad, who always
sat so, and never leaned, and this to save his coat-tails.
BEG_SENT His
broad-brim was placed beside him; his legs were stiffly crossed; his
drab vesture was buttoned up to his chin; and spectacles on nose, he
seemed absorbed in reading from a ponderous volume.
BEG_SENT "Bildad," cried Captain Peleg, "at it again, Bildad, eh?
BEG_SENT Ye have been
studying those Scriptures, now, for the last thirty years, to my
certain knowledge.
BEG_SENT How far ye got, Bildad?"
BEG_SENT As if long habituated to such profane talk from his old shipmate,
Bildad, without noticing his present irreverence, quietly looked up,
and seeing me, glanced again inquiringly towards Peleg.
BEG_SENT "He says he's our man, Bildad," said Peleg, "he wants to ship."
BEG_SENT "Dost thee?"
BEG_SENT said Bildad, in a hollow tone, and turning round to me.
BEG_SENT "I dost," said I unconsciously, he was so intense a Quaker.
BEG_SENT "What do ye think of him, Bildad?"
BEG_SENT said Peleg.
BEG_SENT "He'll do," said Bildad, eyeing me, and then went on spelling away at
his book in a mumbling tone quite audible.
BEG_SENT I thought him the queerest old Quaker I ever saw, especially as
Peleg, his friend and old shipmate, seemed such a blusterer.
BEG_SENT But I
said nothing, only looking round me sharply.
BEG_SENT Peleg now threw open a
chest, and drawing forth the ship's articles, placed pen and ink
before him, and seated himself at a little table.
BEG_SENT I began to think it
was high time to settle with myself at what terms I would be willing
to engage for the voyage.
BEG_SENT I was already aware that in the whaling
business they paid no wages; but all hands, including the captain,
received certain shares of the profits called lays, and that these
lays were proportioned to the degree of importance pertaining to the
respective duties of the ship's company.
BEG_SENT I was also aware that being
a green hand at whaling, my own lay would not be very large; but
considering that I was used to the sea, could steer a ship, splice a
rope, and all that, I made no doubt that from all I had heard I
should be offered at least the 275th lay- that is, the 275th part of
the clear net proceeds of the voyage, whatever that might eventually
amount to.
BEG_SENT And though the 275th lay was what they call a rather long
lay, yet it was better than nothing; and if we had a lucky voyage,
might pretty nearly pay for the clothing I would wear out on it, not
to speak of my three years' beef and board, for which I would not
have to pay one stiver.
BEG_SENT It might be thought that this was a poor way to accumulate a princely
fortune- and so it was, a very poor way indeed.
BEG_SENT But I am one of those
who never take on about princely fortunes, and am quite content if
the world is ready to board and lodge me, while I am putting up at
this grim sign of the Thunder Cloud.
BEG_SENT Upon the whole, I thought the
275th lay would be about the fair thing, but would not have been
surprised had I been offered the 200th, considering I was of a
broad-shouldered make.
BEG_SENT But one thing, nevertheless, that made me a little distrustful about
receiving a generous share of the profits was this: Ashore, I had
heard something of both Captain Peleg and his unaccountable old crony
Bildad; how that they being the principal proprietors of the Pequod,
therefore the other and more inconsiderable and scattered owners,
left nearly the whole management of the ship's affairs to these
two.
BEG_SENT And I did not know but what the stingy old Bildad might have a
mighty deal to say about shipping hands, especially as I now found
him on board the Pequod, quite at home there in the cabin, and
reading his Bible as if at his own fireside.
BEG_SENT Now while Peleg was
vainly trying to mend a pen with his jack-knife, old Bildad, to my no
small surprise, considering that he was such an interested party in
these proceedings; Bildad never heeded us, but went on mumbling to
himself out of his book, "Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon
earth, where moth-"

"Well, Captain Bildad," interrupted Peleg, "what d'ye say, what lay
shall we give this young man?"
BEG_SENT "Thou knowest best," was the sepulchral reply, "the seven hundred and
seventy-seventh wouldn't be too much, would it?- 'where moth and rust
do corrupt, but lay-'"

Lay, indeed, thought I, and such a lay!
BEG_SENT the seven hundred and
seventy-seventh!
BEG_SENT Well, old Bildad, you are determined that I, for
one, shall not lay up many lays here below, where moth and rust do
corrupt.
BEG_SENT It was an exceedingly long lay that, indeed; and though from
the magnitude of the figure it might at first deceive a landsman, yet
the slightest consideration will show that though seven hundred and
seventy-seven is a pretty large number, yet, when you come to make a
teenth of it, you will then see, I say, that the seven hundred and
seventy-seventh part of a forthing is a good deal less than seven
hundred and seventy-seven gold doubloons; and so I thought at the
time.
BEG_SENT "Why, blast your eyes, Bildad," cried Peleg, "thou dost not want to
swindle this young man!
BEG_SENT he must have more than that."
BEG_SENT "Seven hundred and seventy-seventh," again said Bildad, without
lifting his eyes; and then went on mumbling- "for where your treasure
is, there will your heart be also."
BEG_SENT "I am going to put him down for the three hundredth," said Peleg, "do
ye hear that, Bildad!
BEG_SENT The three hundredth lay, I say."
BEG_SENT Bildad laid down his book, and turning solemnly towards him said,
"Captain Peleg, thou hast a generous heart; but thou must consider
the duty thou owest to the other owners of this ship- widows and
orphans, many of them- and that if we too abundantly reward the
labors of this young man, we may be taking the bread from those
widows and those orphans.
BEG_SENT The seven hundred and seventy-seventh lay,
Captain Peleg."
BEG_SENT "Thou Bildad!"
BEG_SENT roared Peleg, starting up and clattering about the
cabin.
BEG_SENT "Blast ye, Captain Bildad, if I had followed thy advice in
these matters, I would afore now had a conscience to lug about that
would be heavy enough to founder the largest ship that ever sailed
round Cape Horn."
BEG_SENT "Captain Peleg," said Bildad steadily, "thy conscience may be drawing
ten inches of water, or ten fathoms, I can't tell; but as thou art
still an impenitent man, Captain Peleg, I greatly fear lest thy
conscience be but a leaky one; and will in the end sink thee
foundering down to the fiery pit, Captain Peleg."
BEG_SENT "Fiery pit!
BEG_SENT fiery pit!
BEG_SENT ye insult me, man; past all natural bearing,
ye insult me.
BEG_SENT It's an all-fired outrage to tell any human creature
that he's bound to hell.
BEG_SENT Flukes and flames!
BEG_SENT Bildad, say that again to
me, and start my soulbolts, but I'll- I'll- yes, I'll swallow a live
goat with all his hair and horns on.
BEG_SENT Out of the cabin, ye canting,
drab-colored son of a wooden gun- a straight wake with ye!"
BEG_SENT As he thundered out this he made a rush at Bildad, but with a
marvellous oblique, sliding celerity, Bildad for that time eluded
him.
BEG_SENT Alarmed at this terrible outburst between the two principal and
responsible owners of the ship, and feeling half a mind to give up
all idea of sailing in a vessel so questionably owned and temporarily
commanded, I stepped aside from the door to give egress to Bildad,
who, I made no doubt, was all eagerness to vanish from before the
awakened wrath of Peleg.
BEG_SENT But to my astonishment, he sat down again on
the transom very quietly, and seemed to have not the slightest
intention of withdrawing.
BEG_SENT He seemed quite used to impenitent Peleg
and his ways.
BEG_SENT As for Peleg, after letting off his rage as he had,
there seemed no more left in him, and he, too, sat down like a lamb,
though he twitched a little as if still nervously agitated.
BEG_SENT "Whew!"
BEG_SENT he whistled at last- "the squall's gone off to leeward, I
think.
BEG_SENT Bildad, thou used to be good at sharpening a lance, mend that
pen, will ye.
BEG_SENT My jack-knife here needs the grindstone.
BEG_SENT That's he;
thank ye, Bildad.
BEG_SENT Now then, my young man, Ishmael's thy name, didn't
ye say?
BEG_SENT Well then, down ye go here, for the three hundredth lay."
BEG_SENT "Captain Peleg," said I, "I have a friend with me who wants to ship
too- shall I bring him down to-morrow?"
BEG_SENT "To be sure," said Peleg.
BEG_SENT "Fetch him along, and we'll look at him."
BEG_SENT "What lay does he want?"
BEG_SENT groaned Bildad, glancing up from the Book in
which he had again been burying himself.
BEG_SENT "Oh!
BEG_SENT never thee mind about that, Bildad," said Peleg.
BEG_SENT "Has he ever
whaled it any?"
BEG_SENT turning to me.
BEG_SENT "Killed more whales than I can count, Captain Peleg."
BEG_SENT "Well, bring him along then."
BEG_SENT And, after signing the papers, off I went; nothing doubting but that
I had done a good morning's work, and that the Pequod was the
identical ship that Yojo had provided to carry Queequeg and me round
the Cape.
BEG_SENT But I had not proceeded far, when I began to bethink me that the
Captain with whom I was to sail yet remained unseen by me; though,
indeed, in many cases, a whale-ship will be completely fitted out,
and receive all her crew on board, ere the captain makes himself
visible by arriving to take command; for sometimes these voyages are
so prolonged, and the shore intervals at home so exceedingly brief,
that if the captain have family, or any absorbing concernment of that
sort, he does not trouble himself much about his ship in port, but
leaves her to the owners till all is ready for sea.
BEG_SENT However, it is
always as well to have a look at him before irrevocably committing
yourself into his hands.
BEG_SENT Turning back I accosted Captain Peleg,
inquiring where Captain Ahab was to be found.
BEG_SENT "And what dost thou want of Captain Ahab?
BEG_SENT It's all right enough; thou
art shipped."
BEG_SENT "Yes, but I should like to see him."
BEG_SENT "But I don't think thou wilt be able to at present.
BEG_SENT I don't know
exactly what's the matter with him; but he keeps close inside the
house; a sort of sick, and yet he don't look so.
BEG_SENT In fact, he ain't
sick; but no, he isn't well either.
BEG_SENT Any how, young man, he won't
always see me, so I don't suppose he will thee.
BEG_SENT He's a queer man,
Captain Ahab- so some think- but a good one.
BEG_SENT Oh, thou'lt like him
well enough; no fear, no fear.
BEG_SENT He's a grand, ungodly, god-like man,
Captain Ahab; doesn't speak much; but, when he does speak, then you
may well listen.
BEG_SENT Mark ye, be forewarned; Ahab's above the common;
Ahab's been in colleges, as well as 'mong the cannibals; been used to
deeper wonders than the waves; fixed his fiery lance in mightier,
stranger foes than whales.
BEG_SENT His lance!
BEG_SENT aye, the keenest and surest
that out of all our isle!
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT he ain't Captain Bildad; no, and he
ain't Captain Peleg; he's Ahab, boy; and Ahab of old, thou knowest,
was a crowned king!"
BEG_SENT "And a very vile one.
BEG_SENT When that wicked king was slain, the dogs, did
they not lick his blood?"
BEG_SENT "Come hither to me- hither, hither," said Peleg, with a significance
in his eye that almost startled me.
BEG_SENT "Look ye, lad; never say that on
board the Pequod.
BEG_SENT Never say it anywhere.
BEG_SENT Captain Ahab did not name
himself .
BEG_SENT 'Twas a foolish, ignorant whim of his crazy, widowed mother,
who died when he was only a twelvemonth old.
BEG_SENT And yet the old squaw
Tistig, at Gayhead, said that the name would somehow prove
prophetic.
BEG_SENT And, perhaps, other fools like her may tell thee the
same.
BEG_SENT I wish to warn thee.
BEG_SENT It's a lie.
BEG_SENT I know Captain Ahab well; I've
sailed with him as mate years ago; know what he is- a good man- not a
pious, good man, like Bildad, but a swearing good man- something like
me- only there's a good deal more of him.
BEG_SENT Aye, aye, I know that he
was never very jolly; and I know that on the passage home he was a
little out of his mind for a spell; but it was the sharp shooting
pains in his bleeding stump that brought that about, as any one might
see.
BEG_SENT I know, too, that ever since he lost his leg last voyage by that
accursed whale, he's been a kind of moody- desperate moody, and
savage sometimes; but that will all pass off.
BEG_SENT And once for all, let
me tell thee and assure thee, young man, it's better to sail with a
moody good captain than a laughing bad one.
BEG_SENT So good-bye to thee- and
wrong not Captain Ahab, because he happens to have a wicked
name.
BEG_SENT Besides, my boy, he has a wife- not three voyages wedded- a
sweet, resigned girl.
BEG_SENT Think of that; by that sweet girl that old man
had a child: hold ye then there can be any utter, hopeless harm in
Ahab?
BEG_SENT No, no, my lad; stricken, blasted, if he be, Ahab has his
humanities!"
BEG_SENT As I walked away, I was full of thoughtfulness; what had been
incidentally revealed to me of Captain Ahab, filled me with a certain
wild vagueness of painfulness concerning him.
BEG_SENT And somehow, at the
time, I felt a sympathy and a sorrow for him, but for I don't know
what, unless it was the cruel loss of his leg.
BEG_SENT And yet I also felt a
strange awe of him; but that sort of awe, which I cannot at all
describe, was not exactly awe; I do not know what it was.
BEG_SENT But I felt
it; and it did not disincline me towards him; though I felt
impatience at what seemed like mystery in him, so imperfectly as he
was known to me then.
BEG_SENT However, my thoughts were at length carried in
other directions, so that for the present dark Ahab slipped my mind.
BEG_SENT The Ramadan


As Queequeg's Ramadan, or Fasting and Humiliation, was to continue
all day, I did not choose to disturb him till towards night-fall; for
I cherish the greatest respect towards everybody's religious
obligations, never mind how comical, and could not find it in my
heart to undervalue even a congregation of ants worshipping a
toad-stool; or those other creatures in certain parts of our earth,
who with a degree of footmanism quite unprecedented in other planets,
bow down before the torso of a deceased landed proprietor merely on
account of the inordinate possessions yet owned and rented in his
name.
BEG_SENT I say, we good Presbyterian Christians should be charitable in these
things, and not fancy ourselves so vastly superior to other mortals,
pagans and what not, because of their half-crazy conceits on these
subjects.
BEG_SENT There was Queequeg, now, certainly entertaining the most
absurd notions about Yojo and his Ramadan;- but what of that?
BEG_SENT Queequeg thought he knew what he was about, I suppose; he seemed to
be content; and there let him rest.
BEG_SENT All our arguing with him would
not avail; let him be, I say: and Heaven have mercy on us all-
Presbyterians and Pagans alike- for we are all somehow dreadfully
cracked about the head, and sadly need mending.
BEG_SENT Towards evening, when I felt assured that all his performances and
rituals must be over, I went to his room and knocked at the door; but
no answer.
BEG_SENT I tried to open it, but it was fastened
inside.
BEG_SENT "Queequeg," said I softly through the key-hole:- all
silent.
BEG_SENT "I say, Queequeg!
BEG_SENT why don't you speak?
BEG_SENT It's I- Ishmael."
BEG_SENT But
all remained still as before.
BEG_SENT I began to grow alarmed.
BEG_SENT I had allowed
him such abundant time; I thought he might have had an apoplectic
fit.
BEG_SENT I looked through the key-hole; but the door opening into an odd
corner of the room, the key-hole prospect was but a crooked and
sinister one.
BEG_SENT I could only see part of the foot-board of the bed and
a line of the wall, but nothing more.
BEG_SENT I was surprised to behold
resting against the wall the wooden shaft of Queequeg's harpoon,
which the landlady the evening previous had taken from him, before
our mounting to the chamber.
BEG_SENT That's strange, thought I; but at any
rate, since the harpoon stands yonder, and he seldom or never goes
abroad without it, therefore he must be inside here, and no possible
mistake.
BEG_SENT "Queequeg!- Queequeg!
BEG_SENT "- all still.
BEG_SENT Something must have
happened.
BEG_SENT Apoplexy!
BEG_SENT I tried to burst open the door; but it stubbornly
resisted.
BEG_SENT Running down stairs, I quickly stated my suspicions to the
first person I met- the chamber-maid.
BEG_SENT "La!
BEG_SENT la!"
BEG_SENT she cried, "I thought
something must the matter.
BEG_SENT I went to make the bed after breakfast,
and the door was locked; and not a mouse to be heard; and it's been
just so silent ever since.
BEG_SENT But I thought, may be, you had both gone
off and locked your baggage in for safe keeping.
BEG_SENT La!
BEG_SENT la, ma'am!-
Mistress!
BEG_SENT murder!
BEG_SENT Mrs. Hussey!
BEG_SENT apoplexy!
BEG_SENT "- and with these cries she
ran towards the kitchen, I following.
BEG_SENT Mrs. Hussey soon appeared, with a mustard-pot in one hand and a
vinegar-cruet in the other, having just broken away from the
occupation of attending to the castors, and scolding her little black
boy meantime.
BEG_SENT "Wood-house!"
BEG_SENT cried I, "which way to it?
BEG_SENT Run for God's sake, and
fetch something to pry open the door- the axe!- the axe!
BEG_SENT he's had a
stroke; depend upon it!
BEG_SENT "- and so saying I was unmethodically rushing
up stairs again empty-handed, when Mrs. Hussey interposed the
mustard-pot and vinegar-cruet, and the entire castor of her
countenance.
BEG_SENT "What's the matter with you, young man?"
BEG_SENT "Get the axe!
BEG_SENT For God's sake, run for the doctor, some one, while I
pry it open!"
BEG_SENT "Look here," said the landlady, quickly putting down the
vinegar-cruet, so as to have one hand free; "look here; are you
talking about prying open any of my doors?
BEG_SENT "- and with that she seized
my arm.
BEG_SENT "What's the matter with you?
BEG_SENT What's the matter with you,
shipmate?"
BEG_SENT In as calm, but rapid a manner as possible, I gave her to understand
the whole case.
BEG_SENT Unconsciously clapping the vinegar-cruet to one side
of her nose, she ruminated for an instant; then exclaimed- "No!
BEG_SENT I
haven't seen it since I put it there."
BEG_SENT Running to a little closet
under the landing of the stairs, she glanced in, and returning, told
me that Queequeg's harpoon was missing.
BEG_SENT "He's killed himself," she
cried.
BEG_SENT "It's unfort'nate Stiggs done over again there goes another
counterpane- God pity his poor mother!- it will be the ruin of my
house.
BEG_SENT Has the poor lad a sister?
BEG_SENT Where's that girl?- there, Betty,
go to Snarles the Painter, and tell him to paint me a sign, with- "no
suicides permitted here, and no smoking in the parlor;"- might as
well kill both birds at once.
BEG_SENT Kill?
BEG_SENT The Lord be merciful to his
ghost!
BEG_SENT What's that noise there?
BEG_SENT You, young man, avast there!"
BEG_SENT And running after me, she caught me as I was again trying to force
open the door.
BEG_SENT "I won't allow it; I won't have my premises spoiled.
BEG_SENT Go for the
locksmith, there's one about a mile from here.
BEG_SENT But avast!"
BEG_SENT putting
her hand in her side pocket, "here's a key that'll fit, I guess;
let's see."
BEG_SENT And with that, she turned it in the lock; but alas!
BEG_SENT Queequeg's supplemental bolt remained unwithdrawn within.
BEG_SENT "Have to burst it open," said I, and was running down the entry a
little, for a good start, when the landlady caught at me, again
vowing I should not break down her premises; but I tore from her, and
with a sudden bodily rush dashed myself full against the mark.
BEG_SENT With a prodigious noise the door flew open, and the knob slamming
against the wall, sent the plaster to the ceiling; and there, good
heavens!
BEG_SENT there sat Queequeg, altogether cool on his hams, and holding
Yojo on top of his head.
BEG_SENT He looked neither one way nor the other way
but sat like a carved image with scarce a sign of active life.
BEG_SENT "Queequeg," said I, going up to him, "Queequeg, what's the matter
with you?"
BEG_SENT "He hain't been a sittin' so all day, has he?"
BEG_SENT said the landlady.
BEG_SENT But all we said, not a word could we drag out of him; I almost felt
like pushing him over, so as to change his position, for it was
almost intolerable, it seemed so painfully and unnaturally
constrained; especially, as in all probability he had been sitting so
for upwards of eight or ten hours, going too without his regular
meals.
BEG_SENT "Mrs. Hussey," said I, "he's alive at all events; so leave us, if you
please, and I will see to this strange affair myself."
BEG_SENT Closing the door upon the landlady, I endeavored to prevail upon
Queequeg to take a chair; but in vain.
BEG_SENT There he sat; and all he could
do- for all my polite arts and blandishments- he would not move a
peg, nor say a single word, nor even look at me, nor notice my
presence in the slightest way.
BEG_SENT I wonder, thought I, if this can possibly be a part of his Ramadan;
do they fast on their hams that way in his native land.
BEG_SENT It must be
so; yes, it's a part of his creed, I suppose; well, then, let him
rest; he'll get up sooner or later, no doubt.
BEG_SENT It can't last for ever,
thank God, and his Ramadan only comes once a year; and I don't
believe it's very punctual then.
BEG_SENT I went down to supper.
BEG_SENT After sitting a long time listening to the
long stories of some sailors who had just come from a plum-pudding
voyage, as they called it (that is, a short whaling-voyage in a
schooner or brig, confined to the north of the line, in the Atlantic
Ocean only); after listening to these plum-puddingers till nearly
eleven o'clock, I went up stairs to go to bed, feeling quite sure by
this time Queequeg must certainly have brought his Ramadan to a
termination.
BEG_SENT But no; there he was just where I had left him; he had
not stirred an inch.
BEG_SENT I began to grow vexed with him; it seemed so
downright senseless and insane to be sitting there all day and half
the night on his hams in a cold room, holding a piece of wood on his
head.
BEG_SENT "For heaven's sake, Queequeg, get up and shake yourself; get up and
have some supper.
BEG_SENT You'll starve; you'll kill yourself, Queequeg."
BEG_SENT But
not a word did he reply.
BEG_SENT Despairing of him, therefore, I determined to go to bed and to sleep;
and no doubt, before a great while, he would follow me.
BEG_SENT But previous
to turning in, I took my heavy bearskin jacket, and threw it over
him, as it promised to be a very cold night; and he had nothing but
his ordinary round jacket on.
BEG_SENT For some time, do all I would, I could
not get into the faintest doze.
BEG_SENT I had blown out the candle; and the
mere thought of Queequeg- not four feet off- sitting there in that
uneasy position, stark alone in the cold and dark; this made me
really wretched.
BEG_SENT Think of it; sleeping all night in the same room
with a wide awake pagan on his hams in this dreary, unaccountable
Ramadan!
BEG_SENT But somehow I dropped off at last, and knew nothing more till break
of day; when, looking over the bedside, there squatted Queequeg, as
if he had been screwed down to the floor.
BEG_SENT But as soon as the first
glimpse of sun entered the window, up he got, with stiff grating
joints, but with a cheerful look; limped towards me where I lay;
pressed his forehead again against mine; and said his Ramadan was
over.
BEG_SENT Now, as I before hinted, I have no objection to any person's
religion, be it what it may, so long as that person does not kill or
insult any other person, because that other person don't believe it
also.
BEG_SENT But when a man's religion becomes really frantic; when it is a
positive torment to him; and, in fine, makes this earth of ours an
uncomfortable inn to lodge in; then I think it high time to take that
individual aside and argue the point with him.
BEG_SENT And just so I now did with Queequeg.
BEG_SENT "Queequeg," said I, "get into
bed now, and lie and listen to me."
BEG_SENT I then went on, beginning with
the rise and progress of the primitive religions, and coming down to
the various religions of the present time, during which time I
labored to show Queequeg that all these Lents, Ramadans, and
prolonged ham-squattings in cold, cheerless rooms were stark
nonsense; bad for the health; useless for the soul; opposed, in
short, to the obvious laws of Hygiene and common sense.
BEG_SENT I told him,
too, that he being in other things such an extremely sensible and
sagacious savage, it pained me, very badly pained me, to see him now
so deplorably foolish about this ridiculous Ramadan of his.
BEG_SENT Besides,
argued I, fasting makes the body cave in; hence the spirit caves in;
and all thoughts born of a fast must necessarily be
half-starved.
BEG_SENT This is the reason why most dyspeptic religionists
cherish such melancholy notions about their hereafters.
BEG_SENT In one word,
Queequeg, said I, rather digressively; hell is an idea first born on
an undigested apple-dumpling; and since then perpetuated through the
hereditary dyspepsias nurtured by Ramadans.
BEG_SENT I then asked Queequeg whether he himself was ever troubled with
dyspepsia; expressing the idea very plainly, so that he could take it
in.
BEG_SENT He said no; only upon one memorable occasion.
BEG_SENT It was after a
great feast given by his father the king on the gaining of a great
battle wherein fifty of the enemy had been killed by about two
o'clock in the afternoon, and all cooked and eaten that very evening.
BEG_SENT "No more, Queequeg," said I, shuddering; "that will do;" for I knew
the inferences without his further hinting them.
BEG_SENT I had seen a sailor
who had visited that very island, and he told me that it was the
custom, when a great battle had been gained there, to barbecue all
the slain in the yard or garden of the victor; and then, one by one,
they were placed in great wooden trenchers, and garnished round like
a pilau, with breadfruit and cocoanuts; and with some parsley in
their mouths, were sent round with the victor's compliments to all
his friends, just as though these presents were so many Christmas
turkeys.
BEG_SENT After all, I do not think that my remarks about religion made much
impression upon Queequeg.
BEG_SENT Because, in the first place, he somehow
seemed dull of hearing on that important subject, unless considered
from his own point of view; and, in the second place, he did not more
than one third understand me, couch my ideas simply as I would; and,
finally, he no doubt thought he knew a good deal more about the true
religion than I did.
BEG_SENT He looked at me with a sort of condescending
concern and compassion, as though he thought it a great pity that
such a sensible young man should be so hopelessly lost to evangelical
pagan piety.
BEG_SENT At last we rose and dressed; and Queequeg, taking a prodigiously
hearty breakfast of chowders of all sorts, so that the landlady
should not make much profit by reason of his Ramadan, we sallied out
to board the Pequod, sauntering along, and picking our teeth with
halibut bones.
BEG_SENT His Mark


As we were walking down the end of the wharf towards the ship,
Queequeg carrying his harpoon, Captain Peleg in his gruff voice
loudly hailed us from his wigwam, saying he had not suspected my
friend was a cannibal, and furthermore announcing that he let no
cannibals on board that craft, unless they previously produced their
papers.
BEG_SENT "What do you mean by that, Captain Peleg?"
BEG_SENT said I, now jumping on the
bulwarks, and leaving my comrade standing on the wharf.
BEG_SENT "I mean," he replied, "he must show his papers."
BEG_SENT "Yes," said Captain Bildad in his hollow voice, sticking his head
from behind Peleg's, out of the wigwam.
BEG_SENT "He must show that he's
converted.
BEG_SENT Son of darkness," he added, turning to Queequeg, "art thou
at present in communion with any Christian church?"
BEG_SENT "Why," said I, "he's a member of the first Congregational Church."
BEG_SENT Here be it said, that many tattooed savages sailing in Nantucket
ships at last come to be converted into the churches.
BEG_SENT "First Congregational Church," cried Bildad, "what!
BEG_SENT that worships in
Deacon Deuteronomy Coleman's meeting-house?"
BEG_SENT and so saying, taking
out his spectacles, he rubbed them with his great yellow bandana
handkerchief, and putting them on very carefully, came out of the
wigwam, and leaning stiffly over the bulwarks, took a good long look
at Queequeg.
BEG_SENT "How long hath he been a member?"
BEG_SENT he then said, turning to me; "not
very long, I rather guess, young man."
BEG_SENT "No," said Peleg, "and he hasn't been baptized right either, or it
would have washed some of that devil's blue off his face."
BEG_SENT "Do tell, now," cried Bildad, "is this Philistine a regular member of
Deacon Deuteronomy's meeting?
BEG_SENT I never saw him going there, and I pass
it every Lord's day."
BEG_SENT "I don't know anything about Deacon Deuteronomy or his meeting," said
I; "all I know is, that Queequeg here is a born member of the First
Congregational Church.
BEG_SENT He is a deacon himself, Queequeg is."
BEG_SENT "Young man," said Bildad sternly, "thou art skylarking with me-
explain thyself, thou young Hittite.
BEG_SENT What church dost thee mean?
BEG_SENT answer me."
BEG_SENT Finding myself thus hard pushed, I replied, "I mean, sir, the same
ancient Catholic Church to which you and I, and Captain Peleg there,
and Queequeg here, and all of us, and every mother's son and soul of
us belong; the great and everlasting First Congregation of this whole
worshipping world; we all belong to that; only some of us cherish
some crotchets no ways touching the grand belief; in that we all join
hands."
BEG_SENT "Splice, thou mean'st splice hands," cried Peleg, drawing
nearer.
BEG_SENT "Young man, you'd better ship for a missionary, instead of a
fore-mast hand; I never heard a better sermon.
BEG_SENT Deacon Deuteronomy-
why Father Mapple himself couldn't beat it, and he's reckoned
something.
BEG_SENT Come aboard, come aboard: never mind about the papers.
BEG_SENT I
say, tell Quohog there- what's that you call him?
BEG_SENT tell Quohog to step
along.
BEG_SENT By the great anchor, what a harpoon he's got there!
BEG_SENT looks like
good stuff that; and he handles it about right.
BEG_SENT I say, Quohog, or
whatever your name is, did you ever stand in the head of a
whale-boat?
BEG_SENT did you ever strike a fish?"
BEG_SENT Without saying a word, Queequeg, in his wild sort of way, jumped upon
the bulwarks, from thence into the bows of one of the whale-boats
hanging to the side; and then bracing his left knee, and poising his
harpoon, cried out in some such way as this:-

"Cap'ain, you see him small drop tar on water dere?
BEG_SENT You see him?
BEG_SENT well, spose him one whale eye, well, den!"
BEG_SENT and taking sharp aim at
it, he darted the iron right over old Bildad's broad brim, clean
across the ship's decks, and struck the glistening tar spot out of
sight.
BEG_SENT "Now," said Queequeg, quietly, hauling in the line, "spos-ee him
whale-e eye; why, dad whale dead."
BEG_SENT "Quick, Bildad," said Peleg, his partner, who, aghast at the close
vicinity of the flying harpoon, had retreated towards the cabin
gangway.
BEG_SENT "Quick, I say, you Bildad, and get the ship's papers.
BEG_SENT We
must have Hedgehog there, I mean Quohog, in one of our boats.
BEG_SENT Look
ye, Quohog, we'll give ye the ninetieth lay, and that's more than
ever was given a harpooneer yet out of Nantucket."
BEG_SENT So down we went into the cabin, and to my great joy Queequeg was soon
enrolled among the same ship's company to which I myself belonged.
BEG_SENT When all preliminaries were over and Peleg had got everything ready
for signing, he turned to me and said, "I guess, Quohog there don't
know how to write, does he?
BEG_SENT I say, Quohog, blast ye!
BEG_SENT dost thou sign
thy name or make thy mark?
BEG_SENT But at this question, Queequeg, who had twice or thrice before taken
part in similar ceremonies, looked no ways abashed; but taking the
offered pen, copied upon the paper, in the proper place, an exact
counterpart of a queer round figure which was tattooed upon his arm;
so that through Captain Peleg's obstinate mistake touching his
appellative, it stood something like this:-
Quohog.
BEG_SENT his X mark.
BEG_SENT Meanwhile Captain Bildad sat earnestly and steadfastly
eyeing Queequeg, and at last rising solemnly and fumbling in the huge
pockets of his broadskirted drab coat took out a bundle of tracts,
and selecting one entitled "The Latter Day Coming; or No Time to
Lose," placed it in Queequeg's hands, and then grasping them and the
book with both his, looked earnestly into his eyes, and said, "Son of
darkness, I must do my duty by thee; I am part owner of this ship,
and feel concerned for the souls of all its crew; if thou still
clingest to thy Pagan ways, which I sadly fear, I beseech thee,
remain not for aye a Belial bondsman.
BEG_SENT Spurn the idol Bell, and the
hideous dragon; turn from the wrath to come; mind thine eye, I say;
oh!
BEG_SENT goodness gracious!
BEG_SENT steer clear of the fiery pit!"
BEG_SENT Something of the salt sea yet lingered in old Bildad's language,
heterogeneously mixed with Scriptural and domestic phrases.
BEG_SENT "Avast there, avast there, Bildad, avast now spoiling our
harpooneer," Peleg.
BEG_SENT "Pious harpooneers never make good voyagers- it
takes the shark out of 'em; no harpooneer is worth a straw who aint
pretty sharkish.
BEG_SENT There was young Nat Swaine, once the bravest
boat-header out of all Nantucket and the Vineyard; he joined the
meeting, and never came to good.
BEG_SENT He got so frightened about his
plaguy soul, that he shrinked and sheered away from whales, for fear
of after-claps, in case he got stove and went to Davy Jones."
BEG_SENT "Peleg!
BEG_SENT Peleg!"
BEG_SENT said Bildad, lifting his eyes and hands, "thou
thyself, as I myself, hast seen many a perilous time; thou knowest,
Peleg, what it is to have the fear of death; how, then, can'st thou
prate in this ungodly guise.
BEG_SENT Thou beliest thine own heart,
Peleg.
BEG_SENT Tell me, when this same Pequod here had her three masts
overboard in that typhoon on Japan, that same voyage when thou went
mate with Captain Ahab, did'st thou not think of Death and the
Judgment then?"
BEG_SENT "Hear him, hear him now," cried Peleg, marching across the cabin, and
thrusting his hands far down into his pockets,- "hear him, all of
ye.
BEG_SENT Think of that!
BEG_SENT When every moment we thought the ship would sink!
BEG_SENT Death and the Judgment then?
BEG_SENT What?
BEG_SENT With all three masts making such
an everlasting thundering against the side; and every sea breaking
over us, fore and aft.
BEG_SENT Think of Death and the Judgment then?
BEG_SENT No!
BEG_SENT no
time to think about death then.
BEG_SENT Life was what Captain Ahab and I was
thinking of; and how to save all hands how to rig jury-masts how to
get into the nearest port; that was what I was thinking of."
BEG_SENT Bildad said no more, but buttoning up his coat, stalked on deck,
where we followed him.
BEG_SENT There he stood, very quietly overlooking some
sailmakers who were mending a top-sail in the waist.
BEG_SENT Now and then he
stooped to pick up a patch, or save an end of tarred twine, which
otherwise might have been wasted.
BEG_SENT The Prophet


"Shipmates, have ye shipped in that ship?"
BEG_SENT Queequeg and I had just left the Pequod, and were sauntering from the
water, for the moment each occupied with his own thoughts, when the
above words were put to us by a stranger, who, pausing before us,
levelled his massive forefinger at the vessel in question.
BEG_SENT He was but
shabbily apparelled in faded jacket and patched trowsers; a rag of a
black handkerchief investing his neck.
BEG_SENT A confluent smallpox had in
all directions flowed over his face, and left it like the complicated
ribbed bed of a torrent, when the rushing waters have been dried up.
BEG_SENT "Have ye shipped in her?"
BEG_SENT he repeated.
BEG_SENT "You mean the ship Pequod, I suppose," said I, trying to gain a
little more time for an uninterrupted look at him.
BEG_SENT "Aye, the Pequod- that ship there," he said, drawing back his whole
arm and then rapidly shoving it straight out from him-, with the
fixed bayonet of his pointed finger darted full at the object.
BEG_SENT "Yes," said I, "we have just signed the articles."
BEG_SENT "Anything down there about your souls?"
BEG_SENT "About what?"
BEG_SENT "Oh, perhaps you hav'n't got any," he said quickly.
BEG_SENT "No matter
though, I know many chaps that hav'n't got any,- good luck to 'em;
and they are all the better off for it.
BEG_SENT A soul's a sort of a fifth
wheel to a wagon."
BEG_SENT "What are you jabbering about, shipmate?"
BEG_SENT said I.
BEG_SENT "He's got enough, though, to make up for all deficiencies of that
sort in other chaps," abruptly said the stranger, placing a nervous
emphasis upon the word he.
BEG_SENT "Queequeg," said I, "let's go; this fellow has broken loose from
somewhere; he's talking about something and somebody we don't know."
BEG_SENT "Stop!"
BEG_SENT cried the stranger.
BEG_SENT "Ye said true- ye hav'n't seen Old
Thunder yet, have ye?"
BEG_SENT "Who's Old Thunder?"
BEG_SENT said I, again riveted with the insane
earnestness of his manner.
BEG_SENT "Captain Ahab."
BEG_SENT "What!
BEG_SENT the captain of our ship, the Pequod?"
BEG_SENT "Aye, among some of us old sailor chaps, he goes by that name.
BEG_SENT Ye
hav'n't seen him yet, have ye?"
BEG_SENT "No, we hav'n't.
BEG_SENT He's sick they say, but is getting better, and will
be all right again before long."
BEG_SENT "All right again before long!"
BEG_SENT laughed the stranger, with a solemnly
derisive sort of laugh.
BEG_SENT "Look ye; when Captain Ahab is all right,
then this left arm of mine will be all right; not before."
BEG_SENT "What do you know about him?"
BEG_SENT "What did they tell you about him?
BEG_SENT Say that!"
BEG_SENT "They didn't tell much of anything about him; only I've heard that
he's a good whale-hunter, and a good captain to his crew."
BEG_SENT "That's true, that's true- yes, both true enough.
BEG_SENT But you must jump
when he gives an order.
BEG_SENT Step and growl; growl and go- that's the word
with Captain Ahab.
BEG_SENT But nothing about that thing that happened to him
off Cape Horn, long ago, when he lay like dead for three days and
nights; nothing about that deadly skrimmage with the Spaniard afore
the altar in Santa?- heard nothing about that, eh?
BEG_SENT Nothing about the
silver calabash he spat into?
BEG_SENT And nothing about his losing his leg
last voyage, according to the prophecy.
BEG_SENT Didn't ye hear a word about
them matters and something more, eh?
BEG_SENT No, I don't think ye did; how
could ye?
BEG_SENT Who knows it?
BEG_SENT Not all Nantucket, I guess.
BEG_SENT But hows'ever,
mayhap, ye've heard tell about the leg, and how he lost it; aye, ye
have heard of that, I dare say.
BEG_SENT Oh, yes, that every one knows a'most-
I mean they know he's only one leg; and that a parmacetti took the
other off."
BEG_SENT "My friend," said I, "what all this gibberish of yours is about, I
don't know, and I don't much care; for it seems to me that you must
be a little damaged in the head.
BEG_SENT But if you are speaking of Captain
Ahab, of that ship there, the Pequod, then let me tell you, that I
know all about the loss of his leg."
BEG_SENT "All about it, eh- sure you do?
BEG_SENT all?
BEG_SENT "Pretty sure."
BEG_SENT With finger pointed and eye levelled at the Pequod, the beggar-like
stranger stood a moment, as if in a troubled reverie; then starting a
little, turned and said:- "Ye've shipped, have ye?
BEG_SENT Names down on the
papers?
BEG_SENT Well, well, what's signed, is signed; and what's to be, will
be; and then again, perhaps it won't be, after all.
BEG_SENT Any how, it's all
fixed and arranged already; and some sailors or other must go with
him, I suppose; as well these as any other men, God pity 'em!
BEG_SENT Morning
to ye, shipmates, morning; the ineffable heavens bless ye; I'm sorry
I stopped ye."
BEG_SENT "Look here, friend," said I, "if you have anything important to tell
us, out with it; but if you are only trying to bamboozle us, you are
mistaken in your game; that's all I have to say."
BEG_SENT "And it's said very well, and I like to hear a chap talk up that way;
you are just the man for him- the likes of ye.
BEG_SENT Morning to ye,
shipmates, morning!
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT when ye get there, tell 'em I've concluded
not to make one of 'em."
BEG_SENT "Ah, my dear fellow, you can't fool us that way- you can't fool
us.
BEG_SENT It is the easiest thing in the world for a man to look as if he
had a great secret in him."
BEG_SENT "Morning to ye, shipmates, morning."
BEG_SENT "Morning it is," said I.
BEG_SENT "Come along, Queequeg, let's leave this
crazy man.
BEG_SENT But stop, tell me your name, will you?"
BEG_SENT "Elijah."
BEG_SENT Elijah!
BEG_SENT thought I, and we walked away, both commenting, after each
other's fashion, upon this ragged old sailor; and agreed that he was
nothing but a humbug, trying to be a bugbear.
BEG_SENT But we had not gone
perhaps above a hundred yards, when chancing to turn a corner, and
looking back as I did so, who should be seen but Elijah following us,
though at a distance.
BEG_SENT Somehow, the sight of him struck me so, that I
said nothing to Queequeg of his being behind, but passed on with my
comrade, anxious to see whether the stranger would turn the same
corner that we did.
BEG_SENT He did; and then it seemed to me that he was
dogging us, but with what intent I could not for the life of me
imagine.
BEG_SENT This circumstance, coupled with his ambiguous, half-hinting,
half-revealing, shrouded sort of talk, now begat in me all kinds of
vague wonderments and half-apprehensions, and all connected with the
Pequod; and Captain Ahab; and the leg he had lost; and the Cape Horn
fit; and the silver calabash; and what Captain Peleg had said of him,
when I left the ship the day previous; and the prediction of the
squaw Tistig; and the voyage we had bound ourselves to sail; and a
hundred other shadowy things.
BEG_SENT I was resolved to satisfy myself whether this ragged Elijah was
really dogging us or not, and with that intent crossed the way with
Queequeg, and on that side of it retraced our steps.
BEG_SENT But Elijah
passed on, without seeming to notice us.
BEG_SENT This relieved me; and once
more, and finally as it seemed to me, I pronounced him in my heart, a
humbug.
BEG_SENT All Astir


A day or two passed, and there was great activity aboard the
Pequod.
BEG_SENT Not only were the old sails being mended, but new sails were
coming on board, and bolts of canvas, and coils of rigging; in short,
everything betokened that the ship's preparations were hurrying to a
close.
BEG_SENT Captain Peleg seldom or never went ashore, but sat in his
wigwam keeping a sharp look-out upon the hands: Bildad did all the
purchasing and providing at the stores; and the men employed in the
hold and on the rigging were working till long after night-fall.
BEG_SENT On the day following Queequeg's signing the articles, word was given
at all the inns where the ship's company were stopping, that their
chests must be on board before night, for there was no telling how
soon the vessel might be sailing.
BEG_SENT So Queequeg and I got down our
traps, resolving, however, to sleep ashore till the last.
BEG_SENT But it
seems they always give very long notice in these cases, and the ship
did not sail for several days.
BEG_SENT But no wonder; there was a good deal
to be done, and there is no telling how many things to be thought of,
before the Pequod was fully equipped.
BEG_SENT Every one knows what a multitude of things- beds, sauce-pans, knives
and forks, shovels and tongs, napkins, nut-crackers, and what not,
are indispensable to the business of housekeeping.
BEG_SENT Just so with
whaling, which necessitates a three-years' housekeeping upon the wide
ocean, far from all grocers, costermongers, doctors, bakers, and
bankers.
BEG_SENT And though this also holds true of merchant vessels, yet not
by any means to the same extent as with whalemen.
BEG_SENT For besides the
great length of the whaling voyage, the numerous articles peculiar to
the prosecution of the fishery, and the impossibility of replacing
them at the remote harbors usually frequented, it must be remembered,
that of all ships, whaling vessels are the most exposed to accidents
of all kinds, and especially to the destruction and loss of the very
things upon which the success of the voyage most depends.
BEG_SENT Hence, the
spare boats, spare spars, and spare lines and harpoons, and spare
everythings, almost, but a spare Captain and duplicate ship.
BEG_SENT At the period of our arrival at the Island, the heaviest storage of
the Pequod had been almost completed; comprising her beef, bread,
water, fuel, and iron hoops and staves.
BEG_SENT But, as before hinted, for
some time there was a continual fetching and carrying on board of
divers odds and ends of things, both large and small.
BEG_SENT Chief among those who did this fetching and carrying was Captain
Bildad's sister, a lean old lady of a most determined and
indefatigable spirit, but withal very kindhearted, who seemed
resolved that, if she could help it, nothing should be found wanting
in the Pequod, after once fairly getting to sea.
BEG_SENT At one time she
would come on board with a jar of pickles for the steward's pantry;
another time with a bunch of quills for the chief mate's desk, where
he kept his log; a third time with a roll of flannel for the small of
some one's rheumatic back.
BEG_SENT Never did any woman better deserve her
name, which was Charity- Aunt Charity, as everybody called her.
BEG_SENT And
like a sister of charity did this charitable Aunt Charity bustle
about hither and thither, ready to turn her hand and heart to
anything that promised to yield safety, comfort, and consolation to
all on board a ship in which her beloved brother Bildad was
concerned, and in which she herself owned a score or two of
well-saved dollars.
BEG_SENT But it was startling to see this excellent hearted Quakeress coming
on board, as she did the last day, with a long oil-ladle in one hand,
and still longer whaling lance in the other.
BEG_SENT Nor was Bildad himself
nor Captain Peleg at all backward.
BEG_SENT As for Bildad, he carried about
with him a long list of the articles needed, and at every fresh
arrival, down went his mark opposite that article upon the
paper.
BEG_SENT Every once in a while Peleg came hobbling out of his whalebone
den, roaring at the men down the hatchways, roaring up to the riggers
at the mast-head, and then concluded by roaring back into his wigwam.
BEG_SENT During these days of preparation, Queequeg and I often visited the
craft, and as often I asked about Captain Ahab, and how he was, and
when he was going to come on board his ship.
BEG_SENT To these questions they
would answer, that he was getting better and better, and was expected
aboard every day; meantime, the two captains, Peleg and Bildad, could
attend to everything necessary to fit the vessel for the voyage.
BEG_SENT If I
had been downright honest with myself, I would have seen very plainly
in my heart that I did but half fancy being committed this way to so
long a voyage, without once laying my eyes on the man who was to be
absolute dictator of it, so soon as the ship sailed out upon the open
sea.
BEG_SENT But when a man suspects any wrong, it sometimes happens that if
he be already involved in the matter, he insensibly strives to cover
up his suspicions even from himself.
BEG_SENT And much this way it was with
me.
BEG_SENT I said nothing, and tried to think nothing.
BEG_SENT At last it was given out that some time next day the ship would
certainly sail.
BEG_SENT So next morning, Queequeg and I took a very early
start.
BEG_SENT Going Aboard


It was nearly six o'clock, but only grey imperfect misty dawn, when
we drew nigh the wharf.
BEG_SENT "There are some sailors running ahead there, if I see right," said I
to Queequeg, "it can't be shadow; she's off by sunrise, I guess; come
on!"
BEG_SENT "Avast!"
BEG_SENT cried a voice, whose owner at the same time coming close
behind us, laid a hand upon both our shoulders, and then insinuating
himself between us, stood stooping forward a little, in the uncertain
twilight, strangely peering from Queequeg to me.
BEG_SENT It was Elijah.
BEG_SENT "Going aboard?"
BEG_SENT "Hands off, will you," said I.
BEG_SENT "Lookee here," said Queequeg, shaking himself, "go 'way!"
BEG_SENT "Aint going aboard, then?"
BEG_SENT "Yes, we are," said I, "but what business is that of yours?
BEG_SENT Do you
know, Mr. Elijah, that I consider you a little impertinent?"
BEG_SENT "No, no, no; I wasn't aware of that," said Elijah, slowly and
wonderingly looking from me to Queequeg, with the most unaccountable
glances.
BEG_SENT "Elijah," said I, "you will oblige my friend and me by
withdrawing.
BEG_SENT We are going to the Indian and Pacific Oceans, and would
prefer not to be detained."
BEG_SENT "Ye be, be ye?
BEG_SENT Coming back afore breakfast?"
BEG_SENT "He's cracked, Queequeg," said I, "come on."
BEG_SENT "Holloa!"
BEG_SENT cried stationary Elijah, hailing us when we had removed a
few paces.
BEG_SENT "Never mind him," said I, "Queequeg, come on."
BEG_SENT But he stole up to us again, and suddenly clapping his hand on my
shoulder, said- "Did ye see anything looking like men going towards
that ship a while ago?"
BEG_SENT Struck by this plain matter-of-fact question, I answered, saying,
"Yes, I thought I did see four or five men; but it was too dim to be
sure."
BEG_SENT "Very dim, very dim," said Elijah.
BEG_SENT "Morning to ye."
BEG_SENT Once more we quitted him; but once more he came softly after us; and
touching my shoulder again, said, "See if you can find 'em now, will
ye?
BEG_SENT "Find who?"
BEG_SENT "Morning to ye!
BEG_SENT morning to ye!"
BEG_SENT he rejoined, again moving off.
BEG_SENT "Oh!
BEG_SENT I
was going to warn ye against- but never mind, never mind- it's all
one, all in the family too;- sharp frost this morning, ain't it?
BEG_SENT Good-bye to ye.
BEG_SENT Shan't see ye again very soon, I guess; unless it's
before the Grand Jury."
BEG_SENT And with these cracked words he finally
departed, leaving me, for the moment, in no small wonderment at his
frantic impudence.
BEG_SENT At last, stepping on board the Pequod, we found everything in
profound quiet, not a soul moving.
BEG_SENT The cabin entrance was locked
within; the hatches were all on, and lumbered with coils of
rigging.
BEG_SENT Going forward to the forecastle, we found the slide of the
scuttle open.
BEG_SENT Seeing a light, we went down, and found only an old
rigger there, wrapped in a tattered pea-jacket.
BEG_SENT He was thrown at
whole length upon two chests, his face downwards and inclosed in his
folded arms.
BEG_SENT The profoundest slumber slept upon him.
BEG_SENT "Those sailors we saw, Queequeg, where can they have gone to?"
BEG_SENT said
I, looking dubiously at the sleeper.
BEG_SENT But it seemed that, when on the
wharf, Queequeg had not at all noticed what I now alluded to; hence I
would have thought myself to have been optically deceived in that
matter, were it not for Elijah's otherwise inexplicable question.
BEG_SENT But
I beat the thing down; and again marking the sleeper, jocularly
hinted to Queequeg that perhaps we had best sit up with the body;
telling him to establish himself accordingly.
BEG_SENT He put his hand upon
the sleeper's rear, as though feeling if it was soft enough; and
then, without more ado, sat quietly down there.
BEG_SENT "Gracious!
BEG_SENT Queequeg, don't sit there," said I.
BEG_SENT "Oh; perry dood seat," said Queequeg, "my country way; won't hurt him
face."
BEG_SENT "Face!"
BEG_SENT said I, "call that his face?
BEG_SENT very benevolent countenance
then; but how hard he breathes, he's heaving himself; get off,
Queequeg, you are heavy, it's grinding the face of the poor.
BEG_SENT Get off,
Queequeg!
BEG_SENT Look, he'll twitch you off soon.
BEG_SENT I wonder he don't wake."
BEG_SENT Queequeg removed himself to just beyond the head of the sleeper, and
lighted his tomahawk pipe.
BEG_SENT I sat at the feet.
BEG_SENT We kept the pipe
passing over the sleeper, from one to the other.
BEG_SENT Meanwhile, upon
questioning him in his broken fashion, Queequeg gave me to understand
that, in his land, owing to the absence of settees and sofas of all
sorts, the king, chiefs, and great people generally, were in the
custom of fattening some of the lower orders for ottomans; and to
furnish a house comfortably in that respect, you had only to buy up
eight or ten lazy fellows, and lay them around in the piers and
alcoves.
BEG_SENT Besides, it was very convenient on an excursion; much
better than those garden-chairs which are convertible into walking
sticks; upon occasion, a chief calling his attendant, and desiring
him to make a settee of himself under a spreading tree, perhaps in
some damp marshy place.
BEG_SENT While narrating these things, every time Queequeg received the
tomahawk from me, he flourished the hatchet-side of it over the
sleeper's head.
BEG_SENT "What's that for, Queequeg?"
BEG_SENT "Perry easy, kill-e; oh!
BEG_SENT perry easy!
BEG_SENT He was going on with some wild reminiscences about his tomahawk-pipe
which, it seemed, had in its two uses both brained his foes and
soothed his soul, when we were directly attracted to the sleeping
rigger.
BEG_SENT The strong vapor now completely filling the contracted hole,
it began to tell upon him.
BEG_SENT He breathed with a sort of muffledness;
then seemed troubled in the nose; then revolved over once or twice;
then sat up and rubbed his eyes.
BEG_SENT "Holloa!"
BEG_SENT he breathed at last, "who be ye smokers?"
BEG_SENT "Shipped men," answered I, "when does she sail?"
BEG_SENT "Aye, aye, ye are going in her, be ye?
BEG_SENT She sails to-day.
BEG_SENT The Captain
came aboard last night."
BEG_SENT "What Captain?- Ahab?"
BEG_SENT "Who but him indeed?"
BEG_SENT I was going to ask him some further questions concerning Ahab, when
we heard a noise on deck.
BEG_SENT "Holloa!
BEG_SENT Starbuck's astir," said the rigger.
BEG_SENT "He's a lively chief
mate that; good man, and a pious; but all alive now, I must turn to."
BEG_SENT And so saying he went on deck, and we followed.
BEG_SENT It was now clear sunrise.
BEG_SENT Soon the crew came on board in twos and
threes; the riggers bestirred themselves; the mates were actively
engaged; and several of the shore people were busy in bringing
various last things on board.
BEG_SENT Meanwhile Captain Ahab remained
invisibly enshrined within his cabin.
BEG_SENT Merry Christmas


At length, towards noon, upon the final dismissal of the ship's
riggers, and after the Pequod had been hauled out from the wharf, and
after the ever-thoughtful Charity had come off in a whale-boat, with
her last gift- a nightcap for Stubb, the second mate, her
brother-in-law, and a spare Bible for the steward- after all this,
the two Captains, Peleg and Bildad, issued from the cabin, and
turning to the chief mate, Peleg said:

"Now, Mr. Starbuck, are you sure everything is right?
BEG_SENT Captain Ahab is
all ready- just spoke to him- nothing more to be got from shore, eh?
BEG_SENT Well, call all hands, then.
BEG_SENT Muster 'em aft here- blast 'em!"
BEG_SENT "No need of profane words, however great the hurry, Peleg," said
Bildad, "but away with thee, friend Starbuck, and do our bidding."
BEG_SENT How now!
BEG_SENT Here upon the very point of starting for the voyage, Captain
Peleg and Captain Bildad were going it with a high hand on the
quarter-deck, just as if they were to be joint-commanders at sea, as
well as to all appearances in port.
BEG_SENT And, as for Captain Ahab, no sign
of him was yet to be seen; only, they said he was in the cabin.
BEG_SENT But
then, the idea was, that his presence was by no means necessary in
getting the ship under weigh, and steering her well out to
sea.
BEG_SENT Indeed, as that was not at all his proper business, but the
pilot's; and as he was not yet completely recovered- so they said-
therefore, Captain Ahab stayed below.
BEG_SENT And all this seemed natural
enough; especially as in the merchant service many captains never
show themselves on deck for a considerable time after heaving up the
anchor, but remain over the cabin table, having a farewell
merry-making with their shore friends, before they quit the ship for
good with the pilot.
BEG_SENT But there was not much chance to think over the matter, for Captain
Peleg was now all alive.
BEG_SENT He seemed to do most of the talking and
commanding, and not Bildad.
BEG_SENT "Aft here, ye sons of bachelors," he cried, as the sailors lingered
at the main-mast.
BEG_SENT "Mr. Starbuck, drive aft."
BEG_SENT "Strike the tent there!
BEG_SENT "- was the next order.
BEG_SENT As I hinted before,
this whalebone marquee was never pitched except in port; and on board
the Pequod, for thirty years, the order to strike the tent was well
known to be the next thing to heaving up the anchor.
BEG_SENT "Man the capstan!
BEG_SENT Blood and thunder!- jump!
BEG_SENT "- was the next command,
and the crew sprang for the handspikes.
BEG_SENT Now in getting under weigh, the station generally occupied by the
pilot is the forward part of the ship.
BEG_SENT And here Bildad, who, with
Peleg, be it known, in addition to his other officers, was one of the
licensed pilots of the port- he being suspected to have got himself
made a pilot in order to save the Nantucket pilot-fee to all the
ships he was concerned in, for he never piloted any other craft-
Bildad, I say, might now be seen actively engaged in looking over the
bows for the approaching anchor, and at intervals singing what seemed
a dismal stave of psalmody, to cheer the hands at the windlass, who
roared forth some sort of chorus about the girls in Booble Alley,
with hearty good will.
BEG_SENT Nevertheless, not three days previous, Bildad
had told them that no profane songs would be allowed on board the
Pequod, particularly in getting under weigh; and Charity, his sister,
had placed a small choice copy of Watts in each seaman's berth.
BEG_SENT Meantime, overseeing the other part of the ship, Captain Peleg ripped
and swore astern in the most frightful manner.
BEG_SENT I almost thought he
would sink the ship before the anchor could be got up; involuntarily
I paused on my handspike, and told Queequeg to do the same, thinking
of the perils we both ran, in starting on the voyage with such a
devil for a pilot.
BEG_SENT I was comforting myself, however, with the thought
that in pious Bildad might be found some salvation, spite of his
seven hundred and seventy-seventh lay; when I felt a sudden sharp
poke in my rear, and turning round, was horrified at the apparition
of Captain Peleg in the art of withdrawing his leg from my immediate
vicinity.
BEG_SENT That was my first kick.
BEG_SENT "Is that the way they heave in the marchant service?"
BEG_SENT he roared.
BEG_SENT "Spring, thou sheep-head; spring, and break thy backbone!
BEG_SENT Why don't
ye spring, I say, all of ye- spring!
BEG_SENT Quohog!
BEG_SENT spring, thou chap with
the red whiskers; spring there, Scotch-cap; spring, thou green
pants.
BEG_SENT Spring, I say, all of ye, and spring your eyes out!"
BEG_SENT And so
saying, he moved along the windlass, here and there using his leg
very freely, while imperturbable Bildad kept leading off with his
psalmody.
BEG_SENT Thinks I, Captain Peleg must have been drinking something
to-day.
BEG_SENT At last the anchor was up, the sails were set, and off we glided.
BEG_SENT It
was a short, cold Christmas; and as the short northern day merged
into night, we found ourselves almost broad upon the wintry ocean,
whose freezing spray cased us in ice, as in polished armor.
BEG_SENT The long
rows of teeth on the bulwarks glistened in the moonlight; and like
the white ivory tusks of some huge elephant, vast curving icicles
depended from the bows.
BEG_SENT Lank Bildad, as pilot, headed the first watch, and ever and anon, as
the old craft deep dived into the green seas, and sent the shivering
frost all over her, and the winds howled, and the cordage rang, his
steady notes were heard,-

              "Sweet fields beyond the swelling flood,
                   Stand dressed in living green.
BEG_SENT So to the Jews old Canaan stood,
                    While Jordan rolled between."
BEG_SENT Never did those sweet words sound more sweetly to me than then.
BEG_SENT They
were full of hope and fruition.
BEG_SENT Spite of this frigid winter night in
the boisterous Atlantic, spite of my wet feet and wetter jacket,
there was yet, it then seemed to me, many a pleasant haven in store;
and meads and glades so eternally vernal, that the grass shot up by
the spring, untrodden, unwilted, remains at midsummer.
BEG_SENT At last we gained such an offing, that the two pilots were needed no
longer.
BEG_SENT The stout sail-boat that had accompanied us began ranging
alongside.
BEG_SENT It was curious and not unpleasing, how Peleg and Bildad were affected
at this juncture, especially Captain Bildad.
BEG_SENT For loath to depart,
yet; very loath to leave, for good, a ship bound on so long and
perilous a voyage- beyond both stormy Capes; a ship in which some
thousands of his hardearned dollars were invested; a ship, in which
an old shipmate sailed as captain; a man almost as old as he, once
more starting to encounter all the terrors of the pitiless jaw; loath
to say good-bye to a thing so every way brimful of every interest to
him,- poor old Bildad lingered long; paced the deck with anxious
strides; ran down into the cabin to speak another farewell word
there; again came on deck, and looked to windward; looked towards the
wide and endless waters, only bound by the far-off unseen Eastern
Continents; looked towards the land; looked aloft; looked right and
left; looked everywhere and nowhere; and at last, mechanically
coiling a rope upon its pin, convulsively grasped stout Peleg by the
hand, and holding up a lantern, for a moment stood gazing heroically
in his face, as much as to say, "Nevertheless, friend Peleg, I can
stand it; yes, I can."
BEG_SENT As for Peleg himself, he took it more like a philosopher; but for all
his philosophy, there was a tear twinkling in his eye, when the
lantern came too near.
BEG_SENT And he, too, did not a little run from the
cabin to deck- now a word below, and now a word with Starbuck, the
chief mate.
BEG_SENT But, at last, he turned to his comrade, with a final sort of look
about him,- "Captain Bildad- come, old shipmate, we must go.
BEG_SENT Back the
mainyard there!
BEG_SENT Boat ahoy!
BEG_SENT Stand by to come close alongside, now!
BEG_SENT Careful, careful!- come, Bildad, boy- say your last.
BEG_SENT Luck to ye,
Starbuck- luck to ye, Mr. Stubb- luck to ye, Mr. Flask- good-bye and
good luck to ye all- and this day three years I'll have a hot supper
smoking for ye in old Nantucket.
BEG_SENT Hurrah and away!"
BEG_SENT "God bless ye, and have ye in His holy keeping, men," murmured old
Bildad, almost incoherently.
BEG_SENT "I hope ye'll have fine weather now, so
that Captain Ahab may soon be moving among ye- a pleasant sun is all
he needs, and ye'll have plenty of them in the tropic voyage ye
go.
BEG_SENT Be careful in the hunt, ye mates.
BEG_SENT Don't stave the boats
needlessly, ye harpooneers; good white cedar plank is raised full
three per cent within the year.
BEG_SENT Don't forget your prayers,
either.
BEG_SENT Mr. Starbuck, mind that cooper don't waste the spare
staves.
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT the sail-needles are in the green locker.
BEG_SENT Don't whale it
too much a' Lord's days, men; but don't miss a fair chance either,
that's rejecting Heaven's good gifts.
BEG_SENT Have an eye to the molasses
tierce, Mr. Stubb; it was a little leaky, I thought.
BEG_SENT If ye touch at
the islands, Mr. Flask, beware of fornication.
BEG_SENT Good-bye, good-bye!
BEG_SENT Don't keep that cheese too long down in the hold, Mr. Starbuck; it'll
spoil.
BEG_SENT Be careful with the butter- twenty cents the pound it was, and
mind ye, if--"

"Come, come, Captain Bildad; stop palavering,- away!"
BEG_SENT and with that,
Peleg hurried him over the side, and both dropt into the boat.
BEG_SENT Ship and boat diverged; the cold, damp night breeze blew between; a
screaming gull flew overhead; the two hulls wildly rolled; we gave
three heavy-hearted cheers, and blindly plunged like fate into the
lone Atlantic.
BEG_SENT The Lee Shore


Some chapters back, one Bulkington was spoken of, a tall, newlanded
mariner, encountered in New Bedford at the inn.
BEG_SENT When on that shivering winter's night, the Pequod thrust her
vindictive bows into the cold malicious waves, who should I see
standing at her helm but Bulkington!
BEG_SENT I looked with sympathetic awe
and fearfulness upon the man, who in mid-winter just landed from a
four years' dangerous voyage, could so unrestingly push off again for
still another tempestuous term.
BEG_SENT The land seemed scorching to his
feet.
BEG_SENT Wonderfullest things are ever the unmentionable; deep memories
yield no epitaphs; this six-inch chapter is the stoneless grave of
Bulkington.
BEG_SENT Let me only say that it fared with him as with the
storm-tossed ship, that miserably drives along the leeward land.
BEG_SENT The
port would fain give succor; the port is pitiful; in the port is
safety, comfort, hearthstone, supper, warm blankets, friends, all
that's kind to our mortalities.
BEG_SENT But in that gale, the port, the land,
is that ship's direst jeopardy; she must fly all hospitality; one
touch of land, though it but graze the keel, would make her shudder
through and through.
BEG_SENT With all her might she crowds all sail off
shore; in so doing, fights 'gainst the very winds that fain would
blow her homeward; seeks all the lashed sea's landlessness again; for
refuge's sake forlornly rushing into peril; her only friend her
bitterest foe!
BEG_SENT Know ye now, Bulkington?
BEG_SENT Glimpses do ye seem to see of that mortally
intolerable truth; that all deep, earnest thinking is but the
intrepid effort of the soul to keep the open independence of her sea;
while the wildest winds of heaven and earth conspire to cast her on
the treacherous, slavish shore?
BEG_SENT But as in landlessness alone resides highest truth, shoreless,
indefinite as God- so better is it to perish in that howling
infinite, than be ingloriously dashed upon the lee, even if that were
safety!
BEG_SENT For worm-like, then, oh!
BEG_SENT who would craven crawl to land!
BEG_SENT Terrors of the terrible!
BEG_SENT is all this agony so vain?
BEG_SENT Take heart, take
heart, O Bulkington!
BEG_SENT Bear thee grimly, demigod!
BEG_SENT Up from the spray of
thy ocean-perishing- straight up, leaps thy apotheosis!
BEG_SENT The Advocate


As Queequeg and I are now fairly embarked in this business of
whaling; and as this business of whaling has somehow come to be
regarded among landsmen as a rather unpoetical and disreputable
pursuit; therefore, I am all anxiety to convince ye, ye landsmen, of
the injustice hereby done to us hunters of whales.
BEG_SENT In the first place, it may be deemed almost superfluous to establish
the fact, that among people at large, the business of whaling is not
accounted on a level with what are called the liberal professions.
BEG_SENT If
a stranger were introduced into any miscellaneous metropolitan
society, it would but slightly advance the general opinion of his
merits, were he presented to the company as a harpooneer, say; and if
in emulation of the naval officers he should append the initials
S.W.F.
BEG_SENT (Sperm Whale Fishery) to his visting card, such a procedure
would be deemed preeminently presuming and ridiculous.
BEG_SENT Doubtless one leading reason why the world declines honoring us
whalemen, is this: they think that, at best, our vocation amounts to
a butchering sort of business; and that when actively engaged
therein, we are surrounded by all manner of defilements.
BEG_SENT Butchers we
are, that is true.
BEG_SENT But butchers, also, and butchers of the bloodiest
badge have been all Martial Commanders whom the world invariably
delights to honor.
BEG_SENT And as for the matter of the alleged uncleanliness
of our business, ye shall soon be initiated into certain facts
hitherto pretty generally unknown, and which, upon the whole, will
triumphantly plant the sperm whale-ship at least among the cleanliest
things of this tidy earth.
BEG_SENT But even granting the charge in question
to be true; what disordered slippery decks of a whale-ship are
comparable to the unspeakable carrion of those battle-fields from
which so many soldiers return to drink in all ladies' plaudits?
BEG_SENT And
if the idea of peril so much enhances the popular conceit of the
soldier's profession; let me assure ye that many a veteran who has
freely marched up to a battery, would quickly recoil at the
apparition of the sperm whale's vast tail, fanning into eddies the
air over his head.
BEG_SENT For what are the comprehensible terrors of man
compared with the interlinked terrors and wonders of God!
BEG_SENT But, though the world scouts at us whale hunters, yet does it
unwittingly pay us the profoundest homage; yea, an all-abounding
adoration!
BEG_SENT for almost all the tapers, lamps, and candles that burn
round the globe, burn, as before so many shrines, to our glory!
BEG_SENT But look at this matter in other lights; weigh it in all sorts of
scales; see what we whalemen are, and have been.
BEG_SENT Why did the Dutch in De Witt's time have admirals of their whaling
fleets?
BEG_SENT Why did Louis XVI of France, at his own personal expense, fit
out whaling ships from Dunkirk, and politely invite to that town some
score or two of families from our own island of Nantucket?
BEG_SENT Why did
Britain between the years 1750 and 1788 pay to her whalemen in
bounties upwards of L1,000,000?
BEG_SENT And lastly, how comes it that we
whalemen of America now outnumber all the rest of the banded whalemen
in the world; sail a navy of upwards of seven hundred vessels; manned
by eighteen thousand men; yearly consuming 4,000,000 of dollars; the
ships worth, at the time of sailing, $20,000,000!
BEG_SENT and every year
importing into our harbors a well reaped harvest of $7,000,000.
BEG_SENT How
comes all this, if there be not something puissant in whaling?
BEG_SENT But this is not the half; look again.
BEG_SENT I freely assert, that the cosmopolite philosopher cannot, for his
life, point out one single peaceful influence, which within the last
sixty years has operated more potentially upon the whole broad world,
taken in one aggregate, than the high and mighty business of
whaling.
BEG_SENT One way and another, it has begotten events so remarkable in
themselves, and so continuously momentous in their sequential issues,
that whaling may well be regarded as that Egyptian mother, who bore
offspring themselves pregnant from her womb.
BEG_SENT It would be a hopeless,
endless task to catalogue all these things.
BEG_SENT Let a handful
suffice.
