BEG_SENT For many years past the whale-ship has been the pioneer in
ferreting out the remotest and least known parts of the earth.
BEG_SENT She
has explored seas and archipelagoes which had no chart, where no
Cooke or Vancouver had ever sailed.
BEG_SENT If American and European
men-of-war now peacefully ride in once savage harbors, let them fire
salutes to the honor and glory of the whale-ship, which originally
showed them the way, and first interpreted between them and the
savages.
BEG_SENT They may celebrate as they will the heroes of Exploring
Expeditions, your Cookes, your Krusensterns; but I say that scores of
anonymous Captains have sailed out of Nantucket, that were as great,
and greater, than your Cooke and your Krusenstern.
BEG_SENT For in their
succorless empty-handedness, they, in the heathenish sharked waters,
and by the beaches of unrecorded, javelin islands, battled with
virgin wonders and terrors that Cooke with all his marines and
muskets would not have willingly dared.
BEG_SENT All that is made such a
flourish of in the old South Sea Voyages, those things were but the
life-time commonplaces of our heroic Nantucketers.
BEG_SENT Often, adventures
which Vancouver dedicates three chapters to, these men accounted
unworthy of being set down in the ship's common log.
BEG_SENT Ah, the world!
BEG_SENT Oh, the world!
BEG_SENT Until the whale fishery rounded Cape Horn, no commerce but colonial,
scarcely any intercourse but colonial, was carried on between Europe
and the long line of the opulent Spanish provinces on the Pacific
coast.
BEG_SENT It was the whalemen who first broke through the jealous policy
of the Spanish crown, touching those colonies; and, if space
permitted, it might be distinctly shown how from those whalemen at
last eventuated the liberation of Peru, Chili, and Bolivia from the
yoke of Old Spain, and the establishment of the eternal democracy in
those parts.
BEG_SENT That great America on the other side of the sphere, Australia, was
given to the enlightened world by whaleman.
BEG_SENT After its first
blunder-born discovery by a Dutchman, all other ships, long shunned
those shores as pestiferously barbarous; but the whale-ship touched
there.
BEG_SENT The whale-ship is the true mother of that now mighty
colony.
BEG_SENT Moreover, in the infancy of the first Australian settlement,
the emigrants were several times saved from starvation by the
benevolent biscuit of the whale-ship luckily dropping an anchor in
their waters.
BEG_SENT The uncounted isles of all Polynesia confess the same
truth, and do commercial homage to the whale-ship, that cleared the
way for the missionary and the merchant, and in many cases carried
the primitive missionaries to their first destinations.
BEG_SENT If that
double-bolted land, Japan, is ever to become hospitable, it is the
whale-ship alone to whom the credit will be due; for already she is
on the threshold.
BEG_SENT But if, in the face of all this, you still declare that whaling has
no aesthetically noble associations connected with it, then am I
ready to shiver fifty lances with you there, and unhorse you with a
split helmet every time.
BEG_SENT The whale has no famous author, and whaling no famous chronicler, you
will say.
BEG_SENT The whale no famous author, and whaling no famous chronicler?
BEG_SENT Who
wrote the first account of our Leviathan?
BEG_SENT Who but mighty Job?
BEG_SENT And who
composed the first narrative of a whaling-voyage?
BEG_SENT Who, but no less a
prince than Alfred the Great, who, with his own royal pen, took down
the words from Other, the Norwegian whale-hunter of those times!
BEG_SENT And
who pronounced our glowing eulogy in Parliament?
BEG_SENT Who, but Edmund
Burke!
BEG_SENT True enough, but then whalemen themselves are poor devils; they have
no good blood in their veins.
BEG_SENT No good blood in their veins?
BEG_SENT They have something better than royal
blood there.
BEG_SENT The grandmother of Benjamin Franklin was Mary Morrel;
afterwards, by marriage, Mary Folger, one of the old settlers of
Nantucket, and the ancestress to a long line of Folgers and
harpooneers- all kith and kin to noble Benjamin- this day darting the
barbed iron from one side of the world to the other.
BEG_SENT Good again; but then all confess that somehow whaling is not
respectable.
BEG_SENT Whaling not respectable?
BEG_SENT Whaling is imperial!
BEG_SENT By old English
statutory law, the whale is declared "a royal fish."
BEG_SENT Oh, that's only nominal!
BEG_SENT The whale himself has never figured in any
grand imposing way.
BEG_SENT The whale never figured in any grand imposing way?
BEG_SENT In one of the
mighty triumphs given to a Roman general upon his entering the
world's capital, the bones of a whale, brought all the way from the
Syrian coast, were the most conspicuous object in the cymballed
procession.
BEG_SENT Grant it, since you cite it; but say what you will, there is no real
dignity in whaling.
BEG_SENT No dignity in whaling?
BEG_SENT The dignity of our calling the very heavens
attest.
BEG_SENT Cetus is a constellation in the south!
BEG_SENT No more!
BEG_SENT Drive down
your hat in presence of the Czar, and take it off to Queequeg!
BEG_SENT No
more!
BEG_SENT I know a man that, in his lifetime has taken three hundred and
fifty whales.
BEG_SENT I account that man more honorable than that great
captain of antiquity who boasted of taking as many walled towns.
BEG_SENT And, as for me, if, by any possibility, there be any as yet
undiscovered prime thing in me; if I shall ever deserve any real
repute in that small but high hushed world which I might not be
unreasonably ambitious of; if hereafter I shall do anything upon the
whole, a man might rather have done than to have left undone; if, at
my death, my executors, or more properly my creditors, find any
precious MSS.
BEG_SENT in my desk, then here I prospectively ascribe all the
honor and the glory to whaling; for a whale-ship was my Yale College
and my Harvard.
BEG_SENT Postscript


In behalf of the dignity of whaling, I would fain advance naught but
substantiated facts.
BEG_SENT But after embattling his facts, an advocate who
should wholly suppress a not unreasonable surmise, which might tell
eloquently upon his cause- such an advocate, would he not be
blame-worthy?
BEG_SENT It is well known that at the coronation of kings and queens, even
modern ones, a certain curious process of seasoning them for their
functions is gone through.
BEG_SENT There is a saltcellar of state, so called,
and there may be a castor of state.
BEG_SENT How they use the salt, precisely-
who knows?
BEG_SENT Certain I am, however, that a king's head is solemnly
oiled at his coronation, even as a head of salad.
BEG_SENT Can it be, though,
that they anoint it with a view of making its interior run well, as
they anoint machinery?
BEG_SENT Much might be ruminated here, concerning the
essential dignity of this regal process, because in common life we
esteem but meanly and contemptibly a fellow who anoints his hair, and
palpably smells of that anointing.
BEG_SENT In truth, a mature man who uses
hairoil, unless medicinally, that man has probably got a quoggy spot
in him somewhere.
BEG_SENT As a general rule, he can't amount to much in his
totality.
BEG_SENT But the only thing to be considered here is this- what kind of oil is
used at coronations?
BEG_SENT Certainly it cannot be olive oil, nor macassar
oil, nor castor oil, nor bear's oil, nor train oil, nor cod-liver
oil.
BEG_SENT What then can it possibly be, but the sperm oil in its
unmanufactured, unpolluted state, the sweetest of all oils?
BEG_SENT Think of that, ye loyal Britons!
BEG_SENT we whalemen supply your kings and
queens with coronation stuff!
BEG_SENT Knights and Squires


The chief mate of the Pequod was Starbuck, a native of Nantucket, and
a Quaker by descent.
BEG_SENT He was a long, earnest man, and though born on
an icy coast, seemed well adapted to endure hot latitudes, his flesh
being hard as twice-baked biscuit.
BEG_SENT Transported to the Indies, his
live blood would not spoil like bottled ale.
BEG_SENT He must have been born
in some time of general drought and famine, or upon one of those fast
days for which his state is famous.
BEG_SENT Only some thirty and summers had
he seen; those summers had dried up all his physical
superfluousness.
BEG_SENT But this, his thinness, so to speak, seemed no more
the token of wasting anxieties and cares, than it seemed the
indication of any bodily blight.
BEG_SENT It was merely the condensation of
the man.
BEG_SENT He was by no means ill-looking; quite the contrary.
BEG_SENT His
pure tight skin was an excellent fit; and closely wrapped up in it,
and embalmed with inner health and strength, like a revivified
Egyptian, this Starbuck seemed prepared to endure for long ages to
come, and to endure always, as now; for be it Polar snow or torrid
sun, like a patent chronometer, his interior vitality was warranted
to do well in all climates.
BEG_SENT Looking into his eves, you seemed to see
there the yet lingering images of those thousand-fold perils he had
calmly confronted through life.
BEG_SENT A staid, steadfast man, whose life
for the most part was a telling pantomime of action, and not a tame
chapter of sounds.
BEG_SENT Yet, for all his hardy sobriety and fortitude,
there were certain qualities in him which at times affected, and in
some cases seemed well nigh to overbalance all the rest.
BEG_SENT Uncommonly
conscientious for a seaman, and endued with a deep natural reverence,
the wild watery loneliness of his life did therefore strongly incline
him to superstition; but to that sort of superstition, which in some
organization seems rather to spring, somehow, from intelligence than
from ignorance.
BEG_SENT Outward portents and inward presentiments were his.
BEG_SENT And if at times these things bent the welded iron of his soul, much
more did his far-away domestic memories of his young Cape wife and
child, tend to bend him still more from the original ruggedness of
his nature, and open him still further to those latent influences
which, in some honest-hearted men, restrain the gush of dare-devil
daring, so often evinced by others in the more perilous vicissitudes
of the fishery.
BEG_SENT "I will have no man in my boat," said Starbuck, "who
is not afraid of a whale."
BEG_SENT By this, he seemed to mean, not only that
the most reliable and useful courage was that which arises from the
fair estimation of the encountered peril, but that an utterly
fearless man is a far more dangerous comrade than a coward.
BEG_SENT "Aye, aye," said Stubb, the second mate, "Starbuck, there, is as
careful a man as you'll find anywhere in this fishery."
BEG_SENT But we shall
ere long see what that word "careful" precisely means when used by a
man like Stubb, or almost any other whale hunter.
BEG_SENT Starbuck was no crusader after perils; in him courage was not a
sentiment; but a thing simply useful to him, and always at hand upon
all mortally practical occasions.
BEG_SENT Besides, he thought, perhaps, that
in this business of whaling, courage was one of the great staple
outfits of the ship, like her beef and her bread, and not to be
foolishly wasted.
BEG_SENT Wherefore he had no fancy for lowering for whales
after sun-down; nor for persisting in fighting a fish that too much
persisted in fighting him.
BEG_SENT For, thought Starbuck, I am here in this
critical ocean to kill whales for my living, and not to be killed by
them for theirs; and that hundreds of men had been so killed Starbuck
well knew.
BEG_SENT What doom was his own father's?
BEG_SENT Where, in the bottomless
deeps, could he find the torn limbs of his brother?
BEG_SENT With memories like these in him, and, moreover, given to a certain
superstitiousness, as has been said; the courage of this Starbuck,
which could, nevertheless, still flourish, must indeed have been
extreme.
BEG_SENT But it was not in reasonable nature that a man so organized,
and with such terrible experiences and remembrances as he had; it was
not in nature that these things should fail in latently engendering
an element in him, which, under suitable circumstances, would break
out from its confinement, and burn all his courage up.
BEG_SENT And brave as
he might be, it was that sort of bravery chiefly, visible in some
intrepid men, which, while generally abiding firm in the conflict
with seas, or winds, or whales, or any of the ordinary irrational
horrors of the world, yet cannot withstand those more terrific,
because more spiritual terrors, which sometimes menace you from the
concentrating brow of an enraged and mighty man.
BEG_SENT But were the coming narrative to reveal in any instance, the complete
abasement of poor Starbuck's fortitude, scarce might I have the heart
to write it; but it is a thing most sorrowful, nay shocking, to
expose the fall of valor in the soul.
BEG_SENT Men may seem detestable as
joint stock-companies and nations; knaves, fools, and murderers there
may be; men may have mean and meagre faces; but, man, in the ideal,
is so noble and so sparkling, such a grand and glowing creature, that
over any ignominious blemish in him all his fellows should run to
throw their costliest robes.
BEG_SENT That immaculate manliness we feel within
ourselves, so far within us, that it remains intact though all the
outer character seem gone; bleeds with keenest anguish at the
undraped spectacle of a valor-ruined man.
BEG_SENT Nor can piety itself, at
such a shameful sight, completely stifle her upbraidings against the
permitting stars.
BEG_SENT But this august dignity I treat of, is not the
dignity of kings and robes, but that abounding dignity which has no
robed investiture.
BEG_SENT Thou shalt see it shining in the arm that wields a
pick or drives a spike; that democratic dignity which, on all hands,
radiates without end from God; Himself!
BEG_SENT The great God absolute!
BEG_SENT The
centre and circumference of all democracy!
BEG_SENT His omnipresence, our
divine equality!
BEG_SENT If, then, to meanest mariners, and renegades and castaways, I shall
hereafter ascribe high qualities, though dark; weave around them
tragic graces; if even the most mournful, perchance the most abased,
among them all, shall at times lift himself to the exalted mounts; if
I shall touch that workman's arm with some ethereal light; if I shall
spread a rainbow over his disastrous set of sun; then against all
mortal critics bear me out in it, thou just Spirit of Equality, which
hast spread one royal mantle of humanity over all my kind!
BEG_SENT Bear me
out in it, thou great democratic God!
BEG_SENT who didst not refuse to the
swart convict, Bunyan, the pale, poetic pearl; Thou who didst clothe
with doubly hammered leaves of finest gold, the stumped and paupered
arm of old Cervantes; Thou who didst pick up Andrew Jackson from the
pebbles; who didst hurl him upon a war-horse; who didst thunder him
higher than a throne!
BEG_SENT Thou who, in all Thy mighty, earthly marchings,
ever cullest Thy selectest champions from the kingly commoners; bear
me out in it, O God!
BEG_SENT Knights and Squires


Stubb was the second mate.
BEG_SENT He was a native of Cape Cod; and hence,
according to local usage, was called a Cape-Cod-man.
BEG_SENT A
happy-go-lucky; neither craven nor valiant; taking perils as they
came with an indifferent air; and while engaged in the most imminent
crisis of the chase, toiling away, calm and collected as a journeyman
joiner engaged for the year.
BEG_SENT Good-humored, easy, and careless, he
presided over his whaleboat as if the most deadly encounter were but
a dinner, and his crew all invited guests.
BEG_SENT He was as particular about
the comfortable arrangements of his part of the boat, as an old
stage-driver is about the snugness of his box.
BEG_SENT When close to the
whale, in the very death-lock of the fight, he handled his unpitying
lance coolly and off-handedly, as a whistling tinker his hammer.
BEG_SENT He
would hum over his old rigadig tunes while flank and flank with the
most exasperated monster.
BEG_SENT Long usage had, for this Stubb, converted
the jaws of death into an easy chair.
BEG_SENT What he thought of death
itself, there is no telling.
BEG_SENT Whether he ever thought of it at all,
might be a question; but, if he ever did chance to cast his mind that
way after a comfortable dinner, no doubt, like a good sailor, he took
it to be a sort of call of the watch to tumble aloft, and bestir
themselves there, about something which he would find out when he
obeyed the order, and not sooner.
BEG_SENT What, perhaps, with other things, made Stubb such an easy-going,
unfearing man, so cheerily trudging off with the burden of life in a
world fail of grave peddlers, all bowed to the ground with their
packs; what helped to bring about that almost impious good-humor of
his; that thing must have been his pipe.
BEG_SENT For, like his nose, his
short, black little pipe was one of the regular features of his
face.
BEG_SENT You would almost as soon have expected him to turn out of his
bunk without his nose as without his pipe.
BEG_SENT He kept a whole row of
pipes there ready loaded, stuck in a rack, within easy reach of his
hand; and, whenever he turned in, he smoked them all out in
succession, lighting one from the other to the end of the chapter;
then loading them again to be in readiness anew.
BEG_SENT For, when Stubb
dressed, instead of first putting his legs into his trowsers, he put
his pipe into his mouth.
BEG_SENT I say this continual smoking must have been one cause, at least of
his peculiar disposition; for every one knows that this early air,
whether ashore or afloat, is terribly infected with the nameless
miseries of the numberless mortals who have died exhaling it; and as
in time of the cholera, some people go about with a camphorated
handkerchief to their mouths; so, likewise, against all mortal
tribulations, Stubb's tobacco smoke might have operated as a sort of
disinfecting agent.
BEG_SENT The third mate was Flask, a native of Tisbury, in Martha's
Vineyard.
BEG_SENT A short, stout, ruddy young fellow, very pugnacious
concerning whales, who somehow seemed to think that the great
Leviathans had personally and hereditarily affronted him; and
therefore it was a sort of point of honor with him, to destroy them
whenever encountered.
BEG_SENT So utterly lost was he to all sense of
reverence for the many marvels of their majestic bulk and mystic
ways; and so dead to anything like an apprehension of any possible
danger encountering them; that in his poor opinion, the wondrous
whale was but a species of magnified mouse, or at least water-rat,
requiring only a little circumvention and some small application of
time and trouble in order to kill and boil.
BEG_SENT This ignorant,
unconscious fearlessness of his made him a little waggish in the
matter of whales; he followed these fish for the fun of it; and a
three years' voyage round Cape Horn was only a jolly joke that lasted
that length of time.
BEG_SENT As a carpenter's nails are divided into wrought
nails and cut nails; so mankind may be similarly divided.
BEG_SENT Little
Flask was one of the wrought ones; made to clinch tight and last
long.
BEG_SENT They called him King-Post on board of the Pequod; because, in
form, he could be well likened to the short, square timber known by
that name in Arctic whalers; and which by the means of many radiating
side timbers inserted into it, serves to brace the ship against the
icy concussions of those battering seas.
BEG_SENT Now these three mates- Starbuck, Stubb and Flask, were momentous
men.
BEG_SENT They was who by universal prescription commanded three of the
Pequod's boats as headsmen.
BEG_SENT In that grand order of battle in which
Captain Ahab would probably marshal his forces to descend on the
whales, these three headsmen were as captains of companies.
BEG_SENT Or, being
armed with their long keen whaling spears, they were as a picked trio
of lancers; even as the harpooneers were flingers of javelins.
BEG_SENT And since in this famous fishery, each mate or headsman, like a
Gothic Knight of old, is always accompanied by his boat-steerer or
harpooneer, who in certain conjunctures provides him with a fresh
lance, when the former one has been badly twisted, or elbowed in the
assault; and moreover, as there generally subsists between the two, a
close intimacy and friendliness; it is therefore but meet, that in
this place we set down who the Pequod's harpooneers were, and to what
headsman each of them belonged.
BEG_SENT First of all was Queequeg, whom Starbuck, the chief mate, had
selected for his squire.
BEG_SENT But Queequeg is already known.
BEG_SENT Next was Tashtego, an unmixed Indian from Gay Head, the most westerly
promontory of Martha's Vineyard, where there still exists the last
remnant of a village of red men, which has long supplied the
neighboring island of Nantucket with many of her most daring
harpooneers.
BEG_SENT In the fishery, they usually go by the generic name of
Gay-Headers.
BEG_SENT Tashtego's long, lean, sable hair, his high cheek
bones, and black rounding eyes- for an Indian, Oriental in their
largeness, but Antarctic in their glittering expression- all this
sufficiently proclaimed him an inheritor of the unvitiated blood of
those proud warrior hunters, who, in quest of the great New England
moose, had scoured, bow in hand, the aboriginal forests of the
main.
BEG_SENT But no longer snuffing in the trail of the wild beasts of the
woodland, Tashtego now hunted in the wake of the great whales of the
sea; the unerring harpoon of the son fitly replacing the infallible
arrow of the sires.
BEG_SENT To look at the tawny brawn of his lithe snaky
limbs, you would almost have credited the superstitions of some of
the earlier Puritans and half-believed this wild Indian to be a son
of the Prince of the Powers of the Air.
BEG_SENT Tashtego was Stubb the second
mate's squire.
BEG_SENT Third among the harpooneers was Daggoo, a gigantic, coal-black
negro-savage, with a lion-like tread- an Ahasuerus to
behold.
BEG_SENT Suspended from his ears were two golden hoops, so large that
the sailors called them ringbolts, and would talk of securing the
top-sail halyards to them.
BEG_SENT In his youth Daggoo had voluntarily
shipped on board of a whaler, lying in a lonely bay on his native
coast.
BEG_SENT And never having been anywhere in the world but in Africa,
Nantucket, and the pagan harbors most frequented by the whalemen; and
having now led for many years the bold life of the fishery in the
ships of owners uncommonly heedful of what manner of men they
shipped; Daggoo retained all his barbaric virtues, and erect as a
giraffe, moved about the decks in all the pomp of six feet five in
his socks.
BEG_SENT There was a corporeal humility in looking up at him; and a
white man standing before him seemed a white flag come to beg truce
of a fortress.
BEG_SENT Curious to tell, this imperial negro, Ahasuerus
Daggoo, was the Squire of little Flask, who looked like a chess-man
beside him.
BEG_SENT As for the residue of the Pequod's company, be it said,
that at the present day not one in two of the many thousand men
before the mast employed in the American whale fishery, are Americans
born, though pretty nearly all the officers are.
BEG_SENT Herein it is the
same with the American whale fishery as with the American army and
military and merchant navies, and the engineering forces employed in
the construction of the American Canals and Railroads.
BEG_SENT The same, I
say, because in all these cases the native American literally
provides the brains, the rest of the world as generously supplying
the muscles.
BEG_SENT No small number of these whaling seamen belong to the
Azores, where the outward bound Nantucket whalers frequently touch to
augment their crews from the hardy peasants of those rocky shores.
BEG_SENT In
like manner, the Greenland whalers sailing out of Hull or London, put
in at the Shetland Islands, to receive the full complement of their
crew.
BEG_SENT Upon the passage homewards, they drop them there again.
BEG_SENT How it
is, there is no telling, but Islanders seem to make the best
whalemen.
BEG_SENT They were nearly all Islanders in the Pequod, Isolatoes
too, I call such, not acknowledging the common continent of men, but
each Isolato living on a separate continent of his own.
BEG_SENT Yet now,
federated along one keel, what a set these Isolatoes were!
BEG_SENT An
Anacharsis Clootz deputation from all the isles of the sea, and all
the ends of the earth, accompanying Old Ahab in the Pequod to lay the
world's grievances before that bar from which not very many of them
ever come back.
BEG_SENT Black Little Pip- he never did- oh, no!
BEG_SENT he went
before.
BEG_SENT Poor Alabama boy!
BEG_SENT On the grim Pequod's forecastle, ye shall
ere long see him, beating his tambourine; prelusive of the eternal
time, when sent for, to the great quarter-deck on high, he was bid
strike in with angels, and beat his tambourine in glory; called a
coward here, hailed a hero there!
BEG_SENT Ahab


For several days after leaving Nantucket, nothing above hatches was
seen of Captain Ahab.
BEG_SENT The mates regularly relieved each other at the
watches, and for aught that could be seen to the contrary, they
seemed to be the only commanders of the ship; only they sometimes
issued from the cabin with orders so sudden and peremptory, that
after all it was plain they but commanded vicariously.
BEG_SENT Yet, their
supreme lord and dictator was there, though hitherto unseen by any
eyes not permitted to penetrate into the now sacred retreat of the
cabin.
BEG_SENT Every time I ascended to the deck from my watches below, I instantly
gazed aft to mark if any strange face was visible; for my first vague
disquietude touching the unknown captain, now in the seclusion of the
sea became almost a perturbation.
BEG_SENT This was strangely heightened at
times by the ragged Elijah's diabolical incoherences uninvitedly
recurring to me, with a subtle energy I could not have before
conceived of.
BEG_SENT But poorly could I withstand them, much as in other
moods I was almost ready to smile at the solemn whimsicalities of
that outlandish prophet of the wharves.
BEG_SENT But whatever it was of
apprehensiveness or uneasiness- to call it so- which I felt, yet
whenever I came to look about me in the ship, it seemed against all
warranty to cherish such emotions.
BEG_SENT For though the harpooneers, with
the great body of the crew, were a far more barbaric, heathenish, and
motley set than any of the tame merchant-ship companies which my
previous experiences had made me acquainted with, still I ascribed
this- and rightly ascribed it- to the fierce uniqueness of the very
nature of that wild Scandinavian vocation in which I had so
abandonedly embarked.
BEG_SENT But it was especially the aspect of the three
chief officers of the ship, the mates, which was most forcibly
calculated to allay these colorless misgivings, and induce confidence
and cheerfulness in every presentment of the voyage.
BEG_SENT Three better,
more likely sea-officers and men, each in his own different way,
could not readily be found, and they were every one of them
Americans; a Nantucketer, a Vineyarder, a Cape man.
BEG_SENT Now, it being
Christmas when the ship shot from out her harbor, for a space we had
biting Polar weather, though all the time running away from it to the
southward; and by every degree and minute of latitude which we
sailed, gradually leaving that merciless winter, and all its
intolerable weather behind us.
BEG_SENT It was one of those less lowering, but
still grey and gloomy enough mornings of the transition, when with a
fair wind the ship was rushing through the water with a vindictive
sort of leaping and melancholy rapidity, that as I mounted to the
deck at the call of the forenoon watch, so soon as I levelled my
glance towards the taffrail, foreboding shivers ran over me.
BEG_SENT Reality
outran apprehension; Captain Ahab stood upon his quarter-deck.
BEG_SENT There seemed no sign of common bodily illness about him, nor of the
recovery from any.
BEG_SENT He looked like a man cut away from the stake,
when the fire has overrunningly wasted all the limbs without
consuming them, or taking away one particle from their compacted aged
robustness.
BEG_SENT His whole high, broad form, seemed made of solid bronze,
and shaped in an unalterable mould, like Cellini's cast
Perseus.
BEG_SENT Threading its way out from among his grey hairs, and
continuing right down one side of his tawny scorched face and neck,
till it disappeared in his clothing, you saw a slender rod-like mark,
lividly whitish.
BEG_SENT It resembled that perpendicular seam sometimes made
in the straight, lofty trunk of a great tree, when the upper
lightning tearingly darts down it, and without wrenching a single
twig, peels and grooves out the bark from top to bottom ere running
off into the soil, leaving the tree still greenly alive, but
branded.
BEG_SENT Whether that mark was born with him, or whether it was the
scar left by some desperate wound, no one could certainly say.
BEG_SENT By
some tacit consent, throughout the voyage little or no allusion was
made to it, especially by the mates.
BEG_SENT But once Tashtego's senior, an
old Gay-Head Indian among the crew, superstitiously asserted that not
till he was full forty years old did Ahab become that way branded,
and then it came upon him, not in the fury of any mortal fray, but in
an elemental strife at sea.
BEG_SENT Yet, this wild hint seemed inferentially
negatived, by what a grey Manxman insinuated, an old sepulchral man,
who, having never before sailed out of Nantucket, had never ere this
laid eye upon wild Ahab.
BEG_SENT Nevertheless, the old sea-traditions, the
immemorial credulities, popularly invested this old Manxman with
preternatural powers of discernment.
BEG_SENT So that no white sailor
seriously contradicted him when he said that if ever Captain Ahab
should be tranquilly laid out- which might hardly come to pass, so he
muttered- then, whoever should do that last office for the dead,
would find a birth-mark on him from crown to sole.
BEG_SENT So powerfully did the whole grim aspect of Ahab affect me, and the
livid brand which streaked it, that for the first few moments I
hardly noted that not a little of this overbearing grimness was owing
to the barbaric white leg upon which he partly stood.
BEG_SENT It had
previously come to me that this ivory leg had at sea been fashioned
from the polished bone of the sperm whale's jaw.
BEG_SENT "Aye, he was
dismasted off Japan," said the old Gay-Head Indian once; "but like
his dismasted craft, he shipped another mast without coming home for
it.
BEG_SENT He has a quiver of 'em."
BEG_SENT I was struck with the singular posture he maintained.
BEG_SENT Upon each side
of the Pequod's quarter deck, and pretty close to the mizzen shrouds,
there was an auger hole, bored about half an inch or so, into the
plank.
BEG_SENT His bone leg steadied in that hole; one arm elevated, and
holding by a shroud; Captain Ahab stood erect, looking straight out
beyond the ship's ever-pitching prow.
BEG_SENT There was an infinity of
firmest fortitude, a determinate, unsurrenderable wilfulness, in the
fixed and fearless, forward dedication of that glance.
BEG_SENT Not a word he
spoke; nor did his officers say aught to him; though by all their
minutest gestures and expressions, they plainly showed the uneasy, if
not painful, consciousness of being under a troubled master-eye.
BEG_SENT And
not only that, but moody stricken Ahab stood before them with a
crucifixion in his face; in all the nameless regal overbearing
dignity of some mighty woe.
BEG_SENT Ere long, from his first visit in the air, he withdrew into his
cabin.
BEG_SENT But after that morning, he was every day visible to the crew;
either standing in his pivot-hole, or seated upon an ivory stool he
had; or heavily walking the deck.
BEG_SENT As the sky grew less gloomy;
indeed, began to grow a little genial, he became still less and less
a recluse; as if, when the ship had sailed from home, nothing but the
dead wintry bleakness of the sea had then kept him so secluded.
BEG_SENT And,
by and by, it came to pass, that he was almost continually in the
air; but, as yet, for all that he said, or perceptibly did, on the at
last sunny deck, he seemed as unnecessary there as another mast.
BEG_SENT But
the Pequod was only making a passage now; not regularly cruising;
nearly all whaling preparatives needing supervision the mates were
fully competent to, so that there was little or nothing, out of
himself, to employ or excite Ahab, now; and thus chase away, for that
one interval, the clouds that layer upon layer were piled upon his
brow, as ever all clouds choose the loftiest peaks to pile themselves
upon.
BEG_SENT Nevertheless, ere long, the warm, warbling persuasiveness of the
pleasant, holiday weather we came to, seemed gradually to charm him
from his mood.
BEG_SENT For, as when the red-cheeked, dancing girls, April and
May, trip home to the wintry, misanthropic woods; even the barest,
ruggedest, most thunder-cloven old oak will at least send forth some
few green sprouts, to welcome such gladhearted visitants; so Ahab
did, in the end, a little respond to the playful allurings of that
girlish air.
BEG_SENT More than once did he put forth the faint blossom of a
look, which, in any other man, would have soon flowered out in a
smile.
BEG_SENT Enter Ahab; to Him, Stubb


Some days elapsed, and ice and icebergs all astern, the Pequod now
went rolling through the bright Quito spring, which at sea, almost
perpetually reigns on the threshold of the eternal August of the
Tropic.
BEG_SENT The warmly cool, clear, ringing perfumed, overflowing,
redundant days, were as crystal goblets of Persian sherbet, heaped
up- flaked up, with rose-water snow.
BEG_SENT The starred and stately nights
seemed haughty dames in jewelled velvets, nursing at home in lonely
pride, the memory of their absent conquering Earls, the golden
helmeted suns!
BEG_SENT For sleeping man, 'twas hard to choose between such
winsome days and such seducing nights.
BEG_SENT But all the witcheries of that
unwaning weather did not merely lend new spells and potencies to the
outward world.
BEG_SENT Inward they turned upon the soul, especially when the
still mild hours of eve came on; then, memory shot her crystals as
the clear ice most forms of noiseless twilights.
BEG_SENT And all these subtle
agencies, more and more they wrought on Ahab's texture.
BEG_SENT Old age is always wakeful; as if, the longer linked with life, the
less man has to do with aught that looks like death.
BEG_SENT Among
sea-commanders, the old greybeards will oftenest leave their berths
to visit the night-cloaked deck.
BEG_SENT It was so with Ahab; only that now,
of late, he seemed so much to live in the open air, that truly
speaking, his visits were more to the cabin, than from the cabin to
the planks.
BEG_SENT "It feels like going down into one's tomb,"- he would
mutter to himself- "for an old captain like me to be descending this
narrow scuttle, to go to my grave-dug berth."
BEG_SENT So, almost every twenty-four hours, when the watches of the night
were set, and the band on deck sentinelled the slumbers of the band
below; and when if a rope was to be hauled upon the forecastle, the
sailors flung it not rudely down, as by day, but with some
cautiousness dropt it to its place for fear of disturbing their
slumbering shipmates; when this sort of steady quietude would begin
to prevail, habitually, the silent steersman would watch the
cabin-scuttle; and ere long the old man would emerge, gripping at the
iron banister, to help his crippled way.
BEG_SENT Some considering touch of
humanity was in him; for at times like these, he usually abstained
from patrolling the quarter-deck; because to his wearied mates,
seeking repose within six inches of his ivory heel, such would have
been the reverberating crack and din of that bony step, that their
dreams would have been on the crunching teeth of sharks.
BEG_SENT But once,
the mood was on him too deep for common regardings; and as with
heavy, lumber-like pace he was measuring the ship from taffrail to
mainmast, Stubb, the old second mate, came up from below, with a
certain unassured, deprecating humorousness, hinted that if Captain
Ahab was pleased to walk the planks, then, no one could say nay; but
there might be some way of muffling the noise; hinting something
indistinctly and hesitatingly about a globe of tow, and the insertion
into it, of the ivory heel.
BEG_SENT Ah!
BEG_SENT Stubb, thou didst not know Ahab then.
BEG_SENT "Am I a cannon-ball, Stubb," said Ahab, "that thou wouldst wad me
that fashion?
BEG_SENT But go thy ways; I had forgot.
BEG_SENT Below to thy nightly
grave; where such as ye sleep between shrouds, to use ye to the
filling one at last.- Down, dog, and kennel!"
BEG_SENT Starting at the unforseen concluding exclamation of the so suddenly
scornful old man, Stubb was speechless a moment; then said excitedly,
"I am not used to be spoken to that way, sir; I do but less than half
like it, sir."
BEG_SENT "Avast!
BEG_SENT gritted Ahab between his set teeth, and violently moving
away, as if to avoid some passionate temptation.
BEG_SENT "No, sir; not yet," said Stubb, emboldened, "I will not tamely be
called a dog, sir."
BEG_SENT "Then be called ten times a donkey, and a mule, and an ass, and
begone, or I'll clear the world of thee!"
BEG_SENT As he said this, Ahab advanced upon him with such overbearing terrors
in his aspect, that Stubb involuntarily retreated.
BEG_SENT "I was never served so before without giving a hard blow for it,"
muttered Stubb, as he found himself descending the
cabin-scuttle.
BEG_SENT "It's very queer.
BEG_SENT Stop, Stubb; somehow, now, I don't
well know whether to go back and strike him, or- what's that?- down
here on my knees and pray for him?
BEG_SENT Yes, that was the thought coming
up in me; but it would be the first time I ever did pray.
BEG_SENT It's queer;
very queer; and he's queer too; aye, take him fore and aft, he's
about the queerest old man Stubb ever sailed with.
BEG_SENT How he flashed at
me!- his eyes like powder-pans!
BEG_SENT is he mad!
BEG_SENT Anyway there's something's
on his mind, as sure as there must be something on a deck when it
cracks.
BEG_SENT He aint in his bed now, either, more than three hours out of
the twenty-four; and he don't sleep then.
BEG_SENT Didn't that Dough-Boy, the
steward, tell me that of a morning he always finds the old man's
hammock clothes all rumpled and tumbled, and the sheets down at the
foot, and the coverlid almost tied into knots, and the pillow a sort
of frightful hot, as though a baked brick had been on it?
BEG_SENT A hot old
man!
BEG_SENT I guess he's got what some folks ashore call a conscience; it's
a kind of Tic-Dolly-row they say- worse nor a toothache.
BEG_SENT Well, well;
I don't know what it is, but the Lord keep me from catching it.
BEG_SENT He's
full of riddles; I wonder what he goes into the after hold for, every
night, as Dough-Boy tells me he suspects; what's that for, I should
like to know?
BEG_SENT Who's made appointments with him in the hold?
BEG_SENT Ain't
that queer, now?
BEG_SENT But there's no telling, it's the old game- Here goes
for a snooze.
BEG_SENT Damn me, it's worth a fellow's while to be born into
the world, if only to fall right asleep.
BEG_SENT And now that I think of it,
that's about the first thing babies do, and that's a sort of queer,
too.
BEG_SENT Damn me, but all things are queer, come to think of 'em.
BEG_SENT But
that's against my principles.
BEG_SENT Think not, is my eleventh commandment;
and sleep when you can, is my twelfth- So here goes again.
BEG_SENT But how's
that?
BEG_SENT didn't he call me a dog?
BEG_SENT blazes!
BEG_SENT he called me ten times a
donkey, and piled a lot of jackasses on top of that!
BEG_SENT He might as well
have kicked me, and done with me.
BEG_SENT Maybe he did kick me, and I didn't
observe it, I was so taken aback with his brow, somehow.
BEG_SENT It flashed
like a bleached bone.
BEG_SENT What the devil's the matter with me?
BEG_SENT I don't
stand right on my legs.
BEG_SENT Coming afoul of that old man has a sort of
turned me wrong side out.
BEG_SENT By the Lord, I must have been dreaming,
though- How?
BEG_SENT how?
BEG_SENT how?- but the only way's to stash it; so here goes
to hammock again; and in the morning, I'll see how this plaguey
juggling thinks over by daylight."
BEG_SENT The Pipe


When Stubb had departed, Ahab stood for a while leaning over the
bulwarks; and then, as had been usual with him of late, calling a
sailor of the watch, he sent him below for his ivory stool, and also
his pipe.
BEG_SENT Lighting the pipe at the binnacle lamp and planting the
stool on the weather side of the deck, he sat and smoked.
BEG_SENT In old Norse times, the thrones of the sea-loving Danish kings were
fabricated, saith tradition, of the tusks of the narwhale.
BEG_SENT How could
one look at Ahab then, seated on that tripod of bones, without
bethinking him of the royalty it symbolized?
BEG_SENT For a Khan of the plank,
and a king of the sea and a great lord of Leviathans was Ahab.
BEG_SENT Some moments passed, during which the thick vapor came from his mouth
in quick and constant puffs, which blew back again into his
face.
BEG_SENT "How now," he soliloquized at last, withdrawing the tube, "this
smoking no longer soothes.
BEG_SENT Oh, my pipe!
BEG_SENT hard must it go with me if
thy charm be gone!
BEG_SENT Here have I been unconsciously toiling, not
pleasuring- aye, and ignorantly smoking to windward all the while; to
windward, and with such nervous whiffs, as if, like the dying whale,
my final jets were the strongest and fullest of trouble.
BEG_SENT What
business have I with this pipe?
BEG_SENT This thing that is meant for
sereneness, to send up mild white vapors among mild white hairs, not
among torn iron-grey locks like mine.
BEG_SENT I'll smoke no more-"

He tossed the still lighted pipe into the sea.
BEG_SENT The fire hissed in the
waves; the same instant the ship shot by the bubble the sinking pipe
made.
BEG_SENT With slouched hat, Ahab lurchingly paced the planks.
BEG_SENT Queen Mab


Next morning Stubb accosted Flask.
BEG_SENT "Such a queer dream, King-Post, I never had.
BEG_SENT You know the old man's
ivory leg, well I dreamed he kicked me with it; and when I tried to
kick back, upon my soul, my little man, I kicked my leg right off!
BEG_SENT And then, presto!
BEG_SENT Ahab seemed a pyramid, and I like a blazing fool,
kept kicking at it.
BEG_SENT But what was still more curious, Flask- you know
how curious all dreams are- through all this rage that I was in, I
somehow seemed to be thinking to myself, that after all, it was not
much of an insult, that kick from Ahab.
BEG_SENT 'Why,' thinks I, 'what's the
row?
BEG_SENT It's not a real leg, only a false one.'
BEG_SENT And there's a mighty
difference between a living thump and a dead thump.
BEG_SENT That's what makes
a blow from the hand, Flask, fifty times more savage to bear than a
blow from a cane.
BEG_SENT The living member- that makes the living insult, my
little man.
BEG_SENT And thinks I to myself all the while, mind, while I was
stubbing my silly toes against that cursed pyramid- so confoundedly
contradictory was it all, all the while, I say, I was thinking to
myself, 'what's his leg now, but a cane-.
BEG_SENT a whale-bone cane.
BEG_SENT Yes,'
thinks I, 'it was only a playful cudgelling- in fact, only a
whaleboning that he gave me- not a base kick.
BEG_SENT Besides,' thinks I,
'look at it once; why, the end of it- the foot part- what a small
sort of end it is; whereas, if a broad footed farmer kicked me,
there's a devilish broad insult.
BEG_SENT But this insult is whittled down to
a point only.'
BEG_SENT But now comes the greatest joke of the dream,
Flask.
BEG_SENT While I was battering away at the pyramid, a sort of
badger-haired old merman, with a hump on his back, takes me by the
shoulders, and slews me round.
BEG_SENT 'What are you 'bout?'
BEG_SENT says he.
BEG_SENT Slid!
BEG_SENT man, but I was frightened.
BEG_SENT Such a phiz!
BEG_SENT But, somehow, next moment I
was over the fright.
BEG_SENT 'What am I about?'
BEG_SENT says I at last.
BEG_SENT 'And what
business is that of yours, I should like to know, Mr. Humpback?
BEG_SENT Do
you want a kick?'
BEG_SENT By the lord, Flask, I had no sooner said that, than
he turned round his stern to me, bent over, and dragging up a lot of
seaweed he had for a clout- what do you think, I saw?- why thunder
alive, man, his stern was stuck full of marlinspikes, with the points
out.
BEG_SENT Says I on second thought, 'I guess I won't kick you, old
fellow.'
BEG_SENT 'Wise Stubb,' said he, 'wise Stubb;' and kept muttering it
all the time, a sort of eating of his gums like a chimney hag.
BEG_SENT Seeing
he wasn't going to stop saying over his 'wise Stubb, wise Stubb,' I
thought I might as well fall to kicking the pyramid again.
BEG_SENT But I had
only just lifted my foot for it, when he roared out, 'Stop that
kicking!'
BEG_SENT 'Halloa,' says I, 'what's the matter now, old fellow?'
BEG_SENT 'Look ye here,' says he; 'let's argue the insult.
BEG_SENT Captain Ahab kicked
ye, didn't he?'
BEG_SENT 'Yes, he did,' says I- 'right here it was.'
BEG_SENT 'Very
good,' says he- 'he used his ivory leg, didn't he?'
BEG_SENT 'Yes, he did,'
says I.
BEG_SENT 'Well then,' says he, 'wise Stubb, what have you to complain
of?
BEG_SENT Didn't he kick with right good will?
BEG_SENT it wasn't a common pitch
pine leg he kicked with, was it?
BEG_SENT No, you were kicked by a great man,
and with a beautiful ivory leg, Stubb.
BEG_SENT It's an honor; I consider it
an honor.
BEG_SENT Listen, wise Stubb.
BEG_SENT In old England the greatest lords think
it great glory to be slapped by a queen, and made garter-knights of;
but, be your boast, Stubb, that ye were kicked by old Ahab, and made
a wise man of.
BEG_SENT Remember what I say; be kicked by him; account his
kicks honors; and on no account kick back; for you can't help
yourself, wise Stubb.
BEG_SENT Don't you see that pyramid?'
BEG_SENT With that, he all
of a sudden seemed somehow, in some queer fashion, to swim off into
the air.
BEG_SENT I snored; rolled over; and there I was in my hammock!
BEG_SENT Now,
what do you think of that dream, Flask?"
BEG_SENT "I don't know; it seems a sort of foolish to me, tho.'"
BEG_SENT "May be; may be.
BEG_SENT But it's made a wise man of me, Flask.
BEG_SENT D'ye see Ahab
standing there, sideways looking over the stern?
BEG_SENT Well, the best thing
you can do, Flask, is to let the old man alone; never speak to him,
whatever he says.
BEG_SENT Halloa!
BEG_SENT What's that he shouts?
BEG_SENT Hark!"
BEG_SENT "Mast-head, there!
BEG_SENT Look sharp, all of ye!
BEG_SENT There are whales
hereabouts!
BEG_SENT If ye see a white one, split your lungs for him!
BEG_SENT "What do you think of that now, Flask?
BEG_SENT ain't there a small drop of
something queer about that, eh?
BEG_SENT A white whale- did ye mark that, man?
BEG_SENT Look ye- there's something special in the wind.
BEG_SENT Stand by for it,
Flask.
BEG_SENT Ahab has that that's bloody on his mind.
BEG_SENT But, mum; he comes
this way."
BEG_SENT Cetology


Already we are boldly launched upon the deep; but soon we shall be
lost in its unshored harborless immensities.
BEG_SENT Ere that come to pass;
ere the Pequod's weedy hull rolls side by side with the barnacled
hulls of the leviathan; at the outset it is but well to attend to a
matter almost indispensable to a thorough appreciative understanding
of the more special leviathanic revelations and allusions of all
sorts which are to follow.
BEG_SENT It is some systematized exhibition of the whale in his broad genera,
that I would now fain put before you.
BEG_SENT Yet is it no easy task.
BEG_SENT The
classification of the constituents of a chaos, nothing less is here
essayed.
BEG_SENT Listen to what the best and latest authorities have laid
down.
BEG_SENT "No branch of Zoology is so much involved as that which is entitled
Cetology," says Captain Scoresby, A.D. 1820.
BEG_SENT "It is not my intention, were it in my power, to enter into the
inquiry as to the true method of dividing the cetacea into groups and
families.... Utter confusion exists among the historians of this
animal" (sperm whale), says Surgeon Beale, A.D. 1839.
BEG_SENT "Unfitness to pursue our research in the unfathomable waters."
BEG_SENT "Impenetrable veil covering our knowledge of the cetacea."
BEG_SENT "A field
strewn with thorns."
BEG_SENT "All these incomplete indications but serve to
torture us naturalists."
BEG_SENT Thus speak of the whale, the great Cuvier, and John Hunter, and
Lesson, those lights of zoology and anatomy.
BEG_SENT Nevertheless, though of
real knowledge there be little, yet of books there are a plenty; and
so in some small degree, with cetology, or the science of whales.
BEG_SENT Many are the men, small and great, old and new, landsmen and seamen,
who have at large or in little, written of the whale.
BEG_SENT Run over a
few:- The Authors of the Bible; Aristotle; Pliny; Aldrovandi; Sir
Thomas Browne; Gesner; Ray; Linnaeus; Rondeletius; Willoughby; Green;
Artedi; Sibbald; Brisson; Marten; Lacepede; Bonneterre; Desmarest;
Baron Cuvier; Frederick Cuvier; John Hunter; Owen; Scoresby; Beale;
Bennett; J. Ross Browne; the Author of Miriam Coffin; Olmstead; and
the Rev.
BEG_SENT T. Cheever.
BEG_SENT But to what ultimate generalizing purpose all
these have written, the above cited extracts will show.
BEG_SENT Of the names in this list of whale authors only those following Owen
ever saw living whales; and but one of them was a real professional
harpooneer and whaleman.
BEG_SENT I mean Captain Scoresby.
BEG_SENT On the separate
subject of the Greenland or right-whale, he is the best existing
authority.
BEG_SENT But Scoresby knew nothing and says nothing of the great
sperm whale, compared with which the Greenland whale is almost
unworthy mentioning.
BEG_SENT And here be it said, that the Greenland whale is
an usurper upon the throne of the seas.
BEG_SENT He is not even by any means
the largest of the whales.
BEG_SENT Yet, owing to the long priority of his
claims, and the profound ignorance which till some seventy years
back, invested the then fabulous or utterly unknown sperm-whale, and
which ignorance to this present day still reigns in all but some few
scientific retreats and whale-ports; this usurpation has been every
way complete.
BEG_SENT Reference to nearly all the leviathanic allusions in
the great poets of past days, will satisfy you that the Greenland
whale, without one rival, was to them the monarch of the seas.
BEG_SENT But
the time has at last come for a new proclamation.
BEG_SENT This is Charing
Cross; hear ye!
BEG_SENT good people all,- the Greenland whale is deposed,-
the great sperm whale now reigneth!
BEG_SENT There are only two books in being which at all pretend to put the
living sperm whale before you, and at the same time, in the remotest
degree succeed in the attempt.
BEG_SENT Those books are Beale's and Bennett's;
both in their time surgeons to the English South-Sea whale-ships, and
both exact and reliable men.
BEG_SENT The original matter touching the sperm
whale to be found in their volumes is necessarily small; but so far
as it goes, it is of excellent quality, though mostly confined to
scientific description.
BEG_SENT As yet, however, the sperm whale, scientific
or poetic, lives not complete in any literature.
BEG_SENT Far above all other
hunted whales, his is an unwritten life.
BEG_SENT Now the various species of whales need some sort of popular
comprehensive classification, if only an easy outline one for the
present, hereafter to be filled in all-outward its departments by
subsequent laborers.
BEG_SENT As no better man advances to take this matter in
hand, I hereupon offer my own poor endeavors.
BEG_SENT I promise nothing
complete; because any human thing supposed to be complete must for
that very reason infallibly be faulty.
BEG_SENT I shall not pretend to a
minute anatomical description of the various species, or- in this
space at least- to much of any description.
BEG_SENT My object here is simply
to project the draught of a systematization of cetology.
BEG_SENT I am the
architect, not the builder.
BEG_SENT But it is a ponderous task; no ordinary letter-sorter in the
Post-Office is equal to it.
BEG_SENT To grope down into the bottom of the sea
after them; to have one's hands among the unspeakable foundations,
ribs, and very pelvis of the world; this is a fearful thing.
BEG_SENT What am
I that I should essay to hook the nose of this leviathan!
BEG_SENT The awful
tauntings in Job might well appal me.
BEG_SENT "Will he (the leviathan) make a
covenant with thee?
BEG_SENT Behold the hope of him is vain!
BEG_SENT But I have swam
through libraries and sailed through oceans; I have had to do with
whales with these visible hands; I am in earnest; and I will
try.
BEG_SENT There are some preliminaries to settle.
BEG_SENT First: The uncertain, unsettled condition of this science of Cetology
is in the very vestibule attested by the fact, that in some quarters
it still remains a moot point whether a whale be a fish.
BEG_SENT In his
System of Nature, A.D. 1776, Linnaeus declares, "I hereby separate
the whales from the fish."
BEG_SENT But of my own knowledge, I know that down
to the year 1850, sharks and shad, alewives and herring, against
Linnaeus's express edict, were still found dividing the possession of
the same seas with the Leviathan.
BEG_SENT The grounds upon which Linnaeus would fain have banished the whales
from the waters, he states as follows: "On account of their warm
bilocular heart, their lungs, their moveable eyelids, their hollow
ears, penem intrantem feminam mammis lactantem," and finally, "ex
lege naturae jure meritoque."
BEG_SENT I submitted all this to my friends
Simeon Macey and Charley Coffin, of Nantucket, both messmates of mine
in a certain voyage, and they united in the opinion that the reasons
set forth were altogether insufficient.
BEG_SENT Charley profanely hinted
they were humbug.
BEG_SENT Be it known that, waiving all argument, I take the good old fashioned
ground that the whale is a fish, and call upon holy Jonah to back
me.
BEG_SENT This fundamental thing settled, the next point is, in what
internal respect does the whale differ from other fish.
BEG_SENT Above,
Linnaeus has given you those items.
BEG_SENT But in brief they are these:
lungs and warm blood; whereas, all other fish are lungless and cold
blooded.
BEG_SENT Next: how shall we define the whale, by his obvious externals, so as
conspicuously to label him for all time to come.
BEG_SENT To be short, then, a
whale is a spouting fish with a horizontal tail.
BEG_SENT There you have
him.
BEG_SENT However contracted, that definition is the result of expanded
meditation.
BEG_SENT A walrus spouts much like a whale, but the walrus is not
a fish, because he is amphibious.
BEG_SENT But the last term of the definition
is still more cogent, as coupled with the first.
BEG_SENT Almost any one must
have noticed that all the fish familiar to landsmen have not a flat,
but a vertical, or up-and-down tail.
BEG_SENT Whereas, among spouting fish the
tail, though it may be similarly shaped, invariably assumes a
horizontal position.
BEG_SENT By the above definition of what a whale is, I do by no means exclude
from the leviathanic brotherhood any sea creature hitherto identified
with the whale by the best informed Nantucketers; nor, on the other
hand, link with it any fish hitherto authoritatively regarded as
alien.
BEG_SENT Hence, all the smaller, spouting and horizontal tailed fish
must be included in this ground-plan of cetology.
BEG_SENT Now, then, come the
grand divisions of the entire whale host.
BEG_SENT First: According to magnitude I divide the whales into three primary
BOOKS (subdivisible into CHAPTERS), and these shall comprehend them
all, both small and large.
BEG_SENT I.
BEG_SENT THE FOLIO WHALE; II.
BEG_SENT the OCTAVO WHALE; III.
BEG_SENT the DUODECIMO WHALE.
BEG_SENT As the type of the FOLIO I present the Sperm Whale; of the OCTAVO,
the Grampus; of the DUODECIMO, the Porpoise.
BEG_SENT FOLIOS.
BEG_SENT Among these I here include the following chapters:

I.
BEG_SENT The Sperm Whale; II.
BEG_SENT the Right Whale; III.
BEG_SENT the Fin Back Whale;
IV.
BEG_SENT the Humpbacked Whale; V.  the Razor Back Whale; VI.
BEG_SENT the Sulphur
Bottom Whale

BOOK I.
BEG_SENT (Folio), CHAPTER I.
BEG_SENT (Sperm Whale).
BEG_SENT This whale, among the English of old vaguely known as the Trumpa
whale and the Physeter whale, and the Anvil Headed whale, is the
present Cachalot of the French, and the Pottsfich of the Germans, and
the Macrocephalus of the Long Words.
BEG_SENT He is, without doubt, the
largest inhabitant of the globe; the most formidable of all whales to
encounter; the most majestic in aspect; and lastly, by far the most
valuable in commerce; he being the only creature from which that
valuable substance, spermaceti, is obtained.
BEG_SENT All his peculiarities
will, in many other places, be enlarged upon.
BEG_SENT It is chiefly with his
name that I now have to do.
BEG_SENT Philologically considered, it is
absurd.
BEG_SENT Some centuries ago, when the sperm whale was almost wholly
unknown in his own proper individuality, and when his oil was only
accidentally obtained from the stranded fish; in those days
spermaceti, it would seem, was popularly supposed to be derived from
a creature identical with the one then known in England as the
Greenland or Right Whale.
BEG_SENT It was the idea also, that this same
spermaceti was that quickening humor of the Greenland Whale which the
first syllable of the word literally expresses.
BEG_SENT In those times, also,
spermaceti was exceedingly scarce, not being used for light, but only
as an ointment and medicament.
BEG_SENT It was only to be had from the
druggists as you nowadays buy an ounce of rhubarb.
BEG_SENT When, as I opine,
in the course of time, the true nature of spermaceti became known,
its original name was still retained by the dealers; no doubt to
enhance its value by a notion so strangely significant of its
scarcity.
BEG_SENT And so the appellation must at last have come to be
bestowed upon the whale from which this spermaceti was really
derived.
BEG_SENT BOOK I.
BEG_SENT (Folio), CHAPTER II.
BEG_SENT (Right Whale).
BEG_SENT In one respect this is the most venerable of the leviathans, being
the one first regularly hunted by man.
BEG_SENT It yields the article commonly
known as whalebone or baleen; and the oil specially known as "whale
oil," an inferior article in commerce.
BEG_SENT Among the fishermen, he is
indiscriminately designated by all the following titles: The Whale;
the Greenland Whale; the Black Whale; the Great Whale; the True
Whale; the Right Whale.
BEG_SENT There is a deal of obscurity concerning the
Identity of the species thus multitudinously baptized.
BEG_SENT What then is
the whale, which I include in the second species of my Folios?
BEG_SENT It is
the Great Mysticetus of the English naturalists; the Greenland Whale
of the English whaleman; the Baliene Ordinaire of the French
whalemen; the Growlands Walfish of the Swedes.
BEG_SENT It is the whale which
for more than two centuries past has been hunted by the Dutch and
English in the Arctic seas; it is the whale which the American
fishermen have long pursued in the Indian ocean, on the Brazil Banks,
on the Nor' West Coast, and various other parts of the world,
designated by them Right Whale Cruising Grounds.
BEG_SENT Some pretend to see a difference between the Greenland whale of the
English and the right whale of the Americans.
BEG_SENT But they precisely
agree in all their grand features; nor has there yet been presented a
single determinate fact upon which to ground a radical
distinction.
BEG_SENT It is by endless subdivisions based upon the most
inconclusive differences, that some departments of natural history
become so repellingly intricate.
BEG_SENT The right whale will be elsewhere
treated of at some length, with reference to elucidating the sperm
whale.
BEG_SENT BOOK I.
BEG_SENT (Folio), CHAPTER III.
BEG_SENT (Fin-Back).
BEG_SENT Under this head I reckon a monster which, by the various names of
Fin-Back, Tall-Spout, and Long-John, has been seen almost in every
sea and is commonly the whale whose distant jet is so often descried
by passengers crossing the Atlantic, in the New York
packet-tracks.
BEG_SENT In the length he attains, and in his baleen, the
Fin-back resembles the right whale, but is of a less portly girth,
and a lighter color, approaching to olive.
BEG_SENT His great lips present a
cable-like aspect, formed by the intertwisting, slanting folds of
large wrinkles.
BEG_SENT His grand distinguishing feature, the fin, from which
he derives his name, is often a conspicuous object.
BEG_SENT This fin is some
three or four feet long, growing vertically from the hinder part of
the back, of an angular shape, and with a very sharp pointed
end.
BEG_SENT Even if not the slightest other part of the creature be visible,
this isolated fin will, at times, be seen plainly projecting from the
surface.
BEG_SENT When the sea is moderately calm, and slightly marked with
spherical ripples, and this gnomon-like fin stands up and casts
shadows upon the wrinkled surface, it may well be supposed that the
watery circle surrounding it somewhat resembles a dial, with its
style and wavy hour-lines graved on it.
BEG_SENT On that Ahaz-dial the shadow
often goes back.
BEG_SENT The Fin-Back is not gregarious.
BEG_SENT He seems a
whale-hater, as some men are man-haters.
BEG_SENT Very shy; always going
solitary; unexpectedly rising to the surface in the remotest and most
sullen waters; his straight and single lofty jet rising like a tall
misanthropic spear upon a barren plain; gifted with such wondrous
power and velocity in swimming, as to defy all present pursuit from
man; this leviathan seems the banished and unconquerable Cain of his
race, bearing for his mark that style upon his back.
BEG_SENT From having the
baleen in his mouth, the Fin-Back is sometimes included with the
right whale, among a theoretic species denominated Whalebone whales,
that is, whales with baleen.
BEG_SENT Of these so-called Whalebone whales,
there would seem to be several varieties, most of which, however, are
little known.
BEG_SENT Broad-nosed whales and beaked whales; pike-headed
whales; bunched whales; under-jawed whales and rostrated whales, are
the fisherman's names for a few sorts.
BEG_SENT In connexion with this appellative of "Whalebone whales," it is of
great importance to mention, that however such a nomenclature may be
convenient in facilitating allusions to some kind of whales, yet it
is in vain to attempt a clear classification of the Leviathan,
founded upon either his baleen, or hump, or fin, or teeth;
notwithstanding that those marked parts or features very obviously
seem better adapted to afford the basis for a regular system of
Cetology than any other detached bodily distinctions, which the
whale, in his kinds, presents.
BEG_SENT How then?
BEG_SENT The baleen, hump, back-fin,
and teeth; these are things whose peculiarities are indiscriminately
dispersed among all sorts of whales, without any record to what may
be the nature of their structure in other and more essential
particulars.
BEG_SENT Thus, the sperm whale and the humpbacked whale, each has
a hump; but there the similitude ceases.
BEG_SENT Then this same humpbacked
whale and the Greenland whale, each of these has baleen; but there
again the similitude ceases.
BEG_SENT And it is just the same with the other
parts above mentioned.
BEG_SENT In various sorts of whales, they form such
irregular combinations; or, in the case of any one of them detached,
such an irregular isolation; as utterly to defy all general
methodization formed upon such a basis.
BEG_SENT On this rock every one of the
whale-naturalists has split.
BEG_SENT But it may possibly be conceived that, in the internal parts of the
whale, in his anatomy- there, at least, we shall be able to hit the
right classification.
BEG_SENT Nay; what thing, for example, is there in the
Greenland whale's anatomy more striking than his baleen?
BEG_SENT Yet we have
seen that by his baleen it is impossible correctly to classify the
Greenland whale.
BEG_SENT And if you descend into the bowels of the various
leviathans, why there you will not find distinctions a fiftieth part
as available to the systematizer as those external ones already
enumerated.
BEG_SENT What then remains?
BEG_SENT nothing but to take hold of the whales
bodily, in their entire liberal volume, and boldly sort them that
way.
BEG_SENT And this is the Bibliographical system here adopted; and it is
the only one that can possibly succeed, for it alone is
practicable.
BEG_SENT To proceed.
BEG_SENT BOOK I.
BEG_SENT (Folio) CHAPTER IV.
BEG_SENT (Hump Back).
BEG_SENT This whale is often seen on the northern American coast.
BEG_SENT He has been
frequently captured there, and towed into harbor.
BEG_SENT He has a great pack
on him like a peddler; or you might call him the Elephant and Castle
whale.
BEG_SENT At any rate, the popular name for him does not sufficiently
distinguish him, since the sperm whale also has a hump though a
smaller one.
BEG_SENT His oil is not very valuable.
BEG_SENT He has baleen.
BEG_SENT He is the
most gamesome and light-hearted of all the whales, making more gay
foam and white water generally than any other of them.
BEG_SENT BOOK I.
BEG_SENT (Folio), CHAPTER V. (Razar Back).
BEG_SENT Of this whale little is known but his name.
BEG_SENT I have seen him at a
distance off Cape Horn.
BEG_SENT Of a retiring nature, he eludes both hunters
and philosophers.
BEG_SENT Though no coward, he has never yet shown any part
of him but his back, which rises in a long sharp ridge.
BEG_SENT Let him go.
BEG_SENT I
know little more of him, nor does anybody else.
BEG_SENT BOOK I.
BEG_SENT (Folio), CHAPTER VI.
BEG_SENT (Sulphur Bottom).
BEG_SENT Another retiring gentleman, with a brimstone belly, doubtless got by
scraping along the Tartarian tiles in some of his profounder
divings.
BEG_SENT He is seldom seen; at least I have never seen him except in
the remoter southern seas, and then always at too great a distance to
study his countenance.
BEG_SENT He is never chased; he would run away with
rope-walks of line.
BEG_SENT Prodigies are told of him.
BEG_SENT Adieu, Sulphur Bottom!
BEG_SENT I can say nothing more that is true of ye, nor can the oldest
Nantucketer.
BEG_SENT Thus ends BOOK I.
BEG_SENT (Folio), and now begins BOOK II.
BEG_SENT (Octavo).
BEG_SENT OCTAVOES.
BEG_SENT These embrace the whales of middling magnitude, among which
present may be numbered:

I.   the Grampus;
II.
BEG_SENT the Black Fish;
III.
BEG_SENT the Narwhale;
IV.
BEG_SENT the Thrasher;
V.   the Killer.
BEG_SENT BOOK II.
BEG_SENT (Octavo), CHAPTER I.
BEG_SENT (Grampus).
BEG_SENT Though this fish, whose loud sonorous breathing, or rather blowing,
has furnished a proverb to landsmen, is so well known a denizen of
the deep, yet is he not popularly classed among whales.
BEG_SENT But
possessing all the grand distinctive features of the leviathan, most
naturalists have recognised him for one.
BEG_SENT He is of moderate octave
size, varying from fifteen to twenty-five feet in length, and of
corresponding dimensions round the waist.
BEG_SENT He swims in herds; he is
never regularly hunted, though his oil is considerable in quantity,
and pretty good for light.
BEG_SENT By some fishermen his approach is regarded
as premonitory of the advance of the great sperm whale.
BEG_SENT BOOK II.
BEG_SENT (Octavo), CHAPTER II.
BEG_SENT (Black Fish).
BEG_SENT I give the popular fishermen's names for all these fish, for
generally they are the best.
BEG_SENT Where any name happens to be vague or
inexpressive, I shall say so, and suggest another.
BEG_SENT I do so now
touching the Black Fish, so called because blackness is the rule
among almost all whales.
BEG_SENT So, call him the Hyena Whale, if you
please.
BEG_SENT His voracity is well known and from the circumstance that the
inner angles of his lips are curved upwards, he carries an
everlasting Mephistophelean grin on his face.
BEG_SENT This whale averages
some sixteen or eighteen feet in length.
BEG_SENT He is found in almost all
latitudes.
BEG_SENT He has a peculiar way of showing his dorsal hooked fin in
swimming, which looks something like a Roman nose.
BEG_SENT When not more
profitably employed, the sperm whale hunters sometimes capture the
Hyena whale, to keep up the supply of cheap oil for domestic
employment- as some frugal housekeepers, in the absence of company,
and quite alone by themselves, burn unsavory tallow instead of
odorous wax.
BEG_SENT Though their blubber is very thin, some of these whales
will yield you upwards of thirty gallons of oil.
BEG_SENT BOOK II.
BEG_SENT (Octavo), CHAPTER III.
BEG_SENT (Narwhale), that is, Nostril whale.
BEG_SENT Another instance of a curiously named whale, so named I suppose from
his peculiar horn being originally mistaken for a peaked nose.
BEG_SENT The
creature is some sixteen feet in length, while its horn averages five
feet, though some exceed ten, and even attain to fifteen
feet.
BEG_SENT Strictly speaking, this horn is but a lengthened tusk, growing
out from the jaw in a line a little depressed from the
horizontal.
BEG_SENT But it is only found on the sinister side, which has an
ill effect, giving its owner something analogous to the aspect of a
clumsy left-handed man.
BEG_SENT What precise purpose this ivory horn or lance
answers, it would be hard to say.
BEG_SENT It does not seem to be used like
the blade of the sword-fish and bill-fish; though some sailors tell
me that the Narwhale employs it for a rake in turning over the bottom
of the sea for food.
BEG_SENT Charley Coffin said it was used for an
ice-piercer; for the Narwhale, rising to the surface of the Polar
Sea, and finding it sheeted with ice, thrusts his horn up, and so
breaks through.
BEG_SENT But you cannot prove either of these surmises to be
correct.
BEG_SENT My own opinion is, that however this one-sided horn may
really be used by the Narwhale- however that may be- it would
certainly be very convenient to him for a folder in reading
pamphlets.
BEG_SENT The Narwhale I have heard called the Tusked whale, the
Horned whale, and the Unicorn whale.
BEG_SENT He is certainly a curious
example of the Unicornism to be found in almost every kingdom of
animated nature.
BEG_SENT From certain cloistered old authors I have gathered
that this same sea-unicorn's horn was in ancient days regarded as the
great antidote against poison, and as such, preparations of it
brought immense prices.
BEG_SENT It was also distilled to a volatile salts for
fainting ladies the same way that the horns of the male deer are
manufactured into hartshorn.
BEG_SENT Originally it was in itself accounted an
object of great curiosity.
BEG_SENT Black Letter tells me that Sir Martin
Frobisher on his return from that voyage, when Queen Bess did
gallantly wave her jewelled hand to him from a window of Greenwich
Palace, as his bold ship sailed down the Thames; "when Sir Martin
returned from that voyage," saith Black Letter, "on bended knees he
presented to her highness a prodigious long horn of the Narwhale,
which for a long period after hung in the castle at Windsor."
BEG_SENT An
Irish author avers that the Earl of Leicester, on bended knees, did
likewise present to her highness another horn, pertaining to a land
beast of the unicorn nature.
BEG_SENT The Narwhale has a very picturesque, leopard-like look, being of a
milk-white ground color, dotted with round and oblong spots of
black.
BEG_SENT His oil is very superior, clear and fine; but there is little
of it, and he is seldom hunted.
BEG_SENT He is mostly found in the circumpolar
seas.
BEG_SENT BOOK II.
BEG_SENT (Octavo), CHAPTER IV.
BEG_SENT (Killer).
BEG_SENT Of this whale little is precisely known to the Nantucketer, and
nothing at all to the professed naturalists.
BEG_SENT From what I have seen of
him at a distance, I should say that he was about the bigness of a
grampus.
BEG_SENT He is very savage- a sort of Feegee fish.
BEG_SENT He sometimes takes
the great Folio whales by the lip, and hangs there like a leech, till
the mighty brute is worried to death.
BEG_SENT The Killer is never hunted.
BEG_SENT I
never heard what sort of oil he has.
BEG_SENT Exception might be taken to the
name bestowed upon this whale, on the ground of its
indistinctness.
BEG_SENT For we are all killers, on land and on sea;
Bonapartes and Sharks included.
BEG_SENT BOOK II.
BEG_SENT (Octavo), CHAPTER V. (Thrasher).
BEG_SENT This gentleman is famous for his tail which he uses for a ferule in
thrashing his foes.
BEG_SENT He mounts the Folio whale's back, and as he
swims, he works his passage by flogging him; as some schoolmasters
get along in the world by a similar process.
BEG_SENT Still less is known of
the Thrasher than of the Killer.
BEG_SENT Both are outlaws, even in the
lawless seas.
BEG_SENT Thus ends BOOK II.
BEG_SENT (Octavo), and begins BOOK III, (Duodecimo.)
BEG_SENT DUODECIMOES.- These include the smaller whales.
BEG_SENT I.
BEG_SENT The Huzza Porpoise.
BEG_SENT II.
BEG_SENT The Algerine Porpoise.
BEG_SENT III.
BEG_SENT The Mealy-mouthed Porpoise.
BEG_SENT To those who have not chanced specially to study the subject, it may
possibly seem strange, that fishes not commonly exceeding four or
five feet should be marshalled among WHALES- a word, which, in the
popular sense, always conveys an idea of hugeness.
BEG_SENT But the creatures
set down above as Duodecimoes are infallibly whales, by the terms of
my definition of what a whale is- i.e.
BEG_SENT a spouting fish, with a
horizontal tail.
BEG_SENT BOOK III.
BEG_SENT (Duodecimo), CHAPTER 1.
BEG_SENT (Huzza Porpoise).
BEG_SENT This is the common porpoise found all over the globe.
BEG_SENT The name is of
my own bestowal; for there are more than one sort of porpoises, and
something must be done to distinguish them.
BEG_SENT I call him thus, because
he always swims in hilarious shoals, which upon the broad sea keep
tossing themselves to heaven like caps in a Fourth-of-July
crowd.
BEG_SENT Their appearance is generally hailed with delight by the
mariner.
BEG_SENT Full of fine spirits, they invariably come from the breezy
billows to windward.
BEG_SENT They are the lads that always live before the
wind.
BEG_SENT They are accounted a lucky omen.
BEG_SENT If you yourself can withstand
three cheers at beholding these vivacious fish, then heaven help ye;
the spirit of godly gamesomeness is not in ye.
BEG_SENT A well-fed, plump
Huzza Porpoise will yield you one good gallon of good oil.
BEG_SENT But the
fine and delicate fluid extracted from his jaws is exceedingly
valuable.
BEG_SENT It is in request among jewellers and watchmakers.
BEG_SENT Sailors
put in on their hones.
BEG_SENT Porpoise meat is good eating, you know.
BEG_SENT It may
never have occurred to you that a porpoise spouts.
BEG_SENT Indeed, his spout
is so small that it is not very readily discernible.
BEG_SENT But the next
time you have a chance, watch him; and you will then see the great
Sperm whale himself in miniature.
BEG_SENT BOOK III.
BEG_SENT (Duodecimo), CHAPTER II.
BEG_SENT (Algerine Porpoise).
BEG_SENT A pirate.
BEG_SENT Very savage.
BEG_SENT He is only found, I think, in the Pacific.
BEG_SENT He
is somewhat larger than the Huzza Porpoise, but much of the same
general make.
BEG_SENT Provoke him, and he will buckle to a shark.
BEG_SENT I have
lowered for him many times, but never yet saw him captured.
BEG_SENT BOOK III.
BEG_SENT (Duodecimo), CHAPTER III.
BEG_SENT (Mealy-mouthed Porpoise).
BEG_SENT The largest kind of Porpoise; and only found in the Pacific, so far
as it is known.
BEG_SENT The only English name, by which he has hitherto been
designated, is that of the fisher- Right-Whale Porpoise, from the
circumstance that he is chiefly found in the vicinity of that
Folio.
BEG_SENT In shape, he differs in some degree from the Huzza Porpoise,
being of a less rotund and jolly girth; indeed, he is of quite a neat
and gentleman-like figure.
BEG_SENT He has no fins on his back (most other
porpoises have), he has a lovely tail, and sentimental Indian eyes of
a hazel hue.
BEG_SENT But his mealy-mouth spoils him.
BEG_SENT Though his entire back
down to his side fins is of a deep sable, yet a boundary line,
distinct as the mark in a ship's hull, called the "bright waist,"
that line streaks him from stem to stern, with two separate colors,
black above and white below.
BEG_SENT The white comprises part of his head,
and the whole of his mouth, which makes him look as if he had just
escaped from a felonious visit to a meal-bag.
BEG_SENT A most mean and mealy
aspect!
BEG_SENT His oil is much like that of the common porpoise.
BEG_SENT Beyond the DUODECIMO, this system does not proceed, inasmuch as the
Porpoise is the smallest of the whales.
BEG_SENT Above, you have all the
Leviathans of note.
BEG_SENT But there are a rabble of uncertain, fugitive,
half-fabulous whales, which, as an American whaleman, I know by
reputation, but not personally.
BEG_SENT I shall enumerate them by their
fore-castle appellations; for possibly such a list may be valuable to
future investigators, who may complete what I have here but begun.
BEG_SENT If
any of the following whales, shall hereafter be caught and marked,
then he can readily be incorporated into this System, according to
his Folio, Octavo, or Duodecimo magnitude:- The Bottle-Nose Whale;
the Junk Whale; the Pudding-Headed Whale; the Cape Whale; the Leading
Whale; the Cannon Whale; the Scragg Whale; the Coppered Whale; the
Elephant Whale; the Iceberg Whale; the Quog Whale; the Blue Whale;
&amp;c. From Icelandic, Dutch, and old English authorities, there
might be quoted other lists of uncertain whales, blessed with all
manner of uncouth names.
BEG_SENT But I omit them as altogether obsolete; and
can hardly help suspecting them for mere sounds, full of
Leviathanism, but signifying nothing.
BEG_SENT Finally: It was stated at the outset, that this system would not be
here, and at once, perfected.
BEG_SENT You cannot but plainly see that I have
kept my word.
BEG_SENT But I now leave my cetological System standing thus
unfinished, even as the great Cathedral of Cologne was left, with the
cranes still standing upon the top of the uncompleted tower.
BEG_SENT For
small erections may be finished by their first architects; grand
ones, true ones, ever leave the copestone to posterity.
BEG_SENT God keep me
from ever completing anything.
BEG_SENT This whole book is but a draught- nay,
but the draught of a draught.
BEG_SENT Oh, Time, Strength, Cash, and Patience!
BEG_SENT I am aware that down to the present time, the fish styled Lamatins
and Dugongs (Pig-fish and Sow-fish of the Coffins of Nantucket) are
included by many naturalists among the whales.
BEG_SENT But as these pig-fish
are a noisy, contemptible set, mostly lurking in the mouths of
rivers, and feeding on wet hay, and especially as they do not spout,
I deny their credentials as whales; and have presented them with
their passports to quit the Kingdom of Cetology.
BEG_SENT Why this book of whales is not denominated the Quarto is very plain.
BEG_SENT Because, while the whales of this order, though smaller than those of
the former order, nevertheless retain a proportionate likeness to
them in figure, yet the bookbinder's Quarto volume in its dimensioned
form does not preserve the shape of the Folio volume, but the Octavo
volume does.
