BEG_SENT The Musket


During the most violent shocks of the Typhoon, the man at the
Pequod's jaw-bone tiller had several times been reelingly hurled to
the deck by its spasmodic motions even though preventer tackles had
been attached to it- for they were slack- because some play to the
tiller was indispensable.
BEG_SENT In a severe gale like this, while the ship is but a tossed
shuttlecock to the blast, it is by no means uncommon to see the
needles in the compasses, at intervals, go round and round.
BEG_SENT It was
thus with the Pequod's; at almost every shock the helmsman had not
failed to notice the whirling velocity with which they revolved upon
the cards; it is a sight that hardly anyone can behold without some
sort of unwonted emotion.
BEG_SENT Some hours after midnight, the Typhoon abated so much, that through
the strenuous exertions of Starbuck and Stubb- one engaged forward
and the other aft- the shivered remnants of the jib and fore and
main-top-sails were cut adrift from the spars, and went eddying away
to leeward, like the feathers of an albatross, which sometimes are
cast to the winds when that storm-tossed bird is on the wing.
BEG_SENT The three corresponding new sails were now bent and reefed, and a
storm-trysail was set further aft; so that the ship soon went through
the water with some precision again; and the course- for the present,
East-south-east- which he was to steer, if practicable, was once more
given to the helmsman.
BEG_SENT For during the violence of the gale, he had
only steered according to its vicissitudes.
BEG_SENT But as he was now
bringing the ship as near her course as possible, watching the
compass meanwhile, lo!
BEG_SENT a good sign!
BEG_SENT the wind seemed coming round
astern; aye, the foul breeze became fair!
BEG_SENT Instantly the yards were squared, to the lively song of "Ho!
BEG_SENT the fair
wind!
BEG_SENT oh-ye-ho cheerly, men!"
BEG_SENT the crew singing for joy, that so
promising an event should so soon have falsified the evil portends
preceding it.
BEG_SENT In compliance with the standing order of his commander- to report
immediately, and at any one of the twenty-four hours, any decided
change in the affairs of the deck,- Starbuck had no sooner trimmed
the yards to the breeze- however reluctantly and gloomily,- that he
mechanically went below to apprise Captain Ahab of the circumstance.
BEG_SENT Ere knocking at his state-room, he involuntarily paused before it a
moment.
BEG_SENT The cabin lamp- taking long swings this way and that- was
burning fitfully, and casting fitful shadows upon the old man's
bolted door,- a thin one, with fixed blinds inserted, in place of
upper panels.
BEG_SENT The isolated subterraneousness of the cabin made a
certain humming silence to reign there, though it was hooped round by
all the roar of the elements.
BEG_SENT The loaded muskets in the rack were
shiningly revealed, as they stood upright against the forward
bulkhead.
BEG_SENT Starbuck was an honest, upright man; but out of Starbuck's
heart, at that instant when he saw the muskets, there strangely
evolved an evil thought; but so blent with its neutral or good
accompaniments that for the instant he hardly knew it for itself.
BEG_SENT "He would have shot me once," he murmured, "yes, there's the very
musket that he pointed at me;- that one with the studded lock; let me
touch it- lift it.
BEG_SENT Strange, that I, who have handled so many deadly
lances, strange, that I should shake so now.
BEG_SENT Loaded?
BEG_SENT I must
see.
BEG_SENT Aye, aye; and powder in the pan;- that's not good.
BEG_SENT Best spill
it?- wait.
BEG_SENT I'll cure myself of this.
BEG_SENT I'll hold the musket boldly
while I think.- I come to report a fair wind to him.
BEG_SENT But how fair?
BEG_SENT Fair for death and doom,- that's fair for Moby Dick.
BEG_SENT It's a fair wind
that's only fair for that accursed fish.- The very tube he pointed at

with the very thing I handle now.- Aye and he would fain kill all his
crew.
BEG_SENT Does he not say he will not strike his spars to any gale?
BEG_SENT Has
he not dashed his heavenly quadrant?
BEG_SENT and in these same perilous seas,
gropes he not his way by mere dead reckoning of the error-abounding

BEG_SENT and in this very Typhoon, did he not swear that he would have

BEG_SENT But shall this crazed old man be tamely suffered

BEG_SENT If, then, he were this instant- put

BEG_SENT Ha!

BEG_SENT Sleeping?
BEG_SENT aye, but still

BEG_SENT I can't withstand thee, then, old

BEG_SENT Not reasoning; not remonstrance; not entreaty wilt thou hearken

BEG_SENT Flat obedience to thy own flat commands,

BEG_SENT Aye, and say'st the men have vow'd thy

BEG_SENT no lawful way?- Make him a prisoner to be taken home?
BEG_SENT What!
BEG_SENT hope to wrest this old man's living power from his own living

BEG_SENT I

BEG_SENT What, then, remains?
BEG_SENT The land is hundreds of

BEG_SENT I stand alone here upon

BEG_SENT A

BEG_SENT boy!
BEG_SENT boy!- But if I wake thee not to death, old

BEG_SENT Great God, where art Thou?
BEG_SENT Shall I?
BEG_SENT shall I?- The wind has gone down and shifted, sir; the fore and main
topsails are reefed and set!
BEG_SENT she heads her course."
BEG_SENT "Stern all!
BEG_SENT Oh Moby Dick, I clutch thy heart at last!"
BEG_SENT Such were the sounds that now came hurtling from out the old man's
tormented sleep, as if Starbuck's voice had caused the long dumb

BEG_SENT The yet levelled musket shook like a drunkard's arm against the

BEG_SENT "He's too sound asleep, Mr. Stubb; go thou down, and wake him, and

BEG_SENT I must see to the deck here.
BEG_SENT Thou know'st what to say."
BEG_SENT The Needle


Next morning the not-yet-subsided sea rolled in long slow billows of
mighty bulk, and striving in the Pequod's gurgling track, pushed her
on like giants' palms outspread.
BEG_SENT The strong unstaggering breeze
abounded so, that sky and air seemed vast outbellying sails; the
whole world boomed before the wind.
BEG_SENT Muffled in the full morning
light, the invisible sun was only known by the spread intensity of
his place; where his bayonet rays moved on in stacks.
BEG_SENT Emblazonings,
as of crowned Babylonian kings and queens, reigned over
everything.
BEG_SENT The sea was as a crucible of molten gold, that bubblingly
leaps with light and heat.
BEG_SENT Long maintaining an enchanted silence, Ahab stood apart; and every
time the teetering ship loweringly pitched down her bowsprit, he
turned to eye the bright sun's rays produced ahead; and when she
profoundly settled by the stern, he turned behind, and saw the sun's
rearward place, and how the same yellow rays were blending with his
undeviating wake.
BEG_SENT "Ha, ha, my ship!
BEG_SENT thou mightest well be taken now for the sea-chariot
of the sun.
BEG_SENT Ho, ho!
BEG_SENT all ye nations before my prow, I bring the sun
to ye!
BEG_SENT Yoke on the further billows; hallo!
BEG_SENT a tandem, I drive the
sea!"
BEG_SENT But suddenly reined back by some counter thought, he hurried towards
the helm, huskily demanding how the ship was heading.
BEG_SENT "East-sou-east, sir," said the frightened steersman.
BEG_SENT "Thou liest!"
BEG_SENT smiting him with his clenched fist.
BEG_SENT "Heading East at
this hour in the morning, and the sun astern?"
BEG_SENT Upon this every soul was confounded; for the phenomenon just then
observed by Ahab had unaccountably escaped every one else; but its
very blinding palpableness must have been the cause.
BEG_SENT Thrusting his head half-way into the binnacle, Ahab caught one
glimpse of the compasses; his uplifted arm slowly fell; for a moment
he almost seemed to stagger.
BEG_SENT Standing behind him Starbuck looked,
and lo!
BEG_SENT the two compasses pointed East, and the Pequod was as
infallibly going West.
BEG_SENT But ere the first wild alarm could get out abroad among the crew, the
old man with a rigid laugh exclaimed, "I have it!
BEG_SENT It has happened
before.
BEG_SENT Mr. Starbuck, last night's thunder turned our compasses-
that's all.
BEG_SENT Thou hast before now heard of such a thing, I take it."
BEG_SENT "Aye; but never before has it happened to me, sir," said the pale
mate, gloomily.
BEG_SENT Here, it must needs be said, that accidents like this have in more
than one case occurred to ships in violent storms.
BEG_SENT The magnetic
energy, as developed in the mariner's needle, is, as all know,
essentially one with the electricity beheld in heaven; hence it is
not to be much marvelled at, that such things should be.
BEG_SENT Instances
where the lightning has actually struck the vessel, so as to smite
down some of the spars and rigging, the effect upon the needle has at
times been still more fatal; all its loathsome virtue being
annihilated, so that the before magnetic steel was of no more use
than an old wife's knitting needle.
BEG_SENT But in either case, the needle
never again, of itself, recovers the original virtue thus marred or
lost; and if the binnacle compasses be affected, the same fate
reaches all the others that may be in the ship; even were the
lowermost one inserted into the kelson.
BEG_SENT Deliberately standing before the binnacle, and eyeing the
transpointed compasses, the old man, with the sharp of his extended
hand, now took the precise bearing of the sun, and satisfied that the
needles were exactly inverted, shouted out his orders for the ship's
course to be changed accordingly.
BEG_SENT The yards were hard up; and once
more the Pequod thrust her undaunted bows into the opposing wind, for
the supposed fair one had only been juggling her.
BEG_SENT Meanwhile, whatever were his own secret thoughts, Starbuck said
nothing, but quietly he issued all requisite orders; while Stubb and
Flask- who in some small degree seemed then to be sharing his
feelings- likewise unmurmuringly acquiesced.
BEG_SENT As for the men, though
some of them lowly rumbled, their fear of Ahab was greater than their
fear of Fate.
BEG_SENT But as ever before, the pagan harpooneers remained
almost wholly unimpressed; or if impressed, it was only with a
certain magnetism shot into their congenial hearts from inflexible
Ahab's.
BEG_SENT For a space the old man walked the deck in rolling reveries.
BEG_SENT But
chancing to slip with his ivory heel, he saw the crushed copper
sight-tubes of the quadrant he had the day before dashed to the deck.
BEG_SENT "Thou poor, proud heaven-gazer and sun's pilot!
BEG_SENT yesterday I wrecked
thee, and to-day the compasses would fain have wrecked me.
BEG_SENT So,
so.
BEG_SENT But Ahab is lord over the level loadstone yet.
BEG_SENT Mr. Starbuck- a
lance without the pole; a top-maul, and the smallest of the
sail-maker's needles.
BEG_SENT Quick!"
BEG_SENT Accessory, perhaps, to the impulse dictating the thing he was now
about to do, were certain prudential motives, whose object might have
been to revive the spirits of his crew by a stroke of his subtile
skill, in a matter so wondrous as that of the inverted
compasses.
BEG_SENT Besides, the old man well knew that to steer by
transpointed needles, though clumsily practicable, was not a thing to
be passed over by superstitious sailors, without some shudderings and
evil portents.
BEG_SENT "Men," said he, steadily turning upon the crew, as the mate handed
him the things he had demanded, "my men, the thunder turned old
Ahab's needles; but out of this bit of steel Ahab can make one of his
own, that will point as true as any."
BEG_SENT Abashed glances of servile wonder were exchanged by the sailors, as
this was said; and with fascinated eyes they awaited whatever magic
might follow.
BEG_SENT But Starbuck looked away.
BEG_SENT With a blow from the top-maul Ahab knocked off the steel head of the
lance, and then handing to the mate the long iron rod remaining, bade
him hold it upright, without its touching the deck.
BEG_SENT Then, with the
maul, after repeatedly smiting the upper end of this iron rod, he
placed the blunted needle endwise on the top of it, and less strongly
hammered that, several times, the mate still holding the rod as
before.
BEG_SENT Then going through some small strange motions with it-
whether indispensable to the magnetizing of the steel, or merely
intended to augment the awe of the crew, is uncertain- he called for
linen thread; and moving to the binnacle, slipped out the two
reversed needles there, and horizontally suspended the sail-needle by
its middle, over one of the compass cards.
BEG_SENT At first, the steel went
round and round, quivering and vibrating at either end; but at last
it settled to its place, when Ahab, who had been intently watching
for this result, stepped frankly back from the binnacle, and pointing
his stretched arm towards it, exclaimed,- "Look ye, for yourselves,
if Ahab be not lord of the level loadstone!
BEG_SENT The sun is East, and that
compass swears it!"
BEG_SENT One after another they peered in, for nothing but their own eyes
could persuade such ignorance as theirs, and one after another they
slunk away.
BEG_SENT In his fiery eyes of scorn and triumph, you then saw Ahab in all his
fatal pride.
BEG_SENT The Log and Line


While now the fated Pequod had been so long afloat this voyage, the
log and line had but very seldom been in use.
BEG_SENT Owing to a confident
reliance upon other means of determining the vessel's place, some
merchantmen, and many whalemen, especially when cruising, wholly
neglect to heave the log; though at the same time, and frequently
more for form's sake than anything else, regularly putting down upon
the customary slate the course steered by the ship, as well as the
presumed average of progression every hour.
BEG_SENT It had been thus with the
Pequod.
BEG_SENT The wooden reel and angular log attached hung, long
untouched, just beneath the railing of the after bulwarks.
BEG_SENT Rains and
spray had damped it; sun and wind had warped it; all the elements had
combined to rot a thing that hung so idly.
BEG_SENT But heedless of all this,
his mood seized Ahab, as he happened to glance upon the reel, not
many hours after the magnet scene, and he remembered how his quadrant
was no more, and recalled his frantic oath about the level log and
line.
BEG_SENT The ship was sailing plungingly; astern the billows rolled in
riots.
BEG_SENT "Forward, there!
BEG_SENT Heave the log!"
BEG_SENT Two seamen came.
BEG_SENT The golden-hued Tahitian and the grizzly
Manxman.
BEG_SENT "Take the reel, one of ye, I'll heave."
BEG_SENT They went towards the extreme stern, on the ship's lee side, where
the deck, with the oblique energy of the wind, was now almost dipping
into the creamy, sidelong-rushing sea.
BEG_SENT The Manxman took the reel, and holding it high up, by the projecting
handle-ends of the spindle, round which the spool of line revolved,
so stood with the angular log hanging downwards, till Ahab advanced
to him.
BEG_SENT Ahab stood before him, and was lightly unwinding some thirty or forty
turns to form a preliminary hand-coil to toss overboard, when the old
Manxman, who was intently eyeing both him and the line, made bold to
speak.
BEG_SENT "Sir, I mistrust it; this line looks far gone, long heat and wet have
spoiled it."
BEG_SENT "'Twill hold, old gentleman.
BEG_SENT Long heat and wet, have they spoiled
thee?
BEG_SENT Thou seem'st to hold.
BEG_SENT Oh, truer perhaps, life holds thee; not
thou it."
BEG_SENT "I hold the spool, sir.
BEG_SENT But just as my captain says.
BEG_SENT With these grey
hairs of mine 'tis not worth while disputing, 'specially with a
superior, who'll ne'er confess."
BEG_SENT "What's that?
BEG_SENT there now's a patched professor in Queen Nature's
granite-founded College; but methinks he's too subservient.
BEG_SENT Where
wert thou born?"
BEG_SENT "In the little rocky Isle of Man, sir."
BEG_SENT "Excellent!
BEG_SENT Thou'st hit the world by that."
BEG_SENT "I know not, sir, but I was born there."
BEG_SENT "In the Isle of Man, hey?
BEG_SENT Well, the other way, it's good.
BEG_SENT Here's a
man from Man; a man born in once independent Man, and now unmanned of
Man; which is sucked in- by what?
BEG_SENT Up with the reel!
BEG_SENT The dead, blind
wall butts all inquiring heads at last.
BEG_SENT Up with it!
BEG_SENT So."
BEG_SENT The log was heaved.
BEG_SENT The loose coils rapidly straightened out in a
long dragging line astern, and then, instantly, the reel began to
whirl.
BEG_SENT In turn, jerkingly raised and lowered by the rolling billows,
the towing resistance of the log caused the old reelman to stagger
strangely.
BEG_SENT "Hold hard!"
BEG_SENT Snap!
BEG_SENT the overstrained line sagged down in one long festoon; the
tugging log was gone.
BEG_SENT "I crush the quadrant, the thunder turns the needles, and now the mad
sea parts the log-line.
BEG_SENT But Ahab can mend all.
BEG_SENT Haul in here,
Tahitian; reel up, Manxman.
BEG_SENT And look ye, let the carpenter make
another log, and mend thou the line.
BEG_SENT See to it."
BEG_SENT "There he goes now; to him nothing's happened; but to me, the skewer
seems loosening out of the middle of the world.
BEG_SENT Haul in, haul in,
Tahitian!
BEG_SENT These lines run whole, and whirling out: come in broken,
and dragging slow.
BEG_SENT Ha, Pip?
BEG_SENT come to help; eh, Pip?"
BEG_SENT "Pip?
BEG_SENT whom call ye Pip?
BEG_SENT Pip jumped from the whaleboat.
BEG_SENT Pip's
missing.
BEG_SENT Let's see now if ye haven't fished him up here,
fisherman.
BEG_SENT It drags hard; I guess he's holding on.
BEG_SENT Jerk him, Tahiti!
BEG_SENT Jerk him off we haul in no cowards here.
BEG_SENT Ho!
BEG_SENT there's his arm just
breaking water.
BEG_SENT A hatchet!
BEG_SENT a hatchet!
BEG_SENT cut it off- we haul in no
cowards here.
BEG_SENT Captain Ahab!
BEG_SENT sir, sir!
BEG_SENT here's Pip, trying to get on
board again."
BEG_SENT "Peace, thou crazy loon," cried the Manxman, seizing him by the arm.
BEG_SENT "Away from the quarter-deck!"
BEG_SENT "The greater idiot ever scolds the lesser," muttered Ahab, advancing.
BEG_SENT "Hands off from that holiness!
BEG_SENT Where sayest thou Pip was, boy?
BEG_SENT "Astern there, sir, astern!
BEG_SENT Lo!
BEG_SENT lo!"
BEG_SENT "And who art thou, boy?
BEG_SENT I see not my reflection in the vacant pupils
of thy eyes.
BEG_SENT Oh God!
BEG_SENT that man should be a thing for immortal souls
to sieve through!
BEG_SENT Who art thou, boy?"
BEG_SENT "Bell-boy, sir; ship's-crier; ding, dong, ding!
BEG_SENT Pip!
BEG_SENT Pip!
BEG_SENT One hundred
pounds of clay reward for Pip; five feet high- looks cowardly-
quickest known by that!
BEG_SENT Ding, dong, ding!
BEG_SENT Who's seen Pip the coward?"
BEG_SENT "There can be no hearts above the snow-line.
BEG_SENT Oh, ye frozen heavens!
BEG_SENT look down here.
BEG_SENT Ye did beget this luckless child, and have abandoned
him, ye creative libertines.
BEG_SENT Here, boy; Ahab's cabin shall be Pip's
home henceforth, while Ahab lives.
BEG_SENT Thou touchest my inmost centre,
boy; thou art tied to me by cords woven by my heart-strings.
BEG_SENT Come,
let's down."
BEG_SENT "What's this?
BEG_SENT here's velvet shark-skin," intently gazing at Ahab's
hand, and feeling it.
BEG_SENT "Ah, now, had poor Pip but felt so kind a thing
as this, perhaps he had ne'er been lost!
BEG_SENT This seems to me, sir, as a
man-rope; something that weak souls may hold by.
BEG_SENT Oh, sir, let old
Perth now come and rivet these two hands together; the black one with
the white, for I will not let this go."
BEG_SENT "Oh, boy, nor will I thee, unless I should thereby drag thee to worse
horrors than are here.
BEG_SENT Come, then, to my cabin.
BEG_SENT Lo!
BEG_SENT ye believers in
gods all goodness, and in man all ill, lo you!
BEG_SENT see the omniscient
gods oblivious of suffering man; and man, though idiotic, and knowing
not what he does, yet full of the sweet things of love and
gratitude.
BEG_SENT Come!
BEG_SENT I feel prouder leading thee by thy black hand, than
though I grasped an Emperor's!"
BEG_SENT "There go two daft ones now," muttered the old Manxman.
BEG_SENT "One daft
with strength, the other daft with weakness.
BEG_SENT But here's the end of
the rotten line- all dripping, too.
BEG_SENT Mend it, eh?
BEG_SENT I think we had best
have a new line altogether.
BEG_SENT I'll see Mr.  Stubb about it."
BEG_SENT The Life-Buoy


Steering now south-eastward by Ahab's levelled steel, and her
progress solely determined by Ahab's level log and line; the Pequod
held on her path towards the Equator.
BEG_SENT Making so long a passage
through such unfrequented waters, descrying no ships, and ere long,
sideways impelled by unvarying trade winds, over waves monotonously
mild; all these seemed the strange calm things preluding some riotous
and desperate scene.
BEG_SENT At last, when the ship drew near to the outskirts, as it were, of the
Equatorial fishing-ground, and in the deep darkness that goes before
the dawn, was sailing by a cluster of rocky islets; the watch- then
headed by Flask- was startled by a cry so plaintively wild and
unearthly- like half-articulated wailings of the ghosts of all
Herod's murdered Innocents- that one and all, they started from their
reveries, and for the space of some moments stood, or sat, or leaned
all transfixed by listening, like the carved Roman slave, while that
wild cry remained within hearing.
BEG_SENT The Christian or civilized part of
the crew said it was mermaids, and shuddered; but the pagan
harpooneers remained unappalled.
BEG_SENT Yet the grey Manxman- the oldest
mariner of all- declared that the wild thrilling sounds that were
heard, were the voices of newly drowned men in the sea.
BEG_SENT Below in his hammock, Ahab did not hear of this till grey dawn, when
he came to the deck; it was then recounted to him by Flask, not
unaccompanied with hinted dark meanings.
BEG_SENT He hollowly laughed, and
thus explained the wonder.
BEG_SENT Those rocky islands the ship had passed were the resort of great
numbers of seals, and some young seals that had lost their dams, or
some dams that had lost their cubs, must have risen nigh the ship and
kept company with her, crying and sobbing with their human sort of
wall.
BEG_SENT But this only the more affected some of them, because most
mariners cherish a very superstitious feeling about seals, arising
not only from their peculiar tones when in distress, but also from
the human look of their round heads and semi-intelligent faces, seen
peeringly uprising from the water alongside.
BEG_SENT In the sea, under
certain circumstances, seals have more than once been mistaken for
men.
BEG_SENT But the bodings of the crew were destined to receive a most plausible
confirmation in the fate of one of their number that morning.
BEG_SENT At
sun-rise this man went from his hammock to his mast-head at the fore;
and whether it was that he was not yet half waked from his sleep (for
sailors sometimes go aloft in a transition state), whether it was
thus with the man, there is now no telling; but, be that as it may,
he had not been long at his perch, when a cry was heard- a cry and a
rushing- and looking up, they saw a falling phantom in the air; and
looking down, a little tossed heap of white bubbles in the blue of
the sea.
BEG_SENT The life-buoy- a long slender cask- was dropped from the stern, where
it always hung obedient to a cunning spring; but no hand rose to
seize it, and the sun having long beat upon this cask it had
shrunken, so that it slowly filled, and that parched wood also filled
at its every pore; and the studded iron-bound cask followed the
sailor to the bottom, as if to yield him his pillow, though in sooth
but a hard one.
BEG_SENT And thus the first man of the Pequod that mounted the mast to look
out for the White Whale, on the White Whale's own peculiar ground;
that man was swallowed up in the deep.
BEG_SENT But few, perhaps, thought of
that at the time.
BEG_SENT Indeed, in some sort, they were not grieved at this
event, at least as a portent; for they regarded it, not as a
fore-shadowing of evil in the future, but as the fulfilment of an
evil already presaged.
BEG_SENT They declared that now they knew the reason of
those wild shrieks they had heard the night before.
BEG_SENT But again the old
Manxman said nay.
BEG_SENT The lost life-buoy was now to be replaced; Starbuck was directed to
see to it; but as no cask of sufficient lightness could be found, and
as in the feverish eagerness of what seemed the approaching crisis of
the voyage, all hands were impatient of any toil but what was
directly connected with its final end, whatever that might prove to
be; therefore, they were going to leave the ship's stern unprovided
with a buoy, when by certain strange signs and inuendoes Queequeg
hinted a hint concerning his coffin.
BEG_SENT "A life-buoy of a coffin!"
BEG_SENT cried Starbuck, starting.
BEG_SENT "Rather queer, that, I should say," said Stubb.
BEG_SENT "It will make a good enough one," said Flask, "the carpenter here can
arrange it easily."
BEG_SENT "Bring it up; there's nothing else for it," said Starbuck, after a
melancholy pause.
BEG_SENT "Rig it, carpenter; do not look at me so- the
coffin, I mean.
BEG_SENT Dost thou hear me?
BEG_SENT Rig it."
BEG_SENT "And shall I nail down the lid, sir?"
BEG_SENT moving his hand as with a
hammer.
BEG_SENT "Aye."
BEG_SENT "And shall I caulk the seams, sir?"
BEG_SENT moving his hand as with a
caulking-iron.
BEG_SENT "Aye."
BEG_SENT "And shall I then pay over the same with pitch, sir?"
BEG_SENT moving his hand
as with a pitch-pot.
BEG_SENT "Away!
BEG_SENT what possesses thee to this?
BEG_SENT Make a life-buoy of the coffin,
and no more.- Mr. Stubb, Mr. Flask, come forward with me."
BEG_SENT "He goes off in a huff.
BEG_SENT The whole he can endure; at the parts he
baulks.
BEG_SENT Now I don't like this.
BEG_SENT I make a leg for Captain Ahab, and he
wears it like a gentleman; but I make a bandbox for Queequeg, and he
won't put his head into it.
BEG_SENT Are all my pains to go for nothing with
that coffin?
BEG_SENT And now I'm ordered to make a life-buoy of it.
BEG_SENT It's like
turning an old coat; going to bring the flesh on the other side
now.
BEG_SENT I don't like this cobbling sort of business- I don't like it at
all; it's undignified; it's not my place.
BEG_SENT Let tinkers' brats do
tinkerings; we are their betters.
BEG_SENT I like to take in hand none but
clean, virgin, fair-and-square mathematical jobs, something that
regularly begins at the beginning, and is at the middle when midway,
and comes to an end at the conclusion; not a cobbler's job, that's at
an end in the middle, and at the beginning at the end.
BEG_SENT It's the old
woman's tricks to be giving cobbling jobs.
BEG_SENT Lord!
BEG_SENT what an affection
all old women have for tinkers.
BEG_SENT I know an old woman of sixty-five who
ran away with a bald-headed young tinker once.
BEG_SENT And that's the reason
I never would work for lonely widow old women ashore when I kept my
job-shop in the Vineyard; they might have taken into their lonely old
heads to run off with me.
BEG_SENT But heigh-ho!
BEG_SENT there are no caps at sea but
snow-caps.
BEG_SENT Let me see.
BEG_SENT Nail down the lid; caulk the seams; pay over
the same with pitch; batten them down tight, and hang it with the
snap-spring over the ship's stern.
BEG_SENT Were ever such things done before
with a coffin?
BEG_SENT Some superstitious old carpenters, now, would be tied
up in rigging, ere they would do the job.
BEG_SENT But I'm made of knotty
Aroostook hemlock; I don't budge.
BEG_SENT Cruppered with a coffin!
BEG_SENT Sailing
about with a grave-yard tray!
BEG_SENT But never mind.
BEG_SENT We workers in woods
make bridal bedsteads and card-tables, as well as coffins and
hearses.
BEG_SENT We work by the month, or by the job, or by the profit; not
for us to ask the why and wherefore of our work, unless it be too
confounded cobbling, and then we stash it if we can.
BEG_SENT Hem!
BEG_SENT I'll do the
job, now, tenderly.
BEG_SENT I'll have me- let's see- how many in the ship's
company, all told?
BEG_SENT But I've forgotten.
BEG_SENT Any way, I'll have me thirty
separate, Turk's-headed life-lines, each three feet long hanging all
round to the coffin.
BEG_SENT Then, if the hull go down, there'll be thirty
lively fellows all fighting for one coffin, a sight not seen very
often beneath the sun!
BEG_SENT Come hammer, caulking-iron, pitch-pot, and
marling-spike!
BEG_SENT Let's to it."
BEG_SENT The Deck


The coffin laid upon two line-tubs, between the vice-bench and
the open hatchway; the Carpenter caulking its seams; the string of
twisted oakum slowly unwinding from a large roll of it placed in the
bosom of his frock.- Ahab comes slowly from the cabin-gangway, and
hears Pip following him.
BEG_SENT Back lad; I will be with ye again presently.
BEG_SENT He goes!
BEG_SENT Not this hand
complies with my humor more genially than that boy.- Middle aisle of
a church!
BEG_SENT What's here?"
BEG_SENT "Life-buoy, sir.
BEG_SENT Mr. Starbuck's orders.
BEG_SENT Oh, look, sir!
BEG_SENT Beware the
hatchway!"
BEG_SENT "Thank ye, man.
BEG_SENT Thy coffin lies handy to the vault."
BEG_SENT "Sir?
BEG_SENT The hatchway?
BEG_SENT oh!
BEG_SENT So it does, sir, so it does."
BEG_SENT "Art not thou the leg-maker?
BEG_SENT Look, did not this stump come from thy
shop?"
BEG_SENT "I believe it did, sir; does the ferrule stand, sir?"
BEG_SENT "Well enough.
BEG_SENT But art thou not also the undertaker?"
BEG_SENT "Aye, sir; I patched up this thing here as a coffin for Queequeg; but
they've set me now to turning it into something else."
BEG_SENT "Then tell me; art thou not an arrant, all-grasping, intermeddling,
monopolizing, heathenish old scamp, to be one day making legs, and
the next day coffins to clap them in, and yet again life-buoys out of
those same coffins?
BEG_SENT Thou art as unprincipled as the gods, and as much
of a jack-of-all-trades."
BEG_SENT "But I do not mean anything, sir.
BEG_SENT I do as I do."
BEG_SENT "The gods again.
BEG_SENT Hark ye, dost thou not ever sing working about a
coffin?
BEG_SENT The Titans, they say, hummed snatches when chipping out the
craters for volcanoes; and the grave-digger in the play sings, spade
in hand.
BEG_SENT Dost thou never?"
BEG_SENT "Sing, sir?
BEG_SENT Do I sing?
BEG_SENT Oh, I'm indifferent enough, sir, for that; but
the reason why the grave-digger made music must have been because
there was none in his spade, sir.
BEG_SENT But the caulking mallet is full of
it.
BEG_SENT Hark to it."
BEG_SENT "Aye, and that's because the lid there's a sounding-board; and what
in all things makes the sounding-board is this- there's naught
beneath.
BEG_SENT And yet, a coffin with a body in it rings pretty much the
same, Carpenter.
BEG_SENT Hast thou ever helped carry a bier, and heard the
coffin knock against the churchyard gate, going in?
BEG_SENT "Faith, sir, I've-"

"Faith?
BEG_SENT What's that?"
BEG_SENT "Why, faith, sir, it's only a sort of exclamation-like- that's all,
sir."
BEG_SENT "Um, um; go on."
BEG_SENT "I was about to say, sir, that-"

"Art thou a silk-worm?
BEG_SENT Dost thou spin thy own shroud out of thyself?
BEG_SENT Look at thy bosom!
BEG_SENT Despatch!
BEG_SENT and get these traps out of sight."
BEG_SENT "He goes aft.
BEG_SENT That was sudden, now; but squalls come sudden in hot
latitudes.
BEG_SENT I've heard that the Isle of Albermarle, one of the
Gallipagos, is cut by the Equator right in the middle.
BEG_SENT Seems to me
some sort of Equator cuts yon old man, too, right in his middle.
BEG_SENT He's always under the Line- fiery hot, I tell ye!
BEG_SENT He's looking this
way- come, oakum; quick.
BEG_SENT Here we go again.
BEG_SENT This wooden mallet is the
cork, and I'm the professor of musical glasses- tap, tap!"
BEG_SENT (Ahab to himself)

"There's a sight!
BEG_SENT There's a sound!
BEG_SENT The greyheaded wood-pecker tapping
the hollow tree!
BEG_SENT Blind and dumb might well be envied now.
BEG_SENT See!
BEG_SENT that
thing rests on two line-tubs, full of tow-lines.
BEG_SENT A most malicious
wag, that fellow.
BEG_SENT Rat-tat!
BEG_SENT So man's seconds tick!
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT how immaterial
are all materials!
BEG_SENT What things real are there, but imponderable
thoughts?
BEG_SENT Here now's the very dreaded symbol of grim death, by a
mere hap, made the expressive sign of the help and hope of most
endangered life.
BEG_SENT A life-buoy of a coffin!
BEG_SENT Does it go further?
BEG_SENT Can it
be that in some spiritual sense the coffin is, after all, but an
immortality-preserver!
BEG_SENT I'll think of that.
BEG_SENT But no.
BEG_SENT So far gone am I
in the dark side of earth, that its other side, the theoretic bright
one, seems but uncertain twilight to me.
BEG_SENT Will ye never have done,
Carpenter, with that accursed sound?
BEG_SENT I go below; let me not see that
thing here when I return again.
BEG_SENT Now, then, Pip, we'll talk this over;
I do suck most wondrous philosophies from thee!
BEG_SENT Some unknown worlds
must empty into thee!"
BEG_SENT The Pequod Meets The Rachel


Next day, a large ship, the Rachel, was descried, bearing directly
down upon the Pequod, all her spars thickly clustering with men.
BEG_SENT At
the time the Pequod was making good speed through the water; but as
the broad-winged windward stranger shot nigh to her, the boastful
sails all fell together as blank bladders that are burst, and all
life fled from the smitten hull.
BEG_SENT "Bad news; she brings bad news," muttered the old Manxman.
BEG_SENT But ere
her commander, who, with trumpet to mouth, stood up in his boat; ere
he could hopefully hail, Ahab's voice was heard.
BEG_SENT "Hast seen the White Whale?"
BEG_SENT "Aye, yesterday.
BEG_SENT Have ye seen a whale-boat adrift?"
BEG_SENT Throttling his joy, Ahab negatively answered this unexpected
question; and would then have fain boarded the stranger, when the
stranger captain himself, having stopped his vessel's way, was seen
descending her side.
BEG_SENT A few keen pulls, and his boat-hook soon
clinched the Pequod's main-chains, and he sprang to the
deck.
BEG_SENT Immediately he was recognized by Ahab for a Nantucketer he
knew.
BEG_SENT But no formal salutation was exchanged.
BEG_SENT "Where was he?- not killed!- not killed!"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab, closely
advancing.
BEG_SENT "How was it?"
BEG_SENT It seemed that somewhat late on the afternoon of the day previous,
while three of the stranger's boats were engaged with a shoal of
whales, which had led them some four or five miles from the ship; and
while they were yet in swift chase to windward, the white hump and
head of Moby Dick had suddenly loomed up out of the water, not very
far to leeward; whereupon, the fourth rigged boat- a reserved one-
had been instantly lowered in chase.
BEG_SENT After a keen sail before the
wind, this fourth boat- the swiftest keeled of all- seemed to have
succeeded in fastening- at least, as well as the man at the mast-head
could tell anything about it.
BEG_SENT In the distance he saw the diminished
dotted boat; and then a swift gleam of bubbling white water; and
after that nothing more; whence it was concluded that the stricken
whale must have indefinitely run away with his pursuers, as often
happens.
BEG_SENT There was some apprehension, but no positive alarm, as
yet.
BEG_SENT The recall signals were placed in the rigging; darkness came on;
and forced to pick up her three far to windward boats- ere going in
quest of the fourth one in the precisely opposite direction- the ship
had not only been necessitated to leave that boat to its fate till
near midnight, but, for the time, to increase her distance from
it.
BEG_SENT But the rest of her crew being at last safe aboard, she crowded
all sail- stunsail on stunsail- after the missing boat; kindling a
fire in her try-pots for a beacon; and every other man aloft on the
look-out.
BEG_SENT But though when she had thus sailed a sufficient distance
to gain the presumed place of the absent ones when last seen; though
she then paused to lower her spare boats to pull all around her; and
not finding anything, had again dashed on; again paused, and lowered
her boats; and though she had thus continued doing till daylight; yet
not the least glimpse of the missing keel had been seen.
BEG_SENT The story told, the stranger Captain immediately went on to reveal
his object in boarding the Pequod.
BEG_SENT He desired that ship to unite with
his own in the search; by sailing over the sea some four or five
miles apart, on parallel lines, and so sweeping a double horizon, as
it were.
BEG_SENT "I will wager something now," whispered Stubb to Flask, "that some
one in that missing boat wore off that Captain's best coat; mayhap,
his watch- he's so cursed anxious to get it back.
BEG_SENT Who ever heard of
two pious whale-ships cruising after one missing whale-boat in the
height of the whaling season?
BEG_SENT See, Flask, only see how pale he
looks-pale in the very buttons of his eyes- look- it wasn't the coat-
it must have been the-"

"My boy, my own boy is among them.
BEG_SENT For God's sake- I beg, I conjure"-
here exclaimed the stranger Captain to Ahab, who thus far had but
icily received his petition.
BEG_SENT "For eight-and-forty hours let me
charter your ship- I will gladly pay for it, and roundly pay for it-
if there be no other way- for eight-and-forty hours only- only that-
you must, oh, you must, and you shall do this thing."
BEG_SENT "His son!"
BEG_SENT cried Stubb, "oh, it's his son he's lost!
BEG_SENT I take back the
coat and watch- what says Ahab?
BEG_SENT We must save that boy."
BEG_SENT "He's drowned with the rest on 'em, last night," said the old Manx
sailor standing behind them; "I heard; all of ye heard their
spirits."
BEG_SENT Now, as it shortly turned out, what made this incident of the
Rachel's the more melancholy, was the circumstance, that not only was
one of the Captain's sons among the number of the missing boat's
crew; but among the number of the other boats' crews, at the same
time, but on the other hand, separated from the ship during the dark
vicissitudes of the chase, there had been still another son; as that
for a time, the wretched father was plunged to the bottom of the
cruellest perplexity; which was only solved for him by his chief
mate's instinctively adopting the ordinary procedure of a whaleship
in such emergencies, that is, when placed between jeopardized but
divided boats, always to pick up the majority first.
BEG_SENT But the captain,
for some unknown constitutional reason, had refrained from mentioning
all this, and not till forced to it by Ahab's iciness did he allude
to his one yet missing boy; a little lad, but twelve years old, whose
father with the earnest but unmisgiving hardihood of a Nantucketer's
paternal love, had thus early sought to initiate him in the perils
and wonders of a vocation almost immemorially the destiny of all his
race.
BEG_SENT Nor does it unfrequently occur, that Nantucket captains will
send a son of such tender age away from them, for a protracted three
or four years' voyage in some other ship than their own; so that
their first knowledge of a whaleman's career shall be unenervated by
any chance display of a father's natural but untimely partiality, or
undue apprehensiveness and concern.
BEG_SENT Meantime, now the stranger was still beseeching his poor boon of
Ahab; and Ahab still stood like an anvil, receiving every shock, but
without the least quivering of his own.
BEG_SENT "I will not go," said the stranger, "till you say aye to me.
BEG_SENT Do to me
as you would have me do to you in the like case.
BEG_SENT For you too have a
boy, Captain Ahab- though but a child, and nestling safely at home
now- a child of your old age too- Yes, yes, you relent; I see it-
run, run, men, now, and stand by to square in the yards."
BEG_SENT "Avast," cried Ahab- "touch not a rope-yarn"; then in a voice that
prolongingly moulded every word- "Captain Gardiner, I will not do
it.
BEG_SENT Even now I lose time, Good-bye, good-bye.
BEG_SENT God bless ye, man, and
may I forgive myself, but I must go.
BEG_SENT Mr.  Starbuck, look at the
binnacle watch, and in three minutes from this present instant warn
off all strangers; then brace forward again, and let the ship sail as
before."
BEG_SENT Hurriedly turning, with averted face, he descended into his cabin,
leaving the strange captain transfixed at this unconditional and
utter rejection of his so earnest suit.
BEG_SENT But starting from his
enchantment, Gardiner silently hurried to the side; more fell than
stepped into his boat, and returned to his ship.
BEG_SENT Soon the two ships diverged their wakes; and long as the strange
vessel was in view, she was seen to yaw hither and thither at every
dark spot, however small, on the sea.
BEG_SENT This way and that her yards
were swung around; starboard and larboard, she continued to tack; now
she beat against a head sea; and again it pushed her before it; while
all the while, her masts and yards were thickly clustered with men,
as three tall cherry trees, when the boys are cherrying among the
boughs.
BEG_SENT But by her still halting course and winding, woeful way, you plainly
saw that this ship that so wept with spray, still remained without
comfort.
BEG_SENT She was Rachel, weeping for her children, because they were
not.
BEG_SENT The Cabin


(Ahab moving to go on deck; Pip catches him hy the hand to
follow.)
BEG_SENT Lad, lad, I tell thee thou must not follow Ahab now.
BEG_SENT The hour is
coming when Ahab would not scare thee from him, yet would not have
thee by him.
BEG_SENT There is that in thee, poor lad, which I feel too curing
to my malady.
BEG_SENT Like cures like; and for this hunt, my malady becomes
my most desired health.
BEG_SENT Do thou abide below here, where they shall
serve thee, as if thou wert the captain.
BEG_SENT Aye, lad, thou shalt sit
here in my own screwed chair; another screw to it, thou must be."
BEG_SENT "No, no, no!
BEG_SENT ye have not a whole body, sir; do ye but use poor me for
your one lost leg; only tread upon me, sir; I ask no more, so I
remain a part of ye."
BEG_SENT "Oh!
BEG_SENT spite of million villains, this makes me a bigot in the fadeless
fidelity of man!- and a black!
BEG_SENT and crazy!- but methinks
like-cures-like applies to him too; he grows so sane again."
BEG_SENT "They tell me, sir, that Stubb did once desert poor little Pip, whose
drowned bones now show white, for all the blackness of his living
skin.
BEG_SENT But I will never desert ye, sir, as Stubb did him.
BEG_SENT Sir, I must
go with ye."
BEG_SENT "If thou speakest thus to me much more, Ahab's purpose keels up in
him.
BEG_SENT I tell thee no; it cannot be."
BEG_SENT "Oh good master, master, master!
BEG_SENT "Weep so, and I will murder thee!
BEG_SENT have a care, for Ahab too is
mad.
BEG_SENT Listen, and thou wilt often hear my ivory foot upon the deck,
and still know that I am there.
BEG_SENT And now I quit thee.
BEG_SENT Thy hand!- Met!
BEG_SENT True art thou, lad, as the circumference to its centre.
BEG_SENT So: God for
ever bless thee; and if it come to that,- God for ever save thee, let
what will befall."
BEG_SENT (Ahab goes; Pip steps one step forward.)
BEG_SENT "Here he this instant stood, I stand in his air,- but I'm alone.
BEG_SENT Now
were even poor Pip here I could endure it, but he's missing.
BEG_SENT Pip!
BEG_SENT Pip!
BEG_SENT Ding, dong, ding!
BEG_SENT Who's seen Pip?
BEG_SENT He must be up here; let's try
the door.
BEG_SENT What?
BEG_SENT neither lock, nor bolt, nor bar; and yet there's no
opening it.
BEG_SENT It must be the spell; he told me to stay here: Aye, and
told me this screwed chair was mine.
BEG_SENT Here, then, I'll seat me,
against the transom, in the ship's full middle, all her keel and her
three masts before me.
BEG_SENT Here, our old sailors say, in their black
seventy-fours great admirals sometimes sit at table, and lord it over
rows of captains and lieutenants.
BEG_SENT Ha!
BEG_SENT what's this?
BEG_SENT epaulets!
BEG_SENT epaulets!
BEG_SENT the epaulets all come crowding.
BEG_SENT Pass round the decanters;
glad to see ye; fill up, monsieurs!
BEG_SENT What an odd feeling, now, when a
black boy's host to white men with gold lace upon their coats!-
Monsieurs, have ye seen one Pip?- a little negro lad, five feet high,
hang-dog look, and cowardly!
BEG_SENT Jumped from a whale-boat once;- seen
him?
BEG_SENT No!
BEG_SENT Well then, fill up again, captains, and let's drink shame
upon all cowards!
BEG_SENT I name no names.
BEG_SENT Shame upon them!
BEG_SENT Put one foot upon
the table.
BEG_SENT Shame upon all cowards.- Hist!
BEG_SENT above there, I hear ivory-
Oh, master!
BEG_SENT master!
BEG_SENT I am indeed down-hearted when you walk over
me.
BEG_SENT But there I'll stay, though this stern strikes rocks; and they
bulge through; and oysters come to join me."
BEG_SENT The Hat


And now that at the proper time and place, after so long and wide a
preliminary cruise, Ahab,- all other whaling waters swept- seemed to
have chased his foe into an oceanfold, to slay him the more securely
there; now, that he found himself hard by the very latitude and
longitude where his tormenting wound had been inflicted; now that a
vessel had been spoken which on the very day preceding had actually
encountered Moby Dick;- and now that all his successive meetings with
various ships contrastingly concurred to show the demoniac
indifference with which the white whale tore his hunters, whether
sinning or sinned against; now it was that there lurked a something
in the old man's eyes, which it was hardly sufferable for feeble
souls to see.
BEG_SENT As the unsetting polar star, which through the
livelong, arctic, six months' night sustains its piercing, steady,
central gaze; so Ahab's purpose now fixedly gleamed down upon the
constant midnight of the gloomy crew.
BEG_SENT It domineered above them so,
that all their bodings, doubts, misgivings, fears, were fain to hide
beneath their souls, and not sprout forth a single spear or leaf.
BEG_SENT In this foreshadowing interval, too, all humor, forced or natural,
vanished.
BEG_SENT Stubb no more strove to raise a smile; Starbuck no more
strove to check one.
BEG_SENT Alike, joy and sorrow, hope and fear, seemed
ground to finest dust, and powdered, for the time, in the clamped
mortar of Ahab's iron soul.
BEG_SENT Like machines, they dumbly moved about
the deck, ever conscious that the old man's despot eye was on them.
BEG_SENT But did you deeply scan him in his more secret confidential hours
when he thought no glance but one was on him; then you would have
seen that even as Ahab's eyes so awed the crew's, the inscrutable
Parsee's glance awed his; or somehow, at least, in some wild way, at
times affected it.
BEG_SENT Such an added, gliding strangeness began to invest
the thin Fedallah now; such ceaseless shudderings shook him; that the
men looked dubious at him; half uncertain, as it seemed, whether
indeed he were a mortal substance, or else a tremulous shadow cast
upon the deck by some unseen being's body.
BEG_SENT And that shadow was always
hovering there.
BEG_SENT For not by night, even, had Fedallah ever certainly
been known to slumber, or go below.
BEG_SENT He would stand still for hours:
but never sat or leaned; his wan but wondrous eves did plainly say-
We two watchmen never rest.
BEG_SENT Nor, at any time, by night or day could the mariners now step upon
the deck, unless Ahab was before them; either standing in his
pivot-hole, or exactly pacing the planks between two undeviating
limits,- the main-mast and the mizen; or else they saw him standing
in the cabin-scuttle,- his living foot advanced upon the deck, as if
to step; his hat slouched heavily over his eyes; so that however
motionless he stood, however the days and nights were added on, that
he had not swung in his hammock; yet hidden beneath that slouching
hat, they could never tell unerringly whether, for all this, his eyes
were really closed at times; or whether he was still intently
scanning them; no matter, though he stood so in the scuttle for a
whole hour on the stretch, and the unheeded night-damp gathered in
beads of dew upon that stone-carved coat and hat.
BEG_SENT The clothes that
the night had wet, the next day's sunshine dried upon him; and so,
day after day, and night after night; he went no more beneath the
planks; whatever he wanted from the cabin that thing he sent for.
BEG_SENT He ate in the same open air; that is, his two only meals,- breakfast
and dinner: supper he never touched; nor reaped his beard; which
darkly grew all gnarled, as unearthed roots of trees blown over,
which still grow idly on at naked base, though perished in the upper
verdure.
BEG_SENT But though his whole life was now become one watch on deck;
and though the Parsee's mystic watch was without intermission as his
own; yet these two never seemed to speak- one man to the other-
unless at long intervals some passing unmomentous matter made it
necessary.
BEG_SENT Though such a potent spell seemed secretly to join the
twain; openly, and to the awe-struck crew, they seemed pole-like
asunder.
BEG_SENT If by day they chanced to speak one word; by night, dumb men
were both, so far as concerned the slightest verbal interchange.
BEG_SENT At
times, for longest hours, without a single hail, they stood far
parted in the starlight; Ahab in his scuttle, the Parsee by the
main-mast; but still fixedly gazing upon each other; as if in the
Parsee Ahab saw his forethrown shadow, in Ahab the Parsee his
abandoned substance.
BEG_SENT And yet, somehow, did Ahab- in his own proper self, as daily, hourly,
and every instant, commandingly revealed to his subordinates,- Ahab
seemed an independent lord; the Parsee but his slave.
BEG_SENT Still again
both seemed yoked together, and an unseen tyrant driving them; the
lean shade siding the solid rib.
BEG_SENT For be this Parsee what he may, all
rib and keel was solid Ahab.
BEG_SENT At the first faintest glimmering of the dawn, his iron voice was
heard from aft,- "Man the mast-heads!
BEG_SENT "- and all through the day, till
after sunset and after twilight, the same voice every hour, at the
striking of the helmsman's bell, was heard- "What d'ye see?- sharp!
BEG_SENT sharp!"
BEG_SENT But when three or four days had slided by, after meeting the
children-seeking Rachel; and no spout had yet been seen; the
monomaniac old man seemed distrustful of his crew's fidelity; at
least, of nearly all except the Pagan harpooneers; he seemed to
doubt, even, whether Stubb and Flask might not willingly overlook the
sight he sought.
BEG_SENT But if these suspicions were really his, he
sagaciously refrained from verbally expressing them, however his
actions might seem to hint them.
BEG_SENT "I will have the first sight of the whale myself,"- he said.
BEG_SENT "Aye!
BEG_SENT Ahab must have the doubloon!
BEG_SENT and with his own hands he rigged a nest
of basketed bowlines; and sending a hand aloft, with a single sheaved
block, to secure to the mainmast head, he received the two ends of
the downwardreeved rope; and attaching one to his basket prepared,
pin for the other end, in order to fasten it at the rail.
BEG_SENT This done,
with that end yet in his hand and standing beside the pin, he looked
round upon his crew, sweeping from one to the other; pausing his
glance long upon Daggoo, Queequeg, Tashtego; but shunning Fedallah;
and then settling his firm relying eye upon the chief mate, said,-
"Take the rope, sir- I give it into thy hands, Starbuck."
BEG_SENT Then
arranging his person in the basket, he gave the word for them to
hoist him to his perch, Starbuck being the one who secured the rope
at last; and afterwards stood near it.
BEG_SENT And thus, with one hand
clinging round the royal mast, Ahab gazed abroad upon the sea for
miles and miles,- ahead astern, this side, and that,- within the wide
expanded circle commanded at so great a height.
BEG_SENT When in working with his hands at some lofty almost isolated place in
the rigging, which chances to afford no foothold, the sailor at sea
is hoisted up to that spot, and sustained there by the rope; under
these circumstances, its fastened end on deck is always given in
strict charge to some one man who has the special watch of
it.
BEG_SENT Because in such a wilderness of running rigging, whose various
different relations aloft cannot always be infallibly discerned by
what is seen of them at the deck; and when the deck-ends of these
ropes are being every few minutes cast down from the fastenings, it
would be but a natural fatality, if, unprovided with a constant
watchman, the hoisted sailor should by some carelessness of the crew
be cast adrift and fall all swooping to the sea.
BEG_SENT So Ahab's
proceedings in this matter were not unusual; the only strange thing
about them seemed to be, that Starbuck, almost the one only man who
had ever ventured to oppose him with anything in the slightest degree
approaching to decision- one of those too, whose faithfulness on the
look-out he had seemed to doubt somewhat; it was strange, that this
was the very man he should select for his watchman; freely giving his
whole life into such an otherwise distrusted person's hands.
BEG_SENT Now, the first time Ahab was perched aloft; ere he had been there ten
minutes; one of those red-billed savage sea-hawks which so often fly
incommodiously close round the manned mast-heads of whalemen in these
latitudes; one of these birds came wheeling and screaming round his
head in a maze of untrackably swift circlings.
BEG_SENT Then it darted a
thousand feet straight up into the air; then spiralized downwards,
and went eddying again round his head.
BEG_SENT But with his gaze fixed upon the dim and distant horizon, Ahab seemed
not to mark this wild bird; nor, indeed, would any one else have
marked it much, it being no uncommon circumstance; only now almost
the least heedful eye seemed to see some sort of cunning meaning in
almost every sight.
BEG_SENT "Your hat, your hat, sir!"
BEG_SENT suddenly cried the Sicilian seaman, who
being posted at the mizen-mast-head, stood directly behind Ahab,
though somewhat lower than his level, and with a deep gulf of air
dividing them.
BEG_SENT But already the sable wing was before the old man's eyes; the long
hooked bill at his head: with a scream, the black hawk darted away
with his prize.
BEG_SENT An eagle flew thrice round Tarquin's head, removing his cap to
replace it, and thereupon Tanaquil, his wife, declared that Tarquin
would be king of Rome.
BEG_SENT But only by the replacing of the cap was that
omen accounted good.
BEG_SENT Ahab's hat was never restored; the wild hawk
flew on and on with it; far in advance of the prow: and at last
disappeared; while from the point of that disappearance, a minute
black spot was dimly discerned, falling from that vast height into
the sea.
BEG_SENT The Pequod Meets The Delight


The intense Pequod sailed on; the rolling waves and days went by; the
life-buoy-coffin still lightly swung; and another ship, most
miserably misnamed the Delight, was descried.
BEG_SENT As she drew nigh, all
eyes were fixed upon her broad beams, called shears, which, in some
whaling-ships, cross the quarter-deck at the height of eight or nine
feet; serving to carry the spare, unrigged, or disabled boats.
BEG_SENT Upon the stranger's shears were beheld the shattered, white ribs, and
some few splintered planks, of what had once been a whale-boat; but
you now saw through this wreck, as plainly as you see through the
peeled, half-unhinged, and bleaching skeleton of a horse.
BEG_SENT "Hast seen the White Whale?"
BEG_SENT "Look!"
BEG_SENT replied the hollow-cheeked captain from his taffrail; and
with his trumpet he pointed to the wreck.
BEG_SENT "Hast killed him?"
BEG_SENT "The harpoon is not yet forged that ever will do that," answered the
other, sadly glancing upon a rounded hammock on the deck, whose
gathered sides some noiseless sailors were busy in sewing together.
BEG_SENT "Not forged!"
BEG_SENT and snatching Perth's levelled iron from the crotch,
Ahab held it out, exclaiming- "Look ye, Nantucketer; here in this
hand I hold his death!
BEG_SENT Tempered in blood, and tempered by lightning
are these barbs; and I swear to temper them triply in that hot place
behind the fin, where the White Whale most feels his accursed life!"
BEG_SENT "Then God keep thee, old man- see'st thou that"- pointing to the
hammock- "I bury but one of five stout men, who were alive only
yesterday; but were dead ere night.
BEG_SENT Only that one I bury; the rest
were buried before they died; you sail upon their tomb."
BEG_SENT Then turning
to his crew- "Are ye ready there?
BEG_SENT place the plank then on the rail,
and lift the body; so, then- Oh!
BEG_SENT God"- advancing towards the hammock
with uplifted hands- "may the resurrection and the life-"

"Brace forward!
BEG_SENT Up helm!"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab like lightning to his men.
BEG_SENT But the suddenly started Pequod was not quick enough to escape the
sound of the splash that the corpse soon made as it struck the sea;
not so quick, indeed, but that some of the flying bubbles might have
sprinkled her hull with their ghostly baptism.
BEG_SENT As Ahab now glided from the dejected Delight, the strange life-buoy
hanging at the Pequod's stern came into conspicuous relief.
BEG_SENT "Ha!
BEG_SENT yonder!
BEG_SENT look yonder, men!"
BEG_SENT cried a foreboding voice in her wake.
BEG_SENT "In vain, oh, ye strangers, ye fly our sad burial; ye but turn us
your taffrail to show us your coffin!"
BEG_SENT The Symphony


It was a clear steel-blue day.
BEG_SENT The firmaments of air and sea were
hardly separable in that all-pervading azure; only, the pensive air
was transparently pure and soft, with a woman's look, and the robust
and man-like sea heaved with long, strong, lingering swells, as
Samson's chest in his sleep.
BEG_SENT Hither, and thither, on high, glided the snow-white wings of small,
unspeckled birds; these were the gentle thoughts of the feminine air;
but to and fro in the deeps, far down in the bottomless blue, rushed
mighty leviathans, sword-fish, and sharks; and these were the strong,
troubled, murderous thinkings of the masculine sea.
BEG_SENT But though thus contrasting within, the contrast was only in shades
and shadows without; those two seemed one; it was only the sex, as it
were, that distinguished them.
BEG_SENT Aloft, like a royal czar and king, the sun seemed giving this gentle
air to this bold and rolling sea; even as bride to groom.
BEG_SENT And at the
girdling line of the horizon, a soft and tremulous motion- most seen
here at the Equator- denoted the fond, throbbing trust, the loving
alarms, with which the poor bride gave her bosom away.
BEG_SENT Tied up and twisted; gnarled and knotted with wrinkles; haggardly
firm and unyielding; his eyes glowing like coals, that still glow in
the ashes of ruin; untottering Ahab stood forth in the clearness of
the morn; lifting his splintered helmet of a brow to the fair girl's
forehead of heaven.
BEG_SENT Oh, immortal infancy, and innocency of the azure!
BEG_SENT Invisible winged
creatures that frolic all round us!
BEG_SENT Sweet childhood of air and sky!
BEG_SENT how oblivious were ye of old Ahab's close-coiled woe!
BEG_SENT But so have I
seen little Miriam and Martha, laughing-eyed elves, heedlessly gambol
around their old sire; sporting with the circle of singed locks which
grew on the marge of that burnt-out crater of his brain.
BEG_SENT Slowly crossing the deck from the scuttle, Ahab leaned over the side
and watched how his shadow in the water sank and sank to his gaze,
the more and the more that he strove to pierce the profundity.
BEG_SENT But
the lovely aromas in that enchanted air did at last seem to dispel,
for a moment, the cankerous thing in his soul.
BEG_SENT That glad, happy air,
that winsome sky, did at last stroke and caress him; the step-mother
world, so long cruel- forbidding- now threw affectionate arms round
his stubborn neck, and did seem to joyously sob over him, as if over
one, that however wilful and erring, she could yet find it in her
heart to save and to bless.
BEG_SENT From beneath his slouched hat Ahab
dropped a tear into the sea; nor did all the Pacific contain such
wealth as that one wee drop.
BEG_SENT Starbuck saw the old man; saw him, how he heavily leaned over the
side; and he seemed to hear in his own true heart the measureless
sobbing that stole out of the centre of the serenity around.
BEG_SENT Careful
not to touch him, or be noticed by him, he yet drew near to him, and
stood there.
BEG_SENT Ahab turned.
BEG_SENT "Starbuck!"
BEG_SENT "Sir."
BEG_SENT "Oh, Starbuck!
BEG_SENT it is a mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky.
BEG_SENT On
such a day- very much such a sweetness as this- I struck my first
whale- a boy-harpooneer of eighteen!
BEG_SENT Forty- forty- forty years ago!-
ago!
BEG_SENT Forty years of continual whaling!
BEG_SENT forty years of privation, and
peril, and storm-time!
BEG_SENT forty years on the pitiless sea!
BEG_SENT for forty
years has Ahab forsaken the peaceful land, for forty years to make
war on the horrors of the deep!
BEG_SENT Aye and yes, Starbuck, out of those
forty years I have not spent three ashore.
BEG_SENT When I think of this life
I have led; the desolation of solitude it has been; the masoned,
walled-town of a Captain's exclusiveness, which admits but small
entrance to any sympathy from the green country without- oh,
weariness!
BEG_SENT heaviness!
BEG_SENT Guinea-coast slavery of solitary command!- when
I think of all this; only half-suspected, not so keenly known to me
before- and how for forty years I have fed upon dry salted fare- fit
emblem of the dry nourishment of my soul!- when the poorest landsman
has had fresh fruit to his daily hand, and broken the world's fresh
bread to my mouldy crusts- away, whole oceans away, from that young
girl-wife I wedded past fifty, and sailed for Cape Horn the next day,
leaving but one dent in my marriage pillow- wife?
BEG_SENT wife?- rather a
widow with her husband alive?
BEG_SENT Aye, I widowed that poor girl when I
married her, Starbuck; and then, the madness, the frenzy, the boiling
blood and the smoking brow, with which, for a thousand lowerings old
Ahab has furiously, foamingly chased his prey- more a demon than a
man!- aye, aye!
BEG_SENT what a forty years' fool- fool- old fool, has old
Ahab been!
BEG_SENT Why this strife of the chase?
BEG_SENT why weary, and palsy the arm
at the oar, and the iron, and the lance?
BEG_SENT how the richer or better is
Ahab now?
BEG_SENT Behold.
BEG_SENT Oh, Starbuck!
BEG_SENT is it not hard, that with this weary
load I bear, one poor leg should have been snatched from under me?
BEG_SENT Here, brush this old hair aside; it blinds me, that I seem to
weep.
BEG_SENT Locks so grey did never grow but from out some ashes!
BEG_SENT But do I
look very old, so very, very old, Starbuck?
BEG_SENT I feel deadly faint,
bowed, and humped, as though I were Adam, staggering beneath the
piled centuries since Paradise.
BEG_SENT God!
BEG_SENT God!
BEG_SENT God!- crack my heart!-
stave my brain!- mockery!
BEG_SENT mockery!
BEG_SENT bitter, biting mockery of grey
hairs, have I lived enough joy to wear ye; and seem and feel thus
intolerably old?
BEG_SENT Close!
BEG_SENT stand close to me, Starbuck; let me look into
a human eye; it is better than to gaze into sea or sky; better than
to gaze upon God.
BEG_SENT By the green land; by the bright hearthstone!
BEG_SENT this
is the magic glass, man; I see my wife and my child in thine eye.
BEG_SENT No,
no; stay on board, on board!- lower not when I do; when branded Ahab
gives chase to Moby Dick.
BEG_SENT That hazard shall not be thine.
BEG_SENT No, no!
BEG_SENT not
with the far away home I see in that eye!"
BEG_SENT "Oh, my Captain!
BEG_SENT my Captain!
BEG_SENT noble soul!
BEG_SENT grand old heart, after all!
BEG_SENT why should any one give chase to that hated fish!
BEG_SENT Away with me!
BEG_SENT let
us fly these deadly waters!
BEG_SENT let us home!
BEG_SENT Wife and child, too, are
Starbuck's- wife and child of his brotherly, sisterly, play-fellow
youth; even as thine, sir, are the wife and child of thy loving,
longing, paternal old age!
BEG_SENT Away!
BEG_SENT let us away!- this instant let me
alter the course!
BEG_SENT How cheerily, how hilariously, O my Captain, would
we bowl on our way to see old Nantucket again!
BEG_SENT I think, sir, they
have some such mild blue days, even as this, in Nantucket."
BEG_SENT "They have, they have.
BEG_SENT I have seen them- some summer days in the
morning.
BEG_SENT About this time- yes, it is his noon nap now- the boy
vivaciously wakes; sits up in bed; and his mother tells him of me, of
cannibal old me; how I am abroad upon the deep, but will yet come
back to dance him again."
BEG_SENT "'Tis my Mary, my Mary herself!
BEG_SENT She promised that my boy, every
morning, should be carried to the hill to catch the first glimpse of
his father's sail!
BEG_SENT Yes, yes!
BEG_SENT no more!
BEG_SENT it is done!
BEG_SENT we head for
Nantucket!
BEG_SENT Come, my Captain, study out the course, and let us away!
BEG_SENT See, see!
BEG_SENT the boy's face from the window!
BEG_SENT the boy's hand on the
hill!"
BEG_SENT But Ahab's glance was averted; like a blighted fruit tree he shook,
and cast his last, cindered apple to the soil.
BEG_SENT "What is it, what nameless, inscrutable, unearthly thing is it; what
cozening, hidden lord and master, and cruel, remorseless emperor
commands me; that against all natural lovings and longings, I so keep
pushing, and crowding, and jamming myself on all the time; recklessly
making me ready to do what in my own proper, natural heart, I durst
not so much as dare?
BEG_SENT Is Ahab, Ahab?
BEG_SENT Is it I, God, or who, that lifts
this arm?
BEG_SENT But if the great sun move not of himself; but is an
errand-boy in heaven; nor one single star can revolve, but by some
invisible power; how then can this one small heart beat; this one
small brain think thoughts; unless God does that beating, does that
thinking, does that living, and not I.
BEG_SENT By heaven, man, we are turned
round and round in this world, like yonder windlass, and Fate is the
handspike.
BEG_SENT And all the time, lo!
BEG_SENT that smiling sky, and this unsounded
sea!
BEG_SENT Look!
BEG_SENT see yon Albicore!
BEG_SENT who put it into him to chase and fang
that flying-fish?
BEG_SENT Where do murderers go, man!
BEG_SENT Who's to doom, when the
judge himself is dragged to the bar?
BEG_SENT But it is a mild, mild wind, and
a mild looking sky; and the airs smells now, as if it blew from a
far-away meadow; they have been making hay somewhere under the slopes
of the Andes, Starbuck, and the mowers are sleeping among the
new-mown hay.
BEG_SENT Sleeping?
BEG_SENT Aye, toil we how we may, we all sleep at last
on the field.
BEG_SENT Sleep?
BEG_SENT Aye, and rust amid greenness; as last year's
scythes flung down, and left in the half-cut swarths- Starbuck!"
BEG_SENT But blanched to a corpse's hue with despair, the Mate had stolen
away.
BEG_SENT Ahab crossed the deck to gaze over on the other side; but started at
two reflected, fixed eyes in the water there, Fedallah was
motionlessly leaning over the same rail.
BEG_SENT The Chase - First Day


That night, in the mid-watch when the old man- as his wont at
intervals- stepped forth from the scuttle in which he leaned, and
went to his pivot-hole, he suddenly thrust out his face fiercely,
snuffing up the sea air as a sagacious ship's dog will, in drawing
nigh to some barbarous isle.
BEG_SENT He declared that a whale must be
near.
BEG_SENT Soon that peculiar odor, sometimes to a great distance given
forth by the living sperm whale, was palpable to all the watch; nor
was any mariner surprised when, after inspecting the compass, and
then the dog-vane, and then ascertaining the precise bearing of the
odor as nearly as possible, Ahab rapidly ordered the ship's course to
be slightly altered, and the sail to be shortened.
BEG_SENT The acute policy dictating these movements was sufficiently
vindicated at daybreak, by the sight of a long sleek on the sea
directly and lengthwise ahead, smooth as oil, and resembling in the
pleated watery wrinkles bordering it, the polished metallic-like
marks of some swift tide-rip, at the mouth of a deep, rapid stream.
BEG_SENT "Man the mast-heads!
BEG_SENT Call all hands!"
BEG_SENT Thundering with the butts of three clubbed handspikes on the
forecastle deck, Daggoo roused the sleepers with such judgment claps
that they seemed to exhale from the scuttle, so instantaneously did
they appear with their clothes in their hands.
BEG_SENT "What d'ye see?"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab, flattening his face to the sky.
BEG_SENT "Nothing, nothing sir!"
BEG_SENT was the sound hailing down in reply.
BEG_SENT "T'gallant sails!- stunsails!
BEG_SENT alow and aloft, and on both sides!"
BEG_SENT All sail being set, he now cast loose the life-line, reserved for
swaying him to the main royal-mast head; and in a few moments they
were hoisting him thither, when, while but two thirds of the way
aloft, and while peering ahead through the horizontal vacancy between
the main-top-sail and top-gallant-sail, he raised a gull-like cry in
the air.
BEG_SENT "There she blows!- there she blows!
BEG_SENT A hump like a
snow-hill!
BEG_SENT It is Moby Dick!"
BEG_SENT Fired by the cry which seemed simultaneously taken up by the three
look-outs, the men on deck rushed to the rigging to behold the famous
whale they had so long been pursuing.
BEG_SENT Ahab had now gained his final
perch, some feet above the other look-outs, Tashtego standing just
beneath him on the cap of the top-gallant-mast, so that the Indian's
head was almost on a level with Ahab's heel.
BEG_SENT From this height the
whale was now seen some mile or so ahead, at every roll of the sea
revealing his high sparkling hump, and regularly jetting his silent
spout into the air.
BEG_SENT To the credulous mariners it seemed the same
silent spout they had so long ago beheld in the moonlit Atlantic and
Indian Oceans.
BEG_SENT "And did none of ye see it before?"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab, hailing the perched
men all around him.
BEG_SENT "I saw him almost that same instant, sir, that Captain Ahab did, and
I cried out," said Tashtego.
BEG_SENT "Not the same instant; not the same- no, the doubloon is mine, Fate
reserved the doubloon for me.
BEG_SENT I only; none of ye could have raised
the White Whale first.
BEG_SENT There she blows!- there she blows!- there she
blows!
BEG_SENT There again!- there again!"
BEG_SENT he cried, in long-drawn,
lingering, methodic tones, attuned to the gradual prolongings of the
whale's visible jets.
BEG_SENT "He's going to sound!
BEG_SENT In stunsails!
BEG_SENT Down
top-gallant-sails!
BEG_SENT Stand by three boats.
BEG_SENT Mr. Starbuck, remember, stay
on board, and keep the ship.
BEG_SENT Helm there!
BEG_SENT Luff, luff a point!
BEG_SENT So;
steady, man, steady!
BEG_SENT There go flukes!
BEG_SENT No, no; only black water!
BEG_SENT All
ready the boats there?
BEG_SENT Stand by, stand by!
BEG_SENT Lower me, Mr. Starbuck;
lower, lower,- quick, quicker!"
BEG_SENT and he slid through the air to the
deck.
BEG_SENT "He is heading straight to leeward, sir," cried Stubb, "right away
from us; cannot have seen the ship yet."
BEG_SENT "Be dumb, man!
BEG_SENT Stand by the braces!
BEG_SENT Hard down the helm!- brace up!
BEG_SENT Shiver her!- shiver her!- So; well that!
BEG_SENT Boats, boats!"
BEG_SENT Soon all the boats but Starbuck's were dropped; all the boat-sails
set- all the paddles plying; with rippling swiftness, shooting to
leeward; and Ahab heading the onset.
BEG_SENT A pale, death-glimmer lit up
Fedallah's sunken eyes; a hideous motion gnawed his mouth.
BEG_SENT Like noiseless nautilus shells, their light prows sped through the
sea; but only slowly they neared the foe.
BEG_SENT As they neared him, the
ocean grew still more smooth; seemed drawing a carpet over its waves;
seemed a noon-meadow, so serenely it spread.
BEG_SENT At length the breathless
hunter came so nigh seemingly unsuspecting prey, that his entire
dazzling hump was distinctly visible, sliding along the sea as if an
isolated thing, and continually set in a revolving ring of finest,
fleecy, greenish foam.
BEG_SENT He saw the vast, involved wrinkles of the
slightly projecting head beyond.
BEG_SENT Before it, far out on the soft
Turkish-rugged waters, went the glistening white shadow from his
broad, milky forehead, a musical rippling playfully accompanying the
shade; and behind, the blue waters interchangeably flowed over into
the moving valley of his steady wake; and on either hand bright
bubbles arose and danced by his side.
BEG_SENT But these were broken again by
the light toes of hundreds of gay fowls softly feathering the sea,
alternate with their fitful flight; and like to some flag-staff
rising from the painted hull of an argosy, the tall but shattered
pole of a recent lance projected from the white whale's back; and at
intervals one of the cloud of soft-toed fowls hovering, and to and
fro skimming like a canopy over the fish, silently perched and rocked
on this pole, the long tail feathers streaming like pennons.
BEG_SENT A gentle joyousness- a mighty mildness of repose in swiftness,
invested the gliding whale.
BEG_SENT Not the white bull Jupiter swimming away
with ravished Europa clinging to his graceful horns; his lovely,
leering eyes sideways intent upon the maid; with smooth bewitching
fleetness, rippling straight for the nuptial bower in Crete; not
Jove, not that great majesty Supreme!
BEG_SENT did surpass the glorified White
Whale as he so divinely swam.
BEG_SENT On each soft side- coincident with the parted swell, that but once
leaving him then flowed so wide away- on each bright side, the whale
shed off enticings.
BEG_SENT No wonder there had been some among the hunters
who namelessly transported and allured by all this serenity, had
ventured to assail it; but had fatally found that quietude but the
vesture of tornadoes.
BEG_SENT Yet calm, enticing calm, oh, whale!
BEG_SENT thou
glidest on, to all who for the first time eye thee, no matter how
many in that same way thou mayst have bejuggled and destroyed before.
BEG_SENT And thus, through the serene tranquilities of the tropical sea, among
waves whose hand-clappings were suspended by exceeding rapture, Moby
Dick moved on, still withholding from sight the full terrors of his
submerged trunk, entirely hiding the wrenched hideousness of his
jaw.
BEG_SENT But soon the fore part of him slowly rose from the water; for an
instant his whole marbleized body formed a high arch, like Virginia's
Natural Bridge, and warningly waving his bannered flukes in the air,
the grand god revealed himself, sounded and went out of
sight.
BEG_SENT Hoveringly halting, and dipping on the wing, the white
sea-fowls longingly lingered over the agitated pool that he left.
BEG_SENT With oars apeak, and paddles down, the sheets of their sails adrift,
the three boats now stilly floated, awaiting Moby Dick's
reappearance.
BEG_SENT "An hour," said Ahab, standing rooted in his boat's stern; and he
gazed beyond the whale's place, towards the dim blue spaces and wide
wooing vacancies to leeward.
BEG_SENT It was only an instant; for again his
eyes seemed whirling round in his head as he swept the watery
circle.
BEG_SENT The breeze now freshened; the sea began to swell.
BEG_SENT "The birds!- the birds!"
BEG_SENT cried Tashtego.
BEG_SENT In long Indian file, as when herons take wing, the white birds were
now all flying towards Ahab's boat; and when within a few yards began
fluttering over the water there, wheeling round and round, with
joyous, expectant cries.
BEG_SENT Their vision was keener than man's; Ahab
could discover no sign in the sea.
BEG_SENT But suddenly as he peered down and
down into its depths, he profoundly saw a white living spot no bigger
than a white weasel, with wonderful celerity uprising, and magnifying
as it rose, till it turned, and then there were plainly revealed two
long crooked rows of white, glistening teeth, floating up from the
undiscoverable bottom.
BEG_SENT It was Moby Dick's open mouth and scrolled
jaw; his vast, shadowed bulk still half blending with the blue of the
sea.
BEG_SENT The glittering mouth yawned beneath the boat like an open-doored
marble tomb; and giving one sidelong sweep with his steering oar,
Ahab whirled the craft aside from this tremendous apparition.
BEG_SENT Then,
calling upon Fedallah to change places with him, went forward to the
bows, and seizing Perth's harpoon, commanded his crew to grasp their
oars and stand by to stern.
BEG_SENT Now, by reason of this timely spinning round the boat upon its axis,
its bow, by anticipation, was made to face the whale's head while yet
under water.
BEG_SENT But as if perceiving this stratagem, Moby Dick, with
that malicious intelligence ascribed to him, sidelingly transplanted
himself, as it were, in an instant, shooting his pleated head
lengthwise beneath the boat.
BEG_SENT Through and through; through every plank and each rib, it thrilled
for an instant, the whale obliquely lying on his back, in the manner
of a biting shark slowly and feelingly taking its bows full within
his mouth, so that the long, narrow, scrolled lower jaw curled high
up into the open air, and one of the teeth caught in a row-lock.
BEG_SENT The
bluish pearl-white of the inside of the jaw was within six inches of
Ahab's head, and reached higher than that.
BEG_SENT In this attitude the White
Whale now shook the slight cedar as a mildly cruel cat her
mouse.
BEG_SENT With unastonished eyes Fedallah gazed, and crossed his arms;
but the tiger-yellow crew were tumbling over each other's heads to
gain the uttermost stern.
BEG_SENT And now, while both elastic gunwales were springing in and out, as
the whale dallied with the doomed craft in this devilish way; and
from his body being submerged beneath the boat, he could not be
darted at from the bows, for the bows were almost inside of him, as
it were; and while the other boats involuntarily paused, as before a
quick crisis impossible to withstand, then it was that monomaniac
Ahab, furious with this tantalizing vicinity of his foe, which placed
him all alive and helpless in the very jaws he hated; frenzied with
all this, he seized the long bone with his naked hands, and wildly
strove to wrench from its gripe.
BEG_SENT As now he thus vainly strove, the
jaw slipped from him; the frail gunwales bent in, collapsed, and
snapped, as both jaws, like an enormous shears, sliding further aft,
bit the craft completely in twain, and locked themselves fast again
in the sea, midway between the two floating wrecks.
BEG_SENT These floated
aside, the broken ends drooping, the crew at the stern-wreck clinging
to the gunwales, and striving to hold fast to the oars to lash them
across.
BEG_SENT At that preluding moment, ere the boat was yet snapped, Ahab, the
first to perceive the whale's intent, by the crafty upraising of his
head, a movement that loosed his hold for the time; at that moment
his hand had made one final effort to push the boat out of the
bite.
BEG_SENT But only slipping further into the whale's mouth, and tilting
over sideways as it slipped, the boat had shaken off his hold on the
jaw; spilled him out of it, as he leaned to the push; and so he fell
flat-faced upon the sea.
BEG_SENT Ripplingly withdrawing from his prey, Moby Dick now lay at a little
distance, vertically thrusting his oblong white head up and down in
the billows; and at the same time slowly revolving his whole spindled
body; so that when his vast wrinkled forehead rose- some twenty or
more feet out of the water- the now rising swells, with all their
confluent waves, dazzlingly broke against it; vindictively tossing
their shivered spray still higher into the air.
BEG_SENT So, in a gale, the
but half baffled Channel billows only recoil from the base of the
