Eddystone, triumphantly to overleap its summit with their scud.
BEG_SENT But soon resuming his horizontal attitude, Moby Dick swam swiftly
round and round the wrecked crew; sideways churning the water in his
vengeful wake, as if lashing himself up to still another and more
deadly assault.
BEG_SENT The sight of the splintered boat seemed to madden
him, as the blood of grapes and mulberries cast before Antiochus's
elephants in the book of Maccabees.
BEG_SENT Meanwhile Ahab half smothered in
the foam of the whale's insolent tail, and too much of a cripple to
swim,- though he could still keep afloat, even in the heart of such a
whirlpool as that; helpless Ahab's head was seen, like a tossed
bubble which the least chance shock might burst.
BEG_SENT From the boat's
fragmentary stern, Fedallah incuriously and mildly eved him; the
clinging crew, at the other drifting end, could not succor him; more
than enough was it for them to look to themselves.
BEG_SENT For so revolvingly
appalling was the White Whale's aspect, and so planetarily swift the
ever-contracting circles he made, that he seemed horizontally
swooping upon them.
BEG_SENT And though the other boats, unharmed, still
hovered hard by; still they dared not pull into the eddy to strike,
lest that should be the signal for the instant destruction of the
jeopardized castaways, Ahab and all; nor in that case could they
themselves hope to escape.
BEG_SENT With straining eyes, then, they remained
on the outer edge of the direful zone, whose centre had now become
the old man's head.
BEG_SENT Meantime, from the beginning all this had been descried from the
ship's mast heads; and squaring her yards, she had borne down upon
the scene; and was now so nigh, that Ahab in the water hailed her!-
"Sail on the"- but that moment a breaking sea dashed on him from Moby
Dick, and whelmed him for the time.
BEG_SENT But struggling out of it again,
and chancing to rise on a towering crest, he shouted,- "Sail on the
whale!- Drive him off!"
BEG_SENT The Pequod's prows were pointed-, and breaking up the charmed circle,
she effectually parted the white whale from his victim.
BEG_SENT As he
sullenly swam off, the boats flew to the rescue.
BEG_SENT Dragged into Stubb's boat with blood-shot, blinded eyes, the white
brine caking in his wrinkles; the long tension of Ahab's bodily
strength did crack, and helplessly he yielded to his body's doom for
a time, lying all crushed in the bottom of Stubb's boat, like one
trodden under foot of herds of elephants.
BEG_SENT Far inland, nameless wails
came from him, as desolate sounds from out ravines.
BEG_SENT But this intensity of his physical prostration did but so much the
more abbreviate it.
BEG_SENT In an instant's compass, great hearts sometimes
condense to one deep pang, the sum total of those shallow pains
kindly diffused through feebler men's whole lives.
BEG_SENT And so, such
hearts, though summary in each one suffering; still, if the gods
decree it, in their life-time aggregate a whole age of woe, wholly
made up of instantaneous intensities; for even in their pointless
centres, those noble natures contain the entire circumferences of
inferior souls.
BEG_SENT "The harpoon," said Ahab, half way rising, and draggingly leaning on
one bended arm- "is it safe?"
BEG_SENT "Aye, sir, for it was not darted; this is it," said Stubb, showing
it.
BEG_SENT "Lay it before me;- any missing men?"
BEG_SENT "One, two, three, four, five;- there were five oars, sir, and here
are five men."
BEG_SENT "That's good.- Help me, man; I wish to stand.
BEG_SENT So, so, I see him!
BEG_SENT there!
BEG_SENT there!
BEG_SENT going to leeward still; what a leaping spout!- Hands
off from me!
BEG_SENT The eternal sap runs up in Ahab's bones again!
BEG_SENT Set the
sail; out oars; the helm!"
BEG_SENT It is often the case that when a boat is stove, its crew, being
picked up by another boat, help to work that second boat; and the
chase is thus continued with what is called double-banked oars.
BEG_SENT It
was thus now.
BEG_SENT But the added power of the boat did not equal the added
power of the whale, for he seemed to have treble-banked his every
fin; swimming with a velocity which plainly showed, that if now,
under these circumstances, pushed on, the chase would prove an
indefinitely prolonged, if not a hopeless one; nor could any crew
endure for so long a period, such an unintermitted, intense straining
at the oar; a thing barely tolerable only in some one brief
vicissitude.
BEG_SENT The ship itself, then, as it sometimes happens, offered
the most promising intermediate means of overtaking the chase.
BEG_SENT Accordingly, the boats now made for her, and were soon swayed up to
their cranes- the two parts of the wrecked boat having been
previously secured by her- and then hoisting everything to her side,
and stacking her canvas high up, and sideways outstretching it with
stunsails, like the double-jointed wings of an albatross; the Pequod
bore down in the leeward wake of Moby Dick.
BEG_SENT At the well known,
methodic intervals, the whale's glittering spout was regularly
announced from the manned mast-heads; and when he would be reported
as just gone down, Ahab would take the time, and then pacing the
deck, binnacle-watch in hand, so soon as the last second of the
allotted hour expired, his voice was heard.- "Whose is the doubloon
now?
BEG_SENT D'ye see him?"
BEG_SENT and if the reply was No, sir!
BEG_SENT straightway he
commanded them to lift him to his perch.
BEG_SENT In this way the day wore on;
Ahab, now aloft and motionless; anon, unrestingly pacing the planks.
BEG_SENT As he was thus walking, uttering no sound, except to hail the men
aloft, or to bid them hoist a sail still higher, or to spread one to
a still greater breadth- thus to and fro pacing, beneath his slouched
hat, at every turn he passed his own wrecked boat, which had been
dropped upon the quarter-deck, and lay there reversed; broken bow to
shattered stern.
BEG_SENT At last he paused before it; and as in an already
over-clouded sky fresh troops of clouds will sometimes sail across,
so over the old man's face there now stole some such added gloom as
this.
BEG_SENT Stubb saw him pause; and perhaps intending, not vainly, though, to
evince his own unabated fortitude, and thus keep up a valiant place
in his Captain's mind, he advanced, and eyeing the wreck exclaimed-
"The thistle the ass refused; it pricked his mouth too keenly, sir,
ha!
BEG_SENT ha!"
BEG_SENT "What soulless thing is this that laughs before a wreck?
BEG_SENT Man, man!
BEG_SENT did I not know thee brave as fearless fire (and as mechanical) I
could swear thou wert a paltroon.
BEG_SENT Groan nor laugh should be heard
before a wreck."
BEG_SENT "Aye, sir," said Starbuck drawing near, "'tis a solemn sight; an
omen, and an ill one."
BEG_SENT "Omen?
BEG_SENT omen?- the dictionary!
BEG_SENT If the gods think to speak outright to
man, they will honorably speak outright; not shake their heads, and
give an old wives' darkling hint.- Begone!
BEG_SENT Ye two are the opposite
poles of one thing; Starbuck is Stubb reversed, and Stubb is
Starbuck; and ye two are all mankind; and Ahab stands alone among the
millions of the peopled earth, nor gods nor men his neighbors!
BEG_SENT Cold,
cold- I shiver!- How now?
BEG_SENT Aloft there!
BEG_SENT D'ye see him?
BEG_SENT Sing out for
every spout, though he spout ten times a second!"
BEG_SENT The day was nearly done; only the helm of his golden robe was
rustling.
BEG_SENT Soon it was almost dark, but the look-out men still
remained unset.
BEG_SENT "Can't see the spout now, sir;- too dark"- cried a voice from the
air.
BEG_SENT "How heading when last seen?"
BEG_SENT "As before, sir,- straight to leeward."
BEG_SENT "Good!
BEG_SENT he will travel slower now 'tis night.
BEG_SENT Down royals and
top-gallant stunsails, Mr. Starbuck.
BEG_SENT We must not run over him before
morning; he's making a passage now, and may heave-to a while.
BEG_SENT Helm
there!
BEG_SENT keep her full before the wind!- Aloft!
BEG_SENT come down!- Mr. Stubb,
send a fresh hand to the fore-mast head, and see it manned till
morning.
BEG_SENT "- Then advancing towards the doubloon in the main-mast-
"Men, this gold is mine, for I earned it; but I shall let it abide
here till the White Whale is dead; and then, whosoever of ye first
raises him, upon the day he shall be killed, this gold is that man's;
and if on that day I shall again raise him, then, ten times its sum
shall be divided among all of ye!
BEG_SENT Away now!
BEG_SENT the deck is thine, sir!"
BEG_SENT And so saying, he placed himself half way within the scuttle, and
slouching his hat, stood there till dawn, except when at intervals
rousing himself to see how the night wore on.
BEG_SENT This motion is peculiar to the sperm whale.
BEG_SENT It receives its
designation (pitchpoling) from its being likened to that preliminary
up-and-down poise of the whale-lance, in the exercise called
pitchpoling, previously described.
BEG_SENT By this motion the whale must best
and most comprehensively view whatever objects may be encircling him.
BEG_SENT The Chase - Second Day


At day-break, the three mast-heads were punctually manned afresh.
BEG_SENT "D'ye see him?"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab after allowing a little space for the
light to spread.
BEG_SENT "See nothing, sir."
BEG_SENT "Turn up all hands and make sail!
BEG_SENT he travels faster than I thought
for;- the top-gallant sails!- aye, they should have been kept on her
all night.
BEG_SENT But no matter- 'tis but resting for the rush."
BEG_SENT Here be it said, that this pertinacious pursuit of one particular
whale, continued through day into night, and through night into day,
is a thing by no means unprecedented in the South sea fishery.
BEG_SENT For
such is the wonderful skill, prescience of experience, and invincible
confidence acquired by some great natural geniuses among the
Nantucket commanders; that from the simple observation of a whale
when last descried, they will, under certain given circumstances,
pretty accurately foretell both the direction in which he will
continue to swim for a time, while out of sight, as well as his
probable rate of progression during that period.
BEG_SENT And, in these cases,
somewhat as a pilot, when about losing sight of a coast, whose
general trending he well knows, and which he desires shortly to
return to again, but at some further point; like as this pilot stands
by his compass, and takes the precise bearing of the cape at present
visible, in order the more certainly to hit aright the remote, unseen
headland, eventually to be visited: so does the fisherman, at his
compass, with the whale; for after being chased, and diligently
marked, through several hours of daylight, then, when night obscures
the fish, the creature's future wake through the darkness is almost
as established to the sagacious mind of the hunter, as the pilot's
coast is to him.
BEG_SENT So that to this hunter's wondrous skill, the
proverbial evanescence of a thing writ in water, a wake, is to all
desired purposes well nigh as reliable as the steadfast land.
BEG_SENT And as
the mighty iron Leviathan of the modern railway is so familiarly
known in its every pace, that, with watches in their hands, men time
his rate as doctors that of a baby's pulse; and lightly say of it,
the up train or the down train will reach such or such a spot, at
such or such an hour; even so, almost, there are occasions when these
Nantucketers time that other Leviathan of the deep, according to the
observed humor of his speed; and say to themselves, so many hours
hence this whale will have gone two hundred miles, will have about
reached this or that degree of latitude or longitude.
BEG_SENT But to render
this acuteness at all successful in the end, the wind and the sea
must be the whaleman's allies; for of what present avail to the
becalmed or wind-bound mariner is the skill that assures him he is
exactly ninety-three leagues and a quarter from his port?
BEG_SENT Inferable
from these statements, are many collateral subtile matters touching
the chase of whales.
BEG_SENT The ship tore on; leaving such a furrow in the sea as when a
cannonball, missent, becomes a plough-share and turns up the level
field.
BEG_SENT "By salt and hemp!"
BEG_SENT cried Stubb, "but this swift motion of the deck
creeps up one's legs and tingles at the heart.
BEG_SENT This ship and I are
two brave fellows!- Ha, ha!
BEG_SENT Some one take me up, and launch me,
spine-wise, on the sea,- for by live-oaks!
BEG_SENT my spine's a keel.
BEG_SENT Ha, ha!
BEG_SENT we go the gait that leaves no dust behind!"
BEG_SENT "There she blows- she blows!- she blows!- right ahead!"
BEG_SENT was now the
mast-head cry.
BEG_SENT "Aye, aye!"
BEG_SENT cried Stubb, "I knew it- ye can't escape- blow on and
split your spout, O whale!
BEG_SENT the mad fiend himself is after ye!
BEG_SENT blow
your trump- blister your lungs!- Ahab will dam off your blood, as a
miller shuts his watergate upon the stream!"
BEG_SENT And Stubb did but speak out for well nigh all that crew.
BEG_SENT The frenzies
of the chase had by this time worked them bubblingly up, like old
wine worked anew.
BEG_SENT Whatever pale fears and forebodings some of them
might have felt before; these were not only now kept out of sight
through the growing awe of Ahab, but they were broken up, and on all
sides routed, as timid prairie hares that scatter before the bounding
bison.
BEG_SENT The hand of Fate had snatched all their souls; and by the
stirring perils of the previous day; the rack of the past night's
suspense; the fixed, unfearing, blind, reckless way in which their
wild craft went plunging towards its flying mark; by all these
things, their hearts were bowled along.
BEG_SENT The wind that made great
bellies of their sails, and rushed the vessel on by arms invisible as
irresistible; this seemed the symbol of that unseen agency which so
enslaved them to the race.
BEG_SENT They were one man, not thirty.
BEG_SENT For as the one ship that held them
all; though it was put together of all contrasting things- oak, and
maple, and pine wood; iron, and pitch, and hemp- yet all these ran
into each other in the one concrete hull, which shot on its way, both
balanced and directed by the long central keel; even so, all the
individualities of the crew, this man's valor, that man's fear; guilt
and guiltiness, all varieties were welded into oneness, and were all
directed to that fatal goal which Ahab their one lord and keel did
point to.
BEG_SENT The rigging lived.
BEG_SENT The mast-heads, like the tops of tall palms, were
outspreadingly tufted with arms and legs.
BEG_SENT Clinging to a spar with one
hand, some reached forth the other with impatient wavings; others,
shading their eyes from the vivid sunlight, sat far out on the
rocking yards; all the spars in full bearing of mortals, ready and
ripe for their fate.
BEG_SENT Ah!
BEG_SENT how they still strove through that infinite
blueness to seek out the thing that might destroy them!
BEG_SENT "Why sing ye not out for him, if ye see him?"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab, when, after
the lapse of some minutes since the first cry, no more had been
heard.
BEG_SENT "Sway me up, men; ye have been deceived; not Moby Dick casts
one odd jet that way, and then disappears."
BEG_SENT It was even so; in their headlong eagerness, the men had mistaken
some other thing for the whale-spout, as the event itself soon
proved; for hardly had Ahab reached his perch; hardly was the rope
belayed to its pin on deck, when he struck the key-note to an
orchestra, that made the air vibrate as with the combined discharge
of rifles.
BEG_SENT The triumphant halloo of thirty buckskin lungs was heard,
as- much nearer to the ship than the place of the imaginary jet, less
than a mile ahead- Moby Dick bodily burst into view!
BEG_SENT For not by any
calm and indolent spoutings; not by the peaceable gush of that mystic
fountain in his head, did the White Whale now reveal his vicinity;
but by the far more wondrous phenomenon of breaching.
BEG_SENT Rising with his
utmost velocity from the furthest depths, the Sperm Whale thus booms
his entire bulk into the pure element of air, and piling up a
mountain of dazzling foam, shows his place to the distance of seven
miles and more.
BEG_SENT In those moments, the torn, enraged waves he shakes
off, seem his mane; in some cases, this breaching is his act of
defiance.
BEG_SENT "There she breaches!
BEG_SENT there she breaches!"
BEG_SENT was the cry, as in his
immeasurable bravadoes the White Whale tossed himself salmon-like to
Heaven.
BEG_SENT So suddenly seen in the blue plain of the sea, and relieved
against the still bluer margin of the sky, the spray that he raised,
for the moment, intolerably glittered and glared like a glacier; and
stood there gradually fading and fading away from its first sparkling
intensity, to the dim mistiness of an advancing shower in a vale.
BEG_SENT "Aye, breach your last to the sun, Moby Dick!"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab, "thy hour
and thy harpoon are at hand!- Down!
BEG_SENT down all of ye, but one man at
the fore.
BEG_SENT The boats!- stand by!"
BEG_SENT Unmindful of the tedious rope-ladders of the shrouds, the men, like
shooting stars, slid to the deck, by the isolated backstays and
halyards; while Ahab, less dartingly, but still rapidly was dropped
from his perch.
BEG_SENT "Lower away," he cried, so soon as he had reached his boat- a spare
one, rigged the afternoon previous.
BEG_SENT "Mr. Starbuck, the ship is thine-
away from the boats, but keep near them.
BEG_SENT Lower, all!"
BEG_SENT As if to strike a quick terror into them, by this time being the
first assailant himself, Moby Dick had turned, and was now coming for
the three crews.
BEG_SENT Ahab's boat was central; and cheering his men, he
told them he would take the whale head-and-head,- that is, pull
straight up to his forehead,- a not uncommon thing; for when within a
certain limit, such a course excludes the coming onset from the
whale's sidelong vision.
BEG_SENT But ere that close limit was gained, and
while yet all three boats were plain as the ship's three masts to his
eye; the White Whale churning himself into furious speed, almost in
an instant as it were, rushing among the boats with open jaws, and a
lashing tail, offered appalling battle on every side; and heedless of
the iron darted at him from every boat, seemed only intent on
annihilating each separate plank of which those boats were made.
BEG_SENT But
skilfully manoeuvred, incessantly wheeling like trained chargers in
the field; the boats for a while eluded him; though, at times, but by
a plank's breadth; while all the time, Ahab's unearthly slogan tore
every other cry but his to shreds.
BEG_SENT But at last in his untraceable evolutions, the White Whale so crossed
and recrossed, and in a thousand ways entangled the slack of the
three lines now fast to him, that they foreshortened, and, of
themselves, warped the devoted boats towards the planted irons in
him; though now for a moment the whale drew aside a little, as if to
rally for a more tremendous charge.
BEG_SENT Seizing that opportunity, Ahab
first paid out more line; and then was rapidly hauling and jerking in
upon it again- hoping that way to disencumber it of some snarls- when
lo!- a sight more savage than the embattled teeth of sharks!
BEG_SENT Caught and twisted- corkscrewed in the mazes of the line, loose
harpoons and lances, with all their bristling barbs and points, came
flashing and dripping up to the chocks in the bows of Ahab's
boat.
BEG_SENT Only one thing could be done.
BEG_SENT Seizing the boat-knife, he
critically reached within- through- and then, without- the rays of
steel; dragged in the line beyond, passed it, inboard, to the
bowsman, and then, twice sundering the rope near the chocks- dropped
the intercepted fagot of steel into the sea; and was all fast again.
BEG_SENT That instant, the White Whale made a sudden rush among the remaining
tangles of the other lines; by so doing, irresistibly dragged the
more involved boats of Stubb and Flask towards his flukes; dashed
them together like two rolling husks on a surf-beaten beach, and
then, diving down into the sea, disappeared in a boiling maelstrom,
in which, for a space, the odorous cedar chips of the wrecks danced
round and round, like the grated nutmeg in a swiftly stirred bowl of
punch.
BEG_SENT While the two crews were yet circling in the waters, reaching out
after the revolving line-tubs, oars, and other floating furniture,
while aslope little Flask bobbed up and down like an empty vial,
twitching his legs upwards to escape the dreaded jaws of sharks; and
Stubb was lustily singing out for some one to ladle him up; and while
the old man's line- now parting- admitted of his pulling into the
creamy pool to rescue whom he could;- in that wild simultaneousness
of a thousand concreted perils,- Ahab's yet unstricken boat seemed
drawn up towards Heaven by invisible wires,- as, arrow-like, shooting
perpendicularly from the sea, the White Whale dashed his broad
forehead against its bottom, and sent it turning over and over, into
the air; till it fell again- gunwale down- and Ahab and his men
struggled out from under it, like seals from a sea-side cave.
BEG_SENT The first uprising momentum of the whale- modifying its direction as
he struck the surface- involuntarily launched him along it, to a
little distance from the centre of the destruction he had made; and
with his back to it, he now lay for a moment slowly feeling with his
flukes from side to side; and whenever a stray oar, bit of plank, the
least chip or crumb of the boats touched his skin, his tail swiftly
drew back, and came sideways smiting the sea.
BEG_SENT But soon, as if
satisfied that his work for that time was done, he pushed his pleated
forehead through the ocean, and trailing after him the intertangled
lines, continued his leeward way at a traveller's methodic pace.
BEG_SENT As before, the attentive ship having descried the whole fight, again
came bearing down to the rescue, and dropping a boat, picked up the
floating mariners, tubs, oars, and whatever else could be caught at,
and safely landed them on her decks.
BEG_SENT Some sprained shoulders, wrists,
and ankles; livid contusions; wrenched harpoons and lances;
inextricable intricacies of rope; shattered oars and planks; all
these were there; but no fatal or even serious ill seemed to have
befallen any one.
BEG_SENT As with Fedallah the day before, so Ahab was now
found grimly clinging to his boat's broken half, which afforded a
comparatively easy float; nor did it so exhaust him as the previous
day's mishap.
BEG_SENT But when he was helped to the deck, all eyes were fastened upon him;
as instead of standing by himself he still half-hung upon the
shoulder of Starbuck, who had thus far been the foremost to assist
him.
BEG_SENT His ivory leg had been snapped off, leaving but one short sharp
splinter.
BEG_SENT "Aye, aye, Starbuck, 'tis sweet to lean sometimes, be the leaner who
he will; and would old Ahab had leaned oftener than he has."
BEG_SENT "The ferrule has not stood, sir," said the carpenter, now coming up;
put good work into that leg."
BEG_SENT "But no bones broken, sir, I hope," said Stubb with true concern.
BEG_SENT "Aye!
BEG_SENT and all splintered to pieces, Stubb!- d'ye see it.- But even
with a broken bone, old Ahab is untouched; and I account no living
bone of mine one jot more me, than this dead one that's lost.
BEG_SENT Nor
white whale, nor man, nor fiend, can so much as graze old Ahab in his
own proper and inaccessible being.
BEG_SENT Can any lead touch yonder floor,
any mast scrape yonder roof?- Aloft there!
BEG_SENT which way?"
BEG_SENT "Dead to leeward, sir."
BEG_SENT "Up helm, then; pile on the sail again, ship keepers!
BEG_SENT down the rest
of the spare boats and rig them- Mr. Starbuck away, and muster the
boat's crews."
BEG_SENT "Let me first help thee towards the bulwarks, sir."
BEG_SENT "Oh, oh, oh!
BEG_SENT how this splinter gores me now!
BEG_SENT Accursed fate!
BEG_SENT that the
unconquerable captain in the soul should have such a craven mate!"
BEG_SENT "Sir?"
BEG_SENT "My body, man, not thee.
BEG_SENT Give me something for a cane- there, that
shivered lance will do.
BEG_SENT Muster the men.
BEG_SENT Surely I have not seen him
yet.
BEG_SENT By heaven it cannot be!-missing?- quick!
BEG_SENT call them all."
BEG_SENT The old man's hinted thought was true.
BEG_SENT Upon mustering the company,
the Parsee was not there.
BEG_SENT "The Parsee!"
BEG_SENT cried Stubb- "he must have been caught in-"

"The black vomit wrench thee!- run all of ye above, alow, cabin,
forecastle- find him- not gone- not gone!"
BEG_SENT But quickly they returned to him with the tidings that the Parsee was
nowhere to be found.
BEG_SENT "Aye, sir," said Stubb- "caught among the tangles of your line- I
thought I saw him dragging under."
BEG_SENT "My line!
BEG_SENT my line?
BEG_SENT Gone?- gone?
BEG_SENT What means that little word?- What
death-knell rings in it, that old Ahab shakes as if he were the
belfry.
BEG_SENT The harpoon, too!- toss over the litter there,- d'ye see it?-
the forged iron, men, the white whale's- no, no, no,- listered fool!
BEG_SENT this hand did dart it!- 'tis in the fish!- Aloft there!
BEG_SENT Keep him
nailed-Quick!- all hands to the rigging of the boats- collect the
oars- harpooneers!
BEG_SENT the irons, the irons!- hoist royals higher- a pull
on all the sheets!- helm there!
BEG_SENT steady, steady for your life!
BEG_SENT I'll
ten times girdle the unmeasured globe; yea and dive straight through
it, but I'll slay him yet!
BEG_SENT "Great God!
BEG_SENT but for one single instant show thyself," cried Starbuck;
"never, never wilt thou capture him, old man- In Jesus' name no more
of this, that's worse than devil's madness.
BEG_SENT Two days chased; twice
stove to splinters; thy very leg once more snatched from under thee;
thy evil shadow gone- all good angels mobbing thee with warnings:-
what more wouldst thou have?- Shall we keep chasing this murderous
fish till he swamps the last man?
BEG_SENT Shall we be dragged by him to the
bottom of the sea?
BEG_SENT Shall we be towed by him to the infernal world?
BEG_SENT Oh, oh,- Impiety and blasphemy to hunt him more!"
BEG_SENT "Starbuck, of late I've felt strangely moved to thee; ever since that
hour we both saw- thou know'st what, in one another's eyes.
BEG_SENT But in
this matter of the whale, be the front of thy face to me as the palm
of this hand- a lipless, unfeatured blank.
BEG_SENT Ahab is for ever Ahab,
man.
BEG_SENT This whole act's immutably decreed.
BEG_SENT 'Twas rehearsed by thee and
me a billion years before this ocean rolled.
BEG_SENT Fool!
BEG_SENT I am the Fates'
lieutenant; I act under orders.
BEG_SENT Look thou, underling!
BEG_SENT that thou
obeyest mine.- Stand round men, men.
BEG_SENT Ye see an old man cut down to
the stump; leaning on a shivered lance; propped up on a lonely
foot.
BEG_SENT 'Tis Ahab- his body's part; but Ahab's soul's a centipede, that
moves upon a hundred legs.
BEG_SENT I feel strained, half-stranded, as ropes
that tow dismasted frigates in a gale; and I may look so.
BEG_SENT But ere I
break, yell hear me crack; and till ye hear that, know that Ahab's
hawser tows his purpose yet.
BEG_SENT Believe ye, men, in the things called
omens?
BEG_SENT Then laugh aloud, and cry encore!
BEG_SENT For ere they drown, drowning
things will twice rise to the surface; then rise again, to sink for
evermore.
BEG_SENT So with Moby Dick- two days he's floated- to-morrow will be
the third.
BEG_SENT Aye, men, he'll rise once more,- but only to spout his
last!
BEG_SENT D'ye feel brave men, brave?"
BEG_SENT "As fearless fire," cried Stubb.
BEG_SENT "And as mechanical," muttered Ahab.
BEG_SENT Then as the men went forward, he
muttered on: "The things called omens!
BEG_SENT And yesterday I talked the
same to Starbuck there, concerning my broken boat.
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT how valiantly
I seek to drive out of others' hearts what's clinched so fast in
mine!- The Parsee- the Parsee!- gone, gone?
BEG_SENT and he was to go before:-
but still was to be seen again ere I could perish- How's that?-
There's a riddle now might baffle all the lawyers backed by the
ghosts of the whole line of judges:- like a hawk's beak it pecks my
brain.
BEG_SENT I'll, I'll solve it, though!"
BEG_SENT When dusk descended, the whale was still in sight to leeward.
BEG_SENT So once more the sail was shortened, and everything passed nearly as
on the previous night; only, the sound of hammers, and the hum of the
grindstone was heard till nearly daylight, as the men toiled by
lanterns in the complete and careful rigging of the spare boats and
sharpening their fresh weapons for the morrow.
BEG_SENT Meantime, of the
broken keel of Ahab's wrecked craft the carpenter made him another
leg; while still as on the night before, slouched Ahab stood fixed
within his scuttle; his hid, heliotrope glance anticipatingly gone
backward on its dial; sat due eastward for the earliest sun.
BEG_SENT The Chase - Third Day


The morning of the third day dawned fair and fresh, and once more the
solitary night-man at the fore-mast-head was relieved by crowds of
the daylight look-outs, who dotted every mast and almost every spar.
BEG_SENT "D'ye see him?"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab; but the whale was not yet in sight.
BEG_SENT "In his infallible wake, though; but follow that wake, that's
all.
BEG_SENT Helm there; steady, as thou goest, and hast been going.
BEG_SENT What a
lovely day again!
BEG_SENT were it a new-made world, and made for a
summer-house to the angels, and this morning the first of its
throwing open to them, a fairer day could not dawn upon that
world.
BEG_SENT Here's food for thought, had Ahab time to think; but Ahab
never thinks; he only feels, feels, feels; that's tingling enough for
mortal man!
BEG_SENT to think's audacity.
BEG_SENT God only has that right and
privilege.
BEG_SENT Thinking is, or ought to be, a coolness and a calmness;
and our poor hearts throb, and our poor brains beat too much for
that.
BEG_SENT And yet, I've sometimes thought my brain was very calm- frozen
calm, this old skull cracks so, like a glass in which the contents
turned to ice, and shiver it.
BEG_SENT And still this hair is growing now;
this moment growing, and heat must breed it; but no, it's like that
sort of common grass that will grow anywhere, between the earthy
clefts of Greenland ice or in Vesuvius lava.
BEG_SENT How the wild winds blow
it; they whip it about me as the torn shreds of split sails lash the
tossed ship they cling to.
BEG_SENT A vile wind that has no doubt blown ere
this through prison corridors and cells, and wards of hospitals, and
ventilated them, and now comes blowing hither as innocent as
fleeces.
BEG_SENT Out upon it!- it's tainted.
BEG_SENT Were I the wind, I'd blow no
more on such a wicked, miserable world.
BEG_SENT I'd crawl somewhere to a
cave, and slink there.
BEG_SENT And yet, 'tis a noble and heroic thing, the
wind!
BEG_SENT who ever conquered it?
BEG_SENT In every fight it has the last and
bitterest blow.
BEG_SENT Run tilting at it, and you but run through it.
BEG_SENT Ha!
BEG_SENT a
coward wind that strikes stark naked men, but will not stand to
receive a single blow.
BEG_SENT Even Ahab is a braver thing- a nobler thing
than that.
BEG_SENT Would now the wind but had a body; but all the things that
most exasperate and outrage mortal man, all these things are
bodiless, but only bodiless as objects, not as agents.
BEG_SENT There's a most
special, a most cunning, oh, a most malicious difference!
BEG_SENT And yet, I
say again, and swear it now, that there's something all glorious and
gracious in the wind.
BEG_SENT These warm Trade Winds, at least, that in the
clear heavens blow straight on, in strong and steadfast, vigorous
mildness; and veer not from their mark, however the baser currents of
the sea may turn and tack, and mightiest Mississippies of the land
swift and swerve about, uncertain where to go at last.
BEG_SENT And by the
eternal Poles!
BEG_SENT these same Trades that so directly blow my good ship
on; these Trades, or something like them- something so unchangeable,
and full as strong, blow my keeled soul along!
BEG_SENT To it!
BEG_SENT Aloft there!
BEG_SENT What d'ye see?"
BEG_SENT "Nothing, sir."
BEG_SENT "Nothing!
BEG_SENT and noon at hand!
BEG_SENT The doubloon goes a-begging!
BEG_SENT See the sun!
BEG_SENT Aye, aye, it must be so.
BEG_SENT I've over-sailed him.
BEG_SENT How, got the start?
BEG_SENT Aye, he's chasing me now; not I, him- that's bad; I might have known
it, too.
BEG_SENT Fool!
BEG_SENT the lines- the harpoons he's towing.
BEG_SENT Aye, aye, I have
run him by last night.
BEG_SENT About!
BEG_SENT about!
BEG_SENT Come down, all of ye, but the
regular look outs!
BEG_SENT Man the braces!"
BEG_SENT Steering as she had done, the wind had been somewhat on the Pequod's
quarter, so that now being pointed in the reverse direction, the
braced ship sailed hard upon the breeze as she rechurned the cream in
her own white wake.
BEG_SENT "Against the wind he now steers for the open jaw," murmured Starbuck
to himself, as he coiled the new-hauled main-brace upon the
rail.
BEG_SENT "God keep us, but already my bones feel damp within me, and
from the inside wet my flesh.
BEG_SENT I misdoubt me that I disobey my God in
obeying him!"
BEG_SENT "Stand by to sway me up!"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab, advancing to the hempen basket.
BEG_SENT "We should meet him soon."
BEG_SENT "Aye, aye, sir," and straightway Starbuck did Ahab's bidding, and
once more Ahab swung on high.
BEG_SENT A whole hour now passed; gold-beaten out to ages.
BEG_SENT Time itself now
held long breaths with keen suspense.
BEG_SENT But at last, some three points
off the weather bow, Ahab descried the spout again, and instantly
from the three mast-heads three shrieks went up as if the tongues of
fire had voiced it.
BEG_SENT "Forehead to forehead I meet thee, this third time, Moby Dick!
BEG_SENT On
deck there!- brace sharper up; crowd her into the wind's eye.
BEG_SENT He's
too far off to lower yet, Mr.  Starbuck.
BEG_SENT The sails shake!
BEG_SENT Stand over
that helmsman with a top-maul!
BEG_SENT So, so; he travels fast, and I must
down.
BEG_SENT But let me have one more good round look aloft here at the sea;
there's time for that.
BEG_SENT An old, old sight, and yet somehow so young;
aye, and not changed a wink since I first saw it, a boy, from the
sand-hills of Nantucket!
BEG_SENT The same- the same!- the same to Noah as to
me.
BEG_SENT There's a soft shower to leeward.
BEG_SENT Such lovely leewardings!
BEG_SENT They
must lead somewhere- to something else than common land, more palmy
than the palms.
BEG_SENT Leeward!
BEG_SENT the white whale goes that way; look to
windward, then; the better if the bitterer quarter.
BEG_SENT But good bye,
good bye, old mast-head!
BEG_SENT What's this?- green?
BEG_SENT aye, tiny mosses in
these warped cracks.
BEG_SENT No such green weather stains on Ahab's head!
BEG_SENT There's the difference now between man's old age and matter's.
BEG_SENT But
aye, old mast, we both grow old together; sound in our hulls, though
are we not, my ship?
BEG_SENT Aye, minus a leg, that's all.
BEG_SENT By heaven this
dead wood has the better of my live flesh every way.
BEG_SENT I can't compare
with it; and I've known some ships made of dead trees outlast the
lives of men made of the most vital stuff of vital fathers.
BEG_SENT What's
that he said?
BEG_SENT he should still go before me, my pilot; and yet to be
seen again?
BEG_SENT But where?
BEG_SENT Will I have eyes at the bottom of the sea,
supposing I descend those endless stairs?
BEG_SENT and all night I've been
sailing from him, wherever he did sink to.
BEG_SENT Aye, aye, like many more
thou toldist direful truth as touching thyself, O Parsee; but, Ahab,
there thy shot fell short.
BEG_SENT Good bye, mast-head- keep a good eye upon
the whale, the while I'm gone.
BEG_SENT We'll talk to-morrow, nay, to-night,
when the white whale lies down there, tied by head and tail."
BEG_SENT He gave the word; and still gazing round him, was steadily lowered
through the cloven blue air to the deck.
BEG_SENT In due time the boats were lowered; but as standing in his shallop's
stern, Ahab just hovered upon the point of the descent, he waved to
the mate,- who held one of the tackle- ropes on deck- and bade him
pause.
BEG_SENT "Starbuck!"
BEG_SENT "Sir?"
BEG_SENT "For the third time my soul's ship starts upon this voyage,
Starbuck."
BEG_SENT "Aye, sir, thou wilt have it so."
BEG_SENT "Some ships sail from their ports, and ever afterwards are missing,
Starbuck!"
BEG_SENT "Truth, sir: saddest truth."
BEG_SENT "Some men die at ebb tide; some at low water; some at the full of the
flood;- and I feel now like a billow that's all one crested comb,
Starbuck.
BEG_SENT I am old;- shake hands with me, man."
BEG_SENT Their hands met; their eyes fastened; Starbuck's tears the glue.
BEG_SENT "Oh, my captain, my captain!- noble heart- go not- go not!- see, it's
a brave man that weeps; how great the agony of the persuasion then!"
BEG_SENT "Lower away!
BEG_SENT "-cried Ahab, tossing the mate's arm from him.
BEG_SENT "Stand by
for the crew!"
BEG_SENT In an instant the boat was pulling round close under the stern.
BEG_SENT "The sharks!
BEG_SENT the sharks!"
BEG_SENT cried a voice from the low cabin-window
there; "O master, my master, come back!"
BEG_SENT But Ahab heard nothing; for his own voice was high-lifted then; and
the boat leaped on.
BEG_SENT Yet the voice spake true; for scarce had he pushed from the ship,
when numbers of sharks, seemingly rising from out the dark waters
beneath the hull, maliciously snapped at the blades of the oars,
every time they dipped in the water; and in this way accompanied the
boat with their bites.
BEG_SENT It is a thing not uncommonly happening to the
whale-boats in those swarming seas; the sharks at times apparently
following them in the same prescient way that vultures hover over the
banners of marching regiments in the east.
BEG_SENT But these were the first
sharks that had been observed by the Pequod since the White Whale had
been first descried; and whether it was that Ahab's crew were all
such tiger-yellow barbarians, and therefore their flesh more musky to
the senses of the sharks- a matter sometimes well known to affect
them,- however it was, they seemed to follow that one boat without
molesting the others.
BEG_SENT "Heart of wrought steel!"
BEG_SENT murmured Starbuck gazing over the side, and
following with his eyes the receding boat- "canst thou yet ring
boldly to that sight?- lowering thy keel among ravening sharks, and
followed by them, open-mouthed to the chase; and this the critical
third day?- For when three days flow together in one continuous
intense pursuit; be sure the first is the morning, the second the
noon, and the third the evening and the end of that thing- be that
end what it may.
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT my God!
BEG_SENT what is this that shoots through me, and
leaves me so deadly calm, yet expectant,- fixed at the top of a
shudder!
BEG_SENT Future things swim before me, as in empty outlines and
skeletons; all the past is somehow grown dim.
BEG_SENT Mary, girl; thou fadest
in pale glories behind me; boy!
BEG_SENT I seem to see but thy eyes grown
wondrous blue.
BEG_SENT Strangest problems of life seem clearing; but clouds
sweep between- Is my journey's end coming?
BEG_SENT My legs feel faint; like
his who has footed it all day.
BEG_SENT Feel thy heart,- beat it yet?
BEG_SENT Stir
thyself, Starbuck!- stave it off- move, move!
BEG_SENT speak aloud!- Mast-head
there!
BEG_SENT See ye my boy's hand on the hill?- Crazed;- aloft there!- keep
thy keenest eye upon the boats:- mark well the whale!- Ho!
BEG_SENT again!-
drive off that hawk!
BEG_SENT see!
BEG_SENT he pecks- he tears the vane"- pointing to
the red flag flying at the main-truck- "Ha, he soars away with it!-
Where's the old man now?
BEG_SENT see'st thou that sight, oh Ahab!- shudder,
shudder!"
BEG_SENT The boats had not gone very far, when by a signal from the
mast-heads- a downward pointed arm, Ahab knew that the whale had
sounded; but intending to be near him at the next rising, he held on
his way a little sideways from the vessel; the becharmed crew
maintaining the profoundest silence, as the head-bent waves hammered
and hammered against the opposing bow.
BEG_SENT "Drive, drive in your nails, oh ye waves!
BEG_SENT to their uttermost heads
drive them in!
BEG_SENT ye but strike a thing without a lid; and no coffin
and no hearse can be mine:- and hemp only can kill me!
BEG_SENT Ha!
BEG_SENT ha!"
BEG_SENT Suddenly the waters around them slowly swelled in broad circles; then
quickly upheaved, as if sideways sliding from a submerged berg of
ice, swiftly rising to the surface.
BEG_SENT A low rumbling sound was heard; a
subterraneous hum; and then all held their breaths; as bedraggled
with trailing ropes, and harpoons, and lances, a vast form shot
lengthwise, but obliquely from the sea.
BEG_SENT Shrouded in a thin drooping
veil of mist, it hovered for a moment in the rainbowed air; and then
fell swamping back into the deep.
BEG_SENT Crushed thirty feet upwards, the
waters flashed for an instant like heaps of fountains, then brokenly
sank in a shower of flakes, leaving the circling surface creamed like
new milk round the marble trunk of the whale.
BEG_SENT "Give way!"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab to the oarsmen, and the boats darted forward
to the attack; but maddened by yesterday's fresh irons that corroded
in him, Moby Dick seemed combinedly possessed by all the angels that
fell from heaven.
BEG_SENT The wide tiers of welded tendons overspreading his
broad white forehead, beneath the transparent skin, looked knitted
together; as head on, he came churning his tail among the boats; and
once more flailed them apart; spilling out the irons and lances from
the two mates' boats, and dashing in one side of the upper part of
their bows, but leaving Ahab's almost without a scar.
BEG_SENT While Daggoo and Queequeg were stopping the strained planks; and as
the whale swimming out from them, turned, and showed one entire flank
as he shot by them again; at that moment a quick cry went up.
BEG_SENT Lashed
round and round to the fish's back; pinioned in the turns upon turns
in which, during the past night, the whale had reeled the involutions
of the lines around him, the half torn body of the Parsee was seen;
his sable raiment frayed to shreds; his distended eyes turned full
upon old Ahab.
BEG_SENT The harpoon dropped from his hand.
BEG_SENT "Befooled, befooled!
BEG_SENT "- drawing in a long lean breath- "Aye, Parsee!
BEG_SENT I
see thee again.- Aye, and thou goest before; and this, this then is
the hearse that thou didst promise.
BEG_SENT But I hold thee to the last
letter of thy word.
BEG_SENT Where is the second hearse?
BEG_SENT Away, mates, to the
ship!
BEG_SENT those boats are useless now; repair them if ye can in time, and
return to me; if not, Ahab is enough to die- Down, men!
BEG_SENT the first
thing that but offers to jump from this boat I stand in, that thing I
harpoon.
BEG_SENT Ye are not other men, but my arms and my legs; and so obey
me.- Where's the whale?
BEG_SENT gone down again?"
BEG_SENT But he looked too nigh the boat; for as if bent upon escaping with
the corpse he bore, and as if the particular place of the last
encounter had been but a stage in his leeward voyage, Moby Dick was
now again steadily swimming forward; and had almost passed the ship,-
which thus far had been sailing in the contrary direction to him,
though for the present her headway had been stopped.
BEG_SENT He seemed
swimming with his utmost velocity, and now only intent upon pursuing
his own straight path in the sea.
BEG_SENT "Oh!
BEG_SENT Ahab," cried Starbuck, "not too late is it, even now, the third
day, to desist.
BEG_SENT See!
BEG_SENT Moby Dick seeks thee not.
BEG_SENT It is thou, thou, that
madly seekest him!"
BEG_SENT Setting sail to the rising wind, the lonely boat was swiftly impelled
to leeward, by both oars and canvas.
BEG_SENT And at last when Ahab was
sliding by the vessel, so near as plainly to distinguish Starbuck's
face as he leaned over the rail, he hailed him to turn the vessel
about, and follow him, not too swiftly, at a judicious
interval.
BEG_SENT Glancing upwards he saw Tashtego, Queequeg, and Daggoo,
eagerly mounting to the three mast-heads; while the oarsmen were
rocking in the two staved boats which had just been hoisted to the
side, and were busily at work in repairing them.
BEG_SENT One after the other,
through the port-holes, as he sped, he also caught flying glimpses of
Stubb and Flask, busying themselves on deck among bundles of new
irons and lances.
BEG_SENT As he saw all this; as he heard the hammers in the
broken boats; far other hammers seemed driving a nail into his
heart.
BEG_SENT But he rallied.
BEG_SENT And now marking that the vane or flag was gone
from the main-mast-head, he shouted to Tashtego, who had just gained
that perch, to descend again for another flag, and a hammer and
nails, and so nail it to the mast.
BEG_SENT Whether fagged by the three days' running chase, and the resistance
to his swimming in the knotted hamper he bore; or whether it was some
latent deceitfulness and malice in him: whichever was true, the White
Whale's way now began to abate, as it seemed, from the boat so
rapidly nearing him once more; though indeed the whale's last start
had not been so long a one as before.
BEG_SENT And still as Ahab glided over
the waves the unpitying sharks accompanied him; and so pertinaciously
stuck to the boat; and so continually bit at the plying oars, that
the blades became jagged and crunched, and left small splinters in
the sea, at almost every dip.
BEG_SENT "Heed them not!
BEG_SENT those teeth but give new rowlocks to your oars.
BEG_SENT Pull
on!
BEG_SENT 'tis the better rest, the sharks' jaw than the yielding water."
BEG_SENT "But at every bite, sir, the thin blades grow smaller and smaller!"
BEG_SENT "They will last long enough!
BEG_SENT pull on!- But who can tell"- he
muttered- "whether these sharks swim to feast on the whale or on
Ahab?- But pull on!
BEG_SENT Aye, all alive, now- we near him.
BEG_SENT The helm!
BEG_SENT take
the helm!
BEG_SENT let me pass,"- and so saying two of the oarsmen helped him
forward to the bows of the still flying boat.
BEG_SENT At length as the craft was cast to one side, and ran ranging along
with the White Whale's flank, he seemed strangely oblivious of its
advance- as the whale sometimes will- and Ahab was fairly within the
smoky mountain mist, which, thrown off from the whale's spout, curled
round his great Monadnock hump; he was even thus close to him; when,
with body arched back, and both arms lengthwise high-lifted to the
poise, he darted his fierce iron, and his far fiercer curse into the
hated whale.
BEG_SENT As both steel and curse sank to the socket, as if sucked
into a morass, Moby Dick sidewise writhed; spasmodically rolled his
nigh flank against the bow, and, without staving a hole in it, so
suddenly canted the boat over, that had it not been for the elevated
part of the gunwale to which he then clung, Ahab would once more have
been tossed into the sea.
BEG_SENT As it was, three of the oarsmen- who
foreknew not the precise instant of the dart, and were therefore
unprepared for its effects- these were flung out; but so fell, that,
in an instant two of them clutched the gunwale again, and rising to
its level on a combing wave, hurled themselves bodily inboard again;
the third man helplessly dropping astern, but still afloat and
swimming.
BEG_SENT Almost simultaneously, with a mighty volition of ungraduated,
instantaneous swiftness, the White Whale darted through the weltering
sea.
BEG_SENT But when Ahab cried out to the steersman to take new turns with
the line, and hold it so; and commanded the crew to turn round on
their seats, and tow the boat up to the mark; the moment the
treacherous line felt that double strain and tug, it snapped in the
empty air!
BEG_SENT "What breaks in me?
BEG_SENT Some sinew cracks!- 'tis whole again; oars!
BEG_SENT oars!
BEG_SENT Burst in upon him!"
BEG_SENT Hearing the tremendous rush of the sea-crashing boat, the whale
wheeled round to present his blank forehead at bay; but in that
evolution, catching sight of the nearing black hull of the ship;
seemingly seeing in it the source of all his persecutions; bethinking
it- it may be- a larger and nobler foe; of a sudden, he bore down
upon its advancing prow, smiting his jaws amid fiery showers of foam.
BEG_SENT Ahab staggered; his hand smote his forehead.
BEG_SENT "I grow blind; hands!
BEG_SENT stretch out before me that I may yet grope my way.
BEG_SENT Is't night?"
BEG_SENT "The whale!
BEG_SENT The ship!"
BEG_SENT cried the cringing oarsmen.
BEG_SENT "Oars!
BEG_SENT oars!
BEG_SENT Slope downwards to thy depths, O sea that ere it be for
ever too late, Ahab may slide this last, last time upon his mark!
BEG_SENT I
see: the ship!
BEG_SENT the ship!
BEG_SENT Dash on, my men!
BEG_SENT will ye not save my ship?"
BEG_SENT But as the oarsmen violently forced their boat through the
sledge-hammering seas, the before whale-smitten bow-ends of two
planks burst through, and in an instant almost, the temporarily
disabled boat lay nearly level with the waves; its half-wading,
splashing crew, trying hard to stop the gap and bale out the pouring
water.
BEG_SENT Meantime, for that one beholding instant, Tashtego's mast-head hammer
remained suspended in his hand; and the red flag, half-wrapping him
as with a plaid, then streamed itself straight out from him, as his
own forward-flowing heart; while Starbuck and Stubb, standing upon
the bowsprit beneath, caught sight of the down-coming monster just as
soon as he.
BEG_SENT "The whale, the whale!
BEG_SENT Up helm, up helm!
BEG_SENT Oh, all ye sweet powers of
air, now hug me close!
BEG_SENT Let not Starbuck die, if die he must, in a
woman's fainting fit.
BEG_SENT Up helm, I say- ye fools, the jaw!
BEG_SENT the jaw!
BEG_SENT Is
this the end of all my bursting prayers?
BEG_SENT all my life-long fidelities?
BEG_SENT Oh, Ahab, Ahab, lo, thy work.
BEG_SENT Steady!
BEG_SENT helmsman, steady.
BEG_SENT Nay, nay!
BEG_SENT Up
helm again!
BEG_SENT He turns to meet us!
BEG_SENT Oh, his unappeasable brow drives on
towards one, whose duty tells him he cannot depart.
BEG_SENT My God, stand by
me now!"
BEG_SENT "Stand not by me, but stand under me, whoever you are that will now
help Stubb; for Stubb, too, sticks here.
BEG_SENT I grin at thee, thou
grinning whale!
BEG_SENT Who ever helped Stubb, or kept Stubb awake, but
Stubb's own unwinking eye?
BEG_SENT And now poor Stubb goes to bed upon a
mattrass that is all too soft; would it were stuffed with brushwood!
BEG_SENT I grin at thee, thou grinning whale!
BEG_SENT Look ye, sun, moon, and stars!
BEG_SENT I
call ye assassins of as good a fellow as ever spouted up his
ghost.
BEG_SENT For all that, I would yet ring glasses with thee, would ye but
hand the cup!
BEG_SENT Oh, oh!
BEG_SENT oh, oh!
BEG_SENT thou grinning whale, but there'll be
plenty of gulping soon!
BEG_SENT Why fly ye not, O Ahab!
BEG_SENT For me, off shoes
and jacket to it; let Stubb die in his drawers!
BEG_SENT A most mouldy and
over salted death, though;- cherries!
BEG_SENT cherries!
BEG_SENT cherries!
BEG_SENT Oh, Flask,
for one red cherry ere we die!"
BEG_SENT "Cherries?
BEG_SENT I only wish that we were where they grow.
BEG_SENT Oh, Stubb, I
hope my poor mother's drawn my part-pay ere this; if not, few coppers
will now come to her, for the voyage is up."
BEG_SENT From the ship's bows, nearly all the seamen now hung inactive;
hammers, bits of plank, lances, and harpoons, mechanically retained
in their hands, just as they had darted from their various
employments; all their enchanted eyes intent upon the whale, which
from side to side strangely vibrating his predestinating head, sent a
broad band of overspreading semicircular foam before him as he
rushed.
BEG_SENT Retribution, swift vengeance, eternal malice were in his
whole aspect, and spite of all that mortal man could do, the solid
white buttress of his forehead smote the ship's starboard bow, till
men and timbers reeled.
BEG_SENT Some fell flat upon their faces.
BEG_SENT Like
dislodged trucks, the heads of the harpooneers aloft shook on their
bull-like necks.
BEG_SENT Through the breach, they heard the waters pour, as
mountain torrents down a flume.
BEG_SENT "The ship!
BEG_SENT The hearse!- the second hearse!"
BEG_SENT cried Ahab from the boat;
"its wood could only be American!"
BEG_SENT Diving beneath the settling ship, the whale ran quivering along its
keel; but turning under water, swiftly shot to the surface again, far
off the other bow, but within a few yards of Ahab's boat, where, for
a time, he lay quiescent.
BEG_SENT "I turn my body from the sun.
BEG_SENT What ho, Tashtego!
BEG_SENT let me hear thy
hammer.
BEG_SENT Oh!
BEG_SENT ye three unsurrendered spires of mine; thou uncracked
keel; and only god-bullied hull; thou firm deck, and haughty helm,
and Pole-pointed prow,- death- glorious ship!
BEG_SENT must ye then perish,
and without me?
BEG_SENT Am I cut off from the last fond pride of meanest
shipwrecked captains?
BEG_SENT Oh, lonely death on lonely life!
BEG_SENT Oh, now I feel
my topmost greatness lies in my topmost grief.
BEG_SENT Ho, ho!
BEG_SENT from all your
furthest bounds, pour ye now in, ye bold billows of my whole foregone
life, and top this one piled comber of my death!
BEG_SENT Towards thee I roll,
thou all-destroying but unconquering whale; to the last I grapple
with thee; from hell's heart I stab at thee; for hate's sake I spit
my last breath at thee.
BEG_SENT Sink all coffins and all hearses to one
common pool!
BEG_SENT and since neither can be mine, let me then tow to
pieces, while still chasing thee, though tied to thee, thou damned
whale!
BEG_SENT Thus, I give up the spear!"
BEG_SENT The harpoon was darted; the stricken whale flew forward; with
igniting velocity the line ran through the grooves;- ran foul.
BEG_SENT Ahab
stooped to clear it; he did clear it; but the flying turn caught him
round the neck, and voicelessly as Turkish mutes bowstring their
victim, he was shot out of the boat, ere the crew knew he was
gone.
BEG_SENT Next instant, the heavy eye-splice in the rope's final end flew
out of the stark-empty tub, knocked down an oarsman, and smiting the
sea, disappeared in its depths.
BEG_SENT For an instant, the tranced boat's crew stood still; then
turned.
BEG_SENT "The ship?
BEG_SENT Great God, where is the ship?"
BEG_SENT Soon they through
dim, bewildering mediums saw her sidelong fading phantom, as in the
gaseous Fata Morgana; only the uppermost masts out of water; while
fixed by infatuation, or fidelity, or fate, to their once lofty
perches, the pagan harpooneers still maintained their sinking
look-outs on the sea.
BEG_SENT And now, concentric circles seized the lone
boat itself, and all its crew, and each floating oar, and every
lancepole, and spinning, animate and inanimate, all round and round
in one vortex, carried the smallest chip of the Pequod out of sight.
BEG_SENT But as the last whelmings intermixingly poured themselves over the
sunken head of the Indian at the mainmast, leaving a few inches of
the erect spar yet visible, together with long streaming yards of the
flag, which calmly undulated, with ironical coincidings, over the
destroying billows they almost touched;- at that instant, a red arm
and a hammer hovered backwardly uplifted in the open air, in the act
of nailing the flag faster and yet faster to the subsiding spar.
BEG_SENT A
sky-hawk that tauntingly had followed the main-truck downwards from
its natural home among the stars, pecking at the flag, and
incommoding Tashtego there; this bird now chanced to intercept its
broad fluttering wing between the hammer and the wood; and
simultaneously feeling that etherial thrill, the submerged savage
beneath, in his death-gasp, kept his hammer frozen there; and so the
bird of heaven, with archangelic shrieks, and his imperial beak
thrust upwards, and his whole captive form folded in the flag of
Ahab, went down with his ship, which, like Satan, would not sink to
hell till she had dragged a living part of heaven along with her, and
helmeted herself with it.
BEG_SENT Now small fowls flew screaming over the yet yawning gulf; a sullen
white surf beat against its steep sides; then all collapsed, and the
great shroud of the sea rolled on as it rolled five thousand years
ago.
